PETITION.PRESENTERS: ALDRED; BEALE; BILNEY; CAMERON; COURTICE; DUFFY; FISHER; HARVEY; JOHNS; MCGAURAN; MACPHEE; PRICE; RUDDOCK; SAWFORD; SNOWDON; SULLIVAN; THEOPHANOUS; WILSON
PETITION.TITLE: Health Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that,
Australia's population is ageing and most people require more health services as they grow older.
If open not-for-profit Health Funds are to be able to meet the costs of providing benefits to their older members at affordable rates, those costs need to be shared equitably.
Some health insurance organisations are being allowed to avoid meeting the health costs of sick and elderly people.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to,
Take the necessary action to reverse rising cost trends and provide positive incentives to encourage all health funds to share the cost of health care for sick and elderly Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Aldred (from 218 citizens), Mr Beale (from 204 citizens), Mr Bilney (from 289 citizens), Mr Donald Cameron (from 1,213 citizens), Mr Courtice (from 1,169 citizens), Mr Duffy (from 105 citizens), Mr Peter Fisher (from 100 citizens), Mrs Harvey (from 533 citizens), Mr Johns (from 1,263 citizens), Mr McGauran (from 52 citizens), Mr Macphee (from 103 citizens), Mr Price (from 126 citizens), Mr Ruddock (from 199 citizens), Mr Sawford (from 670 citizens), Mr Snowdon (from 90 citizens), Mrs Sullivan (from 588 citizens), Dr Theophanous (from 84 citizens) and Mr Wilson (from 70 citizens).

PETITION.PRESENTERS: ANDERSON; CADMAN; HOLLIS; LEE; RUDDOCK; SIMMONS; WEBSTER; WOODS
PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:
The petition of citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that they:

1. Deplore the changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme ``Authority only'' drug list and the delisting of frequently prescribed drugs without ensuring that alternative products are readily available.

2. Deplore the proposed restructuring of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which will reduce both remuneration to pharmacists and the standard of professional service and counselling provided by pharmacists to ensure that patients follow appropriate medication usage regimes.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House do everything in its power to call on the Minister for Housing and Aged Care and the Minister for Community Services and Health to reconsider the restructuring of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Anderson (from 539 citizens), Mr Cadman (from 19 citizens), Mr Hollis (from 62 citizens), Mr Lee (from 248 citizens), Mr Ruddock (from 53 citizens), Mr Simmons (from 48 citizens), Mr Webster (from 264 citizens) and Dr Woods (from 51,641 citizens).

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BEAZLEY; BEDDALL; BURR; CAMERON; GOODLUCK; JULL; SCOTT; TUCKEY

PETITION.TITLE: Importation of Pornography in Videos, Films and Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of citizens of Australia points out that the community deplores the persistent refusal to ban pornography in X and NVE Videos, Films and Publications, and deplores the resulting escalation of crime and sexual crime in the Australian community.
Because Parliament has a direct and heavy obligation to ensure the safety of women and child-victims, your petitioners therefore request the House:
to ban the importation, and availability of pornography in Videos, Films and Publications,
to prevent black-market trading by banning the possession of X and NVE material,
vote against any recommendation to extend Video and Theatre Film Classifications and Guidelines into television standards,
ensure that Pay Television does not exceed the programme limits of Television standards,
control all censorship criteria and guidelines by substantive legislation,

give earnest consideration to these matters, in order that no Attorney-General shall ever again have the power to change our social and home environment for generations to come, without thorough and full debate in both Houses of Parliament.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beazley (from 16 citizens), Mr Beddall (from 220 citizens), Mr Burr (from 17 citizens), Mr Ian Cameron (from 23 citizens), Mr Goodluck (from 322 citizens), Mr Jull (from 96 citizens), Mr Les Scott (from four citizens) and Mr Tuckey (from 68 citizens).

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BEDDALL; CAMERON; CHARLESWORTH; COURTICE; LINDSAY; WRIGHT
PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that major reforms be made to Australia's Retirement Income System. These reforms are earnestly sought by retired Australians and those facing retirement.
The reforms are:
That the pension be increased to 30% of average weekly earnings (i.e. increasing the basic pension to $146 p.w.).
That the pension become tax exempt.
That the pension be adjusted so that it keeps pace with price rises rather than falling up to 12 months behind.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray that your House/Parliament will see that our request reforms are implemented.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beddall (from 366 citizens), Mr Ian Cameron (from 38 citizens), Dr Charlesworth (from 230 citizens), Mr Courtice (from 34 citizens), Mr Lindsay (from eight citizens) and Mr Wright (from 132 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Importing and Exporting of Chlorofluorocarbons
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of certain Citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth:
That we are concerned at the threat to the environment that may result from an acceleration of the Greenhouse Effect.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to direct the Prime Minister and his Government:
1. To ban immediately both the exporting and the importing of Chlorofluorocarbons (CFC's) with the same exceptions as those specified in the Ozone Protection Bill.
2. To introduce tax deductibility of-
(a) cost and installation of solar heating systems; and
(b) cost and installation of home insulation.
3. To introduce tax incentives for-
(a) research and development of renewable energy alternatives;
(b) manufacturing and marketing of renewable energy alternatives; and
(c) development of new technology to reduce or avoid the use of environmental pollutants.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will legislate to provide these facilities.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Fitzgibbon (from 78 citizens), Mr Simmons (from 44 citizens) and Mr West (from 674 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled require the Hawke-Keating government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force most Australian home-seekers out of the housing market-and many Australians out of their homes-so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will every pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Peter Fisher (from 308 citizens), Mr Ruddock (from 48 citizens) and Mr Webster (from 62 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Romania: Human Rights
PETITION.PARA: Petition to the Right Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Romania, whose Human Rights Record had been worse than that of South Africa's even before she embarked on a diabolic village destruction program, deservedly attracts worldwide condemnation. The systematic cultural genocide of the peoples affected must be prevented.
Therefore your petitioners humbly pray that:
1. the Australian Parliament establish whether or not Romania has satisfied fully her obligations under Treaty of Trianon (1920) and the Peace Treaty of Paris (1947),
2. if found that Rumania violates these agreements, the signatures representing Australia jointly or singularly be withdrawn from the thus invalidated documents,
3. Australia table her findings at the appropriate forums of the United Nations.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will every pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Halverson (from 92 citizens), Mr Macphee (from 73 citizens) and Dr Wooldridge (from 97 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: `Authority Required' Prescriptions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to a person in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will every pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale (from three citizens) and Mrs Darling (from 54 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: International Earth Repair Action Decade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:
our total global environment is rapidly deteriorating;
important natural resources vital to human life and livelihood such as ozone, trees, soil and water are being depleted at an increasing and alarming rate;
there is an urgent need to educate all people in conservation skills and the responsible use and maintenance of natural resources;
the United Nations Association of Australia (the people's arm of the UN), has proclaimed an Australian ERA (Earth Repair Action) Decade from 1988;
Earth Repair Action will unite people, communities, religions and nations in the productive purpose of greening and repairing our Earth for a safer and more peaceful future.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:

Propose that an International Earth Repair Action (ERA) Decade begin on World Environment Day, June 5, 1990 with FIERY, the First International Earth Repair Year, and that this be proclaimed by the United Nations General Assembly. This ten-year plan will ignite the spirit of local and global co-operation to hygienically compost all presently wasted bio-degradable materials into humus to revitalise soils; grow billions of trees to replace forests lost and replenish the atmosphere; establish sustainable, economic and agricultural growth internationally, and end world hunger.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Carlton (from 24 citizens) and Mr Cowan (from 36 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

We, the people of Berowra, wish to draw the attention of Members to the fact that proposed cuts in funding of Pharmaceutical Benefits will severely reduce service and availability of medicines to the public. Your petitioners therefore ask the House to reject these cuts and maintain our family chemist service.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Harry Edwards (from 65 citizens) and Mr Ruddock (from 251 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Madam Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the continued Government interference in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme which has severely affected the viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide the quality and quantity of services to which we as Australians have a right.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to guarantee the provision of an adequately funded pharmaceutical benefits scheme which ensures the availability of pharmaceutical benefits through local community pharmacies.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hollis (from 118 citizens) and Dr Woods (from 12,635 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Madam Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:-

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the continued Government interference in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme which is causing hardship and confusion amongst the sick and elderly.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to guarantee the provision of an adequately funded pharmaceutical benefits scheme which is free from government tampering and provides for the public of Australia a comprehensive range of modern therapeutic products.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Pornography: X-Rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled. We, the undersigned, being appalled that the government has set no penalty for importing unclassified child pornography, do ask that Parliament urgently legislate to:
make the importation of child pornography, and the possession of child pornography, and all tapes and goods banned by Customs, to be a criminal offence, with deterrent penalties, and
close the Customs barriers to pornography in the A.C.T., in respect of X-rated videos, (and ER) and end the shameful Canberra trade, and the Mafia connections.
Because 98% of Australians in other States have banned x rated videos.
Because the trade is still flourishing, and its availability escalates sexual crime.
Because importers of child pornography face only a fine for lying.
Because child pornography peddlers are safe if they cross a border, and cannot be extradited for a summary offence.
Your petitioners therefore humble pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-Rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that both Federal and State Attorneys General support the banning of x-rated videos.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to pass legislation banning x-rated videos.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: Human Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament;
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House . . .
That the Australian Parliament expresses its repugnance that the Socialist Republic of Vietnam has kept imprisoned, 47 Buddhist leaders since 1984.

And further, that the regime in Vietnam has recently tried and sentenced to death: Thich Tri Sieu and Thich Tue Sy, two distinguished scholars from amongst the 47. Both of these religious academics are intellectuals of the highest order, being scholars in Buddhist Scripture.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to denounce the intentions of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam and to call on the Vietnamese Government for clemency and a remission of the death sentence as being barbaric.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Electorate of Indi respectfully showeth that:

Pharmacists condemn the proposed reduction in Budget allocation to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and that they fear for their livelihoods and insist on further constructive consultation with regard to the matter.

That they resent being used as `political footballs' and further request that serious consideration be made to raise the level of recompense through a larger allocation of the health pie, to pharmacists, to a level similar to respective professions.
Pharmacists and staff wish to maintain their professionalism.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament
The petition of certain electors of the Division of Lilley draws to the attention of the House the fact that:

If the cross wind runway at Brisbane Airport were to be used for jet aircraft, residents of Nudgee Beach, Shorncliffe, Pinkenba and Brighton would suffer noise far greater than that suffered by other residents with craft flying at altitudes of 400 feet over Nudgee Beach to 1700 feet over the Eventide Nursing Home.
Given that the `good neighbour' policy between residents of the area and the airport has been successful in the past;

Your petitioners request that the House call on the Prime Minister, the Minister for Transport and Communications and the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support to implement promises made by the Government that Runway 14/32 will not be used for jet aircraft.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The Petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
Federal fuel excise taxation has reached record levels resulting in high costs for fuel and causing severe hardship particularly for people in country areas.
At the same time there has been a considerable reduction in the amount of Federal fuel excise taxation spent on roads, reduced from 66 per cent in 1983 to 20 per cent in 1989.

Your Petitioners therefore pray that the House call on the Federal Government to take heed of the crisis situation facing small business, large fuel users and the crisis situation relation to road infrastructure and-
1. Reduce by half the CPI Federal fuel tax increases
2. Increase by half the proportion of Federal fuel taxation being spent on roads

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, draw to the attention of the House our extreme concern about the impact of any human activities in the Antarctic, such as mining and tourism, on the region's environment and wildlife.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to do everything in its power to prevent such activities, in the interests of Australia and the world; and to ensure that the Antarctic region is preserved as a Heritage Park.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoking Sections on Qantas International Flights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House, that they are opposed to the removal of smoking sections on Qantas international flights.

To do so would jeopardise our fledgling tourist industry and would discriminate against 30 per cent of Australians who wish to smoke. This proposal would also harm Qantas profits and good public image and would cause the international traveller to use overseas airlines who are prepared to provide services which are required by all passengers.
The argument of so-called passive smoking does not apply if the aircraft's air-conditioning system is operating to its optimum.
Your petitioners therefore request the Parliament to totally ignore any such demands made upon Qantas.
Your petitioners, in duty bound, will ever pray.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:
That people throughout rural and regional Australia are being discriminated against by unjustly high fuel prices.

They believe the Government should legislate to require a uniform price discount to all wholesalers when this is offered by the oil companies, and thus remove the major component in the retail price differential of approximately 10 cents per litre.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to amend the legislation to allow cheaper fuel price justice for country people.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully draws to the attention of the House that whilst all State governments have agreed to legislation to prevent the distribution of X-rated videos, a loophole in Commonwealth laws allows the distribution of this material by mail order from Canberra.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the House urge the Government to pass legislation to ban the distribution of X-rated videos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully draws to the attention of the House proposals by Australia Post to close down hundreds of post offices in rural and regional areas.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the House request the Government to ensure that any restructuring of Australia Post's operations does not result in any reduction of postal services to customers.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain electors of the Division of Higgins draws to the attention of the House that we the undersigned members of the Chadstone Senior Citizens Club object to the $2 coin and feel it should be withdrawn by the Federal Government for the following reasons:
(a) The weight of the coin when given change of $10 wears a hole in a female's purse or the male's pocket.
(b) At times persons are unable to identify the $2 coin as it is similar to the 5c coin especially in the dark or a person with failing eyesight.
(c) The $2 coin should be replaced by the plastic $2 note similar to the $10 note.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to take action to accept or reject this petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and all Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully draws to the attention of the House the inequities that presently exist in the treatment of pensioners' income.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the House request the Government to:
Abandon forthwith the changes to the Income Test for pensioners as proposed in the August 1988 Budget;
Increase the Age Pension to 35% of Average Weekly Male Earnings;
Ensure that married pensioners EACH receive the full pension;
Increase the taxation threshold for pensioners to a minimum of $12,500;
Allow EACH pensioner $70 per week of `other income' without any reduction of pension, and that this threshold be indexed to the CPI;
Assess capital gains in the hands of pensioners only under the Assets Test, and NOT as income;
Adjust capital gains in the hands of a pensioner for the effects of inflation over the term of the investment; and
Establish a superannuation fund to provide age pensions without a means test.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in the Parliament.

We, the undersigned citizens of the Northern Territory, point out to the House that the Northern Territory Aboriginal Areas Protection Bill (1988) is totally unacceptable to Aboriginal people. This new law will take control of the protection of sacred sites away from Aboriginal people and give it to a Northern Territory Government Minister.
We therefore ask the House to stop this Bill becoming law, to make a better law, and to help Aboriginal people to properly protect their sacred sites.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That there is a general dissatisfaction in the community at the levels of road funding made available by the Federal Government.
While noting the commitment of the Government to maintain a high standard of roads in Australia, we are specifically concerned at the real cutbacks for road funding in the local government area.
We especially note that roadworks are a labour intensive industry and cutbacks will create unemployment and hardship in rural areas.
Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, give due consideration to increasing the amount of funds available to local government authorities for roadworks.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Antarctica
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House the proposed signing of the Antarctic Mining Convention.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to urge the Australian Government not to sign this convention, and furthermore, to assist in the development and preservation of Antarctica as a world wild-life park.
We believe that to allow any mining to occur in this last wilderness area is an irresponsible action, for the world today, and for our future generations.
`We do not own the world, we only borrow it for our children.'

PETITION.PARA: Petition to the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in the Parliament.
We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, ask the House to note our objection to the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, Part 3, No. 10, Section 3F, 3G, 3H.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray that the House rejects this legislation.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, I present the Committee's report entitled Mergers Takeovers and Monopolies: Profiting from Competition?, including a dissenting report, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mergers Takeovers and Monopolies: Profiting from Competition? is the first report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. It presents the Committee's findings and recommendations in relation to its inquiry into the adequacy of the existing legislative controls over mergers, takeovers and monopolies. The inquiry was initiated in February 1988 following public criticism over the level of takeover activity and industry concentration in Australia. Much of this concern related to the often frenetic takeover activity that occurred prior to the October 1987 market adjustment. The inquiry focused on the merger and misuse of market power provisions contained in sections 46 and 50 of the Trade Practices Act 1974. The effectiveness of the Trade Practices Commission in its implementation of those provisions was also examined.

SPEECH.PARA: At the commencement of the inquiry and prior to two very important judicial decisions relating to the key provisions under scrutiny, my impression was that there would need to be significant amendments to the Act. It was also apparent to me that there should be greater opportunity for public scrutiny in relation to the administration of the Act. The Committee nevertheless approached the inquiry with an open mind. It sought and received evidence from a significant number of participants in the trade practices field, including the regulatory agencies, government departments, consumer organisations, business representatives and other interested parties.

As a result of the breadth of issues and opinions which emerged, the Committee conducted a workshop which provided those who made substantive submissions to the inquiry with the opportunity to test and challenge each other's views in an open forum. This workshop was attended by the senior and leading players in the trade practices field. The evidence gathered at the workshop was of great benefit to the Committee in the formulation of its recommendations.

The Committee also took account of the significant developments in the trade practices field in the course of its inquiry. These developments ought not to be underestimated in terms of their importance to the Committee's conclusions. They were, for example, the appointment of a new chairman of the Trade Practices Commission and the announcement of a modified approach to merger regulation by the Commission. Further, the landmark High Court of Australia decision in the Queensland Wire Industries Pty Ltd case, relevant to section 46 of the Trade Practices Act, proved to be of crucial import. Again, the favourable decision for the Commission in the Australia Meat Holdings Pty Ltd case was of considerable relevance to section 50 of the Act. These developments have strengthened the mergers and misuse of market power provision of the Act and have created a more favourable environment for the enforcement of those provisions by the Commission. In the absence of these developments, more substantial changes than have been recommended in the report would, in my view, have been required.

At this point it is important to note that the Act has a double thrust. Firstly, it should be seen as a consumer protection Act, based on the presumption that effective competition is simply a means to that end. This fact was emphasised by the High Court in the Queensland Wire Industries case to which I have referred. At the same time, this objective must be balanced against the need to promote efficiency and competitiveness in Australian business and industry.

Since 1977 section 50 has facilitated the rationalisation and restructuring of Australian industry through mergers and takeovers. Where this has increased the potential for anti-competitive behaviour, section 46 has offered protection against the misuse of market powers.

Turning to the report, the Committee has made a number of significant recommendations aimed at improving the enforcement of the merger control provisions of the Trade Practices Act. Chief among these is the Committee's recommendation that the private right to injunctive relief in merger cases be reintroduced to the Act, so that persons other than the Minister or the Trade Practices Commission can apply for an injunction in respect of a contravention of the merger provisions. This is a substantial recommendation for reform, which will ensure that private resources are brought to bear in the war against anti-competitive mergers. It will, as a result, facilitate further development of section 50, allowing it to be tested on an ongoing basis. However, because of concerns that the proposal may be used as a tactical weapon to delay or defeat takeovers, the Committee has recommended that takeover targets and associated persons should be excluded from this right.

The Committee has also made a number of recommendations to enhance the role and effectiveness of the Commission. In this regard, the Committee welcomes the modified approach to merger regulation enunciated by the Commission in its Statement of Objectives, Priorities and Work Program for 1988-89. This approach, which places greater emphasis on the authorisation procedure for mergers with the potential to affect market dominance, and which subsequently will allow greater public scrutiny of such mergers, will help to allay recent concerns about the role and effectiveness of the Commission. However, as there remains some concern that the approach is at the discretion of the incumbent officers of the Commission, the Committee has recommended that the Attorney-General issue a direction that the current policy of the Commission towards merger regulation be continued, to ensure that there is a consistent and standardised approach to the public scrutiny of public benefit issues in merger regulation.

The Committee has also recommended that the informal consultative process for mergers, which has allowed business to consult with the Commission about mergers which may have risked breaching section 50, should be given legislative underpinning. This will provide significant advantages, particularly in terms of public accountability considerations and the effectiveness of undertakings entered into as part of the process. Essentially, this should comprise legislative backing for extra statutory activities already carried out by the Trade Practices Commission. Any formalisation of the process should be of a minimal nature.

A significant problem identified by the Committee, arising out of the consultative process for mergers, is that adequate information does not appear to have been made publicly available to allow sufficient public scrutiny of the Commission's decision-making processes. The absence of publicly available information has clearly contributed to the level of criticism generated in recent years as a result of controversial mergers. To remedy this situation, the Committee has recommended that the Trade Practices Commission extend the use of its public register to all merger matters, including matters considered under the consultative process. All matters should be placed on the public register within 12 months, unless there are significant confidentiality problems.

To strengthen the position of the Trade Practices Commission, the Committee has recommended that the Trade Practices Act be amended to provide statutory remedies in respect of undertakings entered into by proponents of mergers as a condition of both the authorisation procedure and the consultative process for mergers. Statutory remedies will give greater force to undertakings made to the Trade Practices Commission. For example, the need for such remedies was highlighted by the Skywest case involving the Ansett takeover of East-West Airlines.

The existing remedies for contraventions of section 46 and 50 were also found to be totally inadequate as an effective deterrent to any corporation or individual contemplating a breach of the misuse of market power or merger provisions of the Trade Practices Act. The current levels of pecuniary penalty attaching to a contravention can hardly be considered realistic in a commercial environment, and may well encourage firms to engage in a cost-benefit analysis. Accordingly, the Committee has recommended a substantial increase in the existing maximum pecuniary penalty. As the Committee considers that pecuniary penalties may not be the most appropriate remedy in every case, it has also recommended that a range of other appropriate remedies be introduced and that the court be provided with broader discretionary powers in relation to the range and level of penalties which may be imposed for contraventions of part IV of the Trade Practices Act.

On the question of the courts, the Committee is of the view that the Federal Court of Australia remains the most appropriate forum for resolution of matters under part IV of the Act, and there is a need to enhance the effectiveness of the court in this area. The Committee has recommended options in that context. The Committee has recommended that the Attorney-General develop appropriate procedures for improving coordination between the Trade Practices Commission and other regulatory agencies which deal with various aspects of merger matters. This will help to ensure that other agencies, such as the Foreign Investment Review Board, give consideration to the attitudes of the Trade Practices Commission in relation to merger matters.

At this point, I must stress that improvements in the trade practices area are sustainable only if there is an active enforcement of the legislation. In this regard, the Committee has recommended that the Trade Practices Commission maintain a pro-active approach to the regulation of the merger and misuse of market power provisions of the Trade Practices Act. The Committee endorses the view of the Australian Consumers Association that the Trade Practices Commission, as the main consumer protection agency in Australia, should `rigorously enforce the provisions of the Trade Practices Act to ensure that consumers' rights are not infringed'.

The Committee, of course, recognises that a more pro-active approach will entail greater demands on the resources of the Trade Practices Commission. In this regard, the Committee is concerned at claims by the Commission that its efforts to promote competition have been severely hampered by the lack of its resources. The Committee is particularly concerned that, if resource constraints feature as a fundamental part of the Commission's decision-making processes in relation to whether it should pursue breaches, there is a strong possibility that the Trade Practices Commission may eventually represent little more than symbolic reassurance for the community. (Extension of time granted). To remedy this situation, the Committee has recommended that cost recovery measures be introduced in relation to the regulation of mergers.

With regard to sections 46 and 50, the Committee has recommended, on the basis of the substantive evidence before it, that, for the present, the merger and misuse of market power provisions of the Trade Practices Act should be retained in their existing form. The recent High Court decisions in relation to both sections have demonstrated that the existing provisions are capable of achieving the purposes for which they are intended. The overwhelming evidence provided to the Committee was that sufficient time should be allowed to ensure that the force and effectiveness of the existing provisions, as recognised in recent judgments, can be fully realised. The Committee considered at length various proposals for reform, particularly in relation to the merger provisions in section 50. Chief among these was the suggestion to abolish the existing dominance threshold and to replace it with a test which would prohibit mergers which result in a substantial lessening of competition.

The Committee considers that the various proposals for reform are inappropriate at this time. During the inquiry, there was considerable opposition to such reforms. Proposals such as a return to the substantial lessening of competition test would involve a significant lowering of the threshold at which mergers would be prohibited. This has the potential to inhibit industry restructuring and rationalisation. Superficially, it may be appealing to alter the wording in the existing provisions to indicate a greater emphasis on consumer protection. However, this ignores the considerable uncertainty which would result if untested provisions were inserted in the Act. The recent Australia Meat Holdings case has clearly demonstrated the capacity of the courts to interpret the existing dominance threshold so as to ensure adequate competition in a market. On balance, therefore, the Committee favours retention of the existing dominance threshold in section 50. The Committee is of the view that the need for improved efficiency and increased international competitiveness has not diminished in the last decade. Indeed, the contrary is the case. Retention of the existing provisions in section 50 will ensure that there is no legislative impediment to the achievement of efficiency and competitiveness through the rationalisation and restructuring of Australian industry. One difficulty which the Committee faced in its assessment of the issues was that the existing evidence on mergers and takeovers is inconclusive. The lack of empirical data was a fundamental problem in the course of the inquiry and the Committee has made certain recommendations to ensure that position does not continue into the future.

In recommending retention of section 50 in its existing form, the Committee was, of course, conscious of concerns about increasing levels of concentration in industry, and the potential for misuse of power which may arise. In this regard, the Committee recognises that an effective provision to prevent misuse of market power is an essential, indeed fundamental, counterbalance to a policy which encourages acquisition and rationalisation. At the outset of the inquiry, it was apparent that varying judicial interpretations of section 46 had created considerable uncertainty about the operation of the section. It was suggested that the narrow interpretation of the existing provisions in recent case law indicated that there may be limits to the section. However, the recent High Court decision in the Queensland Wire Industries case has provided much needed clarification of section 46. While not all areas of concern have been resolved, clearly this case has made a major impact and provides significant guidance to practitioners in the area. The Committee does see a need, though, to clarify some potential areas of concern, and has accordingly recommended that the Trade Practices Commission issue guidelines on the operation of section 46.

While the Committee supports the retention of the existing provisions in sections 46 and 50 at this time, it has adopted this position only on the premise that there will be an active enforcement of those provisions by the Trade Practices Commission. I reiterate that this can be achieved only if sufficient resources are made available to the Commission. If sufficient resources are not forthcoming, then serious consideration will need to be given to strengthening the merger and misuse of market power provisions of the Trade Practices Act. I cannot stress that too strongly.

As Chairman, I would like to thank the Deputy Chairman, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), and my fellow Committee members for the time and commitment they devoted to the inquiry. Thanks are also due to the Secretary of the Committee, Mr Jon Stanhope, as well as to Mr Andres Lomp and Ms Natalie Raine.

Mergers Takeovers and Monopolies: Profiting from competition? will contribute to a greater awareness of the legislative and administrative controls necessary to ensure genuine and robust competitive behaviour in the business environment in Australia. The recommendations in the report are based on a reasoned assessment of all the evidence before the Committee and have attracted bipartisan support. Adoption of the recommendations will help to ensure a continued commitment to the consideration of public interest issues in the implementation of Australian trade practices legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Deputy Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs until today-I have been translated, in a sense, and will not be able to continue my involvement with the Committee, but I value the time I have spent with it-I am pleased that we have been able to complete this important reference. I join the Committee Chairman, the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths), in commending to honourable members the Committee's report on mergers, takeovers and monopolies. The report is based on a realistic assessment of the environment in which the Trade Practices Act is required to operate. While protection of competition for the benefit of consumers is clearly a major objective of the Act, the Committee has acknowledged that improved efficiency and international competitiveness in Australian industry are a vital factor in determining the most appropriate approach to merger regulation.

SPEECH.PARA: The need to promote efficiency and competitiveness through industry rationalisation and restructuring was a catalyst for the 1977 amendments to section 50 of the Trade Practices Act. In introducing the control and dominance threshold to section 50, the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs stated:

There should be no unnecessary impediment, legislative or administrative, to the attainment of rationalisation of Australian industry. It is in Australia's best interest to achieve economies of scale and improved international competitiveness.

This approach was continued with the 1986 amendments to the Act, which saw the section 50 threshold changed to dominance. In recommending that the dominance threshold test be retained, the Committee has not shied away from the reality that rationalisation and restructuring of Australian industry, in order to improve efficiency and international competitiveness, are as important today as they were in 1977. During the inquiry, there was considerable debate about the most appropriate wording for sections 46 and 50, to ensure that the dual aims of consumer protection and business efficiency are achieved. The Committee received much evidence about the effectiveness of the existing provisions and how they could be improved. Reflected in the various proposals for reform, though, was a significant degree of uncertainty as to their implications for the future operation of Australian competition policy. This uncertainty contrasts with the degree of clarification which has been provided recently by the courts in relation to sections 46 and 50. The Australia Meat Holdings case and the Queensland Wire Industries case are significant developments in the trade practices field.

The Australia Meat Holdings case is only the second fully-argued section 50 case since the Trade Practices Act came into force in 1974. It reflects the preparedness of the courts to assess dominance in order that effective competition in the market is maintained. The Queensland Wire Industries case provides much needed clarification of the provisions in section 46. The decision has been arrived at after various judicial interpretations indicated possible limits to the operation of the section. In the light of these developments, the Committee had decided that further time should be given for the testing of the existing provisions. While developments in the law often involve a lengthy process and while some areas of concern remain, there are, at this stage, sound reasons for not rushing in to implement reform. It would, I believe, be unwise to move from a position of some clarity to one of potential uncertainty. The evidence before the Committee has not adequately demonstrated the need for amendments to the existing provisions of sections 46 and 50. Indeed, the overwhelming evidence supports the retention of the existing provisions, as recommended by the Committee.

In order to contain my remarks I was going to go on and deal with aspects of certainty and uncertainty. However, I wish to cover some other issues, particularly in relation to the public interest questions that are involved. In conducting the inquiry, a broad approach to public interest considerations in the Trade Practices Act was taken. The Committee did not specify particular industries or markets for special attention. Nevertheless, it did consider evidence which pointed to factors peculiar to the media as justifying a special case for defined restrictions on the level of ownership and control of the print media, principally to secure and maintain freedom of expression. In this regard, it should be noted that the Parliament has seen fit to legislate in relation to radio and television ownership, and it has taken newspapers into account where broadcasting issues are concerned. There is, of course, no such legislation dealing only with newspaper ownership.

The Committee is conscious of, and sympathetic to, the heightened public expectations that appropriate levels of competition are maintained and, where possible, improved in the newspaper sector. It therefore considers that an inquiry being undertaken by the Trade Practices Commission into certain issues concerning the degree of concentration of newspaper ownership in Australia, which currently has a narrow focus, should be broadened to enable a serious examination of the extent of the powers available to the Commonwealth in relation to the newspaper industry. The examination should consider what, if any, special provisions are appropriate in relation to newspapers. I would like to have been able to talk about the Trade Practices Commission.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade I present the Committee's reports on visits to New Zealand and New Caledonia in April of 1989, together with the minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The two delegation reports which I have just presented to the House relate to visits by members of the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee to New Zealand and New Caledonia in April. I had the pleasure of leading the delegation to New Zealand to participate in the first exchange between committees of the Australian and New Zealand parliaments.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, I was not able to participate in the New Caledonia trip led by Senator Chris Schacht and therefore will confine my comments to the New Zealand leg. This visit was a significant development in the already substantial level of contact between the parliaments of both countries and emphasised the recognition on both sides of the Tasman of the special relationship between our two countries. Discussion has been under way for a number of years to revise the parliamentary contacts, to move away from general fact finding visits to areas that are more specific in their purpose. Following Prime Minister Lange's visit to Australia in August of last year, the subject was again examined and agreement reached to suspend the usual visits conducted under the Fraser-Talboys agreement for a period of two years while the new exchanges were instituted and evaluated.

The South Pacific Subcommittee of the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee had an invitation from the New Zealand Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee to visit New Zealand. The Presiding Officers of the Australian Parliament agreed that this Committee be the first to undertake a visit to New Zealand under the new arrangements. A special working group based around the South Pacific Subcommittee, of which I was the Chairman, was formed to undertake the visit. The working group consisted of Senator Chris Schacht, the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter), the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), and myself as leader.

I pay tribute to the members of the delegation for their hard work and the bipartisan manner in which they participated in the visit. The program of the visit is set out in the report and it will become apparent that in the three days the Committee spent in Wellington the delegation was able to discuss many matters of mutual interest in the foreign affairs, defence and trade areas not only with our counterpart committee but also with Ministers of the New Zealand Government, officials and members of the business community. The program was very full and on a number of occasions discussions could have continued well in excess of the time allowed. We have therefore recommended that future exchanges be at least four days in length, and in my opinion probably five days, with a little time off in the middle to catch one's breath, and contain two sessions with the host committee-one at the start of the program, similar to the one we had, and a second at the end where the issues raised in briefings can be discussed in a committee meeting in the latter part of the five-day visit.

I do not propose to go into detail on all the issues canvassed during our visit, but I would like to refer to one issue that was raised with us many times in discussions-the Anzac frigate program. The delegation's purpose was not to lobby for New Zealand's participation in the program as some New Zealanders thought, but once the matter was raised we engaged in some vigorous discussion and debate on the subject. I must say that we were dismayed at the generally poorly informed level of debate on the whole question and the lack of information about the economic benefits of the program, in particular the $NZ1 billion-plus that would come through the New Zealand defence manufacturing industry, which is a sizeable injection into the New Zealand economy. Unfortunately, New Zealand business appeared to be generally uncertain of the benefits and also reluctant to promote these benefits. On the other hand, I can understand this reluctance as the New Zealand Government has failed to commit itself firmly to the project at this time.

What was most disturbing to the delegation, however, was to hear the program referred to as the Australian frigate program and to hear claims that Australia was attempting to sell New Zealand these frigates. The program has been a cooperative effort of over two years' standing, reflected in the title Anzac. Tender redesign work was undertaken to modify the design to meet both the Royal Australian Navy and the Royal New Zealand Navy requirements and a memorandum of understanding on the program was signed in March 1987. The delegation found it difficult, therefore, to understand why the debate in progress in New Zealand on the surface combatant had not occurred at the time of the publication of the New Zealand White Paper or the signing of the memorandum of understanding.

In presenting this report to the Parliament, I wish to commend the concept of committee exchanges. The visit proved to be a most effective way of enhancing dialogue and understanding between the two parliaments on matters of real substance. The Committee fully supports the continuation of such exchanges beyond the two-year trial period. New Zealand is not only a close neighbour; it is one with which we have strong links of language, culture and history. It is therefore important to strengthen the contact between the parliaments of both countries. The continuation and expansion of such committee exchanges should receive high priority from both parliaments.

The exchanges that took place were very frank and informative. Indeed, the flow of information between the two committees was most valuable. As I mentioned before, this not only occurred between the two committees but involved other business people and officials as well. I found some of the discussions with the officials, particularly of the Department of Defence and the Department of External Relations and Trade-which is the equivalent of our Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade-most informative, and the cross-flow of information most valuable, particularly relating to South Pacific matters.

The success of the inaugural exchange was made possible by many people in both countries, and on behalf of the delegation I would like to thank the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade; the staff of the Australian High Commission in Wellington; the New Zealand Department of External Relations and Trade and Internal Affairs-in particular, Mr Jim Blair for his kind assistance; and, not the least, members and officers of the New Zealand Parliament for their assistance and hospitality. I commend the reports to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak in relation to the tabling of these two reports in relation to the visit to New Zealand and the visit to New Caledonia by the subcommittees of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. The subcommittees were formed specifically for the purpose of undertaking each of the visits. I endorse the comments made by the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles), particularly in relation to the hospitality that we received. In my brief contribution I want to take this opportunity to emphasise to the Parliament the importance of visits of this type within our own region. Honourable members would be aware that the opportunity that is afforded to us to undertake study tours all too frequently means, in relation to the way that those programs are arranged, that we go to those places which are usually more difficult for us to reach, and more expensive in a sense, and thus very often there is little in the way of resources to maintain the important relationships within our own region.

SPEECH.PARA: New Zealand, one of our closest neighbours, is one of those places that honourable members do not often get to, and for that reason I think that the exchange program is of the utmost importance to this Parliament. It is of the utmost importance in ensuring that there is a more adequate understanding of the issues that bring us together, as well as of those on which we disagree. We had an opportunity to explore many of these questions. The importance of our common economic relationships was one of those issues which we spent a good deal of time addressing. Defence relationships was another matter that was of importance, and the report itself is valuable for that reason.

The Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member who spoke before me in this debate, did not accompany us on the visit to New Caledonia, and so I would like to speak briefly on the report in relation to the visit there. The visit to New Caledonia was not able to be undertaken when the South Pacific Subcommittee undertook its program of visits to a number of nations in the South Pacific, and so we went to New Caledonia after we had in fact reported.

The report presently before the House covers a good deal of the difficulties that the South Pacific nation of New Caledonia has. I would like to highlight some of those matters. In relation to the matters that have been addressed, the historical background is canvassed and the political future is addressed. Importantly, we commented on our meeting with Jean-Marie Tjibaou, who was the leader of the Kanak people. Our meeting with him took place only days before he was assassinated. In that sense, the visit was of greater moment for us because of his role in the establishment of the accords whereby a modicum of peace has been achieved in New Caledonia at this time.

We spent a good deal of our visit endeavouring to assess the political future of New Caledonia. I want to emphasise the amount of time that we spent during our visit discussing with the Kanak people the way in which they relate to land, the issue of land ownership and the issue of custom authority and the way in which decisions are made. Those of us who, like you, Mr Deputy Speaker, have taken an interest in Aboriginal affairs in this country will be aware of the importance of land to the Melanesian people and will appreciate the way in which decisions need to be made, taking into account the special relationship that exists.

In the interregnum it has become clear that the French are faced with considering the way in which our European background might well bring about changes in attitude amongst the Melanesians in terms of their custom authority, decision-making processes and attitude towards land. One of the important issues to be considered and to keep on top of is this issue of land ownership and custom authority. If the way in which the Melanesians handle these matters maintains a traditional approach, I do not believe the accords will deliver other than a new Melanesian nation in New Caledonia. If, however, the Melanesian culture is broken down so that individual land ownership becomes the norm, I suspect we will be more likely to see the integration of New Caledonia into metropolitan France being maintained even after the 10-year trial period of the accords. Many of us do not have the background and experience to be able to examine these issues. I certainly hope that those who have the opportunity to visit New Caledonia in the future will make the sort of inquiry which we did, which is referred to in this report, as it will give them a better understanding of the future which that country may have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter The Hon R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to contribute for three or four-perhaps five-minutes to this discussion. First of all, I would like to endorse what both the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) and my colleague the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) have said, which is that there is a tremendous advantage not only in visiting a country which is a neighbour, but in visiting any country. One thing which emerges, which is almost like a conscience vote in Parliament, is that we seem to set aside our political differences. I would like to pay special tribute to the honourable member for Isaacs. I have been on a few delegations with him, and he has a very commendable bipartisan attitude in these matters and a true sense of what is required on these trips.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to pinpoint one or two matters which are of basic importance in relation to our discussion. Much has been said about the discussions regarding the frigate program. One fact which did emerge and which, perhaps, has not been fully aired is that the people of New Zealand-and this became very evident as we spoke to various groups-did not really know what it was all about. They were not aware of the fact that 12 frigates were envisaged-we were to have eight and the New Zealanders were to have four. Over and above that, they were not aware of the most basic consideration of all for a languishing economy such as they have, regrettably, and that is that $1.3 billion would be spent in New Zealand if the agreement were to be concluded.

Another matter which all of us appreciated very much was the general attitude of the various Pacific islands to both countries. I have always been an advocate for making it a little easier for people to visit this country. I do not mean unlimited migration from the Pacific islands, because the islanders would not want that and I am sure that we would have to give very serious thought to any migration from anywhere. It emerged that, experimentally, a period was set aside whereby people of the Pacific islands could visit New Zealand without any inhibitions such as visas. Apparently, many of those people came and settled permanently, which created a bit of an uproar. The experiment lasted for only six weeks. Another matter of great importance, which does not really concern us-we do not go poking around the world to interfere in other people's affairs-relates to the contributions that Japan has made to assist the Pacific islands. Such assistance is to be greatly encouraged but it was, perhaps, a little misplaced. I refer to financial assistance where much more advantagious contributions could have been made.
As to the general feeling towards Australia, there have been differences of opinion. Fundamentally, we realise that we are very much of the same ilk and that we think along the same lines.

A point which is of special interest to me, as one who comes from the remote areas, was the change in thinking in New Zealand in relation to defence and security. The accent had been taken off that to a great extent. We used to think of New Zealand as one of the flag-flying countries loyal to the throne to the nth degree. If we are honest enough to admit it and to face up to the realities, that has been somewhat dissipated. I say with a good deal of pride that that has been put down to the fact that many people in rural areas have drifted to the city. When the hardy, tough people from the rural areas move to the cities to enjoy the comforts that many city people have available, there is a general dissipation of the more rugged characteristics of any country. It is said that that has led greatly to the situation

I conclude with a prophecy. One does not set oneself up as a prophet unless something can be gained from it. Any of us who read the press and observed and met the man would concede that in the not too distant future-perhaps after another election or two-a man named Winston Peters will be the Prime Minister of New Zealand.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO ETHIOPIA, TANZANIA, MOZAMBIQUE AND ZIMBABWE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Ethiopia, Tanzania, Mozambique and Zimbabwe from 19 June to 14 July 1988. Given the publicity that this trip has gained, this report may well set a precedent for parliamentary reports by being a best-seller. I hope that all honourable members will find time to read it. I also hope that the unfortunate publicity earlier this year which tended to trivialise the trip will not detract from the important conclusions contained in the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to place on record my appreciation to the delegation members, especially my two Labor colleagues, the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) and the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Harvey), Mamma Crawford and Mamma Harvey. Having two women parliamentarians with us enabled us to gain additional and most valuable insights into many aspects of the countries we visited. To our hard working secretary, Peter Keele, I give a special word of thanks for carrying out his difficult duties under what were often very trying conditions. I thank our foreign affairs adviser, Michael Potts, for ensuring that our view of Australian policy was always correct. I stress this because there has been some criticism. All statements by me and all press releases issued were checked for accuracy with our foreign affairs advisers and local diplomatic representatives. I thank also the parliamentary and departmental officers for their help, especially Bronwyn Allen, whose assistance to the delegation went far beyond the normal call of duty.

The main objectives of the visit, as outlined in the brief and in the pre-departure briefings, were to foster goodwill and to develop closer ties between the Australian Parliament and the people, parliaments and governments of the host countries. It was also felt important to state Australia's position regarding current events in southern Africa as well as to seek the views of the countries that were visited. I believe that the visit was not only timely but of considerable significance, because many events are unfolding in this part of Africa that will have an important bearing on the future direction and well-being of the entire African continent over the next decade. For this reason it is a matter of personal regret to me that the tabling of this report has been delayed while the Opposition members came to an agreement on their dissenting report.

I think it is only fair to put in the record that it was a physically demanding trip. The comprehensive programs arranged in each country enabled the delegation to cover a wide range of fundamental issues which were discussed at length during the numerous meetings with heads of state, politicians, government officials, business leaders and representatives from numerous international and non-government organisations. One of the most satisfying things to come out of the visit was the clear and unambiguous message of the very high regard in which Australia is held in all four countries. It was put to the delegation time and time again that, unlike many other countries, Australia has an unblemished record in African affairs and our assistance and support has been very well received and appreciated. Australia must continue to support the development and humanitarian goals of the African people.

One issue stressed in the report concerns the closure of our embassy in Addis Ababa. All members of the delegation were of the view that Australia should be re-establish its embassy in Ethiopia not only from the point of view of that country's importance because of its population and strategic location but also because Addis Ababa is the headquarters of the Organisation of African Unity. We feel the decision to close the embassy was short-sighted and wrong and we urge that serious consideration be given to reopening it.

I would like to place on record our appreciation of the hospitality, cooperation and courtesy extended to all members of the delegation. Nothing was too much trouble for our hosts and the itineraries in each country were testimony to their willingness to meet all our wide-ranging interests and demands. The delegation is also grateful to our Australian representatives in the countries visited, especially Mr Doug Campbell and Mr Phil Peters, who helped make our visit a very productive and informative one. I reject utterly the criticism made of our representatives in some statements I have read.

In no way do I regard this report as the definitive statement on the affairs in each country visited. The report endeavours to give an accurate account of the various meetings and visits undertaken by the delegation. The report has commented on only the matters that were discussed and not on hearsay evidence or second-hand information. Whilst it is regrettable that the coalition members felt it necessary to submit a dissenting report, the Government members nonetheless respect their right to do so. I am pleased that they have no disagreement with the main conclusions of the report. However, the Labor members of the delegation think it is naive that the coalition members would have expected to hold official meetings with opponents of the governments of Ethiopia and Mozambique at a time when both countries were engaged in civil wars.

The main report highlights the major problems faced by Ethiopia and Mozambique. We believe that Tanzania needs to continue its austere economic recovery program under the leadership of President Mwinyi. We were impressed with the success achieved in Zimbabwe under the astute and conciliatory leadership of President Robert Mugabe. We are conscious that Zimbabwe faces a number of major problems, particularly in relation to investment and employment.

There were differing views between the Government and Opposition members of the delegation. No restrictions were placed on any members of the delegation at meetings with regard to questions and comments. Naturally, Government members did state official Government policy. It would have been a dereliction of duty if an official Australian parliamentary delegation did not state clearly and precisely current Australian Government policy. What I think upset coalition members was my stress on the bipartisan nature of much of Australia's policy in relation to Africa. As must be obvious to many members, given some recent comments in this House, some Opposition members were outraged by my giving Malcolm Fraser due recognition for his role in Africa and his position as co-chairman of the Eminent Persons Group.

It must be obvious to any thinking person that if South Africa did commence a program of genuine reform, it would be able to play a key role in economic development not only in southern Africa but throughout the entire African continent. This was a clear message from many Zimbabwean politicians, both black and white. South Africa cannot continue to ignore the rightful demands of the majority of its people. As Nelson Mandela said at the Rivonia trial:

We want political rights because without them our disabilities will be permanent . . . it is not true that the disenfranchisement of all will result in racial domination. Political division, based on colour, is entirely artificial and when it disappears so will the domination of one colour group by another.
Zimbabwe is certainly testimony to this statement.

Unlike the coalition members, the Government members of the delegation did not see examples of `Australia's often ill-conceived and inappropriate assistance'. The Ethiopian Catholic Secretariat (ECS) Food for Work dam project near Asmara, the Konso soil conservation project and the Gidole reafforestation project near Arba Minch are good examples of cost-efficient and effective Australian aid projects in these parts of Africa. We are, therefore, somewhat surprised by the statement that `Australia must concentrate its activities on those matters on which it has most to offer-such as in rural skills like prevention of land degradation and reafforestation programs'. These were the very projects we saw.

Similarly, the Labor members were surprised at suggestions that Australian food aid is being diverted. When members of the House of Commons Foreign Affairs Committee visited Ethiopia in 1988 they were impressed by the degree of accountability the Ethiopians displayed towards the proper distribution of food aid. The Labor members of this delegation also support this view. I cannot help thinking that, unfortunately, much of the Opposition members' dissenting report indicates a certain prejudice or hostility by some of them towards current Government policy on Southern Africa. I suggest that this could even indicate a certain hostility by the same members to coalition policies towards Africa.

The Labor members of the delegation have no argument with the final paragraph of the dissenting report. Indeed, we endorse the comments and we would further suggest that all members of outgoing delegations must fully acquaint themselves with the brief prior to departure and if they have any difficulties with that brief they should be raised at that stage of proceedings.

I also take this opportunity to put on the record my concern about the need for Parliament, through the Presiding Officers, to establish a set of clear guidelines relating to the conduct and participation of delegation members and any accompanying spouses. I also suggest that it is important that all members of any outgoing delegation arrive together and participate in all official meetings, briefings and functions unless there are extenuating circumstances. A commitment by any member of parliament to participate in any outgoing delegation should be seen as a commitment to participate in the full program that has been set down by the host countries.

Finally, I believe that this delegation was able to forge closer ties with all host countries and this will reflect well on our Parliament and Australia. On a personal level, I believe that members of the delegation have developed strong and lasting friendships with many of our African brothers and sisters.
