DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE UNITED KINGDOM AND IRELAND

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the report of the Parliamentary Delegation to the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and to the Republic of Ireland. I am happy to be able to report to the House that the parliamentary delegation to Britain and Ireland was a far happier delegation, obviously, than the one to Africa. I would like to thank the members of the delegation, who worked very well together, and the officials who accompanied us. It was an historic delegation-the first time that a delegation had visited Britain from this Parliament for some 17 years and the first time that there has ever been a delegation from this Parliament to the Republic of Ireland.

SPEECH.PARA: When one recalls that about 30 per cent of the people who live in Australia claim some Irish connection, it is remarkable that there has never been a visit to the Irish Parliament until 1988. It was 17 years since the previous visit to Britain, the country that colonised Australia. It shows that often we take for granted the links between countries where we have had a lot of cultural, economic and family ties. The delegation was very keen to point out to the Parliament that we should ensure that those links are made stronger in the future.

I am pleased to say that while we were in Britain we made arrangements for the beginning of a bilateral exchange between this Parliament and that of Britain. I hope that that bilateral exchange will also extend to Ireland. While there is not a great deal of trade between Australia and Ireland, the greatest thing that Ireland has given Australia has been its people. From my point of view and, I know, that of other members of the delegation, it was remarkable that when we arrived in Ireland we really recognised it as being the country in the world that is probably the most like Australia in terms of its people. We most certainly felt that we were at home.

I think a lot of that had to do with the excellent assistance we were given by the Speaker of the Irish Parliament, Sean Treacy, and the work that was done on our behalf by Ambassador Milne, who was our Ambassador to Ireland at the time. The person who took his place, Brian Burke, is also doing a wonderful job on behalf of Australia. Doug McClelland, who is well known to all of us and who is our High Commissioner in Britain, arranged very high level contacts between the delegation and people in Britain, as did Ambassador Milne in Ireland. We met with both the Prime Minister of Britain and the Prime Minister of Ireland. We met the foreign Ministers of both countries and a number of other senior Ministers. Those contacts were very worthwhile for members of this Parliament to put our view on what Australian people feel-particularly in relation to the European Economic Community and its trade embargoes.

We also had interesting discussions-and I might complete my remarks on this-with John Hume in Northern Ireland. All of us were saddened by what is happening in Northern Ireland but when we talked to people like John Hume we realised that there is some hope for the people who live there. One would hope that all shades of politics could take note of the view of a person like John Hume, who is willing to put his life on the line for the cause that the people of Northern Ireland should be able to live together in peace with each other. It was a saddening visit to the north of Ireland but the discussions we had with John Hume made us believe that at least there were some people who had the interests of all of that province at heart. One hopes that the current changes that are taking place in that troubled part of the world will be for the better and along the lines of the views of people like Hume.

In conclusion, I would like to thank the delegation once again for the harmonious way we all worked together. Let us hope that future delegations from this Parliament are more like the delegation to Great Britain and Ireland and less like the delegation to Africa.

It also enabled us to look at matters that are likely to significantly affect Australia. The comments I make are in relation to those two aspects, and firstly in relation to Northern Ireland.

The visit included a period in Northern Ireland. This was not the first time that I had been to Northern Ireland. I had been there earlier as a visitor under a program sponsored by the Foreign and Commonwealth Office of the United Kingdom. DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BUREAU OF STATISTICS AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 April, on motion by Mr Ian Robinson:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Bureau of Statistics Amendment Bill, which we have in front of us for consideration today, is an absolute and abject waste of the time of this Parliament. It is simply nothing more than a reflection of the malicious and small-minded nature of a minority of people who happen to be on the Opposition side of this Parliament in trying to attack an institution that was established in the period of their time in government. It brings to this place no credibility whatsoever. It is an outrageous attack on the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). Opposition members have made spurious claims about the Bureau in the past, and the Bill has proven to be nothing more than a vehicle for self-promotion by certain members of Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill would have an impact in two ways. Firstly, a detailed proposal, together with questionnaires, would have to be tabled in both Houses of Parliament for each and every collection of information undertaken by the ABS, including the renewal, repetition or revision of the survey. Does the honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson), who introduced the Bill, recognise that in 1987-88, for example, something like 1,600 surveys were undertaken by the ABS? If the Bill were passed, every time one of those surveys came into the House or the Senate it would have to be examined. There were 1,600 surveys in 1987-88; how many will there be in the future when we try to obtain further information?

I say by way of general comment that if this Bill were passed, all proposals would be subject to disapproval and disallowance by either House of Parliament. How ridiculous is that? Basically there are two sides to this Bill: a policy side and a practical side. On the policy side, it should be pointed out that the ABS was set up in 1975 as a statutory authority with the role of providing statistics for governments and the community generally. In fact, in parliamentary debates at the time this statutory authority was established, the government of the day spoke highly about the need for it to remain aloof and not to be subjected to government pressure. This Bill goes entirely against that grain. For clarification of that point, I refer Opposition members to the speeches made when the Australian Bureau of Statistics Bill was introduced in order to create the ABS.

More importantly, I refer to some of the features of the Bill and some of the flaws in its approach. In the second reading speech of the honourable member for Page, given on 10 April 1989, we can identify at least 10 areas in which there are not only omissions but also serious errors of fact. Firstly, it is stated in the speech:
Under present arrangements, if the Government Statistician wishes to make a compulsory survey, he is required to table his proposal in both Houses.

Under current arrangements the Statistician is required to table only new proposals. This is where Opposition members have tried to generate interest, saying that the Commonwealth Ombudsman has ruled that each new survey must be presented here and that some of the extensions of surveys presently under way will have to come before this Parliament. That is not the case.
The second point raised in the second reading speech of the honourable member for Page referred to the fact that:
The Statistician did not table the present household expenditure survey . . .

An extensive campaign has been waged by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) and Senator Shirley Walters on this topic, in particular on the household expenditure survey (HES) of 1988-89. They have said-and they have tried to prove-that, in some way, the existing survey is brand new; that it is totally different from what has happened in the past. In August 1988 the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) ruled that the 1988-89 HES was not a new proposal. Unfortunately, the honourable member for Moreton and his cohorts did not agree with that. In fact, they attacked the Australian Statistician and claimed that he had misled the Attorney-General's Department and sought other legal advice. The Attorney-General's Department sought independent legal advice and got it. In December 1988 the Attorney-General's Department again concluded that the HES for 1988-89 was not new and, specifically, that it was not significantly different from the 1984 HES forms that had been approved by a previous government.

Despite all those claims and counterclaims, legal opinions were obtained by the Opposition to the effect that, basically, the ABS is unaware of where that legal advice comes from. It is referred to by the honourable members for Moreton as an expert statistical analysis. Regardless of that view, clearly legally, from independent analysis and from the Attorney-General's Department, this is not a new survey and, therefore, it does not need to be tabled in this Parliament. Again a further spurious claim is contained in the speech on the second reading.

The question of voluntary and compulsory filling in of surveys has also been raised as part of a scaremongering tactic that is being waged by honourable members opposite and the leader of that scaremongering campaign has been the honourable member for Moreton. Let us look at the term `voluntary and compulsory nature of ABS collections'. I refer the honourable member for Moreton to section 6 (3) of the Australian Bureau of Statistics Act, which states:

. . . each new proposal for the collection of information for statistical purposes by the Bureau shall be laid before both Houses of Parliament, unless the proposal is for the collection of information on a voluntary basis.

When that is the case, there are two aspects: by request or by direction. No prosecution has ever been approved in relation to any household income or expenditure survey or any health survey. The honourable member for Moreton has been racing around his electorate claiming that the ABS will take people to court and that they will have to pay a $100 fine if they do not provide this information because it is compulsory. There have been all sorts of scaremongering tactics. Press releases have been put out, but, fortunately, the more responsible parts of the media in this country have not chosen to run with them.

The honourable member for Moreton, having failed to achieve any sort of media response, starts writing letters to editors and letters to the editor columns have been filled up with nonsense. When that does not get very far he races off to the union and says, `Do you know that your census collectors, who are part of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association (ACOA), for example, are being harassed? People really should not be doing this because it is illegal and legal opinion says that the compulsory filling in of the forms is not the way to go'. What is ACOA's position? ACOA wrote to the honourable member for Moreton in relation to this matter and said:

We have not had any complaints from members about householders' reactions to this survey. The only complaints we have had relate to activities by yourself and others in Queensland who are opposed to the survey.
Our members do not find these activities helpful to them, or to the conduct of their work.

So there we have the honourable member for Moreton again using scaremongering tactics, trying to do something about the situation. What is even more worrying in this whole matter is the harassment to which the honourable member for Moreton referred in respect of the census collectors and those who were getting this information for the ABS. That is not where it is really happening. The harassment is coming from people, such as the honourable member for Moreton and others, harassing the collectors themselves and there is evidence to suggest that that is the case. For example, I refer to one letter that was written to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The letter, which was addressed to the person who runs this section of collectors in Brisbane, was a letter of resignation from one of the ABS collectors. I will not refer to the person's name to protect that person from further harassment from honourable members on the other side of the chamber. The letter states:

Interviewers are being subjected to an increasing amount of verbal and physical abuse in the field. In some instances, interviewers have been contacted at their homes both by phone and letter by a member of one political party.
Honourable members would not have to guess which political party that is. It is not ours. The letter continues:
I consider this is a gross case of Invasion of Privacy and should have been followed up by the Bureau.

I submit that that is absolutely correct; the Bureau should follow up that accusation about harassment and about the invasion of people's privacy. Let me add the weight of further evidence to this. I have in front of me a copy of a `With the compliments of' slip from Mr D. M. Cameron, MP, Federal member for Moreton. Contained on that slip is a handwritten message to a collector of the ABS. Again I will not read the person's name to protect this person from further harassment. The message reads:
An HES respondent has advised me you are an ABS collector. In view of past association I wish for you to be aware I am not carrying on about nothing.

The message goes on. So, in other words, the honourable member for Moreton, who purports to represent the view of the community, is harassing census collectors and subjecting them to all forms of pressure, both at home and through letters. Again, he is bringing this place into disrepute by using these scaremongering tactics. I turn now to another aspect of this barrage that has been launched against the ABS. I go to the issue of letters that have been written to various newspapers around the country. A letter headed `Survey flouting law' which appeared in the Sun-Herald on 14 May 1989-on page 159, for reference-was signed by Don Cameron, member for Moreton, and Shirley Walters, senator for Tasmania. Two very interesting things come out of that article. Firstly, the honourable member for Moreton says:
As a result of complaints to the Commonwealth Ombudsman from many private citizens and the undersigned, the Ombudsman conducted a six-month investigation, which he has now completed.

In his report, he states that there are significant legal problems that he is unable to resolve. He states: `If a definitive answer is required, then it would seem necessary for the matter to be tested in court'.

Let me just go to what the Commonwealth Ombudsman actually said. Let us get the facts right and let us put them on the public record to show that the honourable member for Moreton and Senator Shirley Walters are selectively quoting from the Commonwealth Ombudsman's report. After six months investigation, 15 legal advices, 20 or more written submissions from the honourable member for Moreton, 20 telephone conversations with the honourable member for Moreton, extensive correspondence and discussions with Senator Walters and 2,000 folios on the file of the honourable member for Moreton, the Commonwealth Ombudsman, in paragraph 242 and following paragraphs of his report, concluded:

I accordingly do not consider that the Statistician was wrong to implement the original 1988 HES without tabling it . . . Nor does Senator Walters's complaint provide grounds for concluding that it was unlawful to implement the tabled 1988 HES . . .
At paragraph 243 he went on to say:

I further consider that the HES is not oppressive or unreasonably intrusive, bearing in mind the public interest in collection of the information and the protections for privacy . . . It is desirable, however, that the ABS continue to monitor the operations of its interviewers to ensure that there is no undue assertion of ABS powers or harassment of householders.
I conclude: the harassment is not coming from surveyors going out to get information; it is coming from others. Finally, at paragraph 246, the Ombudsman concluded:
I am satisfied that the Attorney-General's Department properly reviewed its legal advice in the light of other legal opinions and factual information . . .
Furthermore, the ABS did not mislead anyone but might well have sought an independent assessment of differences between HESs at an earlier stage . . .

That is the fact of the matter. It is not as the honourable member for Moreton has suggested in his letters to the editors in the newspapers which chose to run them. It is in no way a reflection of that at all. That is not only grossly misleading but also is stretching the truth to the nth degree and it is doing nothing more than continuing this harassment of the ABS and the census collectors and continuing this malicious vendetta which the honourable member for Moreton and other people in this place seem to want to become involved with.

In conclusion, I say that one has to be aware of what the information is used for. The household expenditure survey, which my colleague the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) who will speak in the debate no doubt will go to, provides information for such dreadful things as measuring the CPI. Oh, shock, horror-we are going to measure the CPI to find out by how much prices have gone up around Australia! Do members opposite suggest that we should not do that? I would hope not. The other information is used not only by the Commonwealth, but also by State agencies. There is therefore some question about whether the legislation proposed by the honourable member for Moreton and his attack have any relevance whatsoever to the States. We cannot bind the States with this legislation. The legislation is a waste of the time of the Parliament. It is nothing but self-promotion. It is spurious legislation that has no place here. The ABS is continuing to do the job for which it was established by members opposite when they were in government. It is a malicious vendetta conducted by honourable members in this place who should know better. I reject outright the contents of the Bill and believe that to continue with it wastes the time of the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have the benefit of the assistance of Mr McLennan and Mr Skinner from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS), who are here today obviously to support the Australian Labor Party people in trying to distract attention from the real intentions of this legislation. I inform the previous speaker, the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), that the letter to which he referred was run in the newspapers and-I want the honourable member to listen to this-its content was approved by the Ombudsman. It was sent to him by Shirley Walters and me and was approved. The Ombudsman advised Mr Castles that this was the case. I notice representatives here from the ABS are asking another Government speaker to come over so they can give him more of their information; it is a battle between the bureaucracy and the people.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to my alleged harassment of ABS collectors, if the worst I have done is send a Mrs Boardman a copy of a report with a `with compliments' slip, they have been spared by comparison with what happens to many of the people who are chosen to do surveys. The only collector I can recall speaking to was a lady who was at one respondent's home and I spoke to her on the respondent's phone and later contacted her about another aspect. It is my recollection-we are talking about eight or 10 months ago-that that is the extent of this so-called harassment. I ask the previous speaker to accept that the ABS itself is trying to whip up a phoney campaign and accuse people of doing the things at which its officers are most professional. All this is said in the context of the ABS having more people on its staff as a proportion of the population than any other country. I am quite happy to have heard that in 1987-88 the ABS conducted some 1,600 surveys, because it shows the extent of its activities and indicates the truth of my reference to its staff ratios.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics Amendment Bill was introduced into the Senate and passed through it without dissent. It was a private member's Bill which had the total support of Australian Labor Party, Independent, Australian Democrat, National Party and Liberal Party senators. The complex voluntary-compulsory nexus surrounding the conduct of Australian Bureau of Statistics surveys is one that in the past 12 months has created differences of opinion between and has caused a great deal of confusion among such people as the Commonwealth Ombudsman, legal advisers, members of parliament, the ABS and a multitude of survey respondents. This argument and confusion stems from the fact that the powers to conduct compulsory surveys emanate from two separate Acts-namely, the Australian Bureau of Statistics Act and the Census and Statistics Act. Under section 6 (3) of the Australian Bureau of Statistics Act, the ABS is provided with the power to conduct new proposals for statistical collections on a compulsory basis if such proposals are tabled in both Houses of Parliament beforehand. Under sections 10 (4) and 11 (2) of the Census and Statistics Act, the Statistician is given the power to direct respondents to fill in forms and answer questions with the threat of the imposition of $100 per day fines if such a direction is not obeyed within fourteen days.

The baffling co-existence of the two Acts has led to suggestions that the Statistician can direct people to provide information under the Census and Statistics Act without having first complied with the relevant section 6 (3) provision in the Australian Bureau of Statistics Act. That is, it is claimed he can simply ignore the legislative need to table a new proposal in both Houses of Parliament if it is to be conducted compulsorily, and rely on his powers of compulsion in the Census and Statistics Act. Conversely, the Statistician can set in place the framework for a compulsory survey, refuse to confirm that it is compulsory, and then compel any unwilling respondents to answer questions under the threat of a $100 per day fine.

Due to the complex interrelationship between these two Acts and the amount of discretion that is placed in the hands of the Australian Statistician, the respondents to Australian Bureau of Statistics surveys are made to endure a highly perplexing, catch 22 type interviewing procedure which has been ingeniously developed by the ABS with the aim of maximising response rates and minimising adverse publicity. Initially, respondents receive a welcome-on-board letter informing them they have been chosen to be part of an ABS survey which will have a multiplicity of important benefits for a wide array of government and non-government organisations. Soon after, they are visited by an interviewer who will entice their willing co-operation in the conduct of the survey and reinforce the claimed benefits to the community that will be derived from the survey results. If the respondent enquires about whether the survey is compulsory, the interviewer will, on the first two occasions that the question is posed, re-emphasise that the ABS is seeking his willing co-operation. At last year's Estimates hearings Assistant Statistician Skinner said-he is here today and can go to Hansard for confirmation of this if he needs to-on the third occasion the question is asked, the respondent will be told that the survey is compulsory. During that evidence it was also admitted that when household expenditure surveys were voluntary, interview instructions were that people had to ask three times before they were told the survey was voluntary. I object most strongly to the past and present approach of people not being told the truth from the very beginning, and a system whereby interviewers are trained to be less than honest when dealing with the people who provide their salaries.

If the respondent still refuses to co-operate, things begin to hot up. He or she or the family is forced to endure more letters seeking willing cooperation, phone calls, visits from more senior interviewers seeking co-operation, letters outlining the enforcement clauses in the Census and Statistics Act and even, in some cases, verbal threats of possible fines from frustrated interviewers. If the respondent still continues to refuse, the ABS may allow a cooling period and then return to see if there has been a change of heart. Alternatively, the ABS may decide to disappear altogether, thus making a mockery of the survey's compulsory nature. Then again, that endless seeking of so-called willing co-operation may continue unabated. One Brisbane family reported to the Commonwealth Ombudsman that it had 18 such visits last year because of its disinclination to be part of the current household expenditure survey (HES). I call that harassment of the worst kind. Alternatively, the Statistician may decide to send a person a letter directing him to do the survey within fourteen days and advising him that he is liable to be prosecuted if he does not comply. If he decides to disobey the direction, the Statistician then makes a decision as to whether he will proceed with prosecution-and it sure does happen.

As a result of the Commonwealth Ombudsman's recent report on the conduct of the HES, I am advised that the ABS has agreed to change its procedures in relation to its interpretation of the compulsory nature or otherwise of the ABS surveys. Whereas previously the ABS admitted that it conducted all of its surveys on a compulsory basis and would eventually tell respondents that a survey was compulsory, it seems it has now decided that it will avoid declaring surveys voluntary or compulsory and will rely on advising respondents of the enforcement powers that are available to the Statistician. This change in policy more accurately reflects the complicated legislative framework the ABS works under. However, I firmly believe that it will result in even greater confusion in the minds of respondents.

There is no doubt that the legislation gives tremendous powers and discretion to the Australian Statistician and the ABS. It is he who decides whether the benefits derived from a survey warrant the invasions of personal privacy that are involved in the collection of the information. It is he who decides whether the information is to be collected from respondents on a voluntary or compulsory basis. It is he who decides what techniques are to be used to collect the information, including whether or not he is to prosecute those who refuse to comply. The collection techniques used in the past by the ABS have certainly been reasonably successful in maximising the response rates to the surveys. However, it is most significant that the ABS now appears to be paying a high price for its reliance on a mixture of enticement, persistence and veiled threats. Its integrity as an honest and up-front statistical gathering organisation is being brought more and more into question both in this place and in the general community.

There are two reasons why this is occurring and in combination these two reasons render it imperative that decisions in regard to the compulsory status or otherwise of ABS surveys be no longer at the sole discretion of the Statistician. They should be made by the people's Parliament which, unlike the Statistician, can more objectively weigh up the need for statistical information against the protection of the privacy and the civil rights of individual Australians. The deterioration of the Bureau's public image has been caused, to a large extent, by its own inconsistent statistical collection techniques. It is necessary to point out that, when one calls a spade a spade, practically all ABS surveys are compulsory. However, in terms of the ABS's collection techniques, its surveys are voluntary if one wants to do them and compulsory if one objects to doing them. If one is willing to put one's bankbook on the line and refuse point blank to comply, one enters a tunnel of darkness and only time will tell the outcome. I contend people are entitled to know where they stand from the first point of contact.

As a member of parliament, I have on several occasions made requests to the ABS that the very elderly, the infirm and genuine conscientious objectors not be required to complete surveys. With one recent exception of a 93 year old widow-I give the ABS marks for this-I have been informed that the ABS could not afford to have its supposedly scientifically-based random selection system put at risk by releasing even one person from the thousands selected. If this is true I can only ponder at the accuracy of the results of the current HES because more than 200 households have so far refused to be part of that survey.

Despite the many statements and threats about the compulsory nature of surveys, the ABS has proceeded to prosecute only 47 non-business survey respondents over the last five years. Far from subscribing to mass prosecution for non-compliance, or suggesting that respondents should attempt to run the gauntlet, this figure shows an incredible degree of inconsistency by the Bureau in terms of enforcing the compulsory nature of its surveys. I again refer to the current HES as a prime example. Despite issuing a myriad of statements about the compulsory nature of this survey in newspapers, in background papers and in letters to parliamentarians, and despite repeated visits and phone calls informing a large number of respondents of the compulsory nature of this survey and the issuing of threats about the danger of their being fined for non-compliance, the ABS has never even attempted to prosecute anyone for failing to do a household survey. By handing to the ABS the total discretion to decide whether a survey should be compulsory or voluntary, and then leaving it to the Statistician to decide whether compulsion should be enforced, the Parliament has allowed gross inconsistencies to proliferate.

Many of the questions now contained in ABS surveys are of a highly personal and intrusive nature. Granted, some people do not care what they are asked, but some do care. It is an outright invasion of an individual's personal privacy to compel him or her to reveal facts about himself or herself to a total stranger; facts which many would not even consider revealing to their closest friends. The ABS has done well in maintaining the confidentiality of the information provided, and I know of only a couple of cases where it has blundered in this respect. Nevertheless, confidentiality is of little consolation when one does not want to divulge personal information. For those compelled to do it, it can be an emotionally traumatic event. Let me take just two of the ABS's current surveys as examples. To complete the HES and the national health survey (NHS) respondents would have to provide an interviewer with detailed information about their current income; their last tax return; their outstanding loans; the value of much of their assets; their expenditure on everything from their weekly donation into their church plate to items of personal toiletries; their bankcard and cheque account statements; their current health status; all their illnesses and disabilities; their recent medical consultations; the extent of their deemed unhealthy habits, such as drinking and smoking; what they eat; their education standard; their trade union membership; and their insurance premiums, just to name a few of the scores of subject areas.

If one is a women aged between 18 and 64 and one is caught up in the NHS, one will be asked to volunteer information on a range of personal questions which include pap smears, breast cancer scans, hysterectomies and contraception habits, including whether one is fitted with intra-uterine devices (IUDs). These surveys are not only highly personal in nature, but particularly in the case of the HES also very burdensome. Of course, I recognise that some statistics are most necessary and that there is a reliance on people to provide the information truly needed in the compilation of these statistics. I also recognise that many ABS surveys are not of a personal nature and do not place any great burden upon respondents. However, despite these beliefs, I am totally convinced that the conducting of all ABS surveys, with the threat of compulsion and fines, unfairly maximises both the burden involved and the intrusions into the private lives of individual respondents.

At present the ABS and the Advisory Council have total discretion in regard to the content, size and frequency of the surveys. Obviously, the ABS endeavours to measure up to what it sees as a need for certain statistics against the extent of personal questioning that will be involved in the collection of those statistics. I cast no aspersions as to the ABS's intentions in relation to the making of such difficult decisions. However it is in many respects blinded by a desire to serve every information seeker and seems to find it hard to say no. An excellent example of this was in May 1988 when the Assistant Statistician-he is here!-stated in the midst of a public controversy that there was no way that questions about sex and condoms would get past his desk in relation to the national health survey which commences in October. Unless the ABS drops the section, as I have already mentioned, it is going to ask women about their contraceptive habits, including whether they are fitted with an IUD. If that is not related to sex, what is?

All this must be seen in the context that the ABS is in the business of collecting and selling statistics in the marketplace and that it is being constantly pressured by a large number of organisations and business houses to increase the number of statistics that it collects. The ABS is competing with a large number of privately-owned statistical gathering organisations which can and do collect information of a comparable quality. It must also be remembered that the ABS is neither held accountable to its respondents nor responsible for representing the many wide-ranging interests of its respondents. For these reasons, I support this Bill to the extent that it provides that the Federal Parliament should have a say in deciding whether ABS surveys, considered on an individual basis, should be conducted compulsorily, voluntarily or not at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is typical of the Opposition. When the Opposition is pressed for its policies on anything it is like poking one's finger in a fog; there is absolutely nothing there. Yet, the time of this Parliament is being taken up with this grubby piece of legislation. The simple fact is that the Opposition does not do the hard work. There is no heart and there is no soul to it. It is all gimmicks. If one wanted an example of that, one would only have to look at the Waste Watch Committee, which is nothing more than cheap populism. The rorts committee fell out of sight: it was launched by the former Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), it met only once and was never seen again. Perhaps the most damaging attacks are those made on the Public Service. We have seen today attacks by the Opposition on information collected by the Statistician. Many members of parliament are contacted by the public. I have been contacted by the public over these surveys. My experience has been that when one explains to the public why these surveys are necessary and what use is made of the information, the public is more than happy to comply.

SPEECH.PARA: In his contribution, the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) said that his letter to the press had been approved by the Ombudsman. What he should have said was this: one paragraph of the letter-not a substantive paragraph-was approved by the Ombudsman. That is the way he misleads, because he has said that the letter has been cleared. The letter has not been cleared; one paragraph only has been cleared and the honourable member for Moreton should be honest enough to admit that. In relation to this alleged harassment of the public, the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) has read out to the House the letter of resignation of the collector acting on behalf of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. That is the sort of harassment that this sort of campaign whips up. As members of parliament we all know that sometimes we get an issue on which we can get a bit of a run and whip up a bit of a story. But this one is most damaging and, what is more, there is nothing in it. It is nothing more than a beat-up, as the honourable member himself concedes. The fact is that everybody complies, and there are figures to show that.

There were 7,500 respondents to the household expenditure survey. There were no notices of direction and no prosecutions. The biggest survey resulted in only 39 prosecutions out of a population of 16 million. Overwhelmingly the people of Australia do comply with the requirements of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. They recognise as we do the importance of the information that is collected. That information goes into making up the consumer price index. The three million pensioners that we have in this country rely on that information to make sure that the pension they get truly reflects the cost of living in Australia. It ill-behoves the Opposition to start this sort of campaign to get a bit of a run in the press. The fact is that that is all it is about. I say to the honourable member for Moreton and to the people who engage in that sort of activity that they would be better placed looking after their constituents if they got onto things that really mattered to them.

People do not call me a great deal on this issue. The office of a member of parliament is a good barometer as to what is going on in the electorate. I am always amazed when Opposition speakers talk about the flood of issues and the phone calls they have had on this issue. The fact is that they are not telling the truth. The honourable member for Moreton may have had more than the average number of calls on this issue because he has made an issue of it himself. He has not done himself a lot of good and he has not reflected well on the Parliament.

The simple fact is that anybody with any objectivity who looks at the way the Australian Bureau of Statistics works would understand that, although it is hard getting people to give the sort of information that the honourable member spoke about, it is essential that we have it. What does he want us to do? Does he want us to have no information at all? Does he want us to make judgments on inaccurate information? A government has to make sure that the money spent out of the public purse goes where it is intended to go; that pensions are set at the right level; that departments of this Government receive adequate resources to service the Australian community. A government cannot do that unless it has accurate information.

I have spoken about the Opposition's harassment of the Australian people in regard to the household expenditure survey. The worst of it is when Opposition members go into emotive terms. We start hearing about the $100 a day fines even though, by the honourable member's own admission, they have never been administered, and most people undertaking the survey would not even know of the fines if the honourable member had not brought it up. But it is always good for a headline. It is a cheap shot. In the West Australian some time ago there was a headline, `$100 a day fine'. The fact is that it has never been implemented, and the honourable member knows it. It is just a cheap shot at the Bureau's expense.

How do members of the Opposition think the people in the Bureau of Statistics feel when they see these attacks by a member of parliament on the work that they are doing-work that is required by this Parliament? The Bureau's annual report is tabled in the Parliament. The honourable member can go through that report and offer some constructive criticisms, but we have not had one constructive criticism from him. If a member of parliament wants to make a mug of himself in this place the press is always around to give him a hand. In the honourable member's case, the press has taken him up on his offer. In the Sydney Morning Herald of 6 September 1988 Milton Cockburn had an article headed `The MP who is last among 224 equals'. I will read this article out mainly because it is a reflection of what the press think of the members of parliament and the sorts of issues in which they involve themselves. Mr Cockburn was asked to list the 10 worst members of parliament. He said:
If I were game to list my 10 dumbest MPs, it would be hard to leave out Don Cameron, the Liberal MP for Moreton in Queensland.
Later on in the article he said:
So inconsequential is he that he even suffers the indignity of not having his own personal file in the Herald's Canberra library.

Mr Cameron's latest contribution to the betterment of public life in this country is to try and stop the Household Expenditure Survey . . . by the Australian Bureau of Statistics because he claims the Statistician has not conformed to the relevant legislation.
Later on in the article, he had this to say:

The dire warnings issued by such information luddites as Mr Cameron and the CCL appear to have been ignored. The ABS reports that the response rate by participants to this house expenditure survey is greater than the last one in conducted in 1984. Perhaps this gives a clue to the reasons why Mr Cameron has never made it to the front bench.
I have probably now reduced my Canberra contacts by one but if this is the standard of contribution which Don Cameron makes to public debate in this country I think I can live with that.

That is an accurate reflection of what the press thinks of the Opposition's campaign. It is a grubby campaign. It is a cheap shot at a government body which has been given the unenviable task of collecting some of the most important and confidential information in this country. It does not like having to do it, but the Opposition's attacks on it make it so much harder. I say to the honourable member: `Wake up to yourself. Get back to Queensland and start looking after your constituents because by taking up issues such as this you are reflecting badly on yourself and you are reflecting badly on the Parliament. It is about time that you got back to looking after your electors'.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I table a copy of the letter from the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) to the Acting Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) relating to the matter that has just been debated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1) agrees that services provided by government and the community for disabled people should be considered a right rather than a privilege; and
(2) calls on all concerned people and governments to explore every option to ensure that disabled Australians and their carers can enjoy this right to the fullest extent possible.

It has been said that life was not meant to be easy. For some, this is truer than for others. Many situations exist which try a person's mettle. Our lifespan is one race in which we do not all start with the same handicap. In the context of human endeavour, of striving to enjoy life, to reach our potential of achievement rather than just to exist, the word `handicap' must be defined. It is that which hinders our reaching our full potential. Yet it effectively hinders only where society, or social infrastructure, does not cater to individual needs. For instance, a motorist's mobility is severely hindered without roads along which to travel. A potentially great musical talent is wasted without an instrument on which to express that talent. The overwhelming majority of Australians expect government and community to provide the physical, educational and social infrastructure to enable them to bring their potential to fruition, as a right. As our society becomes more sophisticated, more is expected. The motorist of 1989 expects not only a road on which to travel, but freeways, bridges and roundabouts to facilitate that travel, while the musician's career is hindered without tuition, promoters, venues and audiences.
Against this background of societal expectation, I wish to speak strongly in support of the motion which I have placed on the Notice Paper. It states:
That this House:
(1) agrees that services provided by government and the community for disabled people should be considered a right rather than a privilege; and
(2) calls on all concerned people and governments to explore every option to ensure that disabled Australians and their carers can enjoy this right to the fullest extent possible.

As the expectations of Australians as a whole have risen in tandem with the facilities and options which society, through government and non-government agencies offers them, so too should the expectations, facilities and options offered to people with a handicap be raised. If this is not occurring to the desired extent, we must look for reasons, and we must do so in a spirit of positive intent and cooperation.

Having recently come in contact with some of the fears, hopes and aspirations of many disabled people, their carers, and providers of facilities for disabled people, I wish today to set these down clearly and sympathetically, as the basis of further consideration of what the future holds for them. In looking to the future I do not in any way diminish the past, for it is the work and the dedication of individuals, churches and community organisations which has provided the necessary basis on which to build extensions to the support structure for disabled people in Australia. However, I am most concerned at the apprehension and the lack of confidence experienced by a number of disabled people and their support groups, about the fear of parents in articulating their concerns and wishes, about the providers' fear of criticism, and about a disabled person's fear of not being listened to and of not being heard by those people in whose hands their life options lie.

Some fears are based on experience and some on perceptions, but all are real to those who hold them. I believe that they must be faced if ever they are to be conquered. I say this not in the sense of those fears being ephemeral and negative emotions which those who experience them must overcome but in the context of the need for all concerned, including governments and heretofore uninvolved sectors of society to find the real basis of the fears and to offer real resources to overcome them. These anxieties-and in the case of mildly to moderately intellectually handicapped people in particular, these frustrations-are being expressed to me by a large and ever growing number of people, who shelter behind what some have called a wall of silence. As I grow in knowledge of the people concerned, the wide spectrum of emotions becomes more clearly defined. This wall must be penetrated, this silence broken.

I have already expressed in this House some of the concerns of these people. They relate to training or lack of training, a desire to enter the open work force, and a perceived lack of appropriate services and facilities in some activity therapy centres (ATCs) and workshops-including some of those provided by a major provider with an excellent record in Queensland. Some of these concerns are being actively considered by the providers and departmental officers. I look to positive outcomes for disabled people and their carers.

I have found that some parents do not wish to speak out about these concerns because their self-confidence is diminished: they do not feel that they have a right to demand special attention for their sons or daughters when money is already being spent on facilities, as well as time and effort on overseeing them. Others expect actual retribution if they make any criticism. They are afraid that they will be marked as troublemakers and stirrers. Too many fear that their sons or daughters will lose the support they had if they speak out or hint that they are not satisfied. Some expect actual removal from a residence, a therapy centre or a workshop. There are parents who feel that to express needs would be disloyal to providers or that it could be seen as evidence of disloyalty. Others feel that if they express dissatisfaction they may offend or be scorned by other parents who are satisfied with the status quo. Some believe that they will lose government funding or lose the public's support for their particular provider if they criticise what they have. They are weighed down by the double burden of the unrelenting responsibility of caring for those they love and of carrying feelings of guilt for being recipients of what they perceive as charity.

I have heard of and from people who have started life full of the highest expectations for their children-people who are full of vigour and determination to mould for them the best outcome possible for their capabilities. I have heard of how that expectation has been diminished, how the vision has grown dim against the reality of struggling to cope without adequate support from society. We cannot allow that to continue to happen. The rights of disabled people, as with the rest of society, incorporate provision of facilities and services, access to these facilities and services, and mobility. This means educating disabled people, training them for a job, ensuring that they are not denied access to a job because of their disability, and providing ongoing support, such as monitoring and counselling, to enable them to retain that job.

This needs the support not only of governments and providers but also of employers. It means provision of particular means of recreation where necessary, ensuring access to generally used recreational options where possible. It means independent living to the greatest extent possible, and provision of support services where that is not possible. For a number of years many of these areas have been serviced in varying degrees by Federal and State governments and non-government organisations. I thank these governments and organisations. However, two specific areas where demand is growing beyond immediate supply are those of independent living and of training for and placement in the open workplace. I will discuss the independent living situation on another occasion.

The issue of training and job placement is a vexed one, causing much heartburn, as mildly and moderately intellectually handicapped people voice their frustrations at the limitations of the sheltered workshop environment. But training and placement in the work force is central to the full development of a disabled person. It has consequential offshoots of greater confidence, and thus greater mobility, through an enhanced motivation to cope with the problems and to experience the pleasures of the mainstream of society. As one disabled person with Down's syndrome explained succinctly when attaining job placement through a transition project, `I would rather work than sit around at home'. Indeed, not only the client of a conventional workshop, or the disabled person spending his or her days at home, but the fulltime carers are also the beneficiaries of such placement.

Many providers of facilities and services for disabled people are moving ahead and grasping the opportunities offered under the Disability Services Act to move into the open workplace, but in some cases there has been a breakdown of communication between providers and Department of Community Services and Health officers, leading to a confrontationist attitude towards the Department of Community Services and Health officers, who are seen as predators rather than as arbiters of change. I understand that there were some problems in the implementation of the new directions espoused by the Act, and indeed that discussions are now taking place to seek resolutions to problem areas. I am not denouncing people who may be caught in a breakdown of communication; I am suggesting that they try again in an effort to take advantage of the assistance and resources available to facilitate the move to a new era while retaining the best of the old. Of course, it would not be possible to suddenly remove holus-bolus clients at workshops or in institutions into independent living environments, particularly where the will is not there, nor the capability.

A significant amount of extra ongoing funding has been made available by the Federal Government to assist organisations with the costs of transition to new service types designed to cater for individual needs and to facilitate the transitional process. In this context, I want to make it clear that I have been assured that the Department of Community Services and Health has absolutely no intention of pulling the rug out from under established providers while they consider the best situation for the purposes of their clients. Some $15m has been made available to assist organisations introducing appropriate new services. That is in addition to the recurrent grants of financial assistance that they already receive. About 11,000 people with disabilities are currently attending Australia's 282 disability services program funded sheltered workshops. The estimated recurrent expenditure for 1988-89 is approximately $35m.

I wish to report that in 1987-88 39 sheltered workshops and 27 activity therapy centres received additional funding to assist with their transition. Thirty sheltered workshops reprofiled their services towards supported employment; nine aimed at competitive employment, training and placement; 24 ATCs received funding for supported employment projects; while three ATCs received funding for competitive employment, training and placement. To the end of December 1988, a further 21 employment related transition proposals had been funded, while 10 sheltered workshops were funded to reprofile towards supported employment or competitive employment, training and placement.

In addition, 11 ATCs received funding to assist them to offer supported employment services. While there is still some timidity or reluctance in some areas, the move to enhanced services for disabled people wishing to have greater independence is really on the way. The lifestyles of a large number of people will be improved by this move as it continues to gain momentum, particularly when one considers the disabilities of clients now attending sheltered workshops. I urge those providers who have not considered the new options under the Disability Services Act transition schemes to look at what is now being achieved for such people by many groups, with the support of the Federal Government. For instance, the Competitive Employment Placement and Support Service (COMEPASS) is achieving some great outcomes at Stones Corner in Brisbane. COMEPASS is the baby of the Uniting Church in Australia, and it aims to enable people with intellectual disabilities to retain work in open, competitive employment. TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Honourable members will note that 56.7 per cent of people in sheltered workshops are currently earning less than $20 a week. The Federal Government, of course, provides these people with a pension. Of at least equal and, perhaps, greater importance than the $140 a week increase in income over and above the pension is the dignity and the increased self-esteem and self-confidence experienced as disabled people have learnt to master new tasks in a work environment. Once it would have been considered impossible. Today, it is one of many possibilities open to those who are willing to give it a try. To do so does not indicate disloyalty to past ways; nor it a criticism of the old. Rather, it is a natural development and a celebration of the new.

SPEECH.PARA: Jobsupport, a Federal Government service established in 1986 to place, train and maintain employees with an intellectual disability in open employment, is another successful program funded under the Disability Services Act. Carolyn Manners, a young woman with Down's syndrome, was one of the early successes of Jobsupport in Sydney. When the program found her a job as a helper at the Summers Hill Children's Community Centre, her ambition to work with children was fulfilled. It took two months' training for Carolyn to master her job involving a series of tasks, and that training was followed by back-up training and consultation once a week. On 7 March 1987, New Idea magazine reported of Carolyn, then 21:

Until recently, her life would have been restricted to her family and the narrow world of sheltered workshops. Now . . . Caroline has taken her place in the workforce, doing a real job and getting paid real wages.
This has boosted Caroline's confidence and self-esteem. She now commutes to work by train every weekday, on her own, just like thousands of others in the workforce.

For some, this option may not work. For those who are motivated and are able to take up this option, it offers great opportunities. There are a large variety of transition programs. It is a matter of designing projects to meet the variety of individual needs. There are, or course, degrees of what can be achieved by disabled people, depending on the extent of their individual handicap.

It is the right of all Australians, regardless of handicap, or all the more because of handicap, to receive the support and resources needed to reach their full potential. Where there are disabled people who wish for more, where there are carers who want greater support, these needs should be met to the greatest extent possible. I do not want to raise expectations needlessly. I do want to raise expectations where people have lost hope, but are amongst those of whom a parent and representative of a support group for disabled people said:
Out of sheer tiredness, you do get to a stage of saying `It's not what I want, but it's better than nothing.'

I have spoken today of a yawning chasm which exists in the moral support offered an important sector of our society. I address my comments to that society, not in incrimination but to open further discussion on the need for changes in attitude and in priorities, and to close this chasm. I do not want parents of disabled people to fear change, to fear that there is no support for their aspirations for sons and daughters. I acknowledge that there must be many people whose needs are met-parents and disabled people who are comfortable with their situation. I am happy about this, but this does not excuse complacence towards the many whose needs are not. I recognise and pay tribute to all the people working in centres or at home for disabled people. Many are unpaid, or lowly paid, and their contribution is invaluable. To the silent partners in this work, the public who assist by donation of money or facilities, I record my thanks. To staff members, and to carers, churches and other organisations, to therapists and psychologists and parents and administrators, I pay tribute. But, above all, to disabled people, I register my admiration. I also say, `It is your right to expect services and facilities from a society which certainly views the provision of educational, recreational and social facilities to extend its participation, as a right.' In Australia, 1989, it is your right too. It is not a privilege.'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not only do I offer my wholehearted support for what the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) has said in this debate, but also I forgive her for taking up 25 per cent of my time. It should be made clear that we are talking about a vast number of people. While it is so very easy to become involved with statistics-and I would like to use a few very shortly-what we in this Parliament must always remember is that we are talking about individual people. As the Minister at the table, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), knows from his portfolio, one can be overwhelmed by the mass of the problem. What it boils down to is that every time we talk about any form of government activity, in reality we are talking about its application to one human being-to one Australian citizen.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of us in the community, unless we have somebody in our own family or among our close friends who is disabled or handicapped, do not appreciate what a disability or handicap is really like. As a small child I spent six months in hospital and 18 months on crutches. I have never spent time in a wheelchair and, quite frankly, I hope I never have to. I wonder how any of us in this chamber would cope if we had to spend a period of days, months or years in a wheelchair. It is not a prospect to which any of us would look forward. Therefore, I commend the honourable member for Lilley for bringing this issue forward because it is most important that all Australians should be made aware of the needs, difficulties and very great problems encountered by people suffering from disabilities and handicaps.

It might be useful to define a disabled person. It is a fairly cold way of doing it, but a disabled person is somebody with one or more of a number of selected impairments and disabilities which have lasted, or will last, for more than six months. A handicapped person is a disabled person who is limited in ability to perform simple tasks. There are five areas in which both groups are at a disadvantage compared with the ordinary, mobile, able Australian. They are the lack of self-care in that most need able-bodied assistance from carers at one level or another; a lack of mobility; a low or sometimes complete lack of verbal communication skills; opportunities for schooling and education which vary considerably and are diminished to an incredibly large extent for many of these people; and, of course, employment prospects which are incredibly low. Yet, as citizens-as human beings-who need to enjoy the feeling of pride and self-esteem, to be able to achieve, to have self-confidence and, above all, some dignity in their lives, it is most important that we, as a community or society, are caring and compassionate.

According to a 1988 survey 2,543,000 people in Australia are disabled. That is 15.6 per cent of the population. That figure includes people over the age of 75. Regardless of those, 15.6 per cent of Australians are disabled. That will probably come as a great shock to most Australians. Of this number, 2,124,100-or 13 per cent of the Australian population-are handicapped. When I first saw these figures I was completely surprised because I had no idea that there were so many people suffering in this way.

Four per cent of people, or 650,000, have a severe handicap and need full time help from another person. Another 3.4 per cent, or 550,000 people, have a moderate handicap and require selected assistance from another person. That necessitates a totally different consideration of the problem. We have to be totally aware of the situation of people who care for people with disabilities and handicaps. In Australia, 92.4 per cent of handicapped people live in households. Of those, 26.5 per cent suffer from a severe handicap. When we look at the way this affects families it is very important that it has our full consideration and awareness. At present 7.6 per cent of the handicapped population live in health establishments: hospitals, institutions for the handicapped, and nursing homes. Of those people, 85 per cent have a severe handicap.

Between 1981 and 1988 the number of disabled people increased by 600,800. This places an enormous strain on our society. Again and again we have to cast our minds to the situation of the carers because the responsibility for providing help with at least one activity, whether it be home maintenance, health care, meals, moving about or transport, falls fairly and squarely on the shoulders of the spouse, the partner, the mother or some other member of the disabled person's family. It is a tremendous responsibility. In many cases it involves seven days a week, 24 hours a day. One of the things said by people is that it is a matter of being seen and not heard. Because of the lack of mobility among many disabled people they are not able to get out and about in the community and, as a result, most able bodied people forget they exist. That is true. We should be more aware.

Disabled people need more access to facilities which will allow them to participate in the community. About 60 per cent of disabled people need help with transport, which includes access to wheelchairs and vehicles. Let me reiterate that we need the facilities for disabled people to participate in the community. That comes back to what I spoke about at the beginning of my speech: pride, self-esteem, confidence, a sense of achievement and a sense of dignity. Every human being should enjoy these as a right. I am sure there is no debate on the fact that an out of sight, out of mind mentality has existed in the community. That is why it is so important that we take every opportunity to discuss this issue. Indeed, this debate, sponsored by the honourable member for Lilley, might prompt not only those people who will read the Hansard but also those who are listening to the debate to stop and think about people who are not as well off as they are.

In terms of access, many developers are now taking disabled people into account in designing and planning public areas, such as shopping centres and malls. But much more still needs to be done. There needs to be a much greater awareness of the need for ramps besides steps and elevators in steep areas, particularly in business districts. Disabled people have the same need as other people for contact and communication with insurance companies, real estate agents and any other activity within our society. Further emphasis must be put on that area.

As I mentioned before, education and employment opportunities are very few. Special consideration needs to be given to that. I again refer to home carers. No-one who is not in that situation would know what those people go through. Respite must be provided for carers. We recognise that this need exists for the community of elderly Australians and some progress is being made in that area. But it needs to be extended. The need for respite for carers of disabled and handicapped people is equally as important.

Neither I nor the honourable member for Lilley have introduced politics into this debate. As a member of the Opposition, I can say that members of the Liberal and National parties agree with what I am about to say. I am sure that the honourable member for Lilley would agree as well. We acknowledge that disability does not lessen the right or desire of people to participate in society and to enjoy its opportunities. We agree that people, whatever their handicap or disability, should have the right-not the privilege; let me be quite certain that I am using the words of the motion-to participate in society and to enjoy its opportunities. We are concerned that people with disabilities are often troubled by isolation. They are isolated from society. They are frequently isolated by programs designed to help them, not by any desire on the part of those people operating and involved in the programs but merely because of the institutional overtones attached to them. We need to give a great deal more consideration to removing the isolation suffered by disabled people. Disabled and handicapped people must have greater access to society-more effective integration with the community. There needs to be flexibility in the way this is achieved to allow the views of the individual and his or her family and care providers to be considered. There needs to be adequate consultation and full communication. It is not a question of care being provided or imposed from above by government alone. There needs to be full communication throughout the whole of our society.

The policies of government and political parties should assist people with disabilities to achieve their full potential and exercise maximum control and independence over their lives, to ameliorate the effects of disability and to provide continuing support to help manage the pressures and stresses of daily living. I suggest that those of us who are not in a bed or a wheelchair for 24 hours a day do not really know what those stresses and strains are. I salute, as did the honourable member for Lilley, those people who are struggling and striving-and living and doing well-and the people and the organisations which help them. They are very brave people with a great deal of courage and they deserve all the consideration this Parliament can give them. Disabled and handicapped people need independence and security. Every Australian has a right to be independent and to enjoy some security.

Independence and security are fundamental and are important not only to disabled people but to everybody. It is important to have a place in which to live. We take that for granted but often it is not available to people. It is important that disabled people have access to paid employment. We have vast numbers of unemployed people. I do not know the percentage of unemployed among disabled people, but we can bet our bottom dollars that that percentage is far worse than it is for able people.

The disabled and handicapped need to be able to feel confident and self-reliant and to participate in community activities at various levels. We need the infrastructure to enable them to do that. They need to feel secure in their lives, and most importantly, to have choices and options. I suppose that I have mentioned people in wheelchairs because they are the most visible people. However, people with all sorts of disabilities are prevented from participating fully in the choices and options that we take for granted. If we are stuck, our options are limited and our choices are almost nil. If we as a parliament can do no more than to provide more choices and more options for people suffering from handicaps and disabilities, we could do much worse. If we can give these people, through whatever action we can take, a positive self-image, we can feel we have achieved something for our fellow Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Fishing Industry-Democratic Attitudes-AIDS: Education Program-Election Funding-Investment in Private Companies-Housing-Intellectually and Physically Handicapped Children-Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My contribution to this debate today stems, at least in part, from my particular interest in one of Australia's most popular institutions-fish and chips. My first introduction to the epicurean adventure that awaits the fish and chip devotee was as a boy in Footscray-when sixpence worth of fish and chips was a well-established after school ritual.

SPEECH.PARA: I digress here for just a moment to record my unbiased opinion-as an experienced, long term consumer-that newspaper is a better presentation medium for this simple but exquisite food combination than little cardboard boxes, or even fine china. The newspaper packet, which some years ago unfortunately fell into disrepute as a fish and chip container, had many advantages including its recycled nature, its portability, the delicious uncertainty of never quite knowing when the treat was going to end and the fact that the meal stayed hot right to the last tasty morsel-and when you were finished, you had something to read.

Over the years, I have taken advantage of every opportunity to indulge my predilection for the fruits of our Australian aquicultural industry and have developed my knowledge of, and appreciation for, fish and chips to a point where I believe I can claim the status of `connoisseur'. I have sampled numerous up-market versions and varieties, far removed, in price if not in flavour, from the flake, couta and flathead of my youth. At this point I would like to compliment the staff of the parliamentary dining room, who serve a very crisp chip and moist fillet.

One of the newest names appearing with increasing regularity on the menu-and to which I unashamedly admit a current addiction-is orange roughy. In regard to this superb fish, it is appropriate to recall the words of Shakespeare about roses by any names smelling just as sweet. I am reliably informed by my local fishmonger that orange roughy is marketed under other names, and considerable cost savings may be achieved-at least in Victoria-if one asks for the rather less romantic sounding sea perch. The fact is, however, that one may not be able to ask for orange roughy-by any name-for very much longer. And this brings me to the extremely serious aspect of this whole matter.

Despite the fact that Australia is surrounded by water, our relatively slender fishing resources are most vulnerable and under constant, and in many cases increasing, threat. The present gravity and future implications of the overfished, under-researched situation confronting our billion dollar fishing industry were brought home to me recently in an article by Julian Cribb which was published in the Australian of 16 May. This article, entitled `The fishing harvest for which there may be no tomorrow-the deep sea disaster on our doorstep', makes sobering reading. It concentrates on the uncertain fate of the orange roughy, whilst at the same time highlighting other disasters, or near disasters, which have resulted from over exploitation of a resource of unknown magnitude.

Although I represent a landlocked electorate, and therefore do not have the same direct interest in the commercial fishing industry as do those with watery boundaries, as one who is concerned about environment and conservation issues as well as being a fanatical end product consumer, I was prompted by Mr Cribb's article to find out more about the Australian fishing industry. The news is not good. Poor fishery management techniques, irresponsible industry and government practices and attitudes, insufficient data on existing resources and breeding patterns, and inadequate funding for and encouragement of vital scientific research have all contributed to marine stocks decimated by overfishing.

Over recent years we have witnessed last-minute salvage attempts to protect the rapidly dwindling stocks of southern bluefin tuna, shark, abalone, prawns, rock lobsters, scallops, ocean leather jackets and gemfish-to name just some of the more obvious examples. Orange roughy has now been added to the list. Julian Cribb described the orange roughy's plight in the following words:

A creature once unknown to the Australian dinner table has become, almost overnight, one of the nation's most prized marine delicacies. But the roughy is in many cases older than the humans who feast on its flesh. Scientists now believe individual roughies may live for 50 and 75 years, breeding only rarely in the slow, stable rhythm of the deep-sea world.

More and more they fear that the rich hauls of orange roughy taken from `hot spots' may be a harvest without a tomorrow. If the breeding stocks are ravaged beyond repair, as in so many of Australia's fisheries, the ruffe may vanish as quickly as it came.

Julian Cribb provides some alarming statistics to illustrate the reasons for his concern. These include the fact that the catch rate of southern sharks has fallen by half since 1982, and that fishery now comes within the seriously imperilled category. The abalone harvest has dropped by 40 per cent over five years. The Tasmanian shark fishery is virtually gone. There are fears about the survival of the gemfish fishery off New South Wales, hauls of tiger flathead are down, concern is mounting about future stocks of redfish and ling, and the northern barramundi fisheries remain under heavy pressure. Cribb uses the jack mackerel to further emphasise the point he is making. He writes:

Jack mackerel, a virgin fishery five years ago, exploded into prominence as the nation's biggest commercial species, with 40,000 tonnes taken in 1987-before the fish literally disappeared and catches crashed to zero.
Why the jack mackerel vanished illustrates the fundamental flaw in Australian fisheries management today: the knowledge to forestall disaster simply does not exist.
The fish may have gone because of huge fishing pressures, because of a change in the cycle of their food chain, or because of a combination of both. Nobody knows.

What we do know, however, is that in most cases the damage to our commercial fisheries will take a long time to repair. For some species, and/or in some locations, the damage may even be irreparable. Only in two cases-the Western Australian rock lobster fishery and the northern prawn fishery-can it be confidently claimed that the threat to their commercial survival has been contained. International experts who have reviewed all the available evidence on bluefin tuna have come to the conclusion that the only safe catch is zero.

According to Dr Peter Young, a senior research scientist with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) fisheries division in Hobart, the commercial scallop fishery in south-eastern Australia is to all intents and purposes wiped out. Dr Young says the exploitation of scallops has been so severe that, even with a total halt to scallop dredging in Bass Strait, it will take years before any recovery could occur. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics estimates it will be 15 years before abalone numbers return to safe levels; and Perry Smith, of the ABARE fisheries research section, believes the problems which led to restrictions on gemfish and orange roughy catches are also long term in character. He says:

The rapid increase in fishing capacity in the south-east trawl fishery, resulting from industry expectations of a more substantial sustainable yield than has so far been justified, is likely to remain a major long-term problem with fish stocks put under greater fishing pressure.

One of the problems for those involved in fisheries research is the fact they are dealing with an imprecise science.
