Dr Robert Kearney, Director of the New South Wales Fisheries Research Institute argues that problems of working in an environment such as the sea, where one cannot even see the animals one is studying, are exacerbated by insufficient and often inaccurate industry provided data. He says:
It is unreasonable to expect a physician to make a diagnosis when he is not allowed to examine the patient, is not told the truth, or worse still, is given misleading information.
Why should managers-
he is referring to fisheries managers-
expect more of fisheries scientists?
Dr Peter Young emphasises another aspect of the challenges facing those involved in fisheries research in Australia:
The difference between us and America is that in the US they have a dozen scientists studying a single species. In Australia, we have one scientist studying a dozen species.
As Julian Cribb points out:

Fisheries scientists are themselves an endangered stock. The CSIRO Division of Fisheries has been forced to cut its staff by 29-nearly a third-in recent years. Its appropriation funds have been cut by 25 per cent.

In the fishing industry the odds are heavily in favour of the hunter rather than the prey. Modern fishing technology, the understandable and reasonable desire of fishermen to receive an adequate return on their considerable investments and ongoing costs, and the lack of adequate and appropriate resources to ensure the required scientific data is readily available to assist in the proper management of our marine resources all combine to pose significant problems for the Australian fishing industry. The concept of shutting the stable door after the horse has bolted or, more accurately in this instance, hauling in the net after the fillet has been battered, has never been regarded as an appropriate or acceptable management technique. And yet it seems we are all too frequently tackling the problems confronting our fishing industry by reacting after the event. Time after time we wait until the point of no return has been reached, or almost reached, before any action is taken to stop the unrestrained plunder of our commercial fishing grounds.

On behalf of those who enjoy their fish and chips, as well as the fishermen, managers and scientists, not to mention the fish themselves, is it not time we took another look and adopted a new approach to the management of our significant and endangered fishing industry?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the Minister at the table while I am speaking is the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), who I consider to be one of the more intelligent and very much less fanatical members of the so-called Left in the Australian Labor Party. As I approach the end of my political life as a member of the House of Representatives I want to use a couple of occasions to state or re-state my views on important issues. I say re-state because, remarkably enough, on re-reading my maiden speech given on 10 March 1970, I found a number of points I made then which I still consider extremely important. I shall quote three extracts from my speech. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: I arrived in this country in my early teens from fascist Italy, at a time when Hitler was about to spread an even more totalitarian regime over nearly the whole of Europe.

Fascism in all its successful aggressive forms was defeated, but freedom is far from secure. There are obviously a number of reasons for this. One is the threat of another expansionist totalitarianism claimed to be Socialist or Communist by its supporters and some of its opponents. I would, of course, deny that it is anything but a complete perversion of these ideologies. As a reaction to this clear threat there has been, in many of the democracies, an excessive over-reaction. I bracket these so-called Communist and anti-Communist threats to our freedom together, as they have much in common and share the same lack of faith in human beings making a correct decision when given all the facts.
Later in my speech I said:
. . . I would suggest that they use-
that is, the Government-

the method of a not excessively democratic organisation-the Roman Catholic Church during the last few centuries-and employ a devil's advocate. I would be happy to offer my services in such a capacity . . .

I think I have done that for the last 19 or 20 years. Those who have seen me act in Caucus would certainly agree on that. I was speaking then at the height of the Vietnam War. I went on to refer then to radicals and the new left:
One of my great disappointments is that many of them are unable to see that today-
that is, back in 1970-

this country, and for that matter even more so the United States, are to the `left' of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and of China as of today. Anti-authoritarianism, the right to dissent, the possibility of being able to change the governments, the general level of civil liberty are the issues which should be the main internal concern of the `left'.

Whilst it is easy to understand their fierce opposition to this government's war in Vietnam it is depressing that so many of them are prepared to argue that the North Vietnamese regime represents any of the values they hold dear in this country.
I will not go any further in quoting from my speech because otherwise I will not be able to say what I meant to say today.

I have now been here for nearly 20 years. I have been political for about 55 years-undoubtedly longer than most in this chamber. I do not want to go into details, but my first political memories are from the age of 10. What is more, I have been at least superficially consistent in that I have always supported what are loosely called social democratic attitudes. I have always supported the quickest amelioration of the condition of those in most need consistent with an overwhelming opposition to totalitarianism-whether of the so-called Left or Right, which are usually undistinguishable. Having come from Italy and watched events in Germany, I was aware that Mussolini had been a prominent socialist and that Hitler's party was the National Socialist German Workers Party, the NSDAP. Both of them claimed to appeal to youth. The fascist anthem was called Giovinezza. I wonder how many honourable members have seen the film Cabaret which features the German Nazi song, The future belongs to us. I make this point because especially during the Vietnam war and since we have had similar appeals to youth. During the Vietnam conflict there were appeals-especially at universities in democratic countries-to support peace and the North Vietnamese against the `old' democratic values. The so-called Left became extremely totalitarian, trying to prevent-and often succeeding in preventing-rational discussion of the very complicated issues. These people often behaved like the worst fascist rabble-rousers. My main argument with them was obviously not that they claimed to support peace, but that those in the leadership, at least, were active stooges for the North Vietnamese and Soviet Union and in due course held victory celebrations for the Vietnamese and Pol Pot. These people, who in many cases consciously supported Soviet foreign policy and pretended to be for peace, are the people who gave us Stalin, Pol Pot, the Ayatollah and many of similar ilk. In each case they supported these allegedly `democratic, gentle, peace-loving people'.

Even when I was very young I was intelligent enough not to approve of the Hitler-Stalin pact. Of course I was surprised, but in retrospect I should not have been. Even though, broadly speaking, I was a Left activist, I was never a member of the Communist Party. The Hitler-Stalin pact, the Moscow trials, reading James Burnham's The Managerial Revolution and especially Arthur Koestler's Darkness at Noon-the best political novel ever written in the way it explains the Moscow trials-all made me strongly anti-Stalinist. Professor John Anderson's free thought movement encouraged my spirit of critical inquiry and later Professor Partridge introduced me and later converted me to an acceptance of pluralism. Yet it is undoubtedly true that those interested in politics but not actually in the Sydney University Labour Club considered me an obvious card-carrying Communist Party member. Yet I believed in socialism for a fairly long time, not for economic reasons but because I believed that capitalism was the only cause of imperialism and war.

Since then, of course, we have seen many wars or new wars between self-proclaimed socialist states, beginning with the confrontation between the Soviet Union and Tito's Yugoslavia. Then there was the Soviet invasion of Hungary and Czechoslovakia and lately the Vietnamese invasion of Cambodia and the China-Vietnam conflict. It is interesting to note that since 1918 there has been no war between democratic states and those who are opposed to war-and I assume that includes all of us-would do best to support the democratisation of all countries instead of attacking the United States of America and other democratic countries. The depressing aspect of many so-called left wingers is their belief in conspiracies and secret controllers of society-the Central Intelligence Agency, Wall Street, the military-industrial complex, the zionists, Murdoch, Packer and so on. According to them people are regularly polluting, poisoning, pillaging, corrupting and carcinogenating. With all that it was a wonder that listeners to PM and Late Night Live and readers of the late National Times could get any sleep at all.

The important point I am trying to make is the overlap of the extreme Right and so-called extreme Left as illustrated by their behaviour. Patrick White, the rather simplistic aristocrat adopted by the Left-I do not know whether he considers himself part of the Left-speaking at Monash University last year, supported a proposition put forward by Peter Sawyer and others of the lunatic Right. He said:

Under the cloak of Telecom we have what is ostensibly a telephone exchange at the Deakin Centre in Canberra but which is in fact a surveillance headquarters invading the nation's privacy on an unimaginable scale.

This is of course a hoary myth, spread and possibly even believed by what I call the lunatic Right, including Peter Sawyer, Brian Wilshire of 2GB night time radio, and such groups as the Citizens Electoral Councils and the League of Rights. The so-called and wrongly described Left joins with the Right in believing in such quick fixes. I emphasise that in the case of the members of the so-called Left, very few, if any, Federal parliamentarians share their simplistic economic views, though some of them may still accept the proposition that Nicaragua is a democracy or that the Philippines run by the New People's Army would be an improvement on the current position.

Last evening in Canberra allegedly some 1,000 people agreed with Katharine West and other similar economic gurus-and I am not suggesting for one minute they are members of the Left-that the way to reduce the cost of money reduce interest rates-is to withdraw money currently on deposit with the lenders. I have concentrated on the so-called Left and I keep on emphasising `so-called' because it has much more influence in the media and therefore gets much more publicity than the Right. But the Right's attack on the fluoridation of water and the Left's on the irradiation of foodstuffs have much in common. They are ridiculous scare tactics by people, usually without any scientific training, who have an apocalyptic view of the world. God or earthly conspirators will destroy us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, I want to reflect critically on the Government's acquired immune deficiency syndrome policy and on its AIDS education program, in particular. There were media reports last month of an AIDS survey of university students in Sydney. The survey revealed that approximately 90 per cent of the students had absorbed the technical information about AIDS and the Government sponsored approach to the problem, `Safe Sex', based on condom use. The survey also revealed, however-and this is the crucial point-that only about one-quarter to one-third of the students actually made decisions-that is, practised safe sex-based on that information.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1987 I drew the attention of the House to research in the United States on adolescent sexual behaviour and pregnancy. That research showed that teenagers are handicapped in assessing the personal risks of their sexual behaviour because of cognitive immaturity. It argued that many teenagers are incapable of thinking abstractly and of relating actions to specific consequences. They cannot make the right decisions in terms of contraception specifically, or sexual relations generally.

The reason that the Government's education programs are inadequate to the threat that AIDS poses is that they focus on technical information and pull their punches in the area of morality. AIDS is essentially a question of the breakdown of authority in morals amongst our young people and, secondly, the moral immaturity and nihilism of many adults and policy makers. In my own submission on the AIDS Green Paper, I argued for an amendment of two of its basic principles along the following lines: Principle 2a-essential to our understanding of the nature of the epidemic is our acceptance that it is primarily a spiritual and moral problem; it is fundamentally a matter of the sense of self, of right and wrong and of personal and social responsibilities being affirmed and nurtured in our society. Principle 5b-the primary objective of education and prevention strategies and programs should be the affirmation and promotion of abstention from sexual activity outside marriage.

Let me stress again, the Government's education programs are not working because they duck the central dilemma-a collapse of moral clarity and authority in our community. They assume promiscuity; they assume individual maturity and responsibility; they take the coward's course of hiding behind a moral-neutral policy approach. Let me give an example: in the Green Paper there is the apparently harmless statement that adolescence is a time of sexual experimentation. The reality, of course, is that the extent of sexual experimentation among adolescents is not a `given'-it varies culturally. The question to be addressed is the nurturing of a cultural value disposition which would minimise sexual experimentation and activity amongst adolescents.

The Government's education programs endorse moral relativism and assume promiscuity. In so doing, they legitimise both. They give our young people, and indeed adults, false confidence. In the Green Paper the Government sets as an objective abstention from drug use, but not abstention from sex outside of marriage. The inconsistency here, and when compared with public crusades against smoking, is quite obvious. We do not tell young people to use drugs in moderation; we simply say, `Do not even try them'. We do not say, `Smoke in moderation'; we actively stigmatise smoking altogether and ban it in many instances. It should be the same with homosexuality and with sex outside a faithful marriage, especially in view of the current AIDS crisis. Let us be morally responsible. Let us state the fact bluntly. Let us tell young people that if they fool around it is very likely they will die a lonely and miserable death. They should be warned that through the self-abuse of drugs and sexual irresponsibility they can break a trust with the community, forfeit certain rights and expect certain social sanctions. This is what should also be put bluntly to adult heterosexuals or homosexuals who, in the context of the AIDS crisis, are acting like children.

I have been concentrating on education. I want to now focus on the broader weakness in the set of principles mooted by the Government for AIDS policy in general. On the questions of the rights of the community and of non-infected people and the social obligations of infected individuals, we need a stronger statement-one which shifts the balance back to the common interest. We have all heard this week of inaction in Perth on deliberately irresponsible sexual behaviour by a number of known AIDS carriers.

I suggest the following restatement of principles: First, each person must accept responsibility for preventing himself or herself becoming infected through sexual intercourse, or through sharing of needles, or for preventing further transmission of the virus. Secondly, an individual with an infectious disease has certain social responsibilities and obligations which may, in certain circumstances, be enforceable. Thirdly, the Australian community has the right to access to appropriate protection against infection. On the subject of an infected person's rights and privacy and on testing, I would state, firstly, a very basic principle: No individual has a right to do a wrong; privacy cannot be morally or therefore legally justified in the name of a freedom to do things which harm others or put them at risk. There are a number of consequent principles for policy.

On the question of testing, I think the jury is still out on the feasibility or utility of compulsory universal testing. The basic principle on testing must, however, be strengthened. I would suggest as follows: specific informed consent should be obtained before any test is performed to diagnose a person's AIDS status, except in those circumstances where an individual's behaviour, circumstances or past suggest an overriding public right to know. Under this principle, testing would be mandatory for groups such as prostitutes, drug users, people involved in accidents or public incidents involving blood loss and people entering prison.

A philosopher has described values as personal preferences so central to our collective lives that as a political community we cannot properly be neutral about them. This Government wants to be neutral about AIDS, just as it has been about excessive violence and pornography in videos, on television and in magazines. It is not an exaggeration to say that this Government's value neutrality on AIDS will cost hundreds of lives. I challenge it and State governments to restore the role of government, parliament and the law to that of affirming and nurturing the values which sustain social life and human relations. They are the traditional values embodied in the Judaeo-Christian ethic.

One clear test in this regard would be to emphasise abstention from sex outside marriage and to stigmatise homosexuality in education material. One clear political test would be to come out publicly against the annual gay Mardi gras, for example. The portents for our society because of the AIDS epidemic are grave and frightening. The emotional and social costs of this epidemic will be catastrophic. Yet we have the counterproductive `let's party for tomorrow we die' mentality of the annual gay Mardi gras. We cannot continue to accept an annual celebration of anal intercourse, `gay' misogamy, lesbian misandry and sexual promiscuity which is what the Mardi gras is about. We certainly cannot tolerate such events when they include effigies of those in the community who take a principled stand on AIDS. I refer to the disgraceful portrayal of the Reverend Fred Nile's head on a platter in this year's Mardi gras. I believe that the Mardi gras must be banned. AIDS policy must be based on clear moral principles, based on traditional values and the common interests. My call today to my colleagues is for parliament to begin to champion that common interest, those traditional values and those policy principles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government of Queensland and the Queensland Premier are not renowned for their support of electoral justice or good practice when it comes to electoral matters. However, in late April of this year, the Queensland Premier decided to make certain allegations against myself and the Australian Labor Party (ALP) in relation to the conduct of the 1987 Federal election in the seat of Fisher. Those allegations were, in substance, that I was improperly elected because of the practice of multiple voting or cemetery voting, which occurred to an extent which would have materially affected the result. These allegations are baseless and without a grain of truth. However, for the record I would like to answer them.

SPEECH.PARA: The first allegation concerns that of multiple voting. The report prepared by the Australian Electoral Commission on this question reveals that there were 200 apparent instances of multiple voting-that is, dual voting-in the electorate of Fisher at the last Federal election. Of these 200, some 188 were found to be mistakes by poll clerks-that is, the polling clerk ruling off the wrong name when someone came to claim the vote. A further 11 cases were investigated, but there was no conclusive evidence of any electoral fraud. In one case, and in one case alone, the matter was referred to the Australian Federal Police for consideration. To get some perspective on whether this figure of 200 is an inordinately large number and peculiar to the electorate of Fisher, it is interesting to note some of the figures in surrounding seats and throughout Australia. For instance, in the seat of Maranoa, held by the National Party of Australia, there were 222 instances; in Groom, 166 instances; in Fairfax, 175; in Kennedy, 220; and in the Liberal-held seat of Moreton, which is very marginal, 225. In the seat of Richmond, held by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Blunt), there were 200 cases-exactly the same number as in Fisher. In the seat of the former Leader of the Opposition, Bennelong, there were some 260 cases-that is 60 more than occurred in Fisher. In the seat of the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) there were 205 cases; and in the Kooyong seat of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), some 259 cases.

I suggest that if the Queensland Premier believes that the reporting of 200 apparent cases in Fisher by the Australian Electoral Commission warrants an allegation of electoral fraud against me, he might like to level the same allegation against the Leader of the National Party, the Leader of the Liberal Party, and some of his National Party colleagues in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he raise that matter?
—Certainly he did not raise it and it was just a cheap, grubby little stunt.

SPEECH.PARA: The other little furphy the Queensland Government came out with was the idea of cemetery voting-that is, people voting in place of those who had died but whose names at that stage had not been removed from the electoral roll. Unknown to me at the time, that was apparently referred to the Queensland division of the Australian Electoral Commission by Senator Stone shortly after the Federal election. I was not aware of this, but a full investigation of the allegations was made and not one solitary case was found. The Queensland Electoral Commissioner, Dr David Muffitt, reported that not one case was found. It was also alleged that some 50 names had been submitted to the Electoral Commission of people who were thought to be `phantom enrolments'. Those 50 cases were investigated individually and, again, not one case of fraud was found.

In the lead-up to the Merthyr by-election, where it suffered a huge rebuff, the National Party in Queensland under the leadership of Mr Ahern, who is known as a weak and indecisive man, tried to throw some mud at the ALP and myself. That is what it was all about. Since the National Party, and Mr Ahern in particular, are now taking some sort of interest in matters electoral, may I suggest there are a few other things a bit closer home that they may want to canvass.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about Broadsound.

—I will not go into the gerrymander, but I will mention Broadsound in a minute for the benefit of the honourable member for Hinkler. Let us not talk about the gerrymander. Everyone accepts that Queensland has the most corrupt electoral system in the Western world, but let us forget about that. Let us also forget about the comments of Mr Don Lane when he went to the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct and quite freely admitted that the Queensland Electoral boundaries were rorted. Let us also forget about his practice of falsely enrolling Jack Herbert's son in his seat of Merthyr. Let us forget about all those things-they are well known. Let us talk about the compliance of the Queensland National Party with the disclosure provisions under the Commonwealth Electoral Act.

SPEECH.PARA: For instance, I received information in the lead up to the 1984 Federal election that the National Party received a sum of some $300,000 from a company called National Free Enterprise Ltd. That much was disclosed in the National Party's return for that election. However, what was not disclosed in that return and what a search of the Corporate Affairs Office in Brisbane revealed, was that National Free Enterprise Ltd was incorporated on 27 September 1984. The $300,000 donation by the company was made to the National Party some eight days later, on 5 October 1984. Now this company has a paid up capital of $2 and no apparent assets. The only reasonable inference anyone can draw from that is that this company was used for the purpose of laundering money into the Queensland National Party so that the disclosure provisions under the Commonwealth Electoral Act could be avoided. That was typical of the National Party and in a way this was a forerunner to the events of the 1987 Federal election when we had the creation of the company Kaldeal Pty Ltd, which was formed under the directorship of Sir Edward Lyons and a few other knights of the realm in Queensland for the purposes of bank rolling the abortive `Joh for Canberra' campaign. The `Joh for Canberra' campaign really never got off the ground and the funds paid into Kaldeal Pty Ltd were not actually spent in that election. Under the third party provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act which now exist, the funds paid to Kaldeal Pty Ltd will not have to be disclosed if they are spent by the Queensland National Party in the 1990 Federal election. Therefore, the National Party can again avoid the financial disclosure provisions under the Commonwealth Electoral Act by having donations made to this third party company and the third party company making donations directly to the National Party. In that way the actual disclosure provisions are avoided.

That is very interesting and it is even more interesting when one compares the sum total of the expenditure by the National Party in the last Federal election in Queensland with its admitted donations-that is, those donations and gifts which it has declared on its return. These figures, which are available from the Australian Electoral Commission, show that the Queensland National Party declared some $337,000 by way of donations and gifts in the 1987 election campaign. Yet it spent $1,904,000-nine times the amount it received. Now let us get that into some sort of perspective. In its return the ALP showed that it received some $434,000 in donations and spent $483,000. The Queensland Liberal Party admitted to receiving $326,000 worth of donations and spending some $348,000. That means that obviously during election campaigns all political parties spend money from sources other than donations received in the lead up. But the National Party spent nine times the amount of its disclosed receipts. That followed the events of 1984 when a bogus company was formed with no paid up capital and no assets and which, just eight days after it was formed, paid $300,000 to the National Party. When those events, together with the role of Kaldeal Pty Ltd in the `Joh for Canberra' campaign, are considered, they all point to the fact that the National Party is trying to avoid these electoral requirements. If Mr Ahern is serious about electoral matters he should not go around mudslinging and throwing wild accusations at Labor members. Instead, he should clean up his own act and he can start with his Party's compliance with the provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Then he might even condescend to start looking at his own electoral boundaries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch), who has been complaining so loudly, I must point out that he has some facts wrong. First of all, the Premier of Queensland, Mr Ahern, has nothing to do with the Federal elections, and at that time he would not have done that. Secondly, I am getting complaints from around the place-and particularly from the honourable member's area-about the excessive phone bill that must be mounting up as he rings all his constituents to try to find out, on the basis of a survey from somebody else, how they feel about the way things are running. I think that a close look at his telephone bills would confirm that this is happening.

SPEECH.PARA: Today in this grievance debate, I wish to refer to the spate of liquidations and company collapses around Australia that are, unfortunately, becoming more and more prevalent, and in which the real losers are the small investors of Australia. These are family people, frugal people who are trying to save for future needs. Australia needs more savers and in being able to put money aside, these people are providing benefits. About November of last year we had the spectacle of Rothwells Ltd, which is a Queensland registered company trading out of Perth and supported by a major bank, the Western Australian Government, through Western Australia Inc, and many big business investors, going into liquidation, despite major efforts to save it. On that occasion quite a few depositors, who had been assured of security of the investment by the company and financial advisers, had invested some $32m in the company. More than $5m of that came from investors from around my own constituency and my own city. Fortunately, there was a happy ending for those investors. Through the excellent work of Mr Ian Ferrier, the provisional liquidator, an arrangement was made for the National Australia Bank and Western Australia Inc to contribute certain funds. So the security for these people who had deposited $32m was maintained and they will be paid in full, but without interest. That is an example of investors being led to believe that their funds have been properly secured. They were assured by brokers and the company that they were protected and they then found themselves in a virtually unsecured position with these deposits. As I said, fortunately all has ended well with the Rothwell's depositors and, again, I pay my highest commendation to Mr Ferrier for all his efforts in that regard.

The position of depositors in another recently failed group which involved the Sunmark Corporation and Sun Sovereign Corporation is entirely different. A report by the provisional liquidator, Howarth and Howarth, dated 16 May, recently came into my hands, and this shows the great intrigue relating to the intercompany investment. This schedule of Sunmark Corp shows a tremendous diversity of deposits and interest in subsidiaries that is almost a nightmare to try to follow. Also attached to that report is a schedule indicating intercompany transfers, intercompany loans, and in many cases where these loans have been made to subsidiaries they are marked in the provisional liquidator's mind as `recovery unknown' or `recovery at nil.'

This is a timely report. Sun Sovereign had recently received approximately $45m on deposit, $21m being from many small Australian investors, of which almost $500,00 came from persons living in and around Mackay. These deposits were received through agencies of Sceptre Management Services Pty Ltd, a company now in liquidation and also a subsidiary of Sunmark Corporation Ltd. Some of these depositors are personally known to me. An amount of $5,059 is being held in trust for a blind child, who is only six years old. Another amount of $37,181 represents the savings of a young chap who has worked hard and diligently to buy a house. Another amount of $20,323 has been put in trust by parents for their children.

This list indicates many smaller deposits. In fact, I think that in this area there are about 230 depositors altogether, many of whom are conscientious savers. However, the list itself does not reflect the misery, the trauma and the anger at the loss of their retirement plans, their education and housing plans for the family and the nest egg for survival in these uncertain economic times. These are just normal, everyday Australians planning for their future and that of their children. They had been advised by Sceptre that their deposits were secured against bank bills and Commonwealth equities, where Sun Sovereign covered all deposits from these investments by about 80 per cent. As a result of this report, these deposits are now worth 4c in the dollar and advice is now being received that it was company policy not to exchange securities unless depositors were from Sydney or Melbourne. Apparently it was the company's policy not to recognise people outside these centres as Australians worthy of security. Since when has a company policy overridden corporate law and the need for companies to trade within that law? Advice has also been received that only deposits of $100,000 or more would be secured. However, any security is in doubt as the liquidators test the Supreme Court of New South Wales with a validity of some 30 of those deposits amounting to $5.93m. A result in favour of non-acceptance of those deposits as secured, will increase the proposed dividend to 17c in the dollar, still a loss of 33c.

However, in spite of the assurance given by Sceptre and the company that there was security and that there were bank bills and government bonds, there was no security and there were no bills to cover the deposits. But a Western Australian investor has claimed that four days before the company went into liquidation, a representative from Sun Sovereign had called at his home to collect a $4,000 cheque. One has to ask where the money went and what happened to the bank bills. The company was apparently milked through a system of intercompany transfers and these funds placed offshore. The whole group of companies has been under the control of a Mr C. K. Yap, who was Hong Kong based until very recently. I understand that Sun Sovereign was owned primarily by Chancery Nominees, with 90 per cent, and by Sunmark Corporation with 10 per cent, both with ties back to Mr Yap. Apparently the provisional liquidator has not been able to interview this gentleman as he has transferred his residency to London. On 1 February this year, depositors received letters from Sun Sovereign Limited under the Money Market Corporation logo. One was to confirm a repayment of the deposit with accrued interest, another was to accept that same deposit and the third to say that these were a result of the necessity to conform to National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) regulations, but no advice was given as to why this was all necessary and there was no option given for the withdrawal of the deposit.

Depositors are asking the question: How is it that under Australian corporate laws, the NCSC and the Foreign Investment Review Board Australian companies can come under the control of an offshore enterprise and have their assets stripped? These people can still encourage Australian investment in what could amount to a deliberately fraudulent action in asking for those deposits. The message must be for any investors to insist on the production of the security in any company that opens itself up for an investment of this nature. I believe that any investor would be foolish to take, on face value, the assurances given by those companies and some of their investment agencies.

I want to assure the House that this is not a business bash. I note that in the Australian on 29 May 1989 Gerald Henderson suggested that a business bash was being conducted by certain people within the Corporate Affairs Commission and the NCSC. I do believe that there is a degree of accuracy in reports that the financial reporting by some companies throughout Australia has reached an all time legal and moral low. How can a representative of a company collect deposits only days before a collapse, when it would have been so obvious that the whole financial structure of the company had collapsed. It is obvious that the standard of reporting set would be sufficient to deal with these matters, but in cases such as this where the standards have been wilfully disregarded, some authority must pursue them relentlessly.

I would suggest that the NCSC should investigate this particular collapse thoroughly through the corporate affairs departments within each of the States, and do it with a view to prosecuting those who have deliberately misled these very genuine, small Australian investors and to ascertain whether any professional negligence insurance could be recovered from the agents of Sceptre. This is very important because there might be other companies which have not yet collapsed but are in this same situation. Many more small investors may have invested their life savings in these companies, so it is important that the NCSC carry out that investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak today on the housing debate. The way that things have been going a lot of people are hurting in the community, but perhaps not as many as we are led to believe by some spokesmen for people who are suffering from interest rate rises. The tenor of the present debate about interest rates and home purchase is understandable in Australia. I know that the Minister at the table, the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mrs Kelly), would have a particular interest in this problem, given that she is the honourable member for Canberra and that Canberra was the site of a very loud and well attended meeting last night. But the tenor is also one of frustration and fear.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to denigrate the motives or concerns of any participant in the debate when I say that it could be assisted by the addition of a few facts about the housing situation in Australia as a whole. Some people may have watched the Couchman program on Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) television last night-those who did not attend the meeting in Tuggeranong. If so, I hope they were not as annoyed as I was about the contribution of the Business Review Weekly's representative. I found his comments unhelpful, politically partisan and particularly emotive. I recollect that he actually carried out a similar role once before just after the April statement when he appeared on an ABC television program. I hope that the ABC does not continue to use him because I do not find his contribution particularly helpful to any debate.

In 1986 there were 3,586,405 owner-purchaser households in Australia; that is, 70.4 per cent of the Australian household population. By comparison, 5.5 per cent of households rent housing authority accommodation, that is, State housing in some places, and 19.4 per cent rent privately. Other forms of tenure, including some other government tenures, apply to the remaining 4.7 per cent of households. The latest owner-purchaser figure, from April 1989, I think, is 72 per cent compared with 68.4 per cent in 1976 and 70.1 per cent in 1981. It can be seen from these figures that by far the majority of Australian households either own their own home or are in the process of purchasing it, and that percentage is obviously increasing. In fact, the increase in the last few years has been quite outstanding. In 1988, 83.3 per cent of couples were owner-purchasers, 42.5 per cent were single parents and 56.4 per cent were single people.

Some people who are concerned about the impact of present interest rates on recent home purchases have gone so far as to suggest that the ceiling of 13.5 per cent, which this Government quite correctly placed on existing bank home loans in 1986 at a time when the freeing up of the banking system was having more of an impact, should be removed so as to equalise the burden on home buyers. I believe that this suggestion overlooks the fact that these loans do not represent a very large volume of bank home lending and, therefore, the removal of the ceiling would not assist to any measurable degree the interest rate applying to post-1986 purchasers. It would, of course, increase the pain to pre-1986 purchasers.

I point out for the interest of the House that in terms of the percentage of 13.5 per cent loans held by the banks-not in money terms but in the percentage of their loans that are regulated-the ANZ Bank has 20 per cent of its loans at 13.5 per cent, the National Australia Bank Ltd has 22 per cent, Westpac Banking Corporation has 20 per cent and the Commonwealth Bank has 50 per cent. As I have said, the value of those loans is not great; they were, of course, smaller loans. Obviously, as was pointed out by Carolyn Hirsh, MP, last night in the Couchman program, many of those loans were cocktailed, that is, those people had the majority of their bank loan at 13.5 per cent, but they also had personal loans. Of course, a large number of people were never protected by the 13.5 per cent because they were paying through building societies which were never covered by that ceiling. So it is a fallacy to say that the removal of the 13.5 per cent ceiling would assist existing home purchasers who are experiencing interest rate difficulties.

The demand for housing in Australia is extremely strong. The Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry estimated underlying demand for dwellings in 1988-89 at 144,800. Its estimate for the five years to 1992-93 will average about 153,000 per annum. Any honourable member here will realise that is an extremely high dwelling rate. These figures need to be looked at in comparison with the dwelling commencement in past years, which has fluctuated between 105,000 in 1981-82 and 152,000 in 1984-85, which coincides rather closely with the last time that interest rates really started to bite and the last time that housing costs really started to escalate in Australia.

Graphs of dwelling commencements and underlying demand seem to indicate that 135,000 to 140,000 dwelling commencements per annum is a reasonably sustainable level of activity for the housing construction industry in Australia. Once we get past that point we come up with a lot of problems. In fact, buoyant levels of housing activity in major State capitals and also in south-east Queensland have placed pressure on industry resources. High levels of activity in the alterations and additions sector and in non-residential construction have also contributed to the tight resource situation, particularly for labour. Pressure on resources, particularly land, has caused substantial increases in prices of house and land packages in major housing markets. Whilst Perth has been affected by increases in housing, it has not been affected to the degree that some of the other States have, particularly New South Wales and Victoria, because obviously the pressures are greater in those States.

Several other solutions, apart from this 13.5 per cent ceiling removal, have been floated in recent months. They have included the encouragement of savings, tax deductability on home loan interest payments and things like housing bonds. I think all of these ideas need to be looked at but some are obviously more appropriate than others. One point that is continually overlooked in all of this debate seems to be the assistance that has been provided to home buyers through the first home owners scheme and, also, the $140m which the Commonwealth Government put in to the original 13.5 per cent ceiling protection.

The housing bond idea would depend to a large degree on the tax-free status of interest earned on bonds, which would then allow bond money to be lent also at low interest to first home buyers. I presume that people proposing this scheme mean that it should apply to those buying moderately priced homes, or else there would be no money left to lend to other people. However, it must not be overlooked that the tax-free status would cost the community money from what are essentially public savings through tax forgone.

One benefit of this system which I think needs to be pointed out is that it would take first home loans out of the profit making market, that is, the banks, and this would be a relief to a large section of the community, particularly those who are concerned about their ability to pay in the longer term. The Government has made several attempts to assist these people before, not only through the first home owners scheme but also through the low start loans and key start loans and so on in certain States and across the Commonwealth.

There is also the prospect-I am not sure how many people have discussed this with banks-of getting some sort of contract tightening, some contracted deviation in the rate of interest, or an acceptable interest rate fluctuation within a contract. Many of my constituents have raised with me that perhaps they ought to have, when they sign a contract with the bank, a method that would involve banks in quarantining interest rates on first home loans of an agreed moderate value, where a loan taken out at, say, 14 or 15 per cent could have a variation of 1 or 2 per cent either way. That would give the bank the opportunity to hold the interest at a slightly higher rate once interest rates dropped, with the agreement of the borrower to cover the cost of interest over the allowed limit.

I am fairly sure that some of these policies should be looked at. There is a cost to the broader community, but with 72 per cent of households actually either owning or buying their homes, it is something that we, as a Government and as members of parliament, definitely must consider. However, we should not forget that public housing is a very important element of policy--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bureaucratic muddling and government inertia are causing very serious frustration and inconvenience for the Inala Rudolf Steiner School and Residential of West Pennant Hills. Certainly, frustration and inconvenience are also affecting many other schools which cater for physically and intellectually disabled children in the community. Right at the start I declare that I have a special interest in the Inala school.

SPEECH.PARA: The background to this disturbing and totally unacceptable situation is as follows: In early 1986, responsibility for the education, training and educational support services for children with disabilities was transferred from the Department of Community Services and Health to the Commonwealth Schools Commission. The Department of Community Services and Health retained responsibility for recurrent funding of certain services, or aspects of services, such as those relating to residential facilities attached to schools. Subsequently, in May 1987, the Commonwealth Disability Services Act 1986 was introduced, but children's residential facilities did not fit into any of the eligible service types which can currently be funded under that Act; nor did they comply with the principles and objectives gazetted with the Act. Since 1986, the Department of Employment, Education and Training has provided funding for the capital costs of such residential facilities, but the issues of their recurrent or operational funding remains unresolved to this day.

Let us just consider this situation for a moment. Legislation which has the most important financial implications for children in the physically and intellectually handicapped community is assented to in December 1986; it comes into effect on 5 June 1987, and yet in June 1989-two years later-the question of responsibility over recurrent funding is still not resolved, and that is despite constant efforts on the part of administrators of these schools to have the Government resolve this unfortunate situation.

I would like to outline the inconvenience that this is causing the Rudolf Steiner School at Inala. In 1988, Inala built a new $263,000 residential training facility, which was funded up to 80 per cent by the Federal Department of Employment, Education and Training. In other words, this $263,000 residential training facility was built not only with funds from the Government but also with the blessing of the Department of Employment, Education and Training. It was built to provide a program for severely intellectually and physically handicapped young people whose families have extreme difficulty coping with their needs. It was designed to set up a structured residential program to give these intellectually and physically handicapped children as many living skills as possible, and also at the same time to provide respite care for the parents. Of the cost of the building, more than $50,000 has already been raised by the parents and supporters of the Inala school. This facility was finished in December 1988. In other words, it was ready for occupation in December of last year. It still has not been used. There is a very long waiting list and anyone who has any understanding of the situation of those children in the community who are intellectually and physically handicapped will know that the facilities simply do not provide enough spaces for the number of children seeking those spaces. There is a very long waiting list-at present 25 to 30 children are on the short list to go into this facility. The children have been waiting to go into this program between 12 and 18 months already. What do we find? We find a situation in which the facility has been completed and no children have moved into it.

As the new facility neared completion, Inala applied to the Department for a 1989 recurrent grant to assist in meeting the costs of salaries and other administration associated with the operation of the new building. I mention at this stage that as is the current thinking, the program of this new facility is structured on a family style environment. It is not an old fashioned institutional-type establishment at all; it is right in line with current thinking on the best way to deal with these types of situations. In April 1989 the Department advised Inala that it would offer a one-off payment of $86,000 for 1989, but only on the condition that Inala signed a formal agreement undertaking not to seek money from the Department for this purpose beyond 1989. I just mention at this stage that I have been involved, as have a number of other members, in trying to get some decision from the Government and from the departments involved for many months now. I have not stated the situation publicly because I had hoped it would be resolved between the two Ministers or between the two departments. It simply has not been resolved, and we have had this totally unacceptable offer of one year's funding for $86,000 for the year 1989, but with the requirement that Inala signed a formal agreement undertaking not to seek money from the Department for recurrent expenditure beyond this year.

The costs of running this facility at present are $86,000 per year-obviously, totally beyond the resources of the Inala school. Yet we have this Government and these departments saying, `You must sign an undertaking not to seek money from the Department in the future for recurrent funding purposes'. The situation is totally unacceptable because the facility was built with the encouragement and support of the Department of Employment, Education and Training. It is there ready to be occupied and it cannot be occupied simply because the question of recurrent funding has not been settled, the offer being made being totally unacceptable. How could any responsible organisation commit itself to the employment of staff, house parents, and the enrolment of children, knowing that it would be impossible to continue their employment and enrolment into 1990? It would be cruel, it would be heartless and it would be wrong.

What is also unacceptable is that the Federal Government can offer a considerable financial support for additional school facilities and then, through sheer inertia, force those same facilities to lie idle as this new $263,000 facility is presently lying idle. That such a wasteful and, I think, blatantly stupid situation has occurred can only be due to one thing-a complete breakdown in the management between those government departments charged with the responsibility to coordinate funding arrangements for residential schools. This breakdown in management has been aptly described by the New South Wales Minister for Family and Community Services in a letter to a ministerial colleague on 1 May 1989, and I quote from that letter:

At the 1989 Autumn conferences of social welfare administrators and social welfare Ministers, one of the agenda items identified the disability services area as one which is increasingly becoming a major issue in the provision of Commonwealth State community services. The funding anomalies affecting-
and here a particular school is mentioned-

provide another clear example of the lack of clarity in the roles and responsibilities of each level of government; in the way that major initiatives by one area of government impact upon others in the absence of any formal planning frameworks; and the multiplicity of funding arrangements and differing accountability requirements for non-government organisations providing services for people with disabilities and their families.

The Social Welfare Ministers' conference noted that the disability services area is characterised by complexity, overlap, duplication and gaps, and urgently requires clarification of responsibilities to ensure that rational and coordinated services are available to people with disabilities. That such a serious breakdown in the management of disability services occurred at all is bad enough, but there is simply no excuse for such a totally unacceptable situation to remain unresolved for two years after the legislation came into effect.

This has caused needless distress and anxiety for children who are already under stress. It has caused needless distress and anxiety for families and administrators involved in residential schools for disabled children. I would ask, on their behalf, for the Government to address this problem urgently and take whatever remedial action is necessary to ensure the resumption of normal recurrent funding for residential schools for disabled children. Not to do so will be the greatest indictment on the so called caring and responsible attitude that the Government and its Ministers boast so much about. We have two Ministers involved in this situation, neither of whom have been able to make a decision. It is simply an appalling and unacceptable situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —It appears that the beast of the colosseum is still with us, because in Perth, over the past week or two, we have had this spectacle of a number of media commentators suggesting that it was their right to reveal personal details of the medical history of citizens in Western Australia. Indeed one wonders at the motivation; whether it is to up the ratings or just the pursuit of hysterical populist beliefs. But clearly, the messages that have been put across in respect of the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) virus have been misleading and deserve commentary. Indeed, responsible authorities in this country have been saying for some time now that what we aim to do is arm people with information about this most frightening and terrifying disease, allow them to make responsible decisions about their own behaviour and about the way in which they conduct their affairs. And indeed, it is most distressing that commentators in Western Australia should suggest that all rights of confidentiality and individual privacy should be cut across in this situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I can accept the suggestion that we should be taking up the cudgels for quarantining people who are shown to be recalcitrant in their behaviour in respect of AIDS. But we have to be able to prove the fact. Innuendo and guess-work are not sufficient. The concern is, of course, that when we are looking at the control of AIDS-and this is a difficult problem-we have to look at the larger problem. The overwhelming majority of cases of AIDS come from infection from individuals who did not know they were at risk. One of the most important mechanisms of control of this disease is being able to chase down cases to find out those who are at risk. For that to happen, people need to submit themselves to testing. if they are to submit themselves for testing, then we must be able to provide counselling and assistance for them. If they submit themselves to testing then it is important that they be sure that the system protects their confidentiality and protects them from discrimination.

Indeed, that is the most important issue that is at stake in this debate. Nobody catches AIDS because someone sneezed on them, coughed on them, shook hands with them or talked to them in the street. A person catches AIDS because he or she consented to a particular intimate activity with another person. And the key word here is `consent'. If, indeed, there was no consent then there would be a criminal charge of assault or rape. So if we are talking about the consenting activity of adults in these particular cases, it is most important that we ensure the privacy of those involved. Indeed, the suggestion or the innuendo that we can name individuals without significant or sufficient proof, is abhorrent.

It is clear that the Western Australian Health Department has the power and will take action if it has significant or sufficient proof of recalcitrant behaviour by individuals-individuals who are maliciously infecting others with this most telling virus. But it does not have that proof and, in the absence of that, media commentators should not be taking the opportunity to breach the confidentiality of those people who are involved. The innuendo that is involved is very damaging and dangerous. The media issue is very important and we need to consider it. Are these commentators suggesting, for instance, that everybody who suffers from a sexually transmitted disease should have his or her name made public? What we think of as harmless sexually transmitted diseases play a significant part in causing infertility in females. And, indeed, significant harm can be done to an individual's future and prospects as a result of contracting a disease. But the important thing to remember here is that these diseases are only contracted through consenting adult behaviour which is not forced or--
