DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Breast Cancer-World No-Tobacco Day-St Basil's Homes for the Aged-National Bushfire Research Unit-Medicare-World Environment Day-Gallipoli Anniversary-Government Assistance to the Needy-World War II Veterans-Queensland Primary Industries

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a number of occasions in this place in recent months, I have spoken of the apparent insensitivity of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) to the needs of Australian women for early action on their breast cancer X-ray scanning needs. My comments are exemplified by an excellent article by Glennys Bell in the Bulletin magazine of 30 May titled `Breast cancer: a medical scandal'. She makes the points that about one in 16 Australian women develop breast cancer; that one in 45 risk dying from it and that about 2,200 actually die each year from it. While diagnostic mammograms requiring a doctor's referral are covered by Medicare, breast scanning mammograms for women who have no symptoms or who are in a low risk category are not. Perhaps the Minister perceives greater electoral appeal from the homosexual community than from Australian women as a result of his recently announced limited screening program for acquired immune deficiency syndrome. His reluctance to provide a similar program for breast cancer is indeed a scandal. The Bulletin article concludes:

SPEECH.PARA: Ideally, the solution will be breast-disease centres where health professionals have a specialist commitment; where mammograms are given by expert radiologists; where ultrasound tests decide whether a lump is solid or not; where there are facilities for needle biopsies and knowledgeable referral, if necessary, to a surgeon able to put all the information together and give a woman mature and reflected advice.
If men had breast cancer at the same rates, to paraphrase feminist Gloria Steinem, there would be no hesitation--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity to make a symbolic presentation to the House of this appropriately packaged petition which was presented to me by Canberra Action on Smoking and Health (ASH) yesterday, the second world no-tobacco day. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The female smoker at added risk. World second no-tobacco day, 31 May 1989. Feminine victims. To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. On behalf of our members and supporters, we, the undersigned; recognising that the second world no-tobacco day which is being held on Wednesday, 31 May 1989, has been dedicated to women, that women and adolescent girls have been targeted by the tobacco industry to offset the loss of male smokers, and that women suffer as smokers and as passive smokers, ask that you do all in your power to lift the burden of tobacco from feminine victims, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

This has been signed by a number of different organisations including the ACT Cancer Society; Quits Smoking Cessation Service; Women's Health Service; Life Be In It, Australian Capital Territory; Canberra ASH Incorporated; National Heart Foundation, Australian Capital Territory Division, Australian Capital Territory Alcohol and Drug Service and Health Advancement Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

—Last weekend I had the opportunity, along with a great number of citizens, to visit the opening by the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) of a home of the St Basil's Homes for the Aged in South Australia. It represents a great community effort by the Greek organisation which has taken the care of its people into its heart and, by putting up some bricks and mortar, has completed this exercise in Winchester Street, St Peters. The board is headed by Mr Basil Taliangis and the Deputy Chairman is John Kiosoglous. The home was opened by the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of Australia with its confirmation by His Eminence. Certainly the board members have done a great job, and recognition should be given to the works of the Greek ex-servicemen's association and Mr Kastamis, the Greek Pensioners Association and Mr Kakalias, and, I think, representing West Adelaide Hellas was Mr Devrelis. As the Minister indicated, there will be other aged care facilities opened around Australia. This was a great credit to the Greek community in looking to preserve its heritage and its people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to express my concern at the decision by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) to dismantle the National Bushfire Research Unit (NBRU). Its activities will be reduced by incorporating the greatly diminished research program into the division of forestry research. Funding will drop to a minuscule $27,000 a year. CSIRO claims that the NBRU is too expensive to operate as a separate entity without outside financial support. Bushfires are a regular and calamitous feature of our landscape in the south-east of Australia, particularly in the urban rural fringes such as the Dandenong Ranges and the Blue Mountains. It is six years since the infamous Ash Wednesday fires and on the balance of probabilities, given the strong rains and consequential lush growth, another conflagration will soon be upon us. The research of the NBRU must continue at a high level.

SPEECH.PARA: I urge the Government to consider a one-off grant to enable the NBRU to continue while urgent appeals are made to State Premiers, fire fighting services and the insurance industry. Commercial ventures could be explored with a contribution from beneficiaries or users of bushfire research on a user pays basis and some of the national and overseas consultancy work done on bushfires by the National Safety Council of Australia could be assumed by the NBRU. As a member of the NBRU steering committee, I place on record my appreciation of the work done in the unit by Mr Phil Cheney and his research team. The Government must act now on research in order to prevent unnecessary loss of life and property in bushfires.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Medicare would have to be one of the greatest failures of this Government. The list of criticisms about inequities in health and the lack of sensitivity and compassion grows longer every day. An important example is the decision to reduce the Medicare rebate applying to the treatment of a generic disorder commonly known as port wine stain. Three in every 1,000 babies are born with the abnormal complexes of veins that cause these unsightly face and body markings. Laser technology is available to treat those children and until 1 February a rebate of $210 could be claimed for the argon laser method. But after that date the Government scrapped that item and created a new one covering all three laser treatments. The rebate is now a pitiful $81.60. As a result of that draconian decision, hundreds of Australian children and adults will be denied treatment because they can no longer afford it.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly this Government does not care that they are condemning those people to a lifetime of embarrassment and, in many cases, psychological problems. In one particular case the parents of a small boy in my electorate are now faced with costs running into thousands of dollars to continue this treatment with the latest candela laser. Ironically, Medicare is quite happy to pay $333 rebate for a breast enlargement, $213 for hair transplant, $228 for a nose reduction and $148 for finger shortening, yet it places a very low priority on improving the quality of life for this little boy and many Australians like him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Monday is World Environment Day, a day that I hope all Australians will observe. The Ahern National Party Government in Queensland is no different from the former Bjelke-Petersen regime, particularly on the environment. It is simply a case of the same dog, different bit of string. There is clear evidence of the Ahern Government's lack of commitment to the environment in my own electorate. At present a radioactive waste dump is being proposed at Redbank and a toxic waste dump is planned for Willowbank near the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) base at Amberley. The Redbank radioactive dump site was decided on without any consultation with the locals and without any environmental impact study being carried out. All evidence indicates that the site is environmentally unacceptable because of its closeness to residential areas and the Brisbane River and the fact that the area is subject to soil movement. Understandably, locals are protesting against this project and many have been arrested, including a 79-year-old grandmother on Mothers Day. The rumoured site for the Willowbank toxic waste dump could destroy a national environmental park where many birds and animals live amongst the trees and enjoy clear water from the natural water course. This site is also close to the residential areas of RAAF personnel at Amberley.

SPEECH.PARA: As Monday is World Environment Day it would be a very good day for the Ahern Government to terminate all such ill-conceived projects and to establish set guidelines to include environment factors and community interest before proceeding with any project of this type. I call on the Ahern Government to do just that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Next year, 1990, will be the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Gallipoli campaign-an occasion when Australia attained nationhood and when the blood of young Australians was shed in the defence of freedom. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has recently announced that veterans of that campaign will be taken back to Gallipoli to celebrate this milestone in our history. Many of those who fought and many of those who lost their lives in the Gallipoli campaign were teenagers or only a little older.

SPEECH.PARA: The seventy-fifth anniversary provides an ideal opportunity to make all Australians, particularly young Australians, more aware of the significance of Anzac. A contingent of young army cadets and Australian students should be sent to accompany these veterans. They should act as aids and, in the process, they would be sure to absorb some of the Anzac tradition and spirit. There are thousands of young Australians visiting Gallipoli in Turkey every year. There is a great need for tourist information and for guides in the battlefield area. Canada has a scheme where by students act as volunteer tourist guides at Vimy Ridge on the Somme battlefield in France during the summer vacation. Australia should establish a similar scheme for Gallipoli on Anzac Day 1990 on an on-going basis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the House's attention to an article in today's West Australian which was headed, `Simple plea for needy'. The Anglican Archbishop of Perth, Dr Peter Carnley, has appealed to governments to make it easier for the needy to get information on their entitlement. Dr Carnley said:

SPEECH.PARA: People needing State and Federal Government help were finding it increasingly difficult to find their way through what is becoming a maze of red tape.
It is difficult for clients to obtain clear answers to their questions from government departments.

He then went on to say that organisations like Anglicare, which, of course, is not a government agency but a well-run organisation of the Anglican Church, and government assistance programs needed to provide the information necessary to help people achieve independence.

I raise this issue, Madam Speaker, because as a member I find it increasingly frustrating to receive complaints from constituents who come to my office to say that they cannot understand the information that has been sent to them. It is much worse, of course, when they are required to fill in forms. I think it is important for us to make sure-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not have a thought to speak at this moment, but the comments about Anzac Day by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) have prompted me to do so. We have long been aware that in this House of 148 members there are only two World War II veterans who returned from active service. One is the honourable member for Reid, Tom Uren, for whom the House has the highest regard. The other one, if I may modestly say so, is myself.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Reid has indicated that he will not be returning to this Parliament after the next election. Yesterday I made a similar announcement and I think it is worthy of passing note in this House that as from the next Parliament the prospects of having World War II reinforcements for this place is decidedly remote and therefore the House should be particularly alert to ensuring that the proper entitlements of those who have served our country in past campaigns should be addressed in an appropriate manner. Those entitlements should not be lost simply as a consequence of the effluxion of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the beginning of the year a memo from the Queensland State Department of Primary Industries came into my possession. That memo, which I passed on to the relevant authorities, highlighted the drought rorts that have been going on in Queensland under the incompetent administration of the State Minister for Primary Industries, Mr Neville Harper. But further, information has come to me this week from a departmental officer who has been frightened to come forward himself because the Special Branch has been brought into the Department of Primary Industries. That information highlights the fact that cattle from a drought-stricken property in Queensland went on to win the fat cattle section at the Townsville show. This demonstrates the totally ludicrous situation we have in Queensland where taxpayers' money has been misused; winks and nods have passed for capable administration. Is it any wonder that we have the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct? What we really need is Mr Fitzgerald to put on an Akubra hat, come up into the bush and clean up the rorts that have been bedevilling primary producers for so long. The sad thing is that the greedy have been getting the money, not the needy. The rich squatters have had their hands in the pockets of the Aussie battler farmers for years. I am totally opposed to that proposition.
—Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

—As a matter of courtesy, I inform the House that the Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, is absent on Government business. In his absence, questions normally directed to the Attorney-General should be directed to the Minister for Trade Negotiations, Mr Duffy.
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I ask him: On whose advice did he base his prediction that there will be an increase in real living standards next year?

—In this position-one which the honourable gentleman will never occupy-it is found that one receives advice from a range of people. One receives advice from one's own Department, one's personal staff, the Treasury and a range of departments. I am in the fortunate position that I have the capacity not only to receive and understand that advice but also to add to that a very considerable personal understanding. It was on the basis of all those things that I made the statement.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Can the Minister advise the House of what the Government plans to do with its wheat marketing legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —A question on wheat from the Opposition is about as rare as a question to the Government on the environment. That one question from the honourable member means that he has asked me half as many questions as the entire Opposition this year, and more questions on wheat. The fact of the matter is that the Opposition is trying to wriggle out of the commitment by the former Leader of the Opposition to ensure that there is a deregulated domestic wheat market after 1 July this year. This was repeated by both the new and former Opposition leaders, but they obviously did not know what they were talking about.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition is trying to amend the Wheat Marketing Bill to require a higher underwriting and a grower chairperson for the Australian Wheat Board. Opposition members have adjourned the debate in the Senate in a stunt to try to place pressure on the Government to accept their amendments. I want to advise the House-and tell the Opposition directly to its face-that the Government will not cave in on this issue. We will not give the wheat industry a level of underwriting so high that it will never have any incentive to stand on its own feet; a level that also discriminates against other products, and other grains in particular. We will not accept that the Australian Wheat Board-a $3 billion enterprise-will be led by anyone less than the best person available. That is what the Opposition says it wants, but that is not the real issue.

The real issue is that the new Leader of the Opposition has ratted on his mates who supported deregulation and has returned to the days of Liberal toadying to the backwoods regulators of the National Party of Australia. The National Party wants the sunset clause in the current legislation to trigger, because that would mean that compulsory acquisition of the wheat crop would continue for two years. The National Party does not care about wheat growers. The loss of underwriting under the sunset clause would cost the industry the best part of $100m in extra interest alone.

Wheat deregulation is a necessary part of the Government's program to meet the economic challenges facing Australia. By reducing costs to both growers and users it will increase exports of both wheat and wheat products. The National Party is interested only in the comfort of the status quo of regulation, kneecapping the Liberals and sabotaging the Government's program of micro-economic reform. It is to the eternal discredit of the present Leader of the Opposition that he wants to let it do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer him to a study by the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) entitled External Balance and Economic Growth, published in October 1986, which, on the basis of some fairly optimistic assumptions on interest rates, exchange rates and growth, suggested that our net debt would not stabilise until about 1991. I ask the Prime Minister whether EPAC has updated this study. I also ask the Prime Minister whether the updated assessment is more pessimistic than the assessment in 1986.
—I am not aware whether EPAC has or has not, but it may have. I will check it and, on the basis of checking it, I will provide the honourable gentleman with an answer if I find that it has.

—My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Social Security. Since 1983 the Government's social justice strategy has significantly increased the provision of services for the aged. In October 1988 the Social Security Review issued a report on retirement income. Can the Acting Minister inform the House of the actions taken by the Government to meet the needs of older members of our community? Has the Acting Minister evaluated the consequences for older members in our community of other proposals being made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two distinct features of the Government's approach to aged care; firstly, the recognition that most old people would wish to remain as independent as possible for as long as possible. Indeed, we have designed programs, particularly the home and community care program, to attend to that matter. Secondly, there is the Government's clear commitment to the development of a retirement income policy that is adequate, fair, sustainable and secure. In fact, details of that policy will be released by my colleague the Minister for Social Security in the course of his response to the inquiry, and it will relate both to those who are at present in retirement and to those who are approaching retirement.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that last year the Opposition announced its retirement income policy, but the policy tends to concentrate on those yet to retire, with very little emphasis in the Opposition policy on those people already at pensionable age. Then we have Future Directions, that great document. I do not know what its current status is within the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Old Testament.

—I am told it is Old Testament. Out of 109 pages only four pages have any reference to retirement. Again, the focus is on those approaching retirement, rather than on the 1.7 million people who are at present age and service pensioners. We are told that we have a Liberal Party hotline which will enable people to find out the answers if they have concerns in any of those areas. Of course, there is not one scrap of information of it for anyone, including the aged. All the hotline does is to provide a recorded message asking people to ring the Liberal Party in Canberra. At present, confusion would only mount if anyone did that.

ANSWER.PARA: We debated in this House quite recently the amendments to social security legislation; amendments which directly affect the aged and families in relation to the April statement. The Government always welcomes debate on these issues, but the shadow Minister for Social Security, when I read his speech on that matter, failed to make a single mention of the aged in that speech. His excuse was that he did not have time, even though the two major elements of the legislation which was passed concerned the aged and families. Of course, the shadow Treasurer who-as I have repeated time and time again, and will go on repeating-threatens to slash expenditure in that area. When one puts together that package, looks at Future Directions, looks at the statements from the shadow Minister for Social Security and listens to the remarks from the shadow Treasurer, then clearly under a coalition government the aged would be vulnerable.

I want to compare that with the policies which have been pursued by this Government. We have had a major report from the Social Security Review on the income needs of the aged and a massive consultation exercise with the aged on the issues raised by that Review. As a result of that, we have already had major extensions and improvements of the services which our aged require in their communities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those pensioners got nothing out of the April statement, not a cent.
—Order! The honourable member for Bradfield will not interject.

—I will come to the interjection from the honourable member for Bradfield in one moment. Before going to that, I point out that we have maintained our commitment to increase the aged pension to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings; a commitment we have made and maintained to index aged pensions. Since 1983 the aged pension has increased in real terms by more than 7.5 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: On the point raised by the honourable member for Bradfield, the recent April economic statement was the first stage of the phased retirement incomes policy. Contrary to the interjection, it provided significant advantages to all age pensioners. We have a commitment to bring forward the indexation of age pensions by 12 weeks. So, from 1991 indexation adjustments will be the speediest we have ever had for age pensioners in this country. A commitment was also made that, by July 1990, all income received by age pensioners within the income test free area would be 100 per cent tax free. Not only have we seriously undertaken to address the major issues across this field but also practical legislation is in place, which is a clear response. We will continue to consult with the aged and effectively respond to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, relates to his responsibilities for the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. I ask the Minister: Is he aware that approximately 1,000 submissions on pharmacy have been put before the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal inquiry into the new data base for determining pharmacists' remuneration? Is he aware that the Chairman of the Tribunal, a former Minister in the Whitlam Government, has refused to extend public hearings on the issue beyond the one-day sitting in Melbourne tomorrow? Considering the importance of the Tribunal's determination, in so far as the Government and Australia's 5,500 pharmacists and the wider community are concerned, is the Minister satisfied that a one-day sitting is sufficient for the Tribunal to give proper consideration to all the submissions and other relevant data?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that the Tribunal will be sitting tomorrow. In relation to the other points raised by the honourable member, it needs to be stressed that the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal is an independent tribunal. Quite clearly and simply, it is the prerogative of the Chairman and the Tribunal to conduct that inquiry as they see fit.
—In one day?

—That is their prerogative; they have the submissions before them. This Government and I will not interfere in that process as, quite clearly, the Tribunal is an independent tribunal. I am sure that Deputy President Riordan and the other people on the Tribunal are well aware of the workload in front of them and the importance of this case-it is important for the delivery of health care in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: A point that needs to be made is that, currently, our system of remuneration for pharmacists, which basically, has existed since the introduction of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, remunerates pharmacists for selling pills. This Government is concerned not simply about the fact that more and more pills can be sold and that that is the basis for remuneration; this Government believes that the pharmaceutical benefits scheme should be there for a variety of reasons, principally to ensure that those who require pharmaceuticals will be able to afford them and get access to the best drugs. We will continue to do that in our submissions and in our efforts. It is not simply a matter of remuneration for selling pills. We believe that pharmacy plays an important role in the delivery of health services. I believe that a lot of work has to be done to re-emphasise and develop further the role of pharmacies as health deliverers; not simply as people whose whole being and place in the health care system depend on their selling more and more expensive pills. There is certainly a lot of work to be done. But it is not my place, nor is it the place of any other member in this House, to tell the Tribunal what to do.

After talking to pharmacists right around Australia-and I have had the opportunity to do that quite a lot in recent weeks and months-it has become apparent to me that, in concentrating simply on the remuneration of pharmacists, we do not get the best overall idea of ways of dealing with the pharmaceuticals issue. I will be making a significant announcement later today about ways in which we can improve the consultative process between all players involved in pharmaceutical benefits-whether they be pharmaceutical manufacturers, pharmacists, consumers, doctors or workers. Whilst I take on board the honourable member's question, I think it is also important to recognise that this Government's health care policy is second to none in the history of this country.
Opposition members-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members opposite can laugh about that if they wish. Since they have been in opposition they have had six health policies. Of the six there have been three from the honourable member for Mackellar, one from the honourable member for Barker and one from the honourable member for O'Connor, and we are yet to see an effective policy from the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Tangney.

ANSWER.PARA: This Government is delivering health care services, through Medicare, aged care and, in particular, through the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. I believe that this delivery of services ought to be taken properly into account, as it has been by millions of people-the pensioners, the chronically ill and those on low incomes as well as every other Australian. A point that needs to be made is that the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth, quite clearly has signalled that there should not be tax cuts and that there should be spending cuts, particularly in the health area. I think everyone will be awaiting his pronouncements of where health care and, in particular, pharmaceutical benefits will be going under any government of which he might be a part.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Given the increased community concern with environmental problems, particularly the greenhouse effect, will the Minister take steps to terminate the use of rainforest timbers in Federal construction projects?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important question as rainforests house most of our planet's biological diversity. Their destruction contributes directly to the greenhouse effect of global warming. Honourable members might be aware that I and the Parliament House Construction Authority took steps during the construction of this very building, the new Parliament House, to ban the use of Australian old growth rainforest timber in that process. Timbers logged from forests entered on the register of the National Estate are already banned from Commonwealth construction projects. However, at present significant tonnages of rainforest timber are imported for use in the construction industry, particularly in the Northern Territory where no handy supply of domestic timber is available. However, substitutes are available, such as structural steel and domestic and imported plantation timber.

ANSWER.PARA: Australian Construction Services, which is the construction division of the Department of Administrative Services, is at present conducting a review into these matters. It is examining cost alternatives and proposed new standard conditions of tender and contract to eliminate entirely the use of rainforest timber in Commonwealth projects. At the next ministerial meeting on construction on 30 June next I will be proposing to the State works Ministers that a ban on rainforest products be extended to all public works authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business to his taped interview with three journalists of the Deakin University's newspaper on 22 May. Is it true that, as has subsequently been reported in the Geelong Advertiser, the Minister volunteered to the three journalists that the reason for the science statement of 8 May was that previous funding for sciences had been `stuffed up by the Government'?

—I do not have a copy of the tape. I thought that the quality of the interviewing left something to be desired because the interviewers said, `Look, there appear to be inconsistencies. In one part of the statement it says funding for CSIRO and some other institutions declined and now you are saying more money is coming up'. At the end of it all, I said, `But what's the problem?' They said, `Well, you say funding has declined in some areas and now you say funding is going up'. Again I said, `What is the problem?'. They said, `Well, there's an inconsistency'. I said, `Well, there's no inconsistency; there is simply a frank recognition that some mistakes of degree had been made'. I suppose what I was really saying to the youthful journalist was, `You stuffed it up because you did not understand', because I could not believe-normally, as you know, Madam Speaker, I am the most placid of Ministers-that after the long number of permutations and commutations that the interview went through they could not see the absolutely obvious factor in it. I was saying to them that they did not understand the implications of the matter. It had to be put to them fairly brutally.

—Can the Minister for Community Services and Health inform the House what action the Government is taking in support of the Australian Medical Association's policies advocating vocational training and continuing medical education for general practitioners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the question from the honourable member for Fowler, I am glad to say that at least in words the policy of the Australian Medical Association (AMA) is in complete accord with that of the Government on general practitioner (GP) training and continuing education. I will quote from the 1988 version of the policy platform of the AMA; I do not believe there has been any alteration. It reads:

ANSWER.PARA: Postgraduate education
Adequate postgraduate training is a pre-requisite for unsupervised medical practice.
In the case of general practice the Family Medicine Programme of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners provides one avenue for appropriate postgraduate vocational training.
Access to the Family Medicine Programme, or comparable training, should be available to every medical graduate wishing to undertake unsupervised general practice.
This is most important:
No medical practitioner should ever enter unsupervised general practice without having completed such training.
Those words on training of GPs by the AMA in its own policy statement are in complete accord with Government policy. Similarly, on continuing education the AMA policy states:

Practising doctors have a professional obligation to maintain their standards, skills and efficiency by continuously updating their knowledge. To this end regular participation in continuing medical education is essential-
the words `is essential' are those of the AMA-
The provision of continuing medical education programme and selfassessment programmes for the above purpose is the responsibility of the medical colleges and specialists societies.

In the legislation the Government introduced and which is now before another place, we have done exactly what the AMA has seen as necessary and essential and we provided financial incentives for GPs so they can do that vocational training and have continuing medical education. Indeed, the New South Wales branch of the AMA has made clear that it believes there should be differential fees between those GPs who have had vocational training and those who have not.

The AMA, despite its words being clearly in accord with Government policy, has done its best to prevent the passage of the present legislation. I remind members of the Opposition that if there are some minor finetuning problems in the proposals, as I indicated in my second reading speech, we would introduce further legislation to refine the processes in the next session of the Parliament. There would be every opportunity for any amendments to be made. There is no reason whatsoever to prevent the establishment of registration and the medical benefits that will flow from that both to patients and to doctors. There will be higher medical rebates for patients and the vast majority of GPs would have improved annual incomes. If there are any finetuning difficulties they can be fixed in the legislation which necessarily has to come before this House and the Senate in the next session.

There is wide support for the proposals that have been made both from GPs and the public, and I just refer to that. There is increasing support from pensioner groups because they recognise that these proposals will provide better care for pensioners and, as I said yesterday, will assist doctors to maintain bulk billing. The Federation of Ethnic Community Councils of Australia has written to the honourable member for Tangney pointing out that the Federation is particularly concerned since a sizeable and growing proportion of those who will be adversely affected are from the ethnic communities. The people with whom the Opposition has allied itself are people like Dr Shepherd who this week wrote a letter to all GPs in New South Wales suggesting that they should consider ceasing bulk billing for the disadvantaged, including the unemployed and low income families. The AMA itself is advising GPs to change the new levels and use the content-based fees, but is supporting the Opposition in refusing to allow those rebates to be paid.

I make a last effort on the last day of the meeting of this House, at least for some weeks, and I quote from a joint release from the Australian Pensioners Federation and the Combined Pensioners Association of Australia. I quote this because those organisations sum up very clearly the intent of the legislation, the support of the Royal College and the reasons they support the legislation and the reasons the AMA in its statement advocates these sorts of policies. It reads:

We are supporting the proposed reforms to general practice because it will allow doctors to put the care back into their practices. By reimbursing doctors willing to undergo further training and quality assurance measures people will receive better quality care and the local doctors better rebates-consumers and doctors win.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Acting Treasurer aware that the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) is now admitting to a 12.65 per cent error rate in relation to the posting out of 1,100,000 tax file number letters in Queensland and Western Australia? Was the Acting Treasurer informed that this error rate was calculated on the number of letters-that is, 140,000-actually returned to the Tax Office and that the real error rate is likely to be as high as double that, which means that Australia-wide possibly some 170,000 letters containing tax file numbers remain unaccounted for? In view of the Government's earlier assurances that the tax file number system had integrity, does not this latest information about the ATO's bungled issuing of the numbers indicate that the system has been seriously compromised and impaired?

—I am not aware of the statistics to which the honourable member referred. I will refer the question to the Commissioner of Taxation, who has the statutory responsibility for implementing the tax file number system and get a response for the honourable member.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support. Has the Federal Government been providing the Australian National Railways Commission with a revenue supplement over the past 10 years? Was $51m of taxpayers' money provided in direct subsidy last financial year? Why does the Government continue to support Australian National (AN)?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the question asked by the honourable member for Port Adelaide. I acknowledge that, as a member from South Australia, where Australian National chiefly operates, he has shown a continuing interest in the operation of AN and the functions it fulfils.

ANSWER.PARA: AN started to operate in the way in which it operates at present in about 1978, when we brought together the Tasmanian Railways and the Australian National Railways operating through South Australia. The honourable member's figure of $51m as a revenue supplement to Australian National last year is correct, but I emphasise that since 1983-84 that revenue supplement has been reduced by 60 per cent. AN is now in the process of showing that there is an important role for railways and rails services to play in Australia. There has been a significant number of improvements in the extent to which AN has been operating. Of course, we have provided whatever assistance we have been able to in connection with the upgrading of tracks and terminals, but the changes that have taken place quite clearly reflect a great deal of credit not only on the management of AN but also on its staff and on the responsiveness of the unions involved. These changes have been very substantial.

It is expected, as I mentioned a couple of days ago, that the Rail Industry Council, which brought together a lot of interests involved in rail services in Australia, will report by the end of this year. We hope that, as a result of that type of inquiry and that type of council operation, together with the improvements that have taken place in AN, there will be a substantial improvement generally in the way in which rails services operate in Australia.

It is also interesting that AN has been able to bring about an increase in the freight it carries of in excess of 35 per cent and an improvement in productivity of about 150 per cent. I am delighted with what AN is doing. I am delighted that the Government has had the opportunity to indicate, by its support for AN, that it endorses the role that rail transport can and should play in Australia. I have no doubt at all that those improvements will continue to occur. In short, the answer is yes, we did fund AN by way of revenue supplement last year to the extent of $51m. That supplement has been reduced by 60 per cent in the last five or six years. It is improving and it will continue to improve as a result of the initiative and the cooperation of all the parties involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories and concerns Australia's premier export growth industry-tourism. Does the Minister hold figures indicating a dramatic fall in the number of international tourists arriving in Australia during the first quarter of this year? Are the major declines from the United States of America and Japanese markets? Do the Minister's intelligence sources indicate that the principal reason for the sharp decline is the tragedy that is Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport? Have the constant delays and shutdowns in the inadequate international terminal all featured as a root cause for the decline in growth of the Japanese and United States tourist traffic?

—I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. From the very nature of the question let me say that my intelligence sources are probably much better than his. On the basis that there was a major increase in tourism last year, mainly related to the Bicentennial, I think we would be over-optimistic to expect to maintain that flow of tourism this year. Such information as I have at the moment seems to indicate, on the figures available, that the tourism figure is plateauing at a level below that. I will be taking up the details of that next week. But, certainly, to say that all the problems of Sydney Airport can be laid at the feet of the Government is palpable nonsense. As to whoever has informed the honourable gentleman in those terms, all I can say is that he should perhaps try to establish better intelligence sources.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment and Education Services. Can the Minister inform the House of the outcome of the new start program, designed to assist long term unemployed people in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. I know that she has a very keen interest in this matter and the associated jobs, education and training program. It is certainly early days as far as the new start program is concerned. It has been operating for only three months, but it has been doing so quite successfully. The cooperation between my Department and the Department of Social Security to ensure that people who have been unemployed for a long period, for 12 months or longer, have a fair go and are able to get assistance to get back into the work force has been quite successful. I can tell the House that 5,000 people in the target group-those between 21 and 54 years of age who have been unemployed for 12 months or longer-have found work as a result of the operation of the program. As I say, that is a very satisfactory result, given that the program has been in its formative stages. I am very confident that the program will continue to be successful and that we will see a quite dramatic drop in the numbers of long term unemployed as a result.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, we have a particular difficulty with long term unemployment as a result of the 1982 recession. Many of the people who are still unemployed long term became unemployed during the shakeout that occurred in the 1982-83 recession under Treasurer Howard. Those people are now receiving particular support from this Government to ensure that they will be able to take their place in the work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —Boring!

—The honourable member may think it is boring. These people think it is a very important issue. They want to get into the work force. We are giving them the opportunity. The Opposition put them into unemployment in the first place; we are solving the problem for them.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I might say, in passing, that I am confident his answer will not be a load of nonsense. Is the Minister aware that many small businesses with employees who are not union members are having difficulty in establishing the 3 per cent award-based superannuation fund as required by law, as no two insurance companies agree on the basic rules for an award-based fund and none, apparently, can provide evidence of their scheme's approval by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission? Accordingly, to end the confusion, will the Minister arrange for the provision of appropriate guidelines and a list of approved funds?

—The honourable member has not brought to my attention the matter he has now raised. My understanding is that there is provision within the Insurance and Superannuation Commission to deal with the problems he is talking about. However, since he has dealt with the matter specifically and given his interest and genuine approach to the problem he has raised, I will be happy to deal with him personally and to provide him with an answer later on in light of the information he provides to me.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support. I have seen references to the recently identified Varzin Passage from the Gulf of Carpentaria to the east coast. Can the Minister advise the House of the background to this discovery and indicate to the House its potential importance to the economy of northern Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the question that has been asked by the honourable member for the Northern Territory. I know the importance of this matter not only to the Northern Territory and northern Australia generally, but to the whole of Australia. As a result of opening up that particular passage we have been able to establish a much cheaper and safer navigational channel between Groote Eylandt and Newcastle to get the manganese down to Newcastle and also bauxite from Weipa around to Gladstone. As the honourable member knows, the previous passage that was used up there was the Gannet Passage, which was quite a dangerous passage. The Varzin Passage has been identified as a result of the studies that have been carried out by the Royal Australian Navy and it goes through some of those areas in the Gulf which had previously been believed to have been shallows. It is a much safer passage now to connect the Gulf of Carpentaria around to the east coast.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the interesting things about the process of identifying where we should best place navigational aids was that it normally had to be done by a trial and error system. On this particular occasion we have been able to use a simulator at the Maritime College in Tasmania in order to build up the channel contours in the area through there. We were then able to call on experienced navigators who were with the college and the Department. Some of them were also associated with the Queensland Coast and the Torres Strait Pilot Service. In effect, they were able to navigate a simulated mock-up of the Iron Whyalla, about 147,000 tonnes, through the new passage, and to identify where the navigational aids should go. The advantage of siting our navigational aids in this manner is that it can be done a lot more efficiently and cheaply than may otherwise have happened. I am delighted with the way in which the Australian Maritime College has been able to participate in that. I understand the importance of it to the honourable member for the Northern Territory. It is a great boon as far as we are concerned not only for the Northern Territory but for northern Australia and for Australia generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Community Services and Health to his comments in this House at Question Time yesterday and again today that the Opposition is somehow preventing the Government from paying general practitioners higher rebate levels and therefore, according to his logic, we are somehow guilty of acting against the health interests of the aged? How can he justify these comments, given the fact that he has the authority to introduce new Medicare fees and rebates without the necessity to resort to legislation? If he were so concerned about pensioners he could have endorsed a content based fees schedule a long time ago. Why is he frightened about our proposal for a Senate inquiry? Is it not in his power to grant an interim rebate increase now?

—First of all let me say that this Government believes that there are two sides to this arrangement. One is a commitment from the medical profession to accept some restructuring; that is commitments about vocational--
—Do you want the vocational register?
—Order! The honourable member for Tangney, having asked the question, will now not interject.

—There is a commitment about vocational training and a commitment to in-service training. That is the side we expect from the medical profession. The Government, in return, is prepared to restructure the fees which will bring very genuine income benefits to members of the medical profession. The realistic members of the medical profession accept it. They accept that there are two sides to this. It is not simply a question, as some members of the Opposition say, of just increasing doctors' fees. We are not in that business. The business we are in is making sure that in return for this differential rebate there will be real benefits for patients and those differential benefits can come only as a result of the passage of this legislation.

—Can the Minister for Administrative Services advise the House when the provisions of the new Lands Acquisition Act will become operative and whether they will apply to the Badgerys Creek land acquisitions. Additionally, can he inform the House when the Badgerys Creek land acquisition process will be completed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The new Act will replace the existing legislation I think early this month. It provides additional protection for land owners when the Commonwealth wishes to acquire their property. The desirability of major changes to the Commonwealth's land acquisition legislation was identified and recommended by the Australian Law Reform Commission some time ago. In fact, that inquiry was instigated by the former government and this Government has accepted and acted on the vast majority of the recommendations made by the Law Reform Commission. The Act will provide more open procedures in the acquisition process. It will provide for greater public accountability for the decisions to acquire people's land in the first place and it will provide for improved appeal procedures both on the primary decision to appeal and also on matters of individual compensation for specific properties.

ANSWER.PARA: The provisions of the new Act-I think that these are very important transition arrangements-will apply to all acquisitions that are not completed by the time of the commencement of the new Act. Some owners whose land has already been acquired will also benefit because the transitional provisions provide that where a property has been compulsorily acquired after 26 May last year the compensation provisions of the new Act will apply. This includes the ability to have the Administrative Appeals Tribunal make a binding determining on the amount of compensation to be paid on all those acquisitions that have been commenced but not completed since 26 May last year.

As regards Badgerys Creek, the first major application of this new Act will be seen in the acquisition of the remaining properties on the Badgerys Creek site for the second Sydney airport. The Government has already announced its intention to acquire all the remaining properties at Badgerys Creek by the end of this year. So from early 1990 we will be in a position where construction can start on a general aviation facility and, if necessary, on a much more substantial airport depending on the findings of the environmental assessment of the third runway option at the Kingsford-Smith Airport.
