SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the Minister claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—He may proceed.

—I refer to an article in this morning's Age by Michelle Grattan to the effect that questioning by Senator Button and myself in a Cabinet discussion on coastal shipping and waterfront reform raised the issue of the Government's credentials on micro-economic reform. While not for one moment would I deny that I spoke or asked questions during the Cabinet discussion, I wish to place very squarely on the record that I believe that this Government has more comprehensively dealt with the issues of the waterfront and shipping reform than have any of its predecessors.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister is not making a personal explanation; he is debating the matter. The Minister may not show how policy has been misrepresented.
—I simply say that the imputation in the article was wrong and that the statement to be made by my colleague will be very comprehensive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Heinously, Madam Speaker.
—He may proceed.
—I refer to a letter that was published yesterday in the West Australian, which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Dr Charlesworth, who spends most of his time in Canberra, can only criticise Western Australia.

Indeed, this relates to an article which talks about imputed attacks by me on tourism in Western Australia. Honourable members in this House would know very well that I, of course, am a great supporter of Western Australia and the tourist industry in Western Australia. I have also made the calculation that Parliament has sat for 28 days so far this year and this is the one hundred and fifty-second day of the year; so the suggestion that I spend most of my time in Canberra is clearly untrue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I have.
—The honourable member may proceed.
—An article appeared in today's Australian headlined `Factional intrigue passes unnoticed in the land of nod'. This was in the `View from the gallery' section by Bill Goff. The article stated:

SPEECH.PARA: An otherwise sleepy Question Time was enlivened yesterday by a mischievous intervention from the outgoing Labor Member for Robertson, Barry Cohen.
Mr Cohen seems more interested these days in selling books and telling jokes than in the fortunes of the colleagues who might have treated him badly when he was dropped from the ministry.
There was not much humour in the situation when, after several enthusiastic attempts, he attracted the Speaker's eye for a question to acting Treasurer John Dawkins.

His question began with a reference to the many young people who had bought land after September 1985-a significant date in the life of the capital gains tax-with the intention of building a house on that land.
Was it a fact, he asked, that such young people who did not proceed with their plans for reasons such as not going on with their marriage were subject to capital gains tax when they sold their land?
It was a more difficult teaser than anything the Opposition put to the Government on the day. It also appeared to be genuinely without notice.
Mr Dawkins gave an answer that was totally justified on the surface, but fairly reeked of the factional intrigue which saw the New South Wales ALP Right dump Cohen from the ministry two years ago.
I ask honourable members to listen to the reply. The article continued:
Dawkins, a member of the Centre Left, which has never established much of a hold in New South Wales, clearly saw the chance to duck the question.
`Madam Speaker', he said, `I would be happy to refer the Honourable Member's question to the Treasurer on his return'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Will the honourable member now show the House where he has been misrepresented?

—Yes, Madam Speaker. I am sick and tired, every time I stand in this House to ask a question, of somebody in the gallery interpreting it as some sort of a get square in relation to what happened to me two years ago. The matter to which the question related was raised with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on two occasions by letter and it was raised with the Acting Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) last week. Has it ever occurred to anyone that I might be actually interested in the issue?
—Order! The Chair has been patient, but my patience has come to an end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do, Madam Speaker.
—He may proceed.

—On 25 May the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Ray) issued a statement which was headed `Senior Liberal attacks immigration'. The first paragraph of that press release stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Liberal Party has renewed its attack on immigration to Australia.
These remarks related to a press release that I put out myself the previous day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Was the honourable member's name mentioned in the press release?

—Yes, all the way through the press release. In order to let the House get on with other business, I will not do what the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) did and read out the whole thing. However, first of all let me say that it is totally untrue for the Minister to say that I am opposed to immigration. Indeed, I am proud to say that, as immigration Minister, my father brought 620,000 migrants to Australia himself. My statement had called for an increase in the pool of domestic savings in order to stop immigration exacerbating our foreign debt problem. The Minister's statement went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: It concerns me considerably to see Liberal parliamentarians-
and he was obviously including me in this-
set one group of Australians against another group in this way.
That is a disgraceful, irresponsible and dishonest thing to say, and the Minister stands condemned for that sort of press statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member has made his point.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Hawke Government to make the necessary changes in economic policy to reduce our exposure to foreign debt and to provide the basis for a sustainable improvement in living standards.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I have written this letter on behalf of the Opposition to enable us to discuss matters which have been debated in this Parliament for some time and which were put before us yesterday in such a very clear manner by the shadow Treasurer. I also felt that this would be an opportunity for a significant event if the bait were taken-and it has been taken. For the first time, since the last election at least, the man at the table, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), is prepared to have a debate with the Opposition on the economy as a matter of public importance. One might think that he is here because of the crippling state of the economy, but every member of this Parliament knows that this ego-driven man, harmed and hurt by the reviews of the two debates last week, has felt compelled to come into the chamber today and debate the issue. This is the first time that the Prime Minister has participated, and it is no coincidence that the dent in his ego last week has brought this about.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing I will ask the Prime Minister is whether he can tell us why he has not requested the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to return to Australia-at least at the end of the current ministerial council meeting of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD).

If the Prime Minister regards a sojourn through the Soviet Union as being more important than the Treasurer executing his duties at home, he will allow him to go to the Soviet Union. However, if he regards the reality of the debt figure released yesterday-which exceeds $100 billion-as being important enough to warrant the Treasurer executing his duties, he will say, `Yes, I am bringing him back'. We will get our answer and we know in advance what it will be. The reason for the Opposition's bringing on this debate is not merely to bring in the Prime Minister as a participant in the chamber in a real debate, but also it is due to the fact that yesterday's announcement that Australia's net foreign debt had exceeded $100 billion is a sharp reminder of the state of the economy under Labor, that is, under this Prime Minister.

In March 1983 our net foreign debt was less than 14 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP). It is now over 31 per cent of GDP. I recommend that honourable members look at a table headed `Australia's Billowing Foreign Debt' in today's Australian Financial Review, and the contrast between now and only nine years ago. In 1979-80 the net debt was 5.7 per cent of GDP; now, in this financial year, 1988-89, it is 31 per cent. Honourable members will see that for the last four years it has been stuck at over 30 per cent. There has been no progress and restraint has been urged by the Government without result.

This has taken place in a climate in which the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia has said that there has been a `major miscalculation' in economic management. Never in the history of our country has the Governor of the Reserve Bank been forced to admit that there has been a major miscalculation in economic management. The reality is that the majority of Australians actually did not need the Governor to tell them that. They have felt it. They have copped it as inflation and interest rates have wound up. Put simply, if one wants to use a different expression from that used by the Governor of the Reserve Bank, the Government has blown it. It has done the unthinkable. It is building up Australia's foreign debt at an ever-increasing rate. It is building up Australia's foreign debt at a time of record high commodity prices. One could comprehend a nation such as Australia, which requires profitable trade in its commodities, being in difficulty if the commodity market were down, but at a time of record commodity prices we have record debt.

Let me draw attention to three facts only. Despite the arrogance and disdain of this Government for what is transpiring, at least three salient facts ought to be put. Fact one is that the current account deficit for August of this financial year was the worst on record. It was followed by the worst on record in October, the worst on record in November and the worst on record in January, February and March. The latest figures, namely those for April, gave the Government cause for a sigh of relief. The April figures were not the worst on record; they were the second worst on record. We have had six months of the worst current account deficit figures on record and, in the seventh month, the second worst on record. Yet the current occupant of the Prime Ministership went to a press conference yesterday and said-not under the guise of specific evidence; without any at all, but with the normal recourse to hyperbole that we are becoming accustomed to-that real living standards will rise. That observation ought to be consigned to the same basket as his undertaking earlier this year that interest rates would fall.

Fact two is that, even after the fiddle with the consumer price index, inflation is running at about 7 per cent compared with the Treasurer's forecast of 4.5 per cent by June this year. Fact three is that home mortgage interest rates were 13.5 per cent in June last year and are now 17 per cent. This is despite the fact that at around the beginning of this year, in February, when they increased to 15 per cent the current occupant of the Prime Ministership said that they would fall. The recent spate of distressing economic statistics comes after years of restraint for many in the community-years which I would call restraint without results.

To rub salt into the wounds, this Government has absolutely no sense of urgency. It has not changed policy to correct the situation. It has just implemented a tighter and tighter monetary policy-that blunt instrument that raises interest rates, ruins the chances for young couples to buy their own homes and threatens to abort the recent, albeit long overdue, pick-up in investment. The outlook for next year is for another huge current account deficit, a stubbornly high inflation rate and continued high interest rates.

This is a very serious charge to make against the Government. It has grossly mismanaged the economy. It has hiked interest rates. It has plunged Australia into foreign debt when we have had one of the longest sustained recoveries in the world economy and when we have had record high commodity prices. That is in stark contrast to the banana republic period in 1986 when our terms of trade fell sharply. One would have expected our economic performance to have improved. The Government has driven Australia backwards-backwards on the balance of payments, backwards on foreign debt, backwards on inflation, backwards on interest rates and backwards on the living standards of the overwhelming majority of Australians.

This Australia of ours is not the nation it was when this Government was elected. To the smart alec who wishes to say, `No, it is a better one', I say, `Test it out with the majority who find it difficult to meet the basic requirements of residing in this community-food, clothing, health, education and, above all, housing, which is crippling the majority of Australians today'.

The Government has the hide, in circumstances where it is relying on but one economic lever, as it puts it, or instrument, namely monetary policy, to say that this Opposition has no policies. I will tell the Government what the Opposition would do if faced with these problems. We make no bones about it. We would have, not a draconian, but a tighter fiscal policy. That the Government will not do. We would have a wages policy to ensure that we were directing our efforts on that front towards increased competition and productivity that reflected productivity at either the enterprise or the industry level. Wage increases would be set in relation to productivity increases, and where people did not wish to negotiate we would amend the Industrial Relations Act to ensure that the Industrial Relations Commission took account of productivity, international competitiveness, inflation and employment. The Government cannot do that.

As I said at a press conference, with those two settings in place we would then have a steadier monetary policy to bring down inflation and interest rates. The Government will not move on fiscal policy; it cannot move on wages policy; it will not move on monetary policy; and it cannot go into the area of micro-economic reform which is essential for Australia if we are to cope with the international environment of competitiveness that we face these days.

Tonight this Government will bring down a statement on coastal shipping and the waterfront. Senator Button, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, has already indicated that it is inadequate. Simply to deal with coastal shipping and the waterfront, whilst a gigantic step forward, ignores the other areas that we are prepared to advance across on behalf of the great trading industries in this country to ensure that the non-trading industries that serve them-such as railways, road transport, power generation and telecommunications-bring about the essential reforms that are required. The Government will not do that because it cannot do that.

Over and above that, we have our schedule of privatisation, the benefits of which the Government has talked about, which the Government has recognised as needing to be undertaken, but which the Government could not get through the Labor Party Conference outside this elected chamber. Whether it is on fiscal policy, wages policy, monetary policy or the whole area of micro-economic reform, including privatisation, the Government has not a coordinated approach. We have. We know, on the best and most objective of economic advice, that our approach will work.

Under the Government we are reliant solely on the one blunt instrument-monetary policy. Essentially, members of the Government are sitting on their hands. The Government just raises interest rates. It makes all sorts of vacuous statements about micro-economic reform. The reality is that at the end of the day the Government has created a nation-a nation which was viewed as one of the most egalitarian in the world-for the very few. That might cheer the Prime Minister and some of his mates, but it does not cheer the overwhelming majority of Australians who have suffered at the hands of the Government's arrogance and disdain in failing to address, either at the micro-level or at the macro-level, the policies that are required to turn Australia around.

The foreign debt has quadrupled, and the Prime Minister goes before a press conference and tells people that their standard of living will rise. There has been a rejigging of tax rates-a form of tax reform without any substantive tax relief. The Government has been unable to tackle inflation and thereby reduce interest rates. The Government has ensured that, tragically, standards of living continue to fall until the Opposition returns to government with its wide-ranging set of coordinated programs which are essential to Australia's economic recovery. The Government will continue to rely, with the disdain that we have noticed, on the blunt instrument of monetary policy which forces interest rates higher and higher.

I would love to conclude on the note that I felt confident I would get the message to the Prime Minister so that he would understand that his responsibility is not just to the labour movement and to the Labor Party but that he occupies the highest position in the land with a responsibility to all Australians. I abandoned that notion some time ago because, in the abject manner in which he has pursued economic policy, he has revealed himself as a sectional Prime Minister prepared to depress living standards in this country to a level never before known.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me at the outset put some facts on the table as distinct from the prejudices and the emotion of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock). Since 1983 there has been a dramatic change in this country to create a more egalitarian society. Let me just go--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition was heard in silence. The Prime Minister should be also.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek to answer the speech of the Leader of the Opposition. I hope that I will be given the opportunity to do that in silence. The Leader of the Opposition refers to the question of egalitarianism. Let me take three areas in which I will nail the stupidity of the Leader of the Opposition-three areas which he mentioned in passing: education, taxation and health.
—Pip, pip.
—I warn the honourable member for Adelaide.

—When Opposition members walked out of government in 1983 so many things were left to judge them by as people who had been derelict in their duty of looking after the interests of this country that it was almost impossible to pick the item about which we could say, `This is the worst indictment'. If I had to choose, it would be in the area of education. In the last five years of the Opposition's tenure of government in this country, the participation rate in education moved up by one percentage point, from 35 per cent to 36 per cent. The former Government walked out of office with one of the lowest education retention rates anywhere in the developed world. That meant that the children in this country who came from the homes of low to middle income families had a significantly lower chance of participating in the education system.

SPEECH.PARA: If there is one issue which will determine whether there is something approaching egalitarianism in this country, it is the policy of the government in determining whether kids, from whatever level of family income, are able to stay on in the education system. In the former Government's last five years in office, the participation rate rose from 35 per cent to 36 per cent. When we came to office we said, `There will be an end to this'. If there is one characteristic of a decent society, a society which talks about equality of opportunity, it is the government's attitude to giving the kids the chance of going through the education system.

I ask that the comparison be made between a one per cent increase in the participation rate in the last five years of the conservative Government and an increase from 36 per cent to 58 per cent-a 22 per cent increase-in the participation rate under this Government. That goes right to the heart of egalitarianism. If there is one thing in any society which goes to the question of equality of opportunity, it is whether our children are to have an equal opportunity of being in the education system and of having their talents developed. That is the comparison: a one per cent increase in the participation rate in the former Government's last five years of office; in ours, a 22 per cent increase already.

I turn now to health. The Opposition walked out of office leaving two million of our fellow Australians-the people for whom members of the Opposition now shed crocodile tears-with no health cover at all. Those people were faced with the tragedy of expenses which may arise in regard to medical or hospital treatment. Out of a population of fewer than 16 million, two million Australians had hovering over their heads at all times the possible tragedy of unmeetable expenses in the medical and hospital areas. In one stroke, the Government removed that tragedy, that spectre which haunted two million of our fellow Australians, by producing a situation where not one of our fellow Australians any longer has that spectre over him.

Let me go to the question of taxation. As I had cause to say yesterday, the former Government walked out of office leaving the most dilapidated, inequitable taxation system to be found anywhere in the Western world. That is not my judgment alone. It is the judgment of independent people. It is the judgment of the former Government's own Royal Commissioner who was appointed because the former Government sought to bash the trade unions. But its own Royal Commissioner, Commissioner Costigan, said after the former Government's period in office that the fastest growing industry in Australia was the tax avoidance industry. The Opposition was so concerned about the interests of ordinary Australians that, as Professor Mathews of the Australian National University-not the Australian Labor Party-said, under the former Government it had become a question of choice as to whether the wealthy would pay their tax. That is how much disregard the former Government had. It was a vandal in regard to the conduct of taxation policy. It was no wonder that the former Government walked out of office with a top tax rate of 60c in the dollar. It was not collected from those who should pay. It was imposing a burden upon the ordinary working men and women of this country. Those people cannot hire tax lawyers and accountants. Every week or fortnight they pay their tax. The former Government let the people with the greatest capacity to pay avoid paying.
Let us take the three central areas of education, health and taxation. The former Government inflicted a travesty of justice upon this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Cook Islands?
—I warn the honourable member for O'Connor.

—The Leader of the Opposition has talked about what has happened to the economy. I am glad he has. I want to spend the rest of my time giving a detailed analysis of what the Government has done and comparing it with what the former Government did. The Leader of the Opposition started his speech by going back to 1983. Under the former Government the current account deficit was worse than it is now. In 1981-82 the current account deficit was around 6 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP). In 1988-89 it will be between 4 1/2 per cent and 5 per cent. When talking about the current account deficit, the Leader of the Opposition lists off the bad months and says, `Look what has been happening to the current account deficit'. He cannot avoid the fact because it is indisputable. In the former Government's last year in office the current account deficit, as a percentage of GDP, was worse than it is now. So do not give us this nonsense, reeling off the August, September, October, November and December figures. It is about the only thing that the Leader of the Opposition can get in sequence. He cannot get his facts right.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us talk about what has happened to the economy and whether there is growth and whether things are being done to benefit ordinary Australians. Do honourable members opposite know what their achievement was? It had never before been equalled. No government in the history of this country had been able to achieve what they uniquely did. At one and the same go they had double digit unemployment and double digit inflation. That is what we inherited-a preceding 12-month period with 250,000 of our fellow Australians thrown onto the unemployment scrapheap under the vandalist policies of those opposite. For the first time there was negative growth in this country. As they mismanaged the Australian economy, and as they reaped the most inegalitarian society this country had seen, they stopped the economy in its tracks, something that no-one had ever done before.

Let me contrast the performance of this Government with what honourable members opposite did with the economy. What we did was to say, when we came into office, `First of all, we will start to remove this blot of an inegalitarian society which you foisted upon us', and we did that in the ways I have indicated, in regard to education, taxation and health. Most importantly, we said that we would get Australians back to work. In the last 12 months of the previous Government a quarter of a million people were thrown onto the unemployment scrapheap. What did we do? I can tell honourable members opposite what we did. They do not like to hear the facts, but they have no answer to them. In our term of office we have put 1.4 million of our fellow Australians back into work. There are two things to be said about that figure, a staggering figure-of 1.4 million of our fellow Australians put back to work. The first thing to be said is that it represents a rate of job creation that is four times faster than the rate of job creation in the Liberal term of office. Let those opposite dwell upon that. We have created jobs for Australians four times faster than they did. If they want to talk about an egalitarian society, if they want to remove the problems of a situation in which people are not able to look after themselves, the first thing they must do is to create jobs for them-and we have created jobs four times faster than they did.

The second thing to be said about that statistic is that that rate of job creation is more than twice as fast as that in the rest of the world. If we want a judgment about the appropriateness of our economic policies, let us look at the judgments that have been made recently and last year by the people who have the authority and the responsibility to look at the conduct of economic policy in countries around the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Moody's.

—The Leader of the Opposition says `Moody's'. I will give him Moody's. He should look at every other statement that has been made since the statement by Moody's Investor Services Inc. came out. Standard and Poor's, the Australian rating agency-everyone has come out and contradicted Moody's. The Leader of the Opposition quotes Moody's because he wants to do something that should make him despised by all Australians. He wants to seize upon the one statement which would knock his country and which would say of Australia, `Australia is down.' He picks on the one-Moody's-that puts his country down. Obviously, if we are to ask who the Opposition will look at, we must answer that it will look at Moody's. Why? Because Moody's puts Australia down. That is what the Opposition wants-to put Australia down. Against the Opposition's Moody's which puts Australia down, I will give it Standard and Poor's and the statement by Bill Chambers, the Australian analyst for Standard and Poor's. While honourable members opposite want to grab Moody's because it puts Australia down, I will give them Standard and Poor's. Let us see what the Australian analyst says about this. On the Australian Broadcasting Commission AM program yesterday, the announcer, talking about Bill Chambers of Standard and Poor's, said:

SPEECH.PARA: On general economic policy, he claimed the Government was broadly on track, adding that in reality there's very little argument about the direction of policy.

That is the view of Standard and Poor's. But, of course, this miserable Opposition would not refer to Standard and Poor's. Why? Because Standard and Poor's says good things about the country. It says good things about Australia and about the conduct of economic policy. But the miserable people opposite, inheriting the mantle of their previous Leader, who said, `The times will suit me', have seen their new Leader try to grab hold of Moody's because it puts his country down. If they want to go on with that sort of tactic of putting their country down, they can do it. I can tell them that poll results such as they saw in yesterday's Bulletin, which show that they have already been rejected and repudiated by the Australian people, will get worse and worse. I will have Deep Throat coming to me in the next couple of months telling me what the Howard count is. At the moment I am told that it is 25, but it will rise rapidly, if honourable members opposite go on like this. According to Deep Throat, it will only be a question of when, not if.

Having disposed of that matter, let me go to the question of the debt. The debt is something that has excited honourable members opposite. We are not trying to say that the issue of the debt is something that we ignore or run away from; it is something that must be faced up to. But let us analyse it. Honourable members opposite will not want to do that. What they have tried to do is mischievously and callously to frighten the Australian people about this issue of debt. They take the figure of just over $100 billion of net foreign debt, and then they take the number of households in the country, divide that into the first figure, and say to the poor people of Australia, `Look, you are up for that enormous amount of money. That is the debt with which you are saddled.' It is a lie; it is a gross misrepresentation, and everyone who knows anything about economics knows that. How the good, decent, gentle Professor Edwards could sit back and accept that sort of nonsense, I would not know, because the fact is that--

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. Is it correct for Mr Hawke to refer to me as `Professor Edwards' rather then `the honourable member for Berowra'?
—Order! The Prime Minister should refer to Professor Edwards as the honourable member for Berowra and the honourable member should refer to Mr Hawke as the Prime Minister.

—I was trying to conjure up the fact that the honourable member for Berowra has a professional capacity that is singularly lacking in most other members of the Opposition. He knows the fact. What is the fact? Of the net debt of just over $100 billion, 61 per cent is owed by the private sector. As far as this Government is concerned, no debt is owed by the Commonwealth Government. The people of Australia have no debt owed on their behalf. The debt is owed by the private sector, so however we look at it this motion has been the most pathetically conceived and delivered that I can remember in eight years in this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BLUNT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —What we got today was 1982 rhetoric in place of an answer to 1989 problems. We got the stuff we heard in 1982 and 1983, but not a policy or an answer to the problems of 1989. The evidence of that was on the faces of members on the back bench. They were glum. Of course, the marginals were out there ringing up their electorates and saying, `The votes are out there. There is not a vote for me in the chamber'. Where was the front bench? There are more frontbenchers in here now than when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) began to speak. Of course, the Whip was noticeable by his absence. He spent his time trying to get Government members into the chamber. `Come in and listen to the Prime Minister', he said, but they would not come. They kept saying, `No, I would rather be out here. There are no votes for me in the chamber. Don't ask me to go into the electorate and defend the policies of this Government'.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. The honourable member has reflected upon the Whip in the House. I was here all of the time, sitting on the front bench, and the honourable member has put it over the broadcast that I was not in the chamber.
—Order! There is no point of order. Before the Leader of the National Party continues, honourable members on my right and left might come to order.

—I can understand the sensitivity of the Government. Let us deal with the facts, because the Prime Minister did not. Let us deal with the Government's own standards: people are entitled to be judged by their own standards. Let us quote the Treasurer (Mr Keating), who is absent; he is out buying clocks. Let us address what the Treasurer said just after the last election. That is what we will address in this debate, because this debate is about foreign debt; it is about economic policy; it is about management, something that the Acting Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) is trying to learn about rapidly.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the Government the Treasurer said:
. . . is winning on inflation . . .
What have we got? We have an inflation rate of 7 per cent but the forecast was 4 1/2 per cent. He said:
. . . its winning on interest rates . . .
What are interest rates now? They are 17 per cent if one is buying a house and 23 per cent if one is running a business and they are rising. The Treasurer said:
. . . its winning on growth and is winning on the most important thing of all the current account deficit and our external debt.

That is what the Treasurer said-`We are winning'. He promptly left the country. Where is he when the Government is about to debate this issue? He is in Leningrad or Paris or somewhere. The Prime Minister might not want to acknowledge or even be measured against his Treasurer's statement because he knows that the Treasurer seeks to replace him. Let us measure the Prime Minister against his own statements. This statement was made in April 1988:
But what I'm saying to the workers of this country, and what the Treasurer, Paul Keating, is saying, is that the worst of that time is over. . .
The worst of that time is over? My goodness! He goes on:
Looking at this next year, and the year after that, we will be able to maintain and gradually improve standards.

That is just absolute pious rubbish. He does not believe it and he should be condemned for saying it. The Government hopes that on the last day of this Parliament it will be able to escape from this place and the backbenchers will be able to go back to their electorates. The Prime Minister will be able to visit three shopping centres a week and gladhand the community. At some point in the future, when he asks people to vote for him, he hopes that they will. Let me tell the Prime Minister and the backbenchers that when they go out into the electorate the people might be there but they are not going to be smiling. They are angry. They have to pay the mortgage rate that keeps going up. They are going to have a series of questions. They deserve answers to those questions.

The first question that the Prime Minister will get the first time he walks into a shopping centre is, `Why is my mortgage rate so high? Why can't I send the kids on a school excursion because I have got to pay the mortgage rate?'. There will be other questions: Why is the dollar behaving like a yoyo? Why is the current account deficit more than we spend on roads? Why is inflation 7 per cent after the Government has fiddled the consumer price index (CPI)? What would it be if the Government had not fiddled it a few times? Why is the inflation rate applying to goods on the supermarket shelves more than 10 or 12 per cent? What is this rubbish about a 7 per cent inflation rate and what about this ridiculous forecast of 4 1/2 per cent? That is what members of the Government will get when they go back to their electorates. They should not kid themselves that they will not. They know they will. They get it every day and they get it in the mail. We all do. Every time we go to our electorates people tell us of their concerns. They are worried.

Let me say something else to honourable members. It is what we all know. Australia today is not the Australia that we had in 1982. Australia today is the creation of two men-Bob Hawke and Paul Keating. One of them likes the place so much that he cannot get to Leningrad fast enough. People understand exactly why we have the country we have today. It is because of the policies of this Government, a government that has reduced the value of our dollar by 50 per cent against the yen in the time that it has been in power.

We are discounting our assets, selling at a discount of 50c in the dollar to people who want to invest in this country. We are going backwards. The great ploy of this Government was the tax cuts in the April economic statement. The reality is that inflation and bracket creep mean that even with the tax cuts the Government has offered-cuts that spend $5 billion worth of surplus-in one year's time people will still need an increase of $56 a week in income to be where they were when this Government took over. That is an extra $3,000 a year in 12 months time, after the tax cuts, just to be where they were when this Government came to power.

The Prime Minister's speech was long on rhetoric and short on facts. He failed to acknowledge that this debate is about foreign debt. Let us talk about the facts of foreign debt. Foreign debt has increased from $95 billion at the end of December to over $103 billion when the Statistician brought the figures out the other day. That is over $10 billion in the past year. It is four times the level of debt that this Government had when it came to office. Australia's capacity to deal with that debt is what is worrying everybody. The Acting Treasurer may be sitting there shuffling through his papers but when he goes to the shopping centres-if he ever does-people are going to say, `What is this debt?'. It is $6,000 a person or $24,000 a household. In the time that we are talking here it goes up by $90,000 a minute. What will the Acting Treasurer's answer be-or is he hoping that Mr Keating will be back in the country by then and will be handling the whole issue? The Government's capacity to handle that debt level is the worrying thing. There is no recognition of it on the part of the Government.

In 1983 interest payments on our foreign debt as a percentage of exports were 9.2 per cent. Today they are 17.9 per cent. They have doubled. But another measure is even more frightening. It now requires 62 per cent of our export earnings to service that debt. These are numbers. Perhaps if we put them into tangible examples honourable members will understand just how serious the situation is. Interest payments in the past nine months have added about $6.6 billion to our foreign debt but our export earnings from our major industries have got to be seen against that. The extra interest is $6.6 billion. Total wool exports last year earned $5.7 billion-less than the interest for six months. Meat only brings in $2.5 billion. Grain brings in $2.1 billion. One might say, `What about the minerals and energy sector?' The total value of exports of those resources was only $7.2 billion. The margin between the value of that and the interest payments is getting narrower every month.

The Government knows that and knows that there is a major problem. It knows that the debt servicing ratio is worse than that of any other Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development country. It knows the ratio is worse than some Third World countries-not the countries the Treasurer keeps picking on but some of the ones that people recognise have got a fundamental problem-countries such as Colombia, Venezuela, Indonesia and the Philippines. Heaven only knows what it is like when our country gets compared with those countries.

It is the last day of this session of Parliament but it is also five minutes to midnight for this economy. It is also five minutes to midnight for the Government. The Acting Treasurer knows exactly what the problem is. The Government knows that, because it cannot deal with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, it has only got one arm of policy, and that is monetary policy. It knows what the consequences of using that are. It knows how unselective that policy is. It knows that we desperately need to do something about fiscal policy and address the wages policy question. But it cannot do so. The Government knows it also needs to bring to an end to the featherbedding that exists in our economy. It needs to address the competitiveness of our economy. It needs to go down the track of exposing protected sectors of the economy to international competition. But the Government knows it cannot do it. The Acting Treasurer knows he has got no answers and he knows that his Government is doomed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training and Acting Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) was trying to make the point that this is a serious debate. To sustain that argument he should have found someone a bit more competent and effective than the Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), to participate in this debate. I have been sitting here patiently trying to find exactly what the Opposition wants to debate. Let us go back to the terms of the motion which the Opposition put before the House. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Hawke Government to make the necessary changes in economic policy to reduce our exposure to foreign debt and to provide the basis for a sustainable improvement in living standards.

The Opposition is saying to us that we ought to make changes to policy. Yet where have the suggestions been as to how we might change policy? It is very well known where our policy is. This question about the debt is not something which the Opposition has had to point out to us; it is a question which we have referred to constantly. It remains the focal point of where our policy is directed. We recognise that the debt is too large, and that is why all our arms of policy are dedicated singlemindedly towards first of all stabilising the debt and then reducing it. It should be unnecessary for me to repeat what our policy is but again and again we have a farrago of misrepresentation from the Opposition, using total untruths in relation to what our policy is and trying to exaggerate massively the consequences for Australia of the statistics which have become available in recent times.

The arms of policy which we are using are quite clearly those of fiscal policy. Not only have we got fiscal policy extremely tight as a result of decisions which we took in the context of the April statement, but even since the April statement we have further tightened fiscal policy. As a result of the meeting we had with the States we have reduced the public sector borrowing requirement by a further $2.7 billion to the point where the net public sector borrowing requirement has gone into surplus. Where is the Opposition's policy in relation to that matter?

Fiscal policy is an extremely important arm of policy; it is not, as the Opposition would have it, that we are relying only on monetary policy. Fiscal policy has always been central to the approach this Government has taken. If one looks around the world, one sees that we have a peerless record in terms of being able to run a tight fiscal policy. We have been running a tighter fiscal policy and have been more successful in turning around fiscal policy than any other country in the world. That is a matter which the Opposition will not acknowledge because it knows that its record in this area was so abominable and appalling. Our fiscal policy is even tighter than that which was announced in the April statement.

We have made it quite clear that we have had to resort to the tightening of monetary policy because demand in the economy is outstripping the ability of the economy to produce. That has meant an increase in the inflow of imports; therefore, we have to diminish demand in order to curtail that level of imports. That is not a permanent feature. We have said that we will keep monetary policy tight until such time as there begins to be a turnaround on the imports side.

Wages policy remains the third important arm of policy that we are employing to manage the economy. The Opposition likes to deride the fact that we have a close relationship with the trade union movement. That close relationship has resulted in our being able to reach an agreement with the trade union movement to restrain wages in the coming year to just 6.5 per cent, at a time when there is very strong demand in the economy. When those circumstances existed in the past, particularly under the policies of the Opposition, we saw wages blow out in a way that caused a recession.

The Opposition says in its matter of public importance that we have to make the necessary changes. What changes does it suggest? We had a few feeble suggestions from the Leader of the Opposition. He had the nerve to refer to Government members as being vacuous. I have never heard a more vacuous speech than that of the Leader of the Opposition. It was particularly vacuous when he came to the question of what his policy would be in the unlikely event that he ever becomes Prime Minister. The Leader of the Opposition said that there should be tighter fiscal policy. How much tighter? Has he decided to abandon his shadow Treasurer who, I notice, has been sidelined in this particular debate? The Opposition has gone to a lot of trouble to sideline the shadow Treasurer, but the shadow Treasurer has said that the tightening of fiscal policy should amount to at least $5.5 billion. Despite the fact that the Opposition has yet to identify where that $5.5 billion will come from, that will be its target. The test, when the Opposition comes out with its detailed policy, will be how to make up that $5.5 billion that the shadow Treasurer says, in his view, is necessary to neutralise the tax cuts.

What is the Opposition's tax cut policy? If the Opposition wants tighter fiscal policy, would it really abandon the tax cuts, as Senator Stone, the shadow Finance Minister, has said? Would the Opposition commit itself to retaining those tax cuts? None of those matters was raised; we just heard a throwaway line about tighter fiscal policy.

The Leader of the Opposition talked about linking wages to productivity and decentralising the process of wage fixation in this country. The Opposition thinks that, as a result, it would get wages flexibility. If it thinks that, I can tell it in which direction the flexibility would go; it would go up very strongly. That is the fatal flaw in the Opposition's approach, because it simply does not have a clue about how to run that kind of wages policy, how to restrain a wages blow-out of the kind that occurred in 1982 when the Opposition was last in charge of wages policy.

The Leader of the Opposition went on to talk about micro-economic reform, as if this were something that he had just discovered. The three examples he used of railways, roads and electricity are, of course, matters which are firmly in the hands of the States. Those are not matters which are central to Commonwealth Government policy. Perhaps, therefore, he should have gone a stage further and said what he would do to force changes on the States in those areas.

There was one missing component in the recitation of what passes for policy on the part of the Leader of the Opposition; that is, that the Opposition's real objective is to screw this economy into the ground, to bring about the recession which, in the end, is the only instrument it has to deal with the current circumstances. The Opposition would kill demand by forcing the economy into recession and forcing hundreds of thousands of Australians back onto the dole. We have, of course, rescued some 300,000 families from the dole queues and put them back in the work force. That has been a major contribution to the increase in living standards that Opposition members have decided is a new discovery of theirs.

These questions must be addressed to the Opposition. It has called upon us to make the necessary changes, but when it comes to getting any sensible suggestions from the Opposition about what those changes might be, all we get, once again, are blank page promises that some time in the never-never it will come up with some kind of suggestions. In the meantime, the Opposition can only resort to disparaging the Australian economy and disparaging Australia in the eyes of the world. The Opposition might have lost confidence in Australia, but we have not and will not.

This is a very unsatisfactory situation and demeaning of the dignity of this House, but we persist with it. Some of my colleagues may be more fortunate than I in that regard and they may well stay away. I am not sure how normal we will be able to make that day; we will make it as normal as possible.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL MATTERS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters I present the Committee's report entitled The 1987 Federal Election, which incorporates two dissenting reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Late in 1987 the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters received a reference from the then Minister for Home Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, to inquire into:

SPEECH.PARA: all aspects of the conduct of elections for the Parliament of the Commonwealth including legislation governing and the operation of the Australian Electoral Commission.

The Committee's predecessor, the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, has reported on previous elections. This report concerns the conduct of the 1987 Federal election and is the product of a committee representing both Houses of this Parliament and all shades of political opinion. This report contains over 50 recommendations which will bring about reform and improvement in Australia's electoral system. With the exception of the small number referred to in the minority comments, the recommendations were unanimous. I would like to place on record my appreciation to all members of the Committee for their diligence and constructive contributions. The provision of free time for political advertising will be examined in a separate report which will be released in several weeks.

I now turn to some of the Committee's recommendations in this report. A number of submissions received expressed concern about electoral fraud, particularly the accuracy of the rolls and the possibility of cemetery voting, multiple voting and impersonation. The Committee examined allegations of electoral fraud but was unable to obtain any factual evidence to support them. In one case the allegations turned out to be based on hearsay evidence and were anecdotal in nature. Senator Bishop's allegations about cemetery voting in the Castlereagh by-election were found by the New South Wales Cundy inquiry to be `without substance'.

While no evidence of organised electoral fraud was obtained, the Committee has suggested a number of ways to improve the accuracy of the rolls. Some members of the Committee have called for the introduction of locality voting which would allow electors to cast ordinary votes at only one polling place in their electorate. Prior to 1984 electors had to vote within their subdivision. Voters who attended a polling booth within their electorate, but outside their subdivision, were forced to cast a declaration or absentee vote. In the view of the majority of the Committee locality voting would result in large numbers of electors having to cast declaration votes increasing congestion at booths and dissatisfaction and confusion amongst electors.

Another suggestion was that a computerised electoral role be introduced to prevent multiple voting. This would require an on-line terminal at every table in every polling booth in every electorate and, in our view, would be prohibitively expensive. The Cundy inquiry calculated that it would cost New South Wales alone more than $20m to introduce such a system. Given the seriousness of allegations of electoral fraud, the Committee has recommended a substantial increase in the penalties for electoral fraud. For example, the Committee recommends that for multiple voting and impersonation the penalties set at $1,000 or six months imprisonment should be increased to $12,000 and/or two years maximum imprisonment. This hike in penalties reflects the fact that electoral penalties are well overdue for review. The recommendation will also put Australia in line with other countries which have a history of much higher penalties for electoral fraud than we do here in Australia.

Since the Commonwealth Electoral Act was amended in 1984 only Australian citizens have been eligible to nominate for election to the Commonwealth Parliament. British citizens enrolled before 1984 are eligible to vote but not eligible to nominate unless they become naturalised citizens. After being declared elected to the Senate in 1987 Mr Robert Wood was found to be in this category, although he believed he was an Australian citizen at the time of nominating. To reduce the possibility of persons who are not Australian citizens nominating, the Committee has recommended that the Commonwealth Electoral Act be amended to require candidates to declare on their nomination forms how they became Australian citizens-that is, whether by birth or naturalisation-and if naturalised where and when the ceremony took place.

The Committee rejected a proposal to excuse aged voters from compulsory voting as occurs in Victorian local government elections. The Committee believes most elderly voters would take exception to the idea and supports the continuation of uniformity for Federal, State and local voting to minimise confusion.

The Committee has received a submission from the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths) suggesting that it was in the public interest that candidates be required to declare their political affiliations when nominating. To overcome the difficulty in determining which organisations are `political', the Committee has recommended the candidates be required to declare their membership of any registered political party at the time of nominating. The Committee received a report from the Australian Electoral Commission on an audit of six divisions and was concerned at the number of errors revealed. The Committee welcomes the AEC decision to expand staff training and to conduct future audits using the strictest audit standards to ensure uniform electoral procedures are being followed throughout Australia.

Finally, on behalf of the Committee I wish to thank the Committee Secretary, Mr Trevor Rowe, and other members of the secretariat who have assisted in preparing this report, in particular, Denise Denahy, Helen Misa and Lexia Noakes. I commend the report to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-At the outset, I commend the Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), who has just spoken, on his work. It seems that committee chairmen often go unnoticed, but he has done a lot of work on this report and has handled very well what is potentially a very difficult area. I also acknowledge the work of the Committee secretariat and the Secretary, Trevor Rowe, in particular.

SPEECH.PARA: This report makes recommendations, some of which will have, hopefully, a quite large impact and others of which will have a very minimal impact. For example, as was mentioned, we made recommendations that we hope might prevent a repeat of a situation where a person not an Australian citizen was elected to the Senate. We have proposed that infringement notices be issued to people who do not vote. They should significantly speed and ease the work of the Australian Electoral Commission, even though my personal view is against compulsory voting.

We have concerns in some areas. I am one of three people on this side of the House who made a dissenting report. Our concerns relate to the three-month rule and to locality voting. The other concern that we have, which was shared-members of the Committee were unanimous about it-was the problem with additions to the roll. These three things all reflect our concern with the integrity of the electoral rolls. Questions arise with respect to what might happen immediately before an election when a large number of names are added. There are concerns about the integrity of the way declaration votes can be made and concern about the possibility of fraud. The Committee has made a recommendation about additions to the role. It is that for the next Federal election the Australian Electoral Commission conduct before the election a thorough examination of those persons added to the rolls of two marginal divisions and after the election an examination of those persons deleted from the rolls of the same division, one division to be a Government-held seat, the other to be an Opposition-held seat.

We were concerned because of the experience of members across the spectrum of the Committee. In my case, more than 2,500 people were added to the electoral roll for Chisholm between the time the election was announced and the rolls were closed. I wrote to every one of those and more than 10 per cent were returned with `Not known at this address' written on them. If that is not bad enough, a significant number of the returned envelopes had written on them things like, `Not at this address for three years' and `Not at this address for five years'. In fact, the treasurer of my electorate committee received a letter I had written to the person from whom he had bought a house five years ago. Prior to the election, this person had put himself back on the roll, giving his previous address rather than his present address. There is no check on that. We hope that by doing a thorough audit of the two divisions, we may actually quantify the extent to which this happens.

Our dissenting report relates to the three-month rule. Our concern was with a submission by Mr Trevor Owen, the Victorian Operations Director. He said that people who had left their address several years earlier but had not removed their names from the electoral roll because of the audit and review activity were allowed to cast an ordinary vote. He suggested three reasons why this might happen: because people were simply lazy; because they did not want to be found; or because they believed their vote was worth more in a marginal division. As in my division I have a majority of 500 votes, honourable members can understand my concern about that. We believe that this happens because the three-month rule was removed in 1987 and that if it were reintroduced the problem would be overcome.

The second part of our dissenting report regarded locality voting. We nearly had locality voting when we had subdivisional voting before 1984. We believe that worked very well. In fact, the Electoral Commission told us that 90 per cent of people vote at the polling booth nearest their place of residence. I was in the United States of America in October during an election campaign. A system of precinct voting is followed there, with 1,000 people to a precinct. People have to vote at a given booth. It works very well there; it would work well here and it would significantly reduce any possibility of fraud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-After the election of the Hawke Government in 1983 there were a number of very major rewrites of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Those rewrites encompassed reforms in a number of areas. A significant one was to ensure that people who were entitled to vote were able to do so and were not excluded from voting by technicalities or formalities which were included in the Electoral Act as it then stood. Since then, the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, particularly in this investigation, has looked at how those very major reforms have impacted on our voting system. A number of the recommendations of the Committee and a number of the submissions which the Committee received are concerned with the extent of the reforms and whether they may have gone too far and made it too easy to get a vote, which could lead to an incidence of fraud. A large part of the Committee's work was on that subject.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly, there is no dispute between members of the Committee and, I believe, any member of this House, that we require an electoral system which is accurate, which enables people to enrol and to vote easily, and which at the same time ensures that the result reflects the will of the people and cannot be manipulated. However, despite allegations of fraud, multiple voting, cemetery voting and things of that nature, no evidence was put forward to the Committee which suggested that such things occurred to an extent that would influence the election result in any single division. Until such time as evidence is brought forward, it is difficult for the Committee to make recommendations to attack a problem which may be a figment of the imaginations of people for whom an election result was unwelcome rather than based on fact. Nonetheless, some of the recommendations, particularly those dealing with penalties in relation to fraud, make the system more strict, as does a change in relation to people who had moved during a habitation review being able to claim a declaration vote. That field has been tightened up, as have the new audit provisions for marginal seats-government and opposition seats-which should ensure that if there is any incidence of fraud it can be picked up and severely dealt with.

On the whole, I believe that the Committee's recommendations are sound. They largely fine tune the existing electoral system. I would also like to extend my thanks to the Committee secretariat and to the other members of the Committee. It certainly was an enjoyable experience. There was good cooperation among all members and it was a very worthwhile experience to have served on this Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am delighted to be associated with this constructive report on the 1987 election. I wish to pay tribute to members of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, with whom I worked. I was not on the Committee from its inception. I replaced the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), who was the Deputy Chairman of the Committee. He has since, of course, gone on to higher things. I wish to pay tribute in particular to the Chairman, the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), who has been very cooperative. At all times he was courteous and helpful in accommodating any suggestions I made. I also wish to thank other Government members, such as the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen) and the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch), who are in the House today. I have found that they have been excellent to work with. I also wish to thank the Deputy Chairman-I had the honour of moving that he accept that position-Senator Short, as well as the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), who has already spoken. They both provided wide knowledge and diligence on matters in the report and their contributions were of enormous value. I also found the staff very cooperative and pleasant to work with.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Chisholm has already spoken on the dissenting comments. Most other issues have been canvassed in the report. I would like to comment briefly on two issues. The first is in relation to cardboard boxes, which were introduced at the last election. They have caused some concern and have been the subject of a great deal of comment in the community. This Committee has been particularly concerned with the integrity of the cardboard boxes so that no fiddling may go on. We have recommended-I think quite correctly-that relevant polling staff be given particular emphasis on assembling the boxes and emptying them in their training. This recommendation is not one we wish to see set in concrete forever. In the discussions which took place, we expressed the wish that the use of cardboard boxes, while saving the taxpayer a considerable amount of money, should be monitored. If need be, in the future, further recommendations could be made to change the situation, but at this stage they seem to be working reasonably well.
I was particularly interested in postal votes. I am delighted to see this recommendation:

Australia Post make arrangements to receive and postmark all mail addressed to the Australian Electoral Commission or officers of the Australian Electoral Commission and lodged at Post Offices up until 5.00 p.m. on the Friday immediately preceding an election. This includes mail lodged in locked mail bags.

The problem in the past has been that people who lived in remote areas in my electorate could not get their vote in, particularly if it were a short election campaign. Also, they could not have it postmarked before the election had concluded, even though they may have made their vote a week or so before. Now, as long as that vote is in the locked mail bag it will be counted, even though it may not arrive until the Monday after the election. Also, I had an anomaly in my electorate where people in the town of Bourke could put a postal vote in the post box at 4 o'clock on Friday afternoon but, because the mail closed at 2 o'clock, that mail would not be postmarked until the following Monday. Obviously, that was quite wrong. I am delighted to see that that problem has been overcome. All mail in Australia, which is posted before 5 p.m., will now have to be postmarked and those votes will count.

I am also pleased to see that the Australian Electoral Commission will have to provide full information to postal voters when they receive their forms on the procedures for making postal votes, including these special postal arrangements made by Australia Post so that they will know what they have to do and where they will stand. I think this is a big step forward in this area which was deficient before. I congratulate all who have been associated with this report and I believe it will be a very valuable one in providing a freer and fairer system in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I would very much like to thank the Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), for his excellent contribution to the Committee and for the fine way in which he handled the proceedings of the hearings and the compilation of the report. I would like to thank Mr Rowe and the members of the secretariat for their assistance. They were certainly very professional in their job and they managed to accommodate as many members as was possible, for example, in small changes to the working of the report as required.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important to note the point made by the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) in relation to the three-month rule and locality voting. These things were considered by the Committee at some length. The three-month rule has not been recommended to be reinstituted, but the polling staff has been given the power to ask whatever questions need to be asked-this is in terms of the current legislation which is before the Senate-to ascertain an enrolled person's current address.

The difficulty with the three-month rule, as some members of this House would be aware, was that it was never asked of people turning up to their own local polling booths. In the previous Committee which recommended its removal, both Sir John Carrick and I were able to say that in all the years that we had been voting-he had been voting for many more years than I-we had never been asked the question whether we had lived at that place of residence within the last three months. That question mainly seemed to apply to people who had been struck off the roll or to people seeking an absentee vote.

In the past the absentee voting provision has tended to be misapplied by polling staff. Whilst the Committee did not make a recommendation as such, it drew to the attention of the Electoral Commission the actions of polling staff in sending people who attended a polling booth near the one they were enrolled for, back to their division across the road to vote. This was not, strictly speaking, the way the Act was supposed to prevail. People ought to be able to lodge an absentee vote in whichever polling booth they turn up to, if it is not in their own division. I think this is very important, because a person going in to lodge an absentee vote may be sent away and may not actually get to a polling booth within his division. This person would then be subject to a fine. I think the polling staff ought to have a very firm instruction that it ought not proceed along these lines. I wish to say that it was a pleasure to be on the Committee. It was one of great interest and great bipartisanship, in general. The recommendations are comprehensive and well-founded and I trust that the Government will find them useful.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I will be very brief. I would hope that, in the future, the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters will address the question-which may seem like a simple matter-of whether pens or pencils ought to be made available at polling booths. Whilst one has not heard of allegations, or makes allegations of this kind, I always think there is a possibility that ballot papers can be interfered with and tampered with if pens are not used. I have a similar feeling that cardboard ballot boxes are not as substantial as they should be. They also have the potential to be tampered with. In our society and in our democracy we are remarkably fortunate to be free of corruption, but the potential is there for those who might wish to tamper with ballot papers and boxes. This is a matter which I think in future ought to be taken on board.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Dr Blewett, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Dr BLEWETT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Community Services and Health and Acting Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Bill would implement administrative assessment of child support obligations under a formula set out in the Bill. It would implement stage 2 of the child support scheme. The Bill would have an entirely prospective operation-affecting only people who separate or have a child born on or after its commencement. Under stage 2 of the child support scheme:

Procedures to obtain child support would be dramatically simplified; the level of child support obtained would be directly in line with the capacity of parents to provide it; there would be annual updating of child support levels; the processes of application for sole parent pension and for child support would be closely integrated; the right of parents to apply to the courts to resolve disputes in their particular case would be retained; the facilities for parents to make private agreements between themselves about child support would be enhanced.

The need for reform of child maintenance was identified by the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act, of which I was privileged to be a member. In 1980, only four years after the commencement of the Family Law Act, that Committee identified four key problems with the system of child maintenance: first, the levels of maintenance were inadequate; secondly, the enforcement of maintenance liabilities was ineffective; thirdly, the system of updating child maintenance liabilities was cumbersome and seldom used; and, fourthly, the maintenance and social security systems were poorly integrated. On the question of child maintenance the Joint Select Committee's major recommendation was the implementation of a scheme under which the amount a liable parent should contribute would be administratively assessed in line with his or her capacity to pay. This contribution would have gone to the Department of Social Security. Experience in other countries has shown such schemes to have limited effectiveness-only the revenue benefits so neither parent has any reason to assist in administration of the scheme. Intrusive and expensive mechanisms are therefore required to make them work. Further, because such schemes operate only when a custodian is in receipt of a pension, difficulties arise when custodians find work or repartner.

The Hawke Government therefore has not fully endorsed the approach of the Joint Select Committee. I imagine it was for similar reasons that the Fraser Government did not act to implement this aspect of the report. After the Joint Select Committee reported the next major development was the establishment by the then Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, of the national maintenance inquiry. That inquiry recommended in 1985 the establishment of a national maintenance collection agency to improve the enforcement of maintenance orders. Following work by the Family Law Council the Government decided not to proceed with the national maintenance collection agency because it would not have addressed the issues of: levels of maintenance; updating of liabilities; or interaction of the maintenance and social security systems. A more fundamental reform that synthesised the best of both the Select Committee report and the national maintenance inquiry report was required-a reform that adopted the principles of administrative assessment, integrated private and public provision for children and achieved effective collection of liabilities.

In 1986 the Government published Child Support: A Discussion Paper on Child Maintenance. It proposed a system of: setting of child support levels under a formula related to the income of parents; initial assessment under that formula to be by the Child Support Agency-part of the Australian Taxation Office; access to the courts in contentious cases; annual updating of assessment by the Child Support Agency; collection of child support liabilities by the Child Support Agency.

Following extensive public consultation, the Minister for Social Security announced in March 1987 the introduction of the child support scheme in two stages. Under stage 1 of the scheme, which commenced a year ago today, maintenance orders and agreements made, registered or approved in the courts can be enforced by the Child Support Agency. In his March 1987 statement the Minister announced that he would establish the Child Support Consultative Group, to advise the Government on a legislative formula to apply under stage 2. The group, chaired by Justice Fogarty of the Family Court of Australia, was established in May 1987. This Bill would substantially implement the report of the child support consultative group: Child Support: Formula for Australia. Justice Fogarty described the formula which would be implemented by this Bill. He said:
The formula preserves the right of parents to reach their own agreement (with suitable protection for the revenue when the custodial parent is on a pension or benefit);

It ensures that each parent has an unqualified right to have the matter determined by the court if he or she is not satisfied with the administrative assessment. It continues the right to go to court but will remove the need to do so in many cases;
At the same time it provides a method which will remove the present obligation on parents to go through expensive court proceedings and relieve the courts of the burden of many of these cases;
It provides for the automatic updating of orders annually in accordance with any changes in the financial or other circumstances of the parties;

The percentages which have been chosen have regard to evidence of the proportion of income ordinarily spent on children who live with both their parents and are aimed at achieving reasonable levels of orders proportional to income.

This approach, combined with the enforcement procedures already established under stage 1, should go a long way towards overcoming the unsatisfactory state of child support in Australia and benefit both Australian children and the Australian community generally.

Under the Bill administrative assessment of child support would be available to people having the ongoing daily care of a child from the natural or adoptive parents of the child. The Bill would apply only when the parents have a child born on or after the commencement of stage 2 of the scheme or the parents separate on or after that day; and provided that the applicant is not cohabiting with the parent against whom the claim is made. In all other cases maintenance rights and liabilities will continue to be determined under the Family Law Act. For example, applications by children in their own right would remain under the Family Law Act.
