The Government believes that implementation of the radical reforms which I have announced for the waterfront industry will bring about the restructuring necessary to generate the large productivity improvements predicted by the Inter-State Commission. In our view, these prospective productivity increases would be further enhanced by the introduction of profit sharing or employee share ownership schemes. The joint ventures initiated by the Waterside Workers Federation in some small ports have highlighted the efficiency gains to be achieved by profit sharing arrangements. Such schemes would also reinforce the concept of enterprise employment by promoting closer identification by waterside workers with their enterprise and its financial viability.

The comprehensive program I have just outlined will bring substantial and highly beneficial change to the waterfront industry. It offers benefits to the customers, the industry participants and the nation. In line with the Inter-State Commission report, the program's achievement rests substantially on the cooperation of the parties. If, however, that cooperation is not forthcoming, the industries should be under no illusions about the Government's firm commitment to achieve significant waterfront reform. I will report back to Cabinet within three months on the results of the negotiations on the in-principle agreement. If a satisfactory agreement is not achieved, we will pursue alternative measures to change these industries structurally.
Implementation of Shipping and Waterfront Reforms

As I have already mentioned, the shipping reform task force and the Inter-State Commission both recommended three-year implementation periods for the shipping and waterfront reform strategies. They also recommended independent authorities to oversee the detailed development and implementation of these reform packages. The Government has accepted this approach and will shortly establish the Shipping Industry Reform Authority (SIRA) and the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority (WIRA) which are to run for three years. Both will bear major responsibilities of overseeing and monitoring the day to day implementation by the industries of the reform plans that have been agreed to by the industry parties and by the Government. I expect both authorities to work cooperatively with the industry parties to meet the agreed objectives. Disbursement of government restructuring assistance by the authorities will be contingent upon achievement of strategy targets. Reform will have to be carried through in a systematic and comprehensive way.

The first task of the Waterfront Authority will be to supervise the negotiation of the in-principle agreement. The Authority will also monitor other industry negotiations in order to ensure that they are consistent with government requirements for an in-principle agreement and prepare for an immediate start to reforms once an agreement is signed. It will also ensure that the arrangements for recruiting new entrants will conform with government requirements.
Australian Maritime Safety Authority

To further enhance efficiency and contain costs to industry the Government has decided to establish an Australian Maritime Safety Authority. The Authority, which will replace the Maritime Operations Division in my Department, will administer the standards and procedures for the construction, equipment and safe loading of ships; the qualification and training of crews, the provision of marine navigational aids and the complementation of anti-pollution measures. Such an Authority will be more responsive to industry needs, while remaining properly accountable to government. The Authority will be controlled by a board with membership drawn from industry and government to bring appropriate management skills to the conduct of these important commercial and safety functions. The Authority will be largely self funding through user charges payable by the industry. The cost of providing and maintaining marine navigational aids is already fully recovered through light dues. Similarly, the costs of the national plan to combat oil pollution are paid for by a levy on commercial shipping. The Shipping Registration Office recovers over 80 per cent of its costs on a fee for service basis and is expected to achieve full cost recovery by 1990-91. Charges are made to recover the costs of marine survey, except where the surveys are for regulatory purposes. The Authority would also continue to provide a seamen's engagement system as long as the industry wanted it. The Government's aim is to bring the Authority into being by 1 September 1990.
Light Dues

The system of marine navigational aids provided by the Australian Government for the safe and efficient movement of vessels in Australian waters is paid for by light dues charged to commercial users. Traditionally light dues have been paid at a single rate per net registered ton. This is the practice for light dues around the world. The rate is currently 53c and has remained unchanged since 1983. Following representations from certain sectors of industry, the Government has reviewed the basis for payment of light dues and the formula used to set the rate for individual ships. It has decided that there is a case for providing relief for some of the largest vessels. The new formula provides for a sliding scale of charges by tonnage ranging from 63c to 33c per net registered ton. This will lead to a reduction of dues for large vessels of about 20 per cent and has been achieved without imposing any large increase in fees for the smaller vessels. To illustrate this point, a small coastal vessel of 200 net registered tons will pay only $20 per quarter more, while a large bulk carrier of 72,000 net registered tons will pay $6,900 per quarter less. Ships in the middle tonnage range will experience no change.
Conclusion

These measures represent the most wide-ranging package of reforms ever introduced for Australia's waterfront and shipping industries. They establish a firm basis for continuing reform. On the basis of the findings of the Inter-State Commission and the Shipping Reform Task Force, these measures will greatly increase productivity and create a more competitive environment in our shipping and waterfront industries. They will reduce costs to our exporters and import competing industries, will create new job opportunities and will bring benefits to all Australians by ensuring a more competitive economy. Such improvements are not simply desirable; they are crucial to our future economic well being. Australia has paid dearly for the benign neglect of those opposite who, during their three decades of postwar Government of this country, allowed these industries to become a burden on the nation and a barrier to economic progress. The reforms I have outlined today will ensure that these industries will have a far more positive impact on the economy in the years to come. I commend the reforms to the House. I present the following paper:
Reform of the Shipping and Waterfront Industries-Ministerial Statement, 1 June 1989.
Motion (by Mr Beazley) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Beazley)-by leave-agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the honourable member for Gilmore speaking for a period not exceeding 38 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us this evening two separate but very much interrelated issues which the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) has brought forward in his statement this evening. I know that later this evening he will bring down another statement which the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) will deal with in a more than adequate way. The two issues to which I refer relate to both the waterfront and coastal shipping services. It is my intention to commence in the opposite manner to that of the Minister in his statement this evening and to start first with the waterfront issue. Perhaps the fact that I am doing everything the other way around to the way the Government is doing it is indicative of the way we would attack the whole problem when we got into government.

SPEECH.PARA: We are extremely disappointed at this statement, because we see in it that the Government has proved to the people of Australia that it is nothing more than a pack of wimps. The statement, is very cleverly worded to ensure that the Government looks as though it is pursuing the path as approved and recommended by the Inter-State Commission. However, when one looks at the numbers of `ifs', `buts' and `maybes' written into it, one soon starts to realise that this is not a statement that pursues the full recommendations of the Inter-State Commission. Rather, it tries to wriggle out of so many of those recommendations of the Inter-State Commission.

One must remember that the Inter-State Commission's recommendations are, themselves, a position of compromise. Yet from that position of compromise the Government has further compromised those recommendations and watered them down. That is what causes us to be disappointed and what will cause so many people throughout the coastal shipping and waterfront industries of Australia great disappointment. It proves to us that this Government is prepared to put the interests of its mates ahead of the interests of the people of Australia. The mates of this Government are, of course, the members of the trade union movement. We all know that the Inter-State Commission report was released a little while ago. We have seen comments made by members of the trade union movement. I note that Mr Tas Bull is back in Australia again today with some elightening comments to add to the debate. I notice that over the last few weeks some of his colleagues have made a number of statements; statements which indicate that, unless this Government has an extreme amount of courage, it will not accept in full the recommendations of the Inter-State Commission.

In the Minister's 38-minute statement, we heard that the Government lacks the courage to implement those recommendations and lacks the courage to stand up to the trade union movement and to people such as the Tas Bull's of this world. We have been alerted to the Government's changing position from the Inter-State Commission's recommendations over the last few weeks. Comments by trade unions and by spokesmen for the Minister indicate that certain difficult issues that the Government is trying to deal with in these recommendations are being watered down to try to make them look less important to the people of this country. Tonight, the Government has proved two things: firstly, that its machinery for micro-economic reform has ground to a halt and with it, secondly, that it is not worthy to retain government. I say that because several key issues have not been adequately addressed by the Minister in his statement on the waterfront.

I will start by talking about the first issue; that is, union coverage at the waterfront. Union coverage is one of the key recommendations made by the Inter-State Commission. If we look at what the Minister has said tonight, we discover that what the Inter-State Commission said was necessary is not what this Government is doing. The Government has failed to accept the Inter-State Commission's recommendations on union coverage in bulk handling container depots and the smaller ports. These recommendations are a key element of the Commission's strategy of reducing costs and ensuring greater competition on the waterfront. They go to the very heart of the Waterside Workers Federation's monopoly power. The Government's failure to bite the bullet in this area shows its total lack of commitment to introducing greater competition when it is at the expense of a union with the support of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU).

The Government has also not adequately addressed the area of enterprise employment. Despite the Minister's assurance that the Government will ensure there will be full enterprise employment in the stevedoring industry, employers will not be able to determine their own manning levels. Employers will still be severely restricted in deciding whether to hire and fire employees. The existing prohibition on compulsory redundancy for current employees will remain and be extended to new employees for three years. Furthermore, the Government's plans do not ensure that employers are given unrestricted access to supplementary labour.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was the ISC recommendation.

—As the Minister interjected a few minutes ago in relation to compulsory redundancy for current employees that will mean, as I understand it, a moratorium for a period of three years. At present the industry is going well, but what will happen if there is a downturn in a few years time? Will those companies be compelled to keep all their employees on their books, despite the fact that they do not have the business to justify maintaining them on their work force? That is one issue which we are very concerned about.

SPEECH.PARA: The other issue relates to compulsory stand-downs. In our opinion, the Government has failed to agree to the Inter-State Commission's recommendation concerning the standing down of employees who are unable to work because of industrial action by others. The waterfront is notorious for rolling stoppages. The inability to stand down employees who cannot be usefully employed imposes a massive cost on employers. The Inter-State Commission found that employers needed speedy access to stand down provisions if there is to be effective settling of disputes and in order to ensure that unions comply with agreements. The Government's failure to agree to this key recommendation means that unions will continue to exert enormous industrial muscle on the waterfront which in the past has been used to extract restrictive work practices. So it is in those key areas that the Government has failed to pick up adequately the full intent of the recommendations by the Inter-State Commission. It is in those key areas that we say the Government has failed in its endeavours properly to reform the waterfront. It is in those key areas that we believe this whole issue of reforming the waterfront will fail.

We have had 12 inquiries into the waterfront since World War II. I think that this now makes the thirteenth inquiry. Despite the fact that the 12 inquiries have been given worthy support by Ministers of governments in the past, they have not helped to ensure that Australia's waterfront is any more productive than any other countries around the world. Is it any wonder, with the reform that is being proposed in the Minister's statement tonight, that we are not seeing anything better? We all know that the Australian Labor Party is the product of the union movements. The unions do not want change; they are part of the status quo because change equals a loss of power and privilege. It is unfortunate that the present Minister has been given the task of dealing with this particular issue because we all know that prior to coming to this place he worked for the ACTU. I wonder what the difference would have been if the former Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, had been the Minister handling the reform of the waterfront and the coastal shipping services today? I believe that his more aggressive approach would have led to a substantially different statement being brought down tonight.

The Government has failed its test in micro-economic reform. It is important to remember that the Government set its own agenda. It declared that it would be a main plank in its platform of economic management. We can all recall prior statements of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and other Ministers of this Government in the past that micro-economic reform would be one of the main issues that would be the measurement of success of this Government's management of the Australian economy. The Minister for Transport and Communications was given the task to enact this important section of micro-economic reform and I am afraid that he has failed. The Government has not given a guarantee that there will be proper progress on reform of the waterfront in his statement tonight. Over the last few months we have heard the Prime Minister make such statements. He said, `We are determined not to shirk the challenges that micro-economic reform presents us'.

The cop out today is an example of a government shirking its responsibilities. In his opening remarks the Minister stated that the Australian waterfront is hopelessly inefficient. If we compare our own waterfront to the waterfronts of Europe, we find that our productivity levels are half of its productivity levels. If we compare ourselves with the waterfronts of Asia, we find that our productivity levels only reach 40 per cent of its productivity levels. We are recognised as some of the most cost-efficient producers in the world of various products, particularly primary products today. Australia is known as having some of the most cost-efficient farmers, and yet we find it so difficult to compete in the world market simply because when we take our cost-efficient products to the waterfront we find that the cost of getting them from the Australian shores to the world market prohibits effective competition for our Australian exporters due to the inefficiencies and wastage that is incurred on our waterfront today.

It has been estimated that adequate reform on the waterfront will add $1.1 billion to the gross domestic product of Australia. This would be a crucial injection of income for the Australian economy at a time such as this. Therefore, we realise today just how crucial reform is. Our foreign debt has grown by more than $7 billion over the last quarter. It has now cracked the $100 billion mark; indeed, I think it is $103 billion. Our shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) said only today that Australia is fast going broke. Home owners are going broke and are facing record high interest rates of 17 per cent which we understand will soon rise to 18 per cent. Balance of payments deficits have hit record high levels, the current account is a disaster and inflation is up despite the attempts by the Government to fiddle with the figures. Exports are dropping and imports are rising. Moody's Investor Services Inc. is now reviewing our credit worthiness. It is reviewing it partly because of our slow pace of reform-a slow pace which will be made even slower by tonight's statement by the Minister. I am sure that tonight's statement will help impress upon Moody's why it has decided to review our credit worthiness.

At the moment Australia faces disaster. It is time for action. The Government was right to highlight the importance of micro-economic reform. It was right to target the waterfront as part of that micro-economic reform arena. We all know of the rorts that exist on our waterfront. The Waterside Workers Federation and its activities are well known to us all. The approach of the Liberal and National parties has been to support the Inter-State Commission's recommendations. We recognise that they are not perfect; we recognise that they do not fit properly every one of the aspects that we would like them to. However, we do believe that they are a good basis for fundamental structural reform. We believe that this recommendation by the Inter-State Commission represents a framework for achieving real improvement on the waterfront, and it reflects the coalition's emphasis on increasing competition and a more enterprise-based approach to employee relations.

Competition and delivering the benefits of it to the user, and thus the Australian people, is the key to this reform. Creating the environment for competition is where the Government has fallen down. Fundamental in all of this is a move to full enterprise employment, which I mentioned a few moments ago. Waterfront employers must have the right to hire and fire, just as employers in other industries have. Employers must also be able to be free to hire supplementary labour without having to go through a pool. It means that employers, when they need reserve labour forces, have the right to pick people of their own choice.

Any reform of the waterfront must include compulsory redundancies as a last resort. Of course, we believe that compulsory redundancies should start earlier than the Government has stated tonight. Any government contributions to fund redundancy payments should be paid progressively and be made more dependent on progress in implementing reform on an enterprise basis. This should include complete elimination of restrictive work practices and the introduction of flexible rosters. The Inter-State Commission's recommendations on union coverage and stand-downs must be properly implemented. That is essential if there is to be greater competition and improved industrial relations. We believe that these stand-down requirements are not confrontationist. Employees on the waterfront still enjoy extremely generous pay and conditions by anyone's standards.

The redundancy proposals being put forward in tonight's statement mean that a 55-year-old waterfront labourer who has had 30 years service will receive the equivalent of 247 weeks-nearly five years-of pay as part of his redundancy package, plus, of course, his superannuation package from the superannuation fund into which he has been paying, together with his employer, for all those years. So waterfront labourers will also be able to take early retirement on terms far more favourable than those that are available to the rest of the community. Unions, of course, will continue to play a major role in the waterside industry, but current restrictive work practices must be eliminated. Multi-skilling should be introduced. To enhance the chances of proper competition, we must tackle the monopoly power of the Waterside Workers Federation. Like so many monopolies, the Waterside Workers Federation has enjoyed immense power and privilege but has done nothing but abuse it, to the eventual cost of every Australian.

One final comment that I make in relation to the waterfront concerns the implementation authority, which I note was not addressed in any great detail in tonight's statement. I take this occasion to say that the members of it must be totally independent of the interests involved in the industry and must have a background which will ensure a proper appreciation of the need to improve efficiency and productivity. We have offered the Government its support for genuine reform of the waterfront. We have stated that we will assist in the passage of any necessary legislation, including appropriations. We will also commit a future coalition government to continue implementation of a genuine plan of waterfront reform. This will provide a climate of predictability and certainty for those involved in the industry, including users.

The Government has not taken up our bipartisan offer, an offer that would have taken the political heat out of any tough decisions that the Government was going to announce in its statement tonight. It was an offer ignored, an opportunity lost. The Government has failed its own test. Once again it has been bullied by the unions and the left wing. This inquiry, like the 12 others that have gone before it, will end up producing no net gains in productivity on our waterfront. Australia has missed a golden opportunity.

I now come to the other part of tonight's statement, the part that deals with coastal shipping. This has aroused a great deal of debate over the past few days. The press and industry expectations were that the Government would walk away from genuine reform on coastal shipping-and guess what? It did. I am afraid to say that only a few days ago in this House my colleague, now National Party leader, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) said in a matter of public importance debate that the comments of Mr Ross Gittins, writing for the Sydney Morning Herald, claiming that the Minister for Transport and Communications was the Minister for wimpishness, were too harsh and pre-judged the matter. I do not often disagree with the Leader of the National Party, but I am afraid the honourable member for Richmond was wrong and Mr Gittins was right. On the matter of coastal shipping, the Minister has been most wimpish. Why? Perhaps the best way to illustrate this is to look at the comments of Michelle Grattan, a journalist with the Age newspaper, in an article that she wrote 12 months ago. She set the test by saying:
Coastal shipping is the test for Mr Willis. He either delivers on this or he acknowledges that the Government has no commitment to genuine reform.

By that test, the Minister has failed the reformist's test. Indeed, his performance tonight would qualify the Minister only for the `carry-on regardless' brigade. I am quite sure that the Minister would have fitted in very well as the gentleman conducting the orchestra on board the Titanic as it sank. He will carry on regardless despite the economy sinking.

Why is the Minister's statement a failure to deliver reform? Simply, it does not address several key issues. One of those key issues is that of cabotage, and the other is that it does not adequately deal with company employment. First, in relation to cabotage, I refer to what the Prime Minister said but a few short months ago:

I can think of no reasonable argument why employers and unions in our manufacturing and export sectors must adjust to international trading conditions while stevedoring and shipping remain shielded-efficient coastal shipping is vital.
That is what the Prime Minister said-`efficient coastal shipping is vital'. The Business Council of Australia said after its review of coastal shipping:

The introduction of competition from foreign flag vessels is a fundamental element of any plan to encourage and maintain a competitive Australian industry and must be supported with removal of cost impediments unique to Australian shipping.
The National Bulk Commodities Group wrote recently expressing its view:
Competition on the coast is essential to provide the ongoing market stimulus to improve efficiency and to ensure that the benefits of reform are passed on to shippers.

What cabotage does is protect Australia's shipping industries from competition from foreign vessels. Cabotage is one of those issues which has not been properly addressed in this evening's statement by the Minister. Because of it we have seen a tremendous increase in costs to Australian shipping industries. The Industries Assistance Commission estimated that Australia's shipping costs are as much as 50 per cent higher than they should be. It estimated that the losses to our economy are between $250m and $550m per annum. Putting that loss into context, every Australian pays for this through higher prices, lower economic growth, a weaker balance of payments, lower job growth, lower standards of living, higher interest rates, and an increasing foreign debt.

One can find a number of examples that highlight the additional costs to Australian industry as a consequence of maintaining cabotage over the years. For example, it is cheaper to ship skimmed milk from Tasmania to Taiwan at $72 a tonne than from Tasmania to Melbourne at $82 a tonne. Newsprint from a major European port to London was less than $50 a tonne compared with almost double that amount to ship it the same distance from Hobart to Sydney. Coal is cheaper to transport from South Africa to Tasmania than it is from Tasmania to Port Kembla. Of course, all these things lead to the loss of vital income. For example, Australia has a very efficient salt producing industry, but we cannot compete with the salt market of the Pacific because it is cheaper to ship salt from Mexico than from around the coast of Australia. The need for proper reform is obvious, indeed, vital. Cabotage is one of those issues which has not been properly addressed. Trans-Tasman shipping is another that has not been properly addressed.

I note that the Minister indicated in his speech tonight that discussions would be held between this Government and the New Zealand Government to see what can be done. I am afraid to say that that means that the Government will let this issue fade away into obscurity. It must be remembered how important this issue is. Trans-Tasman shipping is not an official agreement between the governments of Australia and New Zealand-there is nothing written which makes the present arrangements stick. All it is, is a situation that exists as a consequence of union control over our waterfronts and shipping services. Recently, Australia lost some important sales of wheat to New Zealand. Why did we lose them? The Turkish Government was able to provide those wheat sales at a cheaper price than Australia. As the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) pointed out, it was our high shipping costs that stopped the sale of wheat from Australia to New Zealand and forced New Zealand to go to Turkey in order to get its wheat cheaper. One of the reasons why we are so disappointed is that this statement tonight does not address the problems involved with trans-Tasman shipping; it leaves them to another day, a day that will never come.
One other very important issue is that of direct company employment. The Deveson report states:
The question of company employment be left on the long term agenda.

In other words, what the report is saying is, `Let's hide it in the too hard basket, especially as we have an election coming up some time soon'. The industry realises that direct company employment should commence immediately. For the Government just to accept the shipping reform task force's paper is not good enough. I must admit that the odds were stacked against the shipping reform task force bringing out any positive statements when one looks at the people who made it up. As Ross Gittins has said of its recommendations:
If the Government wants to squib on coastal shipping all it has to do is accept the report of the Shipping Reform Taskforce. It surfaced last week and it's a dud.
Ross Gittins goes on to say:

The report shows a willingness to continue changing at a snail's pace, provided the taxpayers subsidise the change and provided the benefits of change stay in the industry and aren't passed on to consumers.

The Government's claims that it will bring down manning levels are not in keeping with what the rest of the world is doing. The Minister highlighted some changes to be made to manning levels on board our coastal shipping services. I would like to point out that because of the leave arrangements that Australian crews have-it requires about 2.2 crews to keep a ship at sea throughout the year compared with other countries which require fewer crew members to keep their ships at sea-Australia will not be within a bull's roar of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries when it comes to manning levels on board ships. I understand that we will be going from 46 to 37 crew members, which is what it takes to man a ship all year round in Australia, compared with European shipping services which require about 22 people in order to keep their ships at sea. Australia is a long way behind the OECD countries when it comes to manning levels for our Australian coastal shipping services.

As a result, our costs will be higher. Our position on coastal shipping is now well known. It was only a month or so ago that the honourable member for Richmond, who is now the Leader of the National Party of Australia, introduced into this place, and published for all to see, our position on coastal shipping. We have said that we will tackle the whole issue of introducing foreign competition to our coastal shipping industry. We will tackle direct company employment. We will do it over a five-year period. We will provide visible protection for the shipping industry to ensure that it has a fair go. Indeed, the point has been made by a number of people within the industry over the last few days with whom I have been in contact that it would be better, in order to bring out the real cost of protecting the Australian coastal shipping services, to have a tariff of around 10 or 15 per cent so that people of Australia can see exactly what it costs in order to protect our coastal shipping services.

I note that in his comments tonight the Minister talked about extending the current licensing arrangements for foreign shipping services. I have had the point made to me already today that the extension of that system is just an extension of something that has not worked properly in the past; an extension of something that has been a failure. Why do we do it? Why do we wait three years before a pricing element can be brought into the cost of coastal shipping services? Why do we have to wait that time? These are good questions that the Minister has not answered in his statement tonight. If we did bring a pricing element into our coastal shipping services today, the cost of it would be there for all to see. International competition would bear down on the cost of our coastal shipping services. As a result we would have cheaper shipping services along the coastline of Australia.

Ultimately, our policy in our coastal shipping position paper will bring down the cost of shipping and transport throughout Australia. The Industries Assistance Commission has estimated that through transport deregulation alone savings of some $3.2 billion will be available to the Australian economy each year. There could be an extra $6 billion to the gross domestic product as a consequence. Indeed, $1.1 billion of that growth could be made available from the waterfront and coastal shipping industries if they are properly reformed. As Anne Davies writes in the Australian Financial Review:
For the Government it is a balancing act. But if it decides to retain cabotage then marketing the decision as a reform is going to be difficult.

Because of the Government's refusal to address properly the issue of cabotage in its statement tonight I am afraid to say that, according to the tests which it has applied and, indeed, according to the tests of media commentators over the last few months, it has failed in its desire to properly and adequately reform the coastal shipping services. It has failed its own tests, it has failed the people of Australia and, as a consequence, it has failed every single Australian who is looking for a rejuvenation of the Australian economy.

I wish to make a couple of points in my concluding remarks. If the Government were to adequately carry out transport reform it would provide a stimulus to the Australian economy that would be bigger than if we abolished all tariffs and quotas-that is, if this Government had the courage to implement adequate reform in our transport industries. I might also say that during the last few weeks we have seen the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy beating his chest in this House and saying how tough he is in the way in which he has deregulated the Australian wheat industry. That is not tough. The Australian Labor Party has no friends in the wheat industry in Australia, but it has many friends in the waterfront industry and many friends in the coastal shipping services of Australia, and when it comes to properly reforming those industries this Government is a wimp. This Government will back down. It has backed down on this particular occasion and, as a consequence, the Australian economy will not get any better; it will continue to have an inefficient and wasteful waterfront and it will continue to have inefficient and wasteful coastal shipping services. I am afraid that today we have seen the wheels fall off the cart of the micro-economic reform that this Government has been trying to push around this country.
Debate (on motion by Mr Peter Morris) adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8.00 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-My portfolio contains 10 major government business enterprises (GBE) operated by the Commonwealth. They are Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines Ltd, Australian National Line (ANL), Australian National Railways Commission, Telecom Australia, Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC), Aussat, Australia Post, the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA), and the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC). These latter two enterprises were established last year to radically restructure safety regulation, the provision of aviation services and related infrastructure.

SPEECH.PARA: During the past six years the Government has systematically worked to put the operations of its transport and communications enterprises on a sounder financial footing and to make them more efficient, more flexible and more businesslike. We have given that task a high priority because of the strategic importance of the GBE in the Australian economy. It is not a task that we have only recently started. Throughout the Government's three terms we have focused on micro-economic reform, including deregulating the financial system, reducing levels of protection and reshaping the GBE. In our third term we have given greater prominence to micro-economic reform and accelerated reform of the GBE.

The eight GBE-excluding the Civil Aviation Authority and the Federal Airports Corporation-are important in their own right. They account for over 9 per cent of total public sector employment. They take up more than 15 per cent of all government investment-which comes to more than two-thirds of the investment by the Commonwealth Government. Their revenues equal 19.7 per cent of Commonwealth Government revenues, and their expenditure is equal to 18.7 per cent of Commonwealth spending. Their assets are worth over $22 billion and government investment in the enterprises, through loans and equity, amounted to in excess of $8 billion as at June 1988. Moreover, the GBE are of strategic importance to every other sector of the economy. They are an essential part of the economic infrastructure on which efficiency gains and export efforts in other sectors of the economy depend. Reforming the GBE is integral to our micro-economic reform agenda because those reforms have a multiplier effect on productivity and competitiveness throughout the economy. They help to determine the speed and efficiency with which goods and services can be exchanged, markets can be developed, trade can be expanded, information can be processed and decisions can be made in every industry in Australia.
Streamlining the GBE

We have progressively modernised and streamlined the GBE. The work on reforming the GBE started early in the life of the Government with essential capital injections for the government airlines, Qantas and Australian Airlines, and for Australian National Line. The ministerial statement on guidelines on government statutory authorities and GBE operations of November 1987 placed the reforms in a comprehensive policy framework. This framework was further consolidated in another ministerial statement of May 1988 on re-shaping the transport and communications GBE. These reforms are now being implemented on a number of fronts, including exhaustive overhauling of legislation, new regulatory arrangements, revaluation of assets, calculation of community service obligations, the preparation of detailed corporate plans and the setting of financial targets for all GBE. The Government has now put in place coherent and comprehensive change to the GBE. The changes are coherent because they are all aimed at making the GBE more enterprising and more businesslike. They are comprehensive because they affect every aspect of the GBE structures and functions. This statement explains more specifically what these changes to our GBE are designed to achieve and reports on the benefits which are now flowing to the economy and to the community generally.
Objectives
All the changes to the GBE are designed to serve the same critical objectives. These objectives are:
To enable the GBE to perform more efficiently and effectively, on a commercial basis, in an increasingly competitive environment;
to make the GBE more financially viable, so that their demands on the Budget are reduced and they have a secure financial base from which to expand and diversify their operations;
to focus the Government's involvement in the operations of the GBE on their strategic direction and financial accountability-put simply, to shift the emphasis from inputs to outputs; and

to ensure the GBE provide substantial and growing benefits to the community, including through a strong emphasis on quality and service, fulfilling the designated community service obligations, where appropriate, and prices that have been constrained in various ways.

We have not imposed change according to some ideological bureaucratic blueprint. In each GBE, the reforms made have been specifically adapted to the particular service the enterprise is providing, the market it caters for, the competition it faces, the assets it holds, the investments it has made, and the returns it has been able to deliver. The changes have been pragmatic and flexible. We have taken pains to make sure that in each case we have adopted the most effective approach to achieve reform.

The process of reform is not yet complete but the policy framework we have established will ensure that the GBE will always remain responsive to the need for change. But our achievements have already been substantial and thorough. They are achievements on which all sectors in the Australian economy can build in the years ahead. Those changes will facilitate and accelerate the structural adjustment on which our future competitiveness-which means, among other things, our ability to create jobs and to maintain our standard of living-will depend.
Financial Base

The GBE are now financially viable and have a solid base for future growth. When we came to office, Australian Airlines, Qantas and the Australian National Line were grossly undercapitalised. They had been starved of equity capital and their scope for future development was severely restricted. At the outset we took decisive action to provide the injection of equity so badly needed, which allowed the airlines to take advantage of the tourist boom and the massive growth in air traffic which came with it. In 1983, Australian Airlines had a paid up capital of only $40m and $25m of that had been injected only in the very last days of the Fraser Government. The Airline's debt to equity ratio was over 90:10, which imposed a severe burden of high interest payments at a time of declining business in the airline industry. In the two years 1981-83, Australian Airlines's losses amounted to more than three-quarters of what had been its paid up capital. This situation was completely untenable, and was immediately addressed by the Hawke Government through an equity injection of $90m in our first Budget. That made the Airline financially viable and put it on a competitive basis. It has not looked back.

Profits earned by Australian Airlines since 1945 when it was established from all sources amount to $176m. Eighty per cent of this amount, $143m, has been earned since 1983. Since 1945 its dividends to the Commonwealth have amounted to $66m of which $28m has been paid in the last two years. In 1987-88, Australian Airlines earned $1.1 billion in revenue for an operating profit of $66.6m before tax. After tax, and extraordinary items, that amounted to a return on equity of 21.5 per cent. The Airline has been able to expand and diversify its operations, and to improve the quality of its service. None of that could have been done without the Government's early financial support.

The improvement in the performance of Qantas is also striking. The Hawke Government has provided Qantas with an injection of $60m in capital, more than two-thirds the amount that had been provided in all the previous 37 years in which the Airline had been operating in government hands. Since 1947, when the Commonwealth acquired all of the shares of Qantas, the company has earned profits from all sources amounting to $564m, of which a staggering $485m, or 86 per cent, has been earned since the Hawke Government come to office in 1983. A similar picture applies to dividends. Since 1947 the company has declared dividends amounting to a total of $137m, with $92m out of this amount being paid since 1983. In the 15 month period ending 30 June 1988, Qantas earned revenue of $3.9 billion, for an operating profit of $272m before tax and an 11.6 per cent rate of return on assets. Obviously these indicators of Qantas's performance within the environment created by the Hawke Government are quite spectacular.

In the case of the government-owned railway, Australian National, government reform has again resulted in a significant improvement in performance. In our term of office, Australian National's call on the Budget for funds has been cut by 63 per cent in real terms. In 1987-88, for the first time, Australian National recorded a small operating surplus on its commercial freight operations. We have gone further than any State government in giving our railway a commercial charter and its performance in the past few years has been unmatched by any other publicly owned rail system in the country.

A similar picture emerges with the Australian National Line, where we inherited an enterprise which was effectively bankrupt. ANL, in 1983, was a debt ridden, heavily subsidised loss maker, without any clear functions or direction. It is not that now. We increased ANL's equity base by $160.5m, to correct its undercapitalisation and high gearing. It has since implemented a rationalisation program which has involved hard decisions about the sale of some ships and termination of some services, and its performance has improved significantly. ANL has recorded a profit in each of the past four years and, in the next few weeks, it will be bringing forward a corporate plan designed to enable it to trade effectively in future years.

For the legislated monopolies, Telecom Australia, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC), Aussat Pty Ltd and Australia Post, profitability is not by itself an appropriate measure of performance. Other factors, such as service performance standards, real decreases in prices and levels of capital investment, are important performance indicators. Taking all these measures together, the GBE are performing well by international comparisons. To enable better measurement of financial performance in the future, we are vesting, for the first time, a proper capital structure in Telecom and Australia Post. Also our complementary telecommunications policy reforms contain mechanisms for monitoring many of the non-financial performance measures.
Corporate Structures

The communications GBE have been given the commercial structure necessary for them to deal with the challenges of increased competition, continuing technological change, and new demands and opportunities in the marketplace. Telecom and Australia Post have been converted from commissions into statutory corporations. Each has been restructured along modern lines, and established with a board of directors. Aussat has been given scope for expanding and diversifying its activities. OTC was transformed into a public company in April 1989 and now trades as OTC Ltd with a better capital structure.

Australian Airlines was set up as an incorporated company in April 1988. Australian National's Act was further modernised to give greater emphasis to the commission's commercial charter. ANL will be converted into a public company in July of this year. It was unnecessary to change the incorporated company status of Qantas Airways Ltd, as it already suited its commercial environment.
Strategic Direction

The Government's involvement in the operations of its GBE is now largely confined to two basic strategic management controls-the discipline and accountability of a forward looking corporate plan, and of an agreed financial target. Corporate plans set strategic directions for the enterprises. They establish the business priorities that enterprises will use each day in guiding their decisions. They provide the Government and the enterprises with a clear sense of direction and a clear awareness of their common purpose and shared interests.

This has created a context for more innovative and creative commercial decisions. It is reflected, for example, in Qantas's acquisition of a minority share in Air New Zealand, in Telecom and OTC's successful bids for international contracts, in Telecom's initiatives in value added services in the telecommunications field, in Australia Post's work on electronic mail transmission, and in Australian National's continued exploration of opportunities for increased efficiency in inter-system railway operations.

It is essential that the community's assets are used in the most effective way by the GBEs. The setting of financial targets gives a basis for measuring their performance. The targets can include the rate of return on assets or shareholder funds, lump sum aggregates or profitability measures related to turnover. In making these assessments, we are taking into account past earnings, industry competition, the opportunity cost of capital, the cost of meeting community service obligations and the performance of similar private sector companies. No single indicator has been arbitrarily imposed on all the GBE.

A prerequisite for setting financial targets has been the revaluation of GBE assets. That task will be completed by 1 July, with the exception of Australian National, the assets of which will be revalued over a five-year period. We have also had to assess the financial value of community service obligations. In Telecom's case, that task is being undertaken by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics under my portfolio in cooperation with the enterprise, and is now near completion.

In all cases, decisions on the financial target are a matter for extensive discussion between the Government and the enterprise. The targets are being set at a level which will oblige the enterprise to improve its performance and, in doing so, to ensure that the Australian people receive full value for the money they have invested in the GBE. We will have an interest in making sure that these enterprises use their great resources as efficiently as possible, and that taxpayers-like shareholders in any business-obtain a proper return on their investment.
Loosening Other Controls

The Government has removed a large number of day-to-day controls on the GBE. Most of those had outlived their usefulness and inhibited the taking of commercial decisions. The controls, which covered such matters as opening bank accounts, letting contracts, major purchases and construction programs, are now a thing of the past. At the same time the Government is loosening up a number of strategic controls. The enterprises have recently been given greater autonomy and independent responsibility in managing their industrial relations arrangements. Most of them have also advertised for, and appointed, chief executives under new terms and conditions which include new employment arrangements involving the abolition of tenure and more market related remuneration.

Yet in this regard it should be noted that the extent to which remaining strategic controls can be relaxed must take account of the macro-economic context in which we are operating. The interaction between macro-economic settings and micro-economic reform will continue to affect the timing and scope of further changes to government controls.
Community Service Obligations

For the GBE, as for all other businesses, profits and return on assets are critical indices of performances. But they are not the only indices we use in assessing the performance of Telecom and Australia Post, which perform important community service obligations (CSO). A CSO is a service that the enterprise is obliged to perform in the interests of the entire community, in circumstances where an enterprise acting solely commercially would not provide the service. Hence we have ensured that all Australians can have access to the high quality telephone service we have built up. Likewise, we have guaranteed that standard letters will continue to be carried at a uniform tariff within Australia.

The Government will retain control over the CSO through the ministerial power to direct variations to the strategies and policies to be followed by Telecom and Australia Post in carrying out their CSO. We have defined these obligations more clearly through new legislation. Provision has also been made for the corporate plans of Telecom and Australia Post to include the strategies and policies they intend to pursue to fulfil those CSO. In addition, their annual reports will include an outline of these strategies and policies. We are breaking new ground in measuring the extent of the CSO. The GBE will be required to give an account of them.
Telecommunications Efficiency Gains

All members of the community will benefit from the greater efficiency of our GBE, in the ways already specified and through lower prices. Telecom has recently implemented a $100m per annum cut in subscriber trunk dialling rates, and OTC has also announced a $50m annual reduction in tariffs. A three-minute phone call between Brisbane and Perth now costs only 55 per cent of what it cost when the Government came to office. Increases in standard postal charges have been kept well below the rate of inflation.

In the case of telecommunications services, we are now going further to ensure that efficiency gains flow through to every consumer of the service provided. That has meant determining new price control mechanisms. As a result, we will be applying price cap regulation as well as setting target rates of return for two of our telecommunications carriers and infrastructure providers, Telecom and OTC. Our aim has been to combine the price gap and the rate of return targets so that the carriers are pushed to achieve further gains in efficiency in delivery of services. Consumers will gain directly, and the whole economy will gain indirectly, from real price reductions for a basket of standard services and improvements in service efficiency generally.

The price gap will operate for three years from 1 July. After examining available productivity gains, and the various factors which influence the rate of return targets for the carriers-Telecom and OTC-we have set the formula for that period at consumer price index minus 4 per cent. The price control arrangements also include ways of ensuring that proposed price increases for specified non-standard services will be subject to scrutiny by Austel, our new independent regulator. At the end of this statement I will be seeking leave to table a detailed account of the price control arrangements.

Our formula means that, overall, consumers of the standard telecommunications services are guaranteed to benefit from substantial real price reductions in each of the next three years. Efficiency gains will enable the carriers to meet the financial targets which have been set. The 4 per cent figure may be increased in subsequent years to take account of a different mix of rate of return requirements, increases in available productivity gains and greater efficiencies resulting from technological change.

We are making major complementary changes to the regulatory arrangements in telecommunications. More market segments are being liberalised. For example, customer equipment and value added telecommunications services are open to full competition. The activities reserved to the carriers-Telecom, OTC and Aussat-are more clearly defined in legislation. Telecom will no longer be the industry regulator as Austel will take over this task. Under legislation currently before the Parliament, Austel will be charged with a number of functions including protection of carrier responsibilities, protection of competitors from unfair practices of carriers, protection of consumers from unfair practices, promotion of efficiency of carriers and technical regulation of the industry.
Conclusion

Reforming the GBE would achieve only limited results if it were not synchronised with other micro-economic reforms. I have referred already to our thorough-going review of the telecommunications policy framework. A package of reforms on the waterfront and coastal shipping is the subject of a separate statement which I have already made today. Those policy steps complement other moves already taken in the transport and communications portfolio including the termination of the two airlines policy; liberalised liner shipping arrangements; the new national arterial roads category of the Australian centennial road development program focusing on roads of economic significance; steps towards nationally uniform weight and speed limits for interstate road vehicles; and liberalisation of international passenger and freight charter flights. In addition, the Civil Aviation Authority and the Federal Airports Corporation will soon be subject to the same GBE reform process as other enterprises in the portfolio.

Our approach has been flexible and pragmatic. We have deliberately chosen the best way, which means the most effective and equitable way, to set the GBE up to do their business. Our approach is, therefore, quite different from that of the Opposition which, during its terms in office, did virtually nothing to reform, or even to maintain, the GBE. They were content to let these enterprises operate in an unbusinesslike way, producing minimum returns on capital and insufficient levels of customer service. As for the future, the Opposition has nothing to offer except a doctrinaire, ideological commitment to privatisation.

We have placed the GBE at the cutting edge of micro-economic reform. We have pursued reform of the GBE in the firm conviction that the upgrading and reshaping of our public enterprises will greatly assist Australia to become more efficient and more competitive in world markets. We are demonstrating that government enterprises can be efficient, even dynamic, and can compete strongly with the private sector. I commend the GBE reforms to the House. I present the following paper:
Government Business Enterprises: Reforms-Ministerial Statement, 1 June 1989.
I seek leave to table the statement on new price controls for telecommunications services.
Leave granted.
Motion (by Mrs Kelly) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mrs Kelly)-by leave-agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the honourable member for Farrer speaking for a period not exceeding 23 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the sun sets on the Thirty-fifth Parliament, first session, fourth period, and as the sun sets on this Federal Government, finally the Government has produced two statements on micro-economic reform. There was one earlier this afternoon, essentially on shipping, and tonight the statement by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) on the implementation of government business enterprises (GBE) reports, reforms and telecommunications pricing. It is a privilege to respond to the statement on behalf of the coalition and, in particular, on behalf of the shadow Minister for business and consumer affairs, the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), the shadow Minister for communications, Senator Richard Alston, and my colleagues the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) and others.

SPEECH.PARA: In so doing I have to say that this Government has really produced minuscule micro-economic reform. As the honourable member for Gilmore said this afternoon, the micro-economic reform bandwagon has derailed and come to a dead halt. In respect of the statement the Minister has tendered to the House on this occasion, to a large extent it has broken no new ground except on the capping of Telecom Australia pricing policy-I acknowledge that that is new ground-and expanding the powers of Austel. As I track through, as I will shortly, the large number of other government business enterprises referred to by the Minister, we will see that there is nothing new. There are just three in-principle directions for those GBE. Essentially there is nothing new. Above all, there is nothing new with regard to the ownership and staff access to the ownership and with regard to the capitalisation arrangements as they stand at this moment, notwithstanding the fact-again I acknowledge it-that this Government has certainly increased capitalisation for a large number of the GBE covered by this statement.

Micro-economic reform, particularly with regard to the transport sector, is absolutely essential if our economy is to survive in the next decade. This nation faces in the 1990s the most competitive decade it has probably ever seen throughout this century as a consequence of the formation of large trading blocs around the world. As we now know so well, from 1992 we will have fortress Europe. We will have the giant market of the European Economic Community and the synchronised energy which will flow from that as the EEC trades as a colossus and strides the world as a trading colossus-which may yet be to our detriment. That remains to be seen.

Clearly it means that we must become more competitive if we are to survive against the colossus of fortress Europe post-1992. Across the Atlantic we have the growing links formed between the United States of America and Canada. An historic election in Canada saw the people there vote for a free trade situation and vote for that trading bloc formation between the United States and Canada. Australia in the 1990s, right down the other end of the world, faces this huge colossus in Europe and an equally large colossus in the United States and Canada. If that is not enough of an incentive to get our transport efficiencies in order, I do not know what is.

In my Australia Day message to my electorate earlier this year I emphasised that time was fast running out to rectify our transport infrastructure inadequacies be they in relation to road, rail or air. The Minister's statement tonight addresses in oblique ways the structure of our transport infrastructure, particularly with regard to government business enterprises. In responding for the coalition to the Minister's micro-economic reform statement, let me say that statement falls far short of what is required as we approach the decade of the 1990s, the fierce competition of the 1990s and the need to maximise the efficiency of every mode of transport if we are to survive economically and produce the exports required.

In terms of considering the statement, I think it is desirable to examine some previous statements made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). On 23 May 1988 the Treasurer made a statement in relation to privatisation. He said:

. . . basically, I don't think the Government ought to be running airlines and that's why I think their equity ought to be sold down. We can't afford to continue providing subventions for their capital base.
Now with scarce Cabinet Room budgetary dollars, we can't be putting billions into Qantas and Australian Airlines and the like.

They are the words of the Treasurer; the words pointing in the direction of privatisation. This was the micro-economic reform package which was meant to be delivered in those comments by the Treasurer, and which clearly has not been so delivered. The Prime Minister's comments were reported in the Age on 29 February 1988 as follows:

Mr Hawke said public assets had to be considered case by case. He reaffirmed his opposition to the sale of Telecom and Australia Post, but added: `I do believe that it is reasonable to ask does it make sense to tie up public resources in, for instance, running an airline. I have a prima facie view that it doesn't.'

It was the Prime Minister making that statement. The Government, in its statement here tonight, has walked away from those comments by the Prime Minister. It is not hard to find out why. If we pick up the Melbourne Herald of 30 May 1989 we see the headline, `Victoria ALP blow to PM on Qantas'. The Minister may well smile. It is nice to see him smiling in the twilight hours of the Thirty-fifth Parliament, first session, fourth period. He might well smile, because his own segment of the Australian Labor Party has dumped on him and on the Government with regard to the privatisation of the airlines. The Victorian ALP has produced a 60-page report which it paid some $6,000 to two academics at Flinders University in Adelaide to produce. The report argues chapter and verse that Qantas and Australian Airlines must remain publicly owned, preferably as one public-owned airline, with a single superannuation scheme covering both organisations, and rejects completely the case for really reforming government business enterprises by privatising our airlines.

We know why the Government has failed in terms of its priorities with regard to the airlines. It is because the Victorian ALP is meeting tomorrow to adopt this report and lock it in at the national level. I am pleased that another luminary of the Victorian ALP, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), has arrived at the table. He is also smiling in this twilight hour of the Thirty-fifth Parliament, first session, fourth period. The tragedy is that the nation will pay a price for this lack of progress with regard to the Government's policy vacuum on the onward operation of Qantas and Australian Airlines.

Well one might ask: What is the policy of the coalition? On this occasion, I am proud to say, it is in black and white and blue. It is a published document and I have a copy of it right here. It addresses each and every one of the government business enterprises dealt with by the Minister in his statement, which the honourable member for Ryan quite accurately described as something of a fizzer. The coalition is not going to muck around with the future of Qantas and the other airlines. With regard to Qantas, our policy is 100 per cent privatisation. Why not let the staff of Qantas have some shares in its operation? Why not give them some basis for incentive in the 1980s and 1990s by being part-owners of their airline? Surely that would appeal even to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on a Sunday morning. Why not give Qantas, the nation's overseas airline, the charter to leap into the twenty-first century by giving it clear-cut private ownership and the right to go out and raise capital, unrestricted by the Loan Council and the Premiers Conference-which, incidentally, dealt Qantas another body blow just a fortnight ago? This is not a laughing matter, because Qantas has suffered more than most from the restriction of being owned by the Government instead of private shareholders.

Let us look at what has happened to the Qantas mechanical and engineering base at Mascot. Its productivity has collapsed. We face the acute embarrassment of seeing Qantas in 1989 having to ferry its jumbo jets around the world empty, to Amsterdam, Dublin and elsewhere, to have them serviced because this Government has not set Qantas up on a basis which enables it to maintain its engineering base. When the coalition was in power, so successful was the Qantas engineering base and so proud were its staff that aircraft came from Asia to be serviced there. Aircraft came from the north-east corridor of the United States to be serviced by Qantas. That is not the case today, six years later.

Last weekend a Qantas crew was flown from Sydney to Melbourne, first class, as crew members perhaps deserve to travel. The same crew was flown from Melbourne to Los Angeles. In Los Angeles the crew members got off their jumbo and utilised the facilities that were quite properly made available for them. Then they picked up an empty Qantas jumbo, with less than 20 people on board-because Qantas cannot carry passengers on a route for which it does not hold a licence-and became perhaps the first ever crew to fly in a jumbo direct from Los Angeles across the Hudson Bay near the North Pole, across Iceland to Amsterdam. There was not a paying passenger on board that jumbo.

Why did that happen? It was because Qantas no longer has the capacity to maintain its own jumbos, due to the restrictions placed on it by government ownership. That jumbo was positioned in Amsterdam for maintenance, as that was the only way it could be done. What a disgrace that we have reached the stage where last weekend that crew had to fly on that empty jumbo at great expense-it was no doubt an exciting route for the crew involved-from Los Angeles to Amsterdam because Qantas can no longer provide the capability to service its own aircraft at its base in Sydney. The Government cannot be proud of its progress on micro-economic reform in relation to Qantas. The Opposition's policy is clear cut: 100 per cent private ownership.

Looking across the seas to British Airways we see the tremendous success of privatisation in terms of productivity. Likewise with Australian Airlines, the coalition has a clear-cut policy of 100 per cent privatisation. Likewise with the Australian National Line: 100 per cent privatisation; no equivocation. The Australian National Railways Commission clearly would need to be reviewed in government. I welcome the great strides that have been made with revamping Australian National and I give credit to the Government for part of that package. It has previously made a profit. The Minister indicated in his statement that Australian National has not previously made a profit, but it made profits for several consecutive years when it first went to diesel from steam. That was back in the Menzies-McEwen period of government. Australian National has a big role to play in the future because rail-mark my words-has a very big role to play in the future right around the world.

I turn to Telecom Australia and Australia Post. The Government and the coalition are as one in terms of their ownership. For the Overseas Telecommunications Commission the Opposition has a strong policy of privatising 49 per cent. Likewise with the Federal Airports Corporation, we would sell the terminals. Our policy is laid out very clearly in Privatisation, The Australian Way, the position paper released by the shadow Minister on behalf of the coalition. The bonus in this document-people can write to the honourable member for Ryan for a copy of it-is the graph which shows the profit performance of privatised companies, essentially in the United Kingdom with its move to privatisation. Pre-privatisation most of them were on just a break-even or a narrow loss. Post-privatisation the graph clearly shows-even though the shortest line between two points might be a circle of infinite radius-that there is a huge uplift in the profits of companies such as British Cable and Wireless, the National Freight Consortium, British Aerospace, British Telecom, British Airways and even Rolls Royce.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I put it to you that the Government has botched its approach to micro-economic reform in dealing with these eight key government business enterprises. It has stopped short of making the one decision which would provide the basis for a leapfrog into the twenty-first century, for an expansion of capital, for a boost to productivity, by altering the very ownership of these government business enterprises. The reason is that members of this Government are the ones who are tied to party policy and ideology. They are the ones who are locked into Victorian Australian Labor Party committee reports which block progress down the privatisation path. The tragedy is that the nation has to pay the price of the Government's lack of progress in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is going to buy them all?

—I will respond to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. No-one, because if people are not given the opportunity to buy them they cannot buy them. But experience around the world has shown that, if we put Qantas on the market and we offer it on reasonable terms to the staff of Qantas for starters, we will find an extraordinary take-up rate. We will find smiles on the faces of the flight attendants and the administrative staff in Sydney and elsewhere because they would be part-owners of the company that they work for. They are injecting the extra effort into their daily labours because they are being given that basic incentive. There will be a leap in productivity and profit as a consequence of that change in ownership.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have mentioned, essentially the statement does not break new ground with regard to the eight big government business enterprises, but it breaks new ground in relation to Telecom, to Telecom pricing and the capping of Telecom price controls. I know that the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) has pursued this policy area with a great deal of interest. So we are to have a formula applied to Telecom's pricing policies of the consumer price index minus X. For the first year the Government has declared that X will be 4 per cent. So it will be 6.9 per cent minus 4 per cent which, even on my mathematics, equals a cost increase for the subscribers to Telecom of 2.9 per cent. Honourable members might think that that is reasonable. But is it, when we consider that Telecom had to pull almost every trick in the pack to get its profit figures below $1 billion for the last year covered by its annual financial report. Try getting a new service connected through Telecom, especially one which requires some additional effort and additional distance. Honourable members will soon find why Telecom makes that sort of profit.

So we have this twinning policy of the Government in relation to Telecom where, on the one hand, it will apply the rate of return regulation and, on the other hand, the price cap regulation. A colleague in the Senate, Senator Richard Alston, will have more to say about this new policy development, probably next week when the Senate deals in detail with this statement. Suffice to say at this stage that we are concerned about aspects of this capping policy. Whilst we are not opposed to the role of Austel, the Australian Telecommunications Authority, we will watch very closely the practical ramifications which flow from the capping policy in relation to the role of Telecom Australia.

Related to this are the moves to further highlight the community service obligations of organisations such as Telecom Australia and other government business enterprises. Again, in one sense, that community service obligation ought to be shown clearly in the reports involved. In another sense, the Government should not take this opportunity to wind back on those parts of the community service obligations which are essential to providing a fair go in this country and essential to providing a fair go for the large, decentralised export industries located over much of inland Australia which face other burdens and pay additional taxes in the process, directly and indirectly, in providing exports. That fact should be taken into account in determining community service obligation policies in respect of government business enterprises.

Tonight we have seen a statement which is nothing more than a blinkered approach by the Government to micro-economic reform. It represents a sham and, in my ways, it represents a shambles. It locks out the staff of Qantas, of Australian Airlines and of these other organisations from any form of ownership which would be the driving force for a big boost to the productivity of our government business enterprises. In short, it is a policy which fails this nation as we enter one of the most competitive decades we will ever face as a nation, as the giant trading block form around the world. As such, this Government must be condemned for failing the test with its micro-economic reform package here tonight. It is a bitter disappointment for those who are looking for the blueprint which would drive these government business enterprises into the 1990s and into the twenty-first century and, at the same time, boost the export performance and help reduce the foreign debt. For these reasons I say to the House that the Government should think again. It should not give up the battle, particularly with regard to privatising Qantas and Australian Airlines before it is too late.
