PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Patents Bill 1989 is a complete redraft of the Patents Act 1952, which it repeals and replaces. It has two main thrusts. First, it implements a number of policy changes flowing from an expert report reviewing the Australian patent system from an economic perspective. Second, it brings the language and structure of the Act down to earth, so that mere mortals without law degrees have some chance of understanding what it is all about, at least in general terms.

When the former Liberal Minister for Productivity, the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), was faced some years ago with criticisms of that complex legal and economic policy instrument which is the Patents Act, he asked for expert advice from the Industrial Property Advisory Committee (IPAC). The Committee was then chaired by John Stonier, a patent and licensing expert from Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. The Committee wrangled over the issues for a few years. When its report Patents, Innovation and Competition in Australia came to me in 1984, it contained a brief statement by economics professor Don Lamberton, dissenting from the majority's findings on a number of central issues. Even Professor Lamberton, however, must have suffered some internal wrangling. With co-authors Tom Mandeville and Jean Bishop from the University of Queensland, he had prepared a separate report, commissioned by IPAC, Economic Effects of the Australian Patent System. The authors gathered and considered some important empirical data on the use of the patent system and tried to assess its effects on the Australian economy. They concluded that the economic costs of the patent system probably exceeded its benefits, but only after first acknowledging that the question was `ultimately a matter of judgment'.

I felt it would be unwise to act on a divided report without first calling for public comment on it. In the event, after considering a wide array of submissions, the Government accepted the bulk of the Committee's recommendations. I tabled the Government's response in the House on 28 November 1986. IPAC's report did not wholeheartedly embrace the patent system, but it by no means rejected it. Some view the system as some kind of mysterious sacrament which has to be observed if we are to proceed along the path to economic heaven. The Committee took a more pragmatic view. Faced with conflicting opinions on economic questions, IPAC recognised that it is imperative that Australia continue to operate a patent system and to participate in the international patent system. IPAC outlined its approach in these terms:

The policy approach to review and change should be to seek to optimise the net benefits arising from the operation of the patent system in the national interest to the extent possible consistent with international conventions, having regard to the particular circumstances of the Australian economy. We should seek to modify the Australian patent laws, adjusting the length, strength and breadth of patent rights so as to maximise the social benefits and to minimise the social costs to Australians.
More specifically this implies seeking-

to gain increased benefits for Australians by fostering indigenous innovation, and utilising the international patent system in development export markets to improve Australia's international competitive position;
to reduce unnecessary social costs including those resulting from undesirable anti-competitive conduct involving patents; and
to improve the efficiency of the administration of the patent system with consequent reduction of direct costs.
It needs also to be recognised that the patent system is a blunt instrument of industrial policy and cannot easily be fine-tuned to take account of particular cases.

One of the most important and constructive measures recommended by IPAC was an adjustment of the standards of novelty and inventiveness required of standard patents. Under the present law, standard patents are tested for novelty only against prior disclosures in Australia. Under the Bill, they are to be tested against disclosures in documentary form anywhere in the world. This change will make it harder to get a 16-year standard patent, but it will bring the requirement into line with similar requirements in most of Australia's trading partner countries. The six-year pretty patent, which is designed more for use by smaller enterprises, will still be tested against the lower `domestic' prior art base. The Bill thus makes a sensible distinction between a patentee which is an export-oriented company, which will benefit from a degree of parity between Australia's patent laws and those of our trading partners, and a smaller company whose ambitions are more restricted to the domestic market.

The Bill comes at a time when Australian researchers are particularly anxious to obtain a return on their investment. Intellectual property issues are likely to be more important when funding is harder to come by, in both private industry and public institutions. There is increasing concern about technological competence and the need to make the use of new technology when it appears. The honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) in his former incarnation would have been very interested in this.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just surprised it took you so long to get it here, Barry.

—That is correct. There is a dilemma for the researcher, however, in balancing the need for protection, and the desire to obtain recognition at the earliest possible stage, against the fear of premature disclosure before commercialisation is realistically possible. Early publication can give other people the edge, but waiting too long can mean loss of intellectual property rights. The patent system does at least address this problem by providing for delayed publication for a period of up to 18 months from filing an application. There is a buffer zone built in.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of international developments which inevitably place this Bill in a wider context. Honourable members will be aware that Australia is taking a leading role in a number of negotiations involved in the multilateral trade negotiations of the Uruguay Round in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). One of the most difficult of the subjects under negotiation-one in which Australia is actively participating-is on the Trade Related Aspects of Intellectual Property, TRIPS for short. These negotiations recognise the value of intellectual property as a traded commodity. Parallel negotiations are dealing likewise with trade in services, in agricultural commodities, and in a number of other areas. The newness to many GATT participants of the concepts of intellectual property, and of intellectual property as a commodity, seems to be making TRIPS the most difficult of the so-called new issues upon which negotiations are proceeding. Generally speaking, the developed countries are seeking greater universal recognition of these concepts. They are also seeking a set of rules under the GATT to facilitate trade in intellectual property on a fair and equitable basis and under agreed rules.

At the same time, within the World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO)-the United Nations specialised agency responsible for intellectual property-there is a range of related negotiations. Most significant among these, so far as this Bill is concerned, are a proposal to develop a treaty providing for international harmonisation for patent law, and the protracted attempt to negotiate a revision of the Paris Convention for the Protection of Intellectual Property. The latter has been proceeding since the mid 1970s. This Bill, by strengthening Australia's patent law and by incorporating more universal standards within that law, will place Australia in a sounder position in relation to the negotiations in both GATT and WIPO. It is also relevant that many of Australia's near neighbours, particularly the rapidly expanding economies in East and South East Asia, have recently modernised their patent laws or are reviewing them. Until this Bill, Australia's Patents Act has been suffering from a series of amendments which have given rise to undue complexity. Our law is therefore somewhat out of kilter with other countries' more recent laws.

Patent law has also been included for discussion in the current round of closer economic relations negotiations with New Zealand. Once again, this new Bill, by simplifying the expression of Australia's law, should assist in clarifying Australia's position. It will be interesting to see whether New Zealand will contemplate taking similar action in relation to its law. Both Australian and New Zealand patent laws, of course, ultimately derive from English law as that once was, but they have diverged over time. The question now is whether that divergence has resulted in any impediments to fair and equitable trade across the Tasman. There are studies on foot to ascertain whether or not such impediments exist. Again, the simpler expression of patent law which this Bill embodies should assist consideration of these issues.

One of IPAC's recommendations was `that the patents legislation be reviewed and completely redrafted to streamline procedures, particularly with a view to eliminating unnecessary steps and procedures, avoiding special categories, and establishing appropriate sanctions for non-compliance'. The Government accepted the recommendation, and announced that the Commissioner of Patents would invite the Law Council of Australia and the Institute of Patent Attorneys of Australia to participate in a working party to review the legislation, particularly with a view to relegating procedural matters to the regulations. That working party was formed and it met more than a dozen times. The Law Council and the Institute of Patent Attorneys each nominated two representatives. The Government is grateful to those organisations for their cooperation, and to the individuals concerned for giving their time and for their devotion to the job. As things turned out, the working party did not formally finalise the text of its draft report, although it had reached firm conclusions. Drafting of the Bill had been delayed while it waited its turn for priority in the Government's legislation program, so when a slot appeared in the drafting program, the working party's conclusions were fed immediately into the process in the form of an informal issues paper. While the Bill as a whole contains many things apart from the working party's conclusions, those conclusions have been incorporated so far as possible.

The drafting style in the Bill breaks some new ground. The definitions in the back are in the form of a dictionary in a schedule, reducing enormously the amount of sheer verbiage to be waded through before getting to the central concepts. And there is a flow chart, right up front, which sets out most of the typical steps involved in getting and maintaining a patent. It explains some difficult procedures in graphic form. This is the first legislation known to me anywhere with these particular features. I am very grateful to the Office of Parliamentary Counsel and the Patents Office for the quality of their work. It is a splendid piece of drafting and a Bill that is notably easy to read.

TALK.START.PARA: —Congratulations!

—They do deserve congratulations. It is simply not possible, of course, to express most complex and detailed ideas in a few monosyllabic words. Grunts and snorts worked fined for cavemen-and they still have their uses-but the evolution of complex societies and complex ideas inevitably carries with it the use of some complex language. I have used some myself, on occasion. But language seems to have two simultaneous but contrary habits, and they are both evident in old Acts of Parliament. First, it tends to atrophy, so you find a plethora of archaic expressions. Second, and paradoxically, language seems to proliferate without cause at times. Too many words and over complicated expressions get used, with the result that the principle or idea behind them can get lost. Both these phenomena seem to have been propagated by the seminal pen nibs, if we can mix the metaphor, of the lawyers, in particular, with the result that the law can become inaccessible to the people it is trying to govern and to serve. I am delighted with the way this Bill attempts to counter the degenerative linguistic evolution of both kinds which has been characteristic of much legislative drafting in the past. No doubt there will be a need for some adjustments, but we are prepared to make them if they are needed.

SPEECH.PARA: Archaic words with hidden meanings are found even in the most central provisions in the present Act, which set out what rights are given by a patent. Present section 69 reads;

Subject to this Act, the effect of a patent is to grant to the patentee the exclusive right, by himself, his agents and licensees, during the term of the patent, to make, use, exercise and vend the invention in such manner as he thinks fit, so that he shall have and enjoy the whole profit and advantage accruing by reason of the invention during the term of the patent.
One will need expensive legal advice to find out what is meant by `exercising' an invention. Compare this with subclause 13 (1) in the Bill:
Subject to this Act, a patent gives the patentee the exclusive rights, during the term of the patent, to exploit the invention and to authorise another person to exploit the invention.

The word `exploit' here bears a sensible, usual meaning. There are, of course, some inherent complexities, and the definition of `exploit' in the dictionary attempts to clear some of those up. One of the more excessive examples in the present Act of words for their own sake can be found in subsection 121 (1), which enables people to take legal action against someone who threatens patent infringement proceedings without justification:

Where a person, by means of circulars, advertisements or otherwise, threatens a person with an action or proceeding for infringement of a patent, or some other like proceeding, then, whether the person making the threats is or is not entitled to or interested in a patent, or is or is not interested in an application for a patent, a person aggrieved may bring an action against the first-mentioned person and may obtain a declaration to the effect that the threats are unjustifiable, and an injunction against the continuance of the threats, and may recover such damages (if any) as he has sustained, unless the first-mentioned person satisfies the court that the acts in respect of which the proceedings were threatened constitute, or, if done, would constitute-
(a) an infringement of a patent in respect of a claim in the specification which is not shown by the plaintiff to be invalid;

(b) an infringement of rights arising under section 54c in respect of a claim in a complete specification that is not shown to be a claim that would be invalid if a standard patent had been granted in respect of the complete specification; or

(c) an infringement of rights arising under section 54d in respect of the claim of a petty patent specification that is not shown to be a claim that would be invalid if a petty patent had been granted in respect of the petty patent specification.

Now, it is not always a fair test to read complex language aloud. The words do, in fact, make sense. But that is not the proper test for whether they should be retained. Subclause 126 (1) of the Bill deals with the same subject matter, with the same results, using fewer words and a straightforward grammatical construction just by saying:

Where a person, by means of circulars, advertisements or otherwise, threatens a person with infringement proceedings, or other similar proceedings, a person aggrieved may apply to a prescribed court, or to another court having jurisdiction to hear and determine the application, for:
(a) a declaration that the threats are unjustifiable; and
(b) an injunction against the continuance of the threats; and
(c) the recovery of any damages sustained by the applicant as a result of the threats.

It is a very good piece of drafting. The question the provision deals with is not exactly earth shattering, although it would matter a lot to a person affected by it. The revised wording still has a few alternatives built into it. But its meaning is transparent rather than obscure. Because the Bill will devolve many matters found in the present Act to the regulations, it will be necessary to redraft the patents regulations in their entirety. I expect that some patent attorneys and lawyers will feel apprehensive of an attempt to somehow pull the rug from under their feet. Well, that is not the case. The terms of reference for the working party encompass the patents regulations as well as the Act itself. I would hope that the working party will make as significant a contribution to the next stage of legislative reform in reviewing the regulations as it has to the first. Work has already started on the preparation of implementing regulations, and I intend to invite public comment on them before they commence, just as we are doing for the Bill.

One of IPAC's recommendations related to patent term. The Government decided to abolish the present procedures for extending patent term, and to replace them with new, simpler, procedures enabling four-year extensions only for pharmaceuticals for human use. The latter decision was announced in September 1987 as part of a package of policies designed to encourage development of the pharmaceutical products industry in Australia. A Patents Amendment Bill to implement that particular matter was introduced last year and is presently awaiting consideration by the Senate. The Bill which I am presently introducing contains the same provisions as the Bill which is in the Senate. Should the other Bill be passed with further amendments, this Bill will need to be amended to take account of those changes.

The Bill represents the end of a lengthy process of consultation. I think that the word `lengthy' can be underlined. Members of the public were invited to make submissions to IPAC as it formulated its report, and to the Government in considering its response to the report. The members of IPAC itself were drawn from a cross-section of interests and view points. The working party on streamlining included representatives of the Law Council and the Institute of Patent Attorneys as well as the Patent Office. The operational areas of the Office have had the opportunity to make their contribution to streamlining the legislation they work under. Even though it meant that there had to be delays, I am sure that the consultation will be reflected in the quality and acceptability of the Bill.

The Bill is not merely a redraft, since it implements the Government's policy as outlined in our response to IPAC's report. We recognise, however, that the Bill does represent a thorough overhaul of the Patents Act with all its complexities. By disposing of some of the archaic language, and relegating procedural matters to the regulations, we hope that the Bill will be more accessible to the non-expert. But it would be remarkable if a redraft of this magnitude were perfect, despite all the care which has gone into its preparation. Some bits of the baby might have accidentally gone out along with the bath water. I would therefore be grateful to have any comment on the way in which the Bill goes about implementing that policy. No doubt there will be some diehards who would prefer to keep all the bath water in the tub-to stick to obscure terminology because it is time-honoured and familiar to their expert gaze. Obscure language may even become meaningful with the benefit of the pronouncements of generations of judges in law cases. I hope, however, that practitioners in the patent field will embrace both the policy and drafting objectives which the redraft is pursuing, and provide constructive comment on it.

I have asked the Commissioner of Patents to prepare a proposal for amending the Bill if, as we expect, further redrafting is needed. I invite the main interest groups, and anyone else who has a contribution to make, to make their views known to the Commissioner by 14 August. The intention is to get the legislation carried in the spring session so that it can be implemented before 1990. The Bill does not yet contain any transitional provisions. They will be separately drafted and introduced as amendments to the Bill or as a separate transitional provisions Bill.

Since the patents legislation creates property rights, it spends a great deal of verbiage on protecting the public interest and the interests of affected third parties, as well as those of inventors and patentees. The transitional provisions will therefore need to be complex, and I hope that interest groups will direct comments to them as well as to the substantive provisions of the Bill. I do not expect the Bill to have any great impact on the level of resources needed in the Patent Office. The Bill does involve streamlining of procedures as well as drafting style, but it also adds further requirements in some areas, such as by introducing a broader prior art base. The changes brought about by the Bill will require no net additional expenditure. The Patent Office, in accordance with Government policy, operates on a full cost recovery basis. Any additional costs will be recovered, just as any savings in costs which might eventuate will be reflected in future official fees. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill, and commend the Bill to the House.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Smith

TALK.START.PARA: —With your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker, before moving that the debate be adjourned I take this opportunity to make a brief non-political comment. We need an adjournment debate to try to better what was a most entertaining second reading speech. This is a major piece of legislation. I say without pre-stating the Opposition's position that it was good to see the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) acknowledge the work of a former Minister from this side of the House, the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), who in 1982 recognised that this legislation needed major attention. It is regrettable that it took so long, but it is good that it got here.

DEBATE.TITLE: MIGRATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989[COGNATE BILL:MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill concurrently with the Migration Amendment Bill. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill and the Migration Amendment Bill, which were introduced into this House today, were, of course, passed in the Senate. I give the Government an assurance that tonight the Opposition will be supporting this legislation. Once we pass the legislation it can then proceed to follow its normal route for implementation. The Bills are important because they considerably expand the law as we know it in relation to migration to Australia. Of late, there has been a good deal of comment about immigration. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) has offered some comments; we have had some debate in the Parliament about a resolution; and in one way or another we have muddled to the point where we have clearly on the record an affirmation of the bipartisan principles of immigration.

SPEECH.PARA: In that sense I am pleased to be able to participate in a debate where, as a result of what is called a bipartisan approach we have been able largely to agree on important legislation and important amendments to improve that legislation. I think it is important that people understand what is meant by `bipartisan'. First, it does not mean that the Government hands down on tablets its view and can immediately assume that in all respects it will be accepted by the loyal Opposition. Nothing could be further from the truth. Bipartisanship can only be obtained through the proper methods of consultation, discussion, accommodation and agreement-certainly not through silent acquiescence by the Opposition. In relation to this legislation, we have seen that that process has worked. I shall put before the House those issues in relation to which there was a degree of disagreement and where the Government and the Opposition have come to an accommodation that I see as being important. The fact that we have agreed on this legislation does not mean that from time to time there will not be other issues on which the Opposition and the Government will disagree.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's bound to happen.

—The Minister says, `It's bound to happen'; and I think it is. However, I assure the House that it will be on those issues which do not arise out of the fundamental principles of migration, such as those that have been endorsed by members on this side of the House in the vote that we took only last week. I think it is important for the House to understand that, because it will then understand the very basis upon which the Opposition will go about making its decisions, in relation to the legislation before us and to other issues that the Government puts before us.

SPEECH.PARA: The second issue that I want to address concerns the role of my predecessor in the shadow portfolio, of immigration and ethnic affairs, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill was introduced into the Senate a month or so ago. We had on record the second reading speech and the explanatory memorandum presented by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray). That was withdrawn after there was an indication from the Opposition and the Australian Democrats that there were objections to various aspects of the legislation, particularly in relation to the system of review proposed and the question of ministerial discretion.

The Minister indicated that he did not propose to redraft the Bill, but discussions were initiated by my predecessor. Although I have had very useful discussions with the Minister and have certainly found it possible to negotiate with him in a constructive way, most of the work was done before I was charged with the task. I commend my colleague for his diligence in pursuing the views of his colleagues and for seeking to have the Opposition view adopted.

The legislation that we are debating is important because it represents the Government's response to the report of the Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies. In that sense it deals with a number of questions. Firstly, it deals with the broad discretions currently found in the Act and develops criteria, both by statute and by regulations, which we will see in due course, for determining migrant entry. The criteria for classes of application which have been prescribed for a decision maker will bind those persons who are making decisions in relation to immigration questions. Decisions will be reviewable only under a new two-tier system, and the people who review these matters will be bound by the same legislative and regulatory framework.

The Bill also gives legislative effect to the modified points system applicable to classes of visa decisions and entry permit decisions that are taken by officials. Points will be allocated for criteria satisfied and aggregate point scores will be derived for each application. There will be a program of control, with a pooling system to operate in relation to visa applications, with specified marks being varied by notice in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. The Minister will have certain discretion to provide for the cessation of receiving applications-`capping', I think, is the word that is used-if the migration program objectives are being achieved. They are important aspects of the reform.

The Bill also provides for a statutory two-tier system of review of certain immigration decisions. The first tier of review is conducted by specially authorised review officers within the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. It is followed by an appeal to an external review body called the Immigration Review Tribunal-one especially created for this task. The present jurisdiction of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in relation to certain matters will not be affected. They are mainly criminal deportation questions. Of course, the present access to the Federal Court in relation to matters of procedure will apply, as it has before. The Bill also provides for mandatory deportation orders in relation to certain illegal immigrants, in addition to the current discretionary deportation proceedings that the law has in place.

Once all avenues for review of an illegal immigrant have been exhausted, if the person has not departed Australia within a certain prescribed time-I believe it to be 28 days-the department can then action a mandatory deportation order which will be signed against that person, and there will be no further review. There are provisions allowing for the release of illegal immigrants from custody under certain conditions, particularly ones for debts owing to the Commonwealth for keeping them to be paid. There is provisions to deal with the assets of persons who owe money as a result of their being in custody and their deportation. To assist in the recovery of funds for keeping such people, if they seek to come back to Australia provision is made for them not to be granted visas or entry permits unless they have made satisfactory arrangements to repay the debts owing. There are also changes relating to the way in which persons who conduct themselves as migration agents are paid, and also in relation to the representations they make about what they can achieve. These provisions are a form of elementary consumer protection. New search provisions have been included, and the act is being amended to increase penalties.

These are the broad statements by the Government as to what its Bill is endeavouring to do. It is against that backgroung that the Opposition was asked to look at the legislation, and we came to certain views about aspects of it. I want to deal with those now. Firstly, it was important that the Bill be able to be reintroduced during this session and debated, and that the development of regulations be started. Although it may be some time before the total legislative framework is put in place, nevertheless if it went past the Budget session the prospect of this legislation coming into effect in the next year or two would have become most problematic. In terms of the timetable for this Bill, the Opposition wanted to accommodate the Government's demand.

The outstanding issues related, firstly, to the place of ministerial discretion. As the Government proposed the matter in the first instance, it was seeking to provide for all decisions that would normally be made by the Minister to be placed in the hands of the Secretary to the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. The Opposition was of the view that it was inappropriate for the Minister to divest himself of that discretion, a discretion which was seen by us to be important and, certainly, was seen to be important to ethnic communities in Australia.

I was interested in the arguments that the Administrative Review Council had sought legislative changes and a certain framework in law for the making of immigration decisions, and that it saw it as being important to have a statute and regulations arising from that statute, rather than the old system of policy announcements and departmental instructions and manuals, which had long been used. I was interested to read chapter 3 of the report entitled `Review of Migration Decisions' by the Administrative Review Council. It became clear that although the Council was of the view that there was a need to have in place a much more structured framework for decisions, it was by no means certain that it was determined that its particular framework ought to be used.
I would like to take the House through some sections of the Administrative Review Council's report. Firstly, the report stated:

The Council accepts that not all areas of government activity are equally suited to the stipulation of detailed rules designed to guide the exercise of discretionary powers in primary decision making. It has considered the specific characteristics of migration decisions and, in the light of past administrative experience in the area and for the following reasons, it concludes that the administration in the field of migration requires the formulation of a range of criteria and principles which need to be of a clear and detailed character.
It gave four reasons, as follows:

First, the Council is firmly of the opinion that as a matter of individual right and justice those who are affected by decisions made in the exercise of discretionary powers in the area of migration should be able to ascertain readily the considerations relevant to the exercise of those powers . . . A second, related factor tendering in favour of the more detailed and formal structuring of migration powers is that compliance with rules and procedures relating to migration can be expected to become more widespread where their content is accessible and, it is hoped, relatively easily comprehended . . .

A third factor persuading the Council to favour the structuring of migration powers is the need for consistency and fairness in the administration of the large number of decisions made in the migration field . . .
A fourth factor is the need, in the Council's view, to give the greatest possible guidance to review bodies in which it is proposed to vest the power to review migration decisions.
It went on to say:

The Council notes that the aim of structuring more precisely and formally the exercise of discretionary powers, by means of the specification of detailed criteria and principles, may be achieved in a variety of ways of which the following are among the most significant in the context of migration decisions . . .

The Council then suggested matters such as inclusion in the statute and inclusion in the regulations, but it went on to suggest that there were other administrative systems that were equally appropriate. It was not necessarily wedded to that one system. It went on to say:

What the Council proposes in this section is the principle of greater formalisation of the structuring of the discretionary powers, to be achieved wherever possible through incorporation in the Act or Regulations . . . the Council believes that the Government should be principally responsible for determining the details of such structuring.
It seems to me that there was plenty of discretion in relation to those recommendations.

I also had a look at what the Committee of Review had to say on much the same subject. It has been put that we ought to be very much guided by what it has to say. In relation to the question of the role of the Minister, the Committee of Review has this to say:

The role of the Minister is pivotal. As the elected person responsible to the Parliament for the administration of the immigration program and immigration and citizenship legislation, his/her authority must receive paramount position in the Bill. Accordingly, our model recommends the following provisions:
Powers under the Act are to be vested in the Minister. Departmental officers have no separate statutory discretions, but act under the powers of the Minister, and with the authority of the Minister.

The Minister will have powers to make rules, subject to Parliamentary scrutiny, that define the criteria for decision making under the Bill. All powers will be exercised under the decision making regime determined by the Minister.

Our view that the Minister's place ought to be maintained was very proper. It was supported by the Government's own inquiry as being the appropriate route to take. When one looks at the Administrative Review Council's report, one finds that there was great latitude in the solutions that were offered. The rigidity attributed to them in the Minister's initial remarks was an assumption that ought not to have been made, given the independent comments on these matters.

The second matter I want to address is the regulations. Honourable members already know that this afternoon the Parliament approved of the establishment of a committee to review regulations. I spoke briefly then about the purposes of the committee, its terms of reference and the matters that the committee was to consider. It is important to note that the way the regulatory framework is to be put in place is an important part of the compromise. The committee is charged with very specific responsibilities to ensure that compassionate circumstances are taken into account. Existing policy provides for discretion on the part of decision-makers. That discretion is to be maintained in the new and formal regulated system. The committee, of which I hope to be a member, will be charged with that responsibility.

The Opposition wants to make it very clear that we accept that the Government is responsible for the making of decisions in relation to immigration; that is, who should be able to come and the number of people who should be able to come. The government of the day should be able to make those determinations in the way in which it has done in the past, that is, it should be unfettered by having to have its views checked by one or other chamber of the Parliament. That is our view and I believe it is the Government's view. I understand that the Minister has agreed to the inclusion of sunset clauses in the regulations that deal with migrant entry criteria so that if the regulations come to an end the House is not in a position to say that those regulations must continue as they have before, particularly if they led to an outcome which was unacceptable to the government of the day. Certainly if we were in office we would want to be in a position to make those decisions. We do not deny that ability to those who are in office at this time.

The third matter I want to address is the system of review. The model the Government has chosen is inquisitorial. It is new. It has been the subject of a good deal of objection, particularly from those who are used to the traditional adversarial methods, especially those available in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) and before our courts. I understand the nature of their objections. I understand why they emphasise the need for legal representation. Much of the material from law councils and the immigration forum with some of it being picked up by organisations like the Federation of Ethnic Communities Council of Australia raise questions which suggest to us a reintroduction of the adversarial approach. We know that the Government is wedded to its inquisitorial model. We have told the Government that, in effect, it can have it on trial.

We are prepared to see how that model works. It may go the same way as the inquisitorial model that was proposed for the family courts. We expect a review in two years, as promised by the Minister. It can either be by a parliamentary committee, by the AAT-as the Minister said to me in our discussions-or it can be independent of those two systems. But there must be a report to this Parliament. I give the assurance on behalf of the Opposition that we would similarly seek, in government, to undertake a review of the system to see that it is providing adequate review of decisions.

There were a number of matters incidental but important to the Opposition. I would like to mention them because they have been accommodated in amendments moved in the Senate. The Government wants to ensure that its program-that is, the target that it sets each year when it specifies how many immigrants it wants in particular categories to come to Australia-is adhered to and not exceeded in any one year. There has to be a capacity to cut off the program in any particular area. I understand that the technical term used is `capping'. The Bill enabled the closure of all or any part of the program if the numbers exceeded the annual program targets.

The Minister has agreed to two specific amendments. One was to exclude the immediate family category-that is, spouses, dependent children and aged parents. I regard it as absolutely unconscionable for a government to say half way through the year, `We have enough spouses in now, we are going to close off the category and no more people in that category can come to Australia-no more husbands and wives, no more dependent children, or aged parents'. I am glad that the Minister has made the decision to exclude those groups. We have saved the Government great agony had it persisted in that area. It is certainly a matter which would have attracted a great deal of adverse criticism. It is important also that the Parliament have available to it the relevant statistics, the capacity to look at the program, the extent to which the program has been achieved and an ability to determine the basis upon which the decision reached by Government has been taken.

The next matter I want to address relates to the 28-day rule under which people are able to access the review process. Originally, it was proposed that all those who had a reviewable decision would have to access that by making a request for review within 28 days. The Minister has agreed, if the applicant involved is overseas, to extend the period to 70 days. I want to make it clear that the decision we have reached on this matter is predicated on advice that we have received from the Minister. I have written advice-which might take me some time to read if I wanted to put it fully before the House; but the Minister might acknowledge this when he closes the debate-which makes it clear that the form of application for review is merely a request. A person may only have to write a letter saying, `I would like to have my decision reviewed'. He can then put together his evidence and information with assistance from advisers at a later date. He is not bound by a time limit.

All the Government needs to know is that that person is to appeal, and nothing more. I have received advice from the Department as to how it believes that situation is arrived at. However, I would like formal acknowledgment because if it is not proven to be the case, I would expect the Government to amend the Act.

In relation to appeals to the Federal Court, the Minister assured me that amendments would put beyond doubt that any period, while a matter is before the Federal Court, will be included in the term `excluded days' for the calculation of the 28 days used for accessing the review process in relation to deportation, which is also determined by 28 days. The Minister has also agreed that access to qualified interpreters will be provided to all who are involved in the review process. Similar provisions to those in the Social Security Act were to be put in place. The Minister assured me-and the Minister at the table, the Minister for Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Holding) may like to confirm this-that recognising the cost of obtaining advice in relation to the review process and to decisions made in the Department of Immigration support would be given to advisory bodies which are able to assist migrants. There is a real dilemma in that because of court cases, one of them involving Shaddock and Parramatta Council in my own area, officials often feel constrained not to offer advice in response to immigration questions over the counter. Often those people are then sent away to get advice from agents who might charge for it or receive it from other people in the community who have very little skills in assisting those who wish to access the system.

There are two other matters I would like to mention. The Opposition accommodated the Government by agreeing to additional amendments to facilitate the prosecution of illegal fishermen who might be brought into Australia. We did not want to see those who are not Australian citizens or permanent residents but who are charged given rights under the immigration law that they would not otherwise have simply because they are to be prosecuted for committing offences here. We facilitated the Government in relation to checking for migration, embarkation and disembarkation purposes those people who interline, that is, those people who travel within Australia, on what would otherwise be international flights.

The final matter I mention relates to some of the requests that have been put to the Government and the Opposition in relation to the handling of refugees and the operation of section 17a, which deals with mandatory deportation. I note that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) read into Hansard in the Senate a statement that was given to me in relation to this question, and I would like to put it on the record again. It states:
It should be borne in mind that the protection of the Convention and the authority to remain pursuant to the Migration Act are two distinct streams.

Those who come as immigrants come under the Migration Act and those who seek to come as refugees obtain protection under certain international conventions. There are two separate streams. While the two streams are joined at various places for the sake of administrative convenience, they are nonetheless separate and apart. There can be protection and asylum in Australia without the benefit of an entry permit.

The Minister quoted the two provisions of the convention in relation to the status of refugees which are relevant. The first is paragraph 1 of Article 31, and the second is Article 33. The Bill allows a period of grace for refugee claimants, if they present themselves without delay. I am assured that the making of a section 17a mandatory deportation order does not prevent or preclude an application for refugee status, and, if that status is obtained, the refugee has the protection of Article 33 of the Convention. I have received certain representations, including representations from Professor Crawford of the Faculty of Law at Sydney University raising possible difficult cases, and all I ask is that, if the law does not protect refugees adequately, this matter be looked at again. In other words, if the undertakings that have been given to me prove to be ill-founded, I hope that the Government will be willing to open up this question again to amend the law.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Chairman of the Government's immigration committee, I welcome the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill. I welcome the new immigration system, because, as the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) has recognised, this is an historic Bill. It sets out enormous changes in the immigration system while, at the same time retaining, the good features that we have learned from the experience of the past 30 years. Before I refer to the Bill, I welcome the appointment of the honourable member for Dundas as the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs. We look forward to a period of cooperation on a bipartisan basis in relation to immigration matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I might say, in relation to the comments of the honourable member for Dundas, that at no stage in the debate last year did we say that the Government was trying to prevent the Opposition from putting forward issues on immigration. That was not the question at all, and on many occasions the previous Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding) and the current Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) said that we were ready to countenance suggestions from the Opposition in relation to the Migration Act and the operation of the system. I believe that our good faith in this matter has been shown by the fact that we accepted a number of important amendments that came from the Opposition. We did that to achieve bipartisanship. I hope that that spirit will continue in the future.

I have described this as an historic Bill, and it certainly is that, because for the first time the legislation will provide a substantial legislative base plus a regulations base for the immigration system; that is, both the legislative and regulations base will provide a thorough and objective basis for the selection of immigrants. However, the Bill also changes completely the review process to make it thorough and objective. In doing both those things the system tries to take account of the two basic goals of immigration, namely, the consideration of Australia's national interests, including our economic interests on the one hand, and on the other hand our social and humanitarian obligations, both to our own people in terms of their relatives coming here and to refugees around the world. There is no doubt that those basic principles have been balanced well in this Bill.

So successful has this approach been that other major immigration countries are looking at copying the Australian model. Recently I returned from a visit to the United States of America where I spoke to the head of the Immigration Division, Commissioner Nelson, who said that he and members of the Congress, including the head of the congressional committee, Alan Morrison, were looking at the Australian system as a possible model for the American system. They are considering it seriously. One reason why that is happening is that we have learned from the experiences of the past and we have tried to instil those elements in this Bill.

This Bill did not come about overnight; it came about in a process of deliberations over two years, starting with the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies and then the Government's protracted discussions of those recommendations, including the acceptance of some and the rejection of others. In those deliberations, the Committee that I have had the honour to chair met more than 20 times in four months to consider amendments, changes and different ways of dealing with the problem. In addition, the Ministers have played a clear role, and I want to pay tribute to the Minister at the table, the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Holding), and to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs for their persistence in working hard to get this system into place.

Other people were involved. We must pay tribute to the National Population Council, which is headed by Professor Castles, who developed the new points system to which I will refer later. The National Population Council was asked to undertake this development because the FitzGerald inquiry did not stipulate a points system as such and left it to the Government to develop. Many other people were involved, people from the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Tribute must be paid to Wayne Gibbons in the Department and Ron Brown, the head of that Department. This has been a collective effort, but it has produced an historic Bill, which we believe, will set the pace not only for Australia but, hopefully, as we move towards greater coordination of our policies, for Canada and the United States. Those countries are looking at a system that is very similar to this system.

What are the positive features of this system? One of the most important positive features I will refer to, because obviously I cannot mention them all in the time available, is that the family reunion category and the economic category are now separate. We have rejected the FitzGerald recommendation that there be one open category. Instead, we have specified that there will be two categories, one for family reunion, and one for independent economic immigration. But we have gone beyond that. We have said that there will be independent point systems. There will be a point system that applies for the concessional family category and a point system that applies for the independent economic category. This is the first time that we have had separate systems for the two categories which recognises their differences.

In additional to that recognition, obviously there is a different emphasis. When one is looking at the issue of family reunion, humanitarian and family factors are important; when one is looking at the issue of economic independent immigration one's emphasis is primarily on skills and employability. This is not to say that the family category has no skills or employability element. It also contains that element. I think it is important in this context that honourable members familiarise themselves with the two new point systems. Mr Deputy Chairman, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which lists the new immigration points system.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. As can be seen from the table, additional points will be given for kinship and family relationship. In particular, there will be additional points not only for the actual relationship of brother and sister and nephew and niece but in relation to the circumstances of the sponsor. This is the first time we have introduced this. In particular, if a sponsor has for the last two years been continuosly employed in Australia and has not claimed benefits for the last month in that period, that person will be eligible for additional points. Why have we put this criterion in? We have put in a criterion that will ensure that relatives who are being sponsored will come to a situation in which the sponsoring relatives are not in difficult economic circumstances themselves. They will be able to assist them. You cannot force people to assist the relatives that they are bringing into Australia. That has been tried and failed. However, we can say, `Look, those people who want to sponsor their relatives should try to ensure that they themselves are in reasonable economic circumstances, and we have chosen this particular criterion.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to that, there is another very important criterion. That is the criterion which looks at certain regions which have low migration patterns. We have chosen those designated regions, as they are called in, for example, the State of South Australia, Tasmania, Northern Territory and part of Queensland. If a sponsor comes from that particular region, he will get additional points.

It should be noted, as I said earlier, that the family category will continue to incorporate points for skills, education and work experience. We are not saying that simply relationship itself is sufficient; we are still keeping that factor. Of course, the age factor is also important. The system is directed towards emphasis on younger applicants, and this is intended to ensure that we deal with the problem of the ageing of the population. Previously we had an age consideration but we have strengthened it in order to take even more account of the problem of the ageing of our population. We are directing our immigration program-both family and economic-towards younger migrants because of the age problem.

The new family category will deal with a problem that has concerned the ethnic communities for more than a decade. I refer to the fact that implicit in the previous system was the criterion that English language was required for family immigration. We have said that in the economic independent category English language is an important factor, but in the family category we have altogether taken out English language as a criterion. Now if we have somebody who is skilled, employed and educated and who has a relative from another country with little or no knowledge of English, that does not count against the relative. We say, `Let's bring that person here and help him to learn English quickly'. We are going to have programs to assist those people to learn English. In doing that we have ended an unconscious or indirect discriminatory element that existed in the previous system. We have said that if those people meet the criteria they can come here as relatives and we will deal with the English language problem for the family reunion category. But we have said that in the economic independent category English language is an important criterion. If people want to migrate under that category they should learn English. I think that is a very important distinction. It is one of the major distinctions between the two point systems.

Another very important factor is the interminable problem of the last 40 years-the recognition of qualifications. If we have a points system which emphasises so much the question of skills, education and employability, we need a reasonable system of recognition of qualifications. For the last 40 years governments of all persuasions have said that this problem is too hard. One of the disappointing factors of the FitzGerald report was that it did not deal with this problem. We have said that we are going to deal directly with this problem and we have set up interdepartmental task forces to do so. We are considering it at a ministerial level and we are talking to the unions, professional associations and other groups in the community in order to get a new system that will deal directly with this very difficult problem of the recognition of overseas qualifications. We hope that within 12 months we will be able to put into place changes which will really deal with the heart of this matter. If we do not do that, the new system will not operate as well as it needs to.

Because of the emphasis on qualifications it is very important that the recognition of qualifications issue be resolved. We ask the Opposition for assistance on a bipartisan basis in helping to get especially those particularly difficult groups in the community that do not want recognition of overseas qualifications applied here to recognise that they have an obligation to this nation to recognise the qualifications of people who are duly qualified.

The Bill before the Parliament does not in itself set down the new selection process. It establishes the general framework. Under this general framework we will establish regulations to govern the system. Those regulations, as the honourable member for Dundas has mentioned, will not be arbitrarily determined by the Minister but will be reviewed by a parliamentary committee. We have made that concession to the Opposition. We were happy to make it. The importance of that concession is that we now have a situation in which the parliamentary scrutiny, both in terms of law and regulation of the immigration system, is the most comprehensive that it has ever been and probably the most comprehensive of any system in the world. As the honourable member for Dundas said, the parliamentary committee has a very important responsibility-to look at whether the actual policy's intentions are met through the specific regulations and their implementation.

One of the consequences of this whole legislative and regulation process is that the powers of the Minister will be substantially reduced. That was almost unavoidable. If one looks at the Migration Act 1958, one will see that the Minister had almost absolute power to do anything. He could virtually admit anyone on any criteria. The Minister's powers were almost total and absolute. Even the actual system was not legislated, but was determined by the Minister himself. Under those circumstances obviously, given that there will be a legal and regulatory framework, the Minister's powers will be reduced. But the reduction of the Minister's powers does not mean that he has no powers at all. We have taken out the references to the Secretary of the Department within the framework of the regulations and the legislation and replaced it with references to the Minister.

We have achieved a very fine balance. The Minister will still have discretion, but his discretion will not be absolute; it will depend upon the law and the regulations. In this context the honourable member for Dundas quoted the FitzGerald inquiry as saying that it was very important that the Minister should retain most powers. The passage he quoted is a little ambivalent as to how many and what powers the Minister should retain. We have now achieved a fine balance between the importance of parliamentary scrutiny and giving the Minister substantial power. That balance should be retained.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not want a millstone around the Minister's neck, do we?

—We do not, but on the other hand we do not want him to have absolute power, as some people wanted him to have. Changes are made to the review system. The honourable member for Dundas mentioned that he has had representations from lawyers. Who has not? We have been bombarded by lawyers ever since we suggested the new review system. The revolutionary point about this system is that it is not an adversary system. We will take the lawyers out of the immigration process, although not completely. They can be advisers, but they will not be making thousands of dollars fighting what are very often hopeless cases on behalf of people who, quite often, they have misguided, having given them hope that they can get through an adversary system. That will not happen. A lawyer can assist a person to prepare his or her own case before the Immigration Review Tribunal at the second tier level.

SPEECH.PARA: The first tier deals with the internal review by the Department. Some people have said that, if a review is internal, surely it will not be objective. We have been given assurances that those who will be doing the internal review will not be the people who have made the decision on the selection.

The second tier is the important one. It is revolutionary in that we will set up an independent Tribunal which will judge people after asking them to come before it. There will be no interrogation by lawyers; a person will simply be asked to explain his or her case. The important thing is that the Department will not be able to appear before the Tribunal to argue against a person's review. That means that the review process will be much more sympathetic than the one that exists at the moment. We highly commend this process to everyone concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I thank the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) for his kind remarks. Having acknowledged that, I move on to the remarks of the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), who made great play of the Government's willingness to negotiate on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill. The fact is that the Opposition and the Australian Democrats had blocked this Bill and it was dead in the water in the Senate. The Government had no option but to negotiate or lose the legislation altogether. So much for the willingness of the Government to negotiate on these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: As shadow Minister for immigration at that time, I had not had an indication of the Government's intention in regard to the legislation until the legislation hit the floor of the Parliament. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) made a statement in December which broadly outlined the Government's intention. But the level of consultation to which the honourable member for Calwell adverted can hardly be considered broad and wide-ranging when the Opposition was not consulted prior to the Government's decision and had to use the powers of the Parliament to stop legislation which was abominable and not in the form that even the honourable member for Calwell wanted.

I know and the whole Parliament knows that the Caucus immigration committee was rolled time and again on this matter. As always, on such matters, it was swept to one side. There cannot be a more ineffective committee of any party in this Parliament than the Caucus committee on immigration. In this instance, but for the Opposition, it would not have won a single round. The Opposition, by blocking this legislation, brought back into the legislation the ministerial discretion that the Caucus committee so dearly wanted. Many other amendments that we have brought forward are receiving wide support because they are sensible and sound.

The need for new legislation in regard to immigration has been obvious for some time. There are a number of reasons why it is needed. The means of modern transportation and the systems that have been adopted for gaining entry to a country have changed dramatically over the past 10 years. The old Migration Act was deficient in a number of areas, particularly in regard to visas, the treatment of illegal immigrants, entry permits and a range of other issues.

However, an additional matter was causing the Government problems. In 1983, early in the Government's career, the Government had to refer to a decision it had reached with the Australian Council of Trade Unions that the basis of migration to Australia should be family reunion and refugees. The union movement did not want a skilled migration program. The accord entered into in late 1982 or early 1983 locked the incoming government into a program of migration that suited the union movement but, frankly, did not suit the rest of Australia. The Government was obliged to follow the commitment that it had agreed to in writing. It quickly moved to a program that was based on humanitarian concern, not on the skills and expertise that this nation needed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hardly.

—The honourable member shakes his head. He has not even looked at the statistics. It is not acknowledged by anybody but him that this is not the case. The Government, under Minister West, quickly reversed the Fraser Government's trend towards a fairly high level of skills with a significant family reunion component which attracted those productive, economic migrants who are critical to the advancement of Australia. Australia does not need in this day and age large numbers of factory employees. Australia needs skilled, competent people who are job creators, who have the capacity to generate downstream employment for others, who are aware of modern technology, who can communicate their skills to others, who are capable of assisting Australia to gain export markets and who can bring an entrepreneurial spirit to the Australian ethos and environment. The type of migrant that Australia needs today is vastly different from the type of migrant that Australia needed 20 or 30 years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government, at a critical time, adopted a most inappropriate immigration policy. There were successive and rapid changes of Ministers-five Ministers in five years. No Minister really had the chance to come to grips with his department and the demographic changes that had occurred in Australia, nor with the needs of the Australian community. Some of those five Ministers showed little interest in what they were charged to do, and so avoided carrying out the oath of their office. That was regrettable, because this is a most significant and important area, locked in with the training of Australians to acquire skills and locked in with the growth of families and family development-the birth rate of Australia. No area is more significant for Australia's future than this one.

It is a shame that, through the accord, through neglect and through rapid change, that very high semi-skilled or unskilled immigration program was continued for a number of years. I remember the honourable member for Calwell saying in regard to one of the changes that were made by one Minister that the concessional category was so desirable that it would be locked in place for ever and that certainly no government would dare change it for the next 10 years. Within 18 months his own Government was forced to bring about changes and impose restrictions to the concessional category of immigration. The fact of the matter is that it was so broad and so loose that, late in 1987, the program blew out to an annual rate of about 197,000 people a year instead of the targeted 120,000 a year. The Government just had to stop that program; it could not carry on. It cancelled the program and stopped officers around the world processing applications for migration.

So the successive changes the Government adopted brought about by inappropriate policies, a lack of attention, an out of date Act and some interesting reports-some produced by bodies such as the Administrative Review Council-necessitated an examination of the Act. The FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies, which was so critical of the Government's immigration program, also indicated that the Government needed to take charge of Australia's immigration program; it needed to exercise control; it needed to be fair; and it needed to have a balanced program, but one which was predominantly based on skills, knowledge and educated migrants. That was a stinging criticism from the FitzGerald Committee. At that point the Government had two options: either to have its Minister take charge of the program, as he was charged to do under the Act and by his oath of office, or to do what it has done-that is, to codify the system. We have seen this practice in many areas of the current Government's operation: when we run into a problem, write more laws and appoint more public servants. It has happened in the Income Tax Assessment Act and a similar technique has been used here.

Whilst I recognise some of the difficulties that have occurred in administrative law since the introduction of the administrative review procedures and access to the Federal Court of Australia, I am not sure that the Government's decision to codify the Migration Act is the most desirable decision. I venture to predict what will occur. There will be extended court cases on the Act and regulations, and interpretations of the Act and regulations, so we may have delays similar to the delays that are experienced in Canada-of up to four years-while decisions are made in particular cases. A body of case law will have to be built up so that the court's interpretation of what the Parliament means will be established. So the legislation, the codification and the writing down of all these matters in the law books will produce a problem.

I find it very difficult to be critical of the programs and the immigration practices of most Ministers since World War II. These have been carried out by sheer administration, by the Minister making a declaration of what the Government thinks is best for Australia's immigration program and that directive then being put into action around the world by Australian immigration officers. I cannot point to too many instances where those officers, working under administrative systems, have made many mistakes. So I guess I am saying that the Government has chosen a new direction for Australia's immigration program-one that is legal; one that is complicated for most people; and one that is also impersonal for most people.

After seeing a lot of difficulties with these proposals, the Opposition decided that, if possible, it should not allow the Government to proceed with the legislation. We decided that that decision should hold on two grounds basically, because the Minister was almost completely withdrawing from his responsibility to supervise and to keep in his hand the affairs of Australia's immigration. Australians want the Minister to be responsible. They want him to take up that charge. It is no good drawing parallels between this area and areas such as social security as the current Minister has done at times. It is a matter of people who are not in Australia being granted entry into Australia and becoming Australian citizens.

The population of this country wants to know where the buck stops. It has to stop with the Minister. The Government has decided to cast that to one side and totally regulate the area. The Opposition did not feel that that was the best way to go. I am very thankful that Senator Robert Ray has chosen to be flexible and thoughtful in regard to changes to the Act and to bring in some significant changes-if fact, all the changes that the Opposition held the Bill up to achieve. Changes in regard to ministerial discretion, in regard to the review processes and in regard to many other matters have been recognised by the Government. It has completely changed its attitude in all these areas from the time that the legislation was introduced until now. I think that is an important achievement on the part of the Opposition. A sensible balance has been struck. As my colleague the honourable member for Dundas has said, in two years time we will have a look at it again and we will see how well it has worked. That is also a sensible suggestion and concession from the Minister.

The other area that is new in this legislation is the area of reviewing decisions. The process that Australia has had up until this point has been one of immigration review panels. That was established first of all by the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) as a way of assisting the Minister to make difficult decisions on individual cases. If those review panels were established in the pattern that the Minister suggested at the time and if they had been followed in the way in which he enunciated them, I do not think we would have got into the strife that we have got into with review panels, delays and all sorts of problems. In those days review panels were supposed to be completely remote from the Department; they were supposed to work on the papers; and they were supposed to give people a fair consideration. Generally, they have but I guess that that community which depends on those decisions has not seen them as objective. Now we have a regulated process as set out in the Act, that is the way in which immigration review decisions will take place.

I must say that it is an innovative approach and one that I generally endorse. It is modelled on the original French process of administrative law. It is simple and somewhat different from the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I think those who have expressed concern ought to give it a go. They ought to let everybody see how it will work out. It could work out so well that, in two years time, nobody will want to change it. It could well be that a decision is then made to refer all reviews of migration decisions to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. It could well be that it does not work well but there will be an opportunity in two years time to make changes if necessary. The appointment of the first Chairman and that first panel will be the critical factor for the Immigration Review Tribunal. The attitudes that they adopt, the methods that they use to hear cases, the sympathy that they express and their firmness in making sure that the policies in the law are followed, will be a critical test. I trust that the Government will take a great deal of care in the selection of those personnel.

Finally, in regard to migration in general, by this process a greater emphasis is placed on the primary decision-maker-the person who conducts the interview and makes the first assessment. That is welcomed. It is time that some of the decision-making capacity went back to those people at the front line and that the importance of their role in selecting migrants for Australia and implementing government policies was recognised.

Apart from the risk of legislation delays and costly processes there is another risk in the approach that the Government is adopting. There is a real risk of having a system that is so rigid, so computerised, so controlled that Australia may not receive the migrants that we would like to see come to this country. I do not know how computers can measure attitudes; a willingness to cooperate and become involved in our society. I do not know how computers by the simple points score system can effectively judge character and willingness to settle, to stay, to make a contribution. Those sorts of judgments used to be made by officers of the Department, but now, as honourable members would know, the computerised system that we are about to see will be a matter of buttons being pushed and programs being cut off. It will be absolutely rock solid tight with little flexibility. The person who pushes that button on the computer will run Australia's immigration program.

The points score system and the computer have become this Government's policy for immigration. It has little else but a points score and a computer. What used to be the tools of immigration have become the policy. That is a great shame because the most marvellous group of people has come to Australia over the last 40 years. They have made a tremendous contribution to this nation. We will throw a lot of that away because of the lack of attention by the Government, the lack of diligence by Ministers, the lack of care by the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Those are the reasons we need a change and those reasons will bring about a highly sterile, rigid system which is so legalised that it will cause massive delays.

I wish the Government well in the approach it has adopted. It has shown a fair degree of commitment; it has shown a fair degree of willingness to come to grips with some of the basic problems. I feel that some of the answers are wrong, but I give the Government credit for trying. I also give the Opposition credit for sticking to its guns and forcing the Government to make essential changes to the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to have the opportunity to speak on this landmark legislation, the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill and the Migration Amendment Bill. Unfortunately, I missed the contribution of the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), but I appreciate his thoughtful and consistent contributions here and I have no doubt that tonight was no exception. The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) blew hot and cold. In one breath he praised the legislation and in the next he was critical of it. He cast some doubts on the effectiveness of the Caucus subcommittee in the area of immigration and ethnic affairs. That is perhaps unfair because the devotion, enthusiasm and, indeed, conscientiousness of the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) in pursuing this issue and representing the Caucus subcommittee before the Cabinet was well understood by those of us who were on that subcommittee, and the Caucus subcommittee had a significant input into this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation is very complex because it is the sort of legislation-like taxation legislation, I suggest-through which everybody is trying to drive a hole; everyone is trying to look for a loophole or an escape mechanism.
