For that reason I suggest to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) that in view of the complexity of the amendments and the already complex nature of the Migration Act, reflecting the many changes that it has had over the years, it will be almost impossible for people wishing to use this legislation to do so in the absence of a consolidated Act being available. This problem has already been recognised by the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee. As a result the Government has sponsored an amendment to the legislation to enable the Migration Act to be renumbered. This has our support. However, I ask the Minister to give an undertaking on behalf of the Government that a consolidated Migration Act will be printed and made available for sale as soon as the legislation is enacted. All of us with an interest in this area would appreciate that.

The legislation before us is the result of very sensible negotiation. It has come together after considerable consultation between the major parties in this place and with some input from the unfettered idealism which the Australian Democrats tend to show in the other place. The suggestion by the honourable member for Mitchell that immigration legislation when the Opposition was in office was very tidy and neat and that in some way it has lost its way over the last four or five years is something to which I take exception. My own experience and that of many other members is that of consistently seeing constituents in our offices about migration inquiries.

When we came to office there were enormous problems. Day after day people who had come to Australia on a working holiday, for a holiday or to visit their friends came to my office and said that the story they had been told at Australian posts all over the world was that if they came out, stayed for a while and decided they wanted to change status, it could be organised, `Nod, nod; wink, wink'. They came to our offices day after day expecting some sort of special privilege, some sort of loophole to be found-and they were successful in large numbers. This Government said, `We will stop this change of status rort. You wait in the queue in your country of origin; you cannot keep coming out here, making some sort of excuse and trying to slip past the system'. It is still the case that people take advantage of the change of status requirements. I accept that and believe that we need to be very careful about it. We are all aware of the arranged marriage or de facto relationship which is manufactured as a means of getting around the legislation. However, the Government was faced with a basic problem and it did something about it.

The problems with the immigration review panels include massive waiting periods; all sorts of different legislation; adversarial situations; and immense difficulty and heartache for people. Again, the legislation tries to do something about it. With respect to the area of discretion of the Minister, previously the legislation was run on ministerial discretion. He variously did as he wished. Indeed, it is the case that those who ask that there be unfettered discretion for the Minister are really pleading for privilege; they are pleading for exceptional access to the Minister which is not available to everybody else. They are pleading for particular opportunities for parliamentarians to approach the Minister to get some benefit, so they can gain kudos in their electorates or elsewhere. I am very proud of the fact that on this side of the House there was considerable discussion about this and although there were people who were for discretion, in the end we came down on the side of trying to make the system as objective as we possibly could because we were looking for a fairer and more objective way of deciding these things. I believe that is a considerable improvement.

The area of illegal immigrants is an immensely interesting and divisive issue in the electorate. Various estimates of the number of illegal immigrants in this country put the figure between 50,000 and 70,000. That seems like a very large number, which it is. Very often these illegal immigrants are exploited by employers and variously they exploit our social security system and other structures within this country. The numbers are not surprising. We think that between 50,000 and 70,000 illegal immigrants is a lot for this country. If one goes to Canada and the United States, one will see that the problem is massively greater than that, but it is still a considerable difficulty here. In the macro sense it is very easy to be hairy chested and to say, `Well, those people are illegal immigrants; we should do something about them; they should be sent home'. But day after day, in fact, members of this House are responsible for the sorts of tear-jerking stories that the media turn up which suggest that a particular case is different and these people should be allowed to stay. It is an area which needs to be addressed. Indeed, this legislation pays attention to the ability of the Government to act on deportation and to make those who are to be deported pay for the cost for their activities to the Australian Government. It also allows for those who are genuine refugees, who deserve the most fair and honest consideration by this Government, to have the best chance to have their cases heard. So it is sensitive and compassionate legislation also.

One of the areas that particularly concerns me within my electorate of Perth is that we have a large number of immigrants of all description but in particular in the inner city area a large number of immigrants have come recently from South-East Asia. These people very often tend to be preyed upon by what I would call very doubtful migration agents. Over the last three or four years there has been a significant increase in the number of these people. To become a migration agent, all a person had to do was fill out a standard form that was produced, pay $50 and the Secretary of the Department was required to classify that person as a migration agent. Then that person was able to put up a board outside an office stating, `I am a qualified migration agent'. In various ways these people in my electorate for a long time have been taking advantage of those who would want to be reunited with their families. Time and time again we see the names appearing when people come to a member's office as a last resort. They have been through the migration agent who had promised that he could fix this or fix that and unfortunately failed. Very often they would come to the member's office and at the same time they would be going to the migration agent. When the member was successful with the case the migration agent would conclude that it was due to his ministration and he would take the credit and charge a very hefty fee for the work which was very often done by the Department or by the local member.

The suggestion that migration agents had some special expertise or skill was very doubtful. Certainly the suggestion that they often made to their clients that they had some special privileged position was extremely questionable. If we look at the figures, it is very interesting to note that this became quite a lucrative business. In 1987 there were 284 new migration agents in the country. In 1988 there was a mushrooming to 474. We find that the same thing occurred in the area of business migration. In late 1987 and during 1988 there were literally hundreds of applications and 203 new business migration agents were approved in 1988. So we saw a considerable push in this area, considerable movement amongst those who would seek to benefit from their position. Many of them were very worthwhile advocates for their clients, but my suggestion is-and I think it is validated by my experience in the electorate-that very often the unsuspecting sponsor was ripped off by the migration agent. This legislation says that there needs to be an annual audit and review of these agents and, indeed, a schedule of fees for the agents which is reasonable and adjusted so that they can charge what is fair. Claims of influence and the sorts of spurious things that we heard in the past will be outlawed.

There are three principle changes to migration policy brought about by this legislation which I believe are most significant. In the time left to me I will endeavour broadly to pass across them. The first is immigration decision-making which I have already touched upon. Within the legislation and through regulation we will spell out the decision-making criteria. People will know how an aged parent is identified and what is necessary within that category to be successful. Whatever the criteria-whether it be for a brother or skilled worker-it will be possible to understand the position. During the period of the development of those criteria, there will be discretion in the areas which have not been set out in the regulations once the Act is proclaimed. This will be the case until those areas have come under regulation.

More than two million visas are supplied by the Government every year. It is absurd to expect in any way at all that the Minister can have anything to do with that sort of magnitude of decision making. What we need for these people is some equality in the way decisions are made. The Minister needs to have discretion in some circumstances but, more important than that, and what was originally entailed in the legislation before amendment, he also has a responsibility. That was always the case. He would always have responsibility, but the fact that he should have unfettered discretion was what we opposed.

Once again, I would say that those who ask for unfettered discretion are asking for a plea or privilege. In the past, by ministerial decree, the Minister could decide whatever he liked. There was no parliamentary scrutiny; there was no control. We are saying that we are going to set down regulations that can be disallowed by this Parliament-regulations that will now become a fixed body of law. When those regulations become law, they will be able to be overseen by the Select Committee of both Houses of this place. Indeed, that Committee will be able to see that these regulations fit within policy requirements and that Committee will be able to judge the flexibility of these regulations. A sunset clause of two years has been applied to them, after which time we will be able to assess progress. I suggest that the ministrations of the Opposition have in this way improved this legislation. Certainly, the consultation that has been undertaken has improved it.

The second part is the new review system. The old Immigration Review Panel was a former mechanism or review for immigration decisions and it operated from 1982, but it was an administrative form. It only had powers of recommendation and there were many fragilities in the system. There was the fragility about whether it was legal to charge a fee, and that has been addressed in this legislation. The new system will apply two tiers: the first will be applied by specifically appointed review officers. The review officers within the Department will be separate from those who make the original decision. There will be an independent and discrete unit of the Department and, as such, its reviews will be undertaken only on the paperwork and the information that is available. It is hoped by that system that many of the present jams will be cleared up. It is hoped that the old adversarial judicial approach will be broken down.

The second tier will be resolved between the claimant and the Immigration Review Tribunal. The Tribunal, as the decision maker, will not be adversarial. There will be no representation of the Department at that stage and, in my belief, it will provide more natural justice, more efficiency-certainly I hope it will speed up the operation of the Tribunal-and it will provide fairness and objectivity.

Again, we are saying within this legislation that we want to review that system in two years. That is a sensible approach for both the Government and the Opposition to take because, as has been mentioned by the honourable member for Mitchell, in one sense this is new ground. I endorse what he says. It deserves to be given a chance. We need to look at how it performs. The Minister will have the power to override the decisions of the Tribunal, but only when it is more favourable for the claimant. When he does do that, it will be necessary for him to report the circumstances to the Parliament. Again, I suggest to the House that it is a very fair and reasonable approach.

The final aspect of this measure that I want to talk about is the mechanism to ensure that a planned migration program is undertaken and is not exceeded. It is Australia's right to decide who comes to Australia to settle. Within the various categories that we have set out we see ourselves as perhaps having the ratio of 50 per cent family reunion to 40 per cent skills and 10 per cent compassion. Australia's record as being a compassionate country in the migration area is well understood overseas. The management of the intake is something that is very important. We have heard examples of how, in the past, it has been overshot. Indeed, the program needs to be planned so that the outcomes are not exceeded.

There are many considerations for Australia. There are economic considerations. For too long, all around this country the consideration has been that migration takes jobs, that every migrant who arrives on Australia's shores takes the job of an Australian, when it is clear that the net benefit of migration is probably the creation of jobs in this country. That is well understood. But there is concern when the economy is bubbling along in the way that it is that migration is a net growth factor. Some could argue on economic grounds that there should be a change in the numbers. I suggest that the figure of 140,000 that we have set is fair. There is a domestic labour market to consider, there is a public health consideration, and there is an infrastructure consideration. People who arrive have to have housing, places to live and jobs, and other aspects of our infrastructure are important for them.

Clearly, there is a different consideration when it comes to providing visas for people for tourism purposes. However, in each category, for those people who wish to come and stay in this country there will be a points system with a floating pass mark. If a person reaches the priority mark his application goes straight to processing. If he reaches the pool entry mark his application is recycled, and if the floating pass mark changes he might be successful the next time around. If he fails, his application will be rejected. The pass mark will be altered by gazettal and consideration will be given in the categories of skill, age and, for independent applicants, language.

There are one or two other things I wish to say about this Bill, but my time is running out. I believe that it returns objectivity. It provides for a fair system; it provides for a system that can be managed; and it answers many of the doubts about immigration that have come from both sides of this House over the past few years. In my view, this historic legislation will greatly improve the fairness, equity and objectivity of our immigration program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —One cannot help being impressed by the standard of debate on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill and the Migration Amendment Bill and the mature way that the debate has proceeded.
—It's getting better, too.

—I hope so, although it is getting very late at night. I acknowledge that this legislation will greatly improve all those issues relating to migration. I acknowledge that many of the circumstances to which the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) referred certainly need correcting. All of us in our roles as elected members of parliament go through the same sorts of representations and difficulties to which the honourable member has referred. While I acknowledge the Government's intent in this legislation, I make the point that I believe that the Opposition was correct in ensuring that ministerial discretion was not totally removed. I believe that it would be a great disadvantage to our democratic system if a Minister responsible for immigration did not have some sorts of discretionary powers.

SPEECH.PARA: While I have not done any research on this issue, I believe that in the 17 years I have been here I have probably taken personally to Ministers only five or six cases concerning applications that I believed may have been unfairly dealt with. I remember one case in particular of an African student and his family. He had finished his studies here in Australia and he came to me in the belief that, due to some past political affiliations, if he returned to his country of origin there would be reprisals and he and his family would be severely disadvantaged. The Minister of the day and his Department did a very detailed brief on the case. I was very impressed with what they did. I believe that they gave the case every consideration. The ultimate decision was that the student return to his country. It was very sad that subsequently and tragically the student and his family were murdered upon returning to their country of origin. I make no criticism of the Minister of the time or the Department because they did an excellent job. I just recite this case to show that I believe there are circumstances where a ministerial discretion is perhaps the only way a particular injustice can be determined. We must never reach a situation where regulation and control and circumstances are so strict that that sort of capacity to provide discretion does not operate.

I also find it surprising tonight that, having been a member of parliament for quite a long time and having an electorate where somewhere in the vicinity of 40 per cent of the people are either new settlers or first or second generation children of new settlers, this is probably the first occasion on which I have spoken on matters relating to our immigration policies and programs. I really set myself to thinking about why that is the case, particularly as a very large part of our office work-as the honourable member for Perth would be aware-involves assisting with passport applications and applications for migration. The reason is that up until recently-and to a large degree it is still the same-my region, the north-west part of Victoria, the Murray Valley horticultural area, has been one of Australia's most successful and excellent examples of the integration of new people into our country-people who are still proud of and are practising their own cultural ties and heritage. They are also people who recognise that they are part of this new country and have adapted rapidly. They have adopted Australia as their own nation and have worked very hard to make a success of their lives as individuals and to contribute to the economic and social values of their new country. Therefore, it is worrying to me that the very reasons why people wish to come to this great country-our freedom of speech and our democratic principles-should be the reasons for this Parliament on occasions using opportunities to misrepresent, to misinform and to create social and racial divisions for purely political or perceived political advantage.

Tonight I would like to state, briefly and in precis, the principles under which I believe the coalition has every right to operate and to portray its policies in the Parliament without fear of misrepresentation. Of course we have a bipartisan policy. However, it is fundamental to national sovereignty that the Australian government alone should determine who will be admitted to Australia. In my view, no person other than an Australian citizen has a basic right to enter this country. Apart from people admitted as refugees and for family reunion, migrant entry criteria should be developed on the basis of benefit to the Australian community and the social, economic and related requirements within Australia. Australia should not admit people for settlement who would present an economic burden to Australia through inordinate claims on welfare, health or other resources or who would endanger the community by criminal or other anti-social activities or whose entry would be to their own detriment.

It is important that the size and composition of migrant intakes should not jeopardise social cohesiveness and harmony within the Australian community. It is also important that immigration policy be applied on a basis which is non-discriminatory. I think all parties and individuals in this place would agree with that. Applicants should be considered for migration as individuals or family units and not as community groups. It is essential that eligibility and suitability standards for migrants should reflect Australian social mores and Australian laws. Polygamous unions should not be accepted, nor should the entry of child fiances or fiancees. Migration to Australia should be for permanent settlement although, of course, there can be no barrier preventing the departure of persons wishing to leave. While migrants should have the same rights as other Australian citizens to choose their place of residence individually or collectively, I believe enclave settlement should not be encouraged. Finally, I believe, as does the coalition, that policies governing entry and settlement should be based on the premise that migrants should integrate into the Australian society.

TALK.START.PARA: —No ghettos.
—No ghettos at all. Consistent with this premise, they should be given every opportunity to preserve and disseminate their own ethnic heritage.

SPEECH.PARA: I now refer specifically to this migration legislation, which includes two Bills-the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill and the Migration Amendment Bill. This is now better legislation, servicing both migrants and the general community alike, because of the mature discussion that has taken place and the debate and consultation that has taken place between the Government and the Opposition. I will briefly mention some of the changes that have occurred to this legislation and some of the major tenets of it. The changes we are debating tonight, of course, flow from the review of immigration undertaken last year by the Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies under the chairmanship of Dr Stephen FitzGerald.

There are three major features of this legislation. The first is a radically revised approach to immigration decision-making. Currently, the Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs portfolio has decision-making discretions which are totally unfettered. They give the Minister power to determine who can enter Australia and who must leave Australia. This, of course, has been accepted by the Government in the debate that has taken place as being too restrictive and amendments have been moved and accepted. As I mentioned earlier, I believe the Minister should have some discretion as, of course, should ethnic communities in our country. I acknowledge the fact that very largely the Government has accepted this view.

A second feature of the legislation is the introduction of a new two-tier review system. There has been dissatisfaction with the former review system, with the end result that in some cases a number of applicants have considered that the only way they could gain an independent review of their case was to pursue judicial review. A new two-tier system has therefore been introduced. The first tier will be a review by specialist officers of the Department specifically authorised and guaranteed independence by legislation to undertake this task. Applicants dissatisfied with the decision made by that tier will be able to appeal to a second tier of review. This tier will be a statutory authority, based independently as a review body. It will be called the Immigration Review Tribunal.

In their consideration of this section of the legislation the Opposition parties believed that the Government model was too inquisitorial. Some objectors prefer the maintenance of traditional adversarial methods such as are available in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Most of the material from law councils and the immigration forum raises questions which would reintroduce aspects of this approach. The Minister was strongly of the view that he would not compromise on these questions, particularly as they related to the change of status of illegal immigrants. He did, however, offer an evaluation of the review system after two years, either independently with a report to Parliament or by the parliamentary committee which has been established. The coalition supports this measure at this time, but will be carefully watching its operation to ensure that reviews and reports of the system become available to this Parliament.

Another major feature of the legislation is that it spells out mechanisms for ensuring that planned immigration program intakes are not exceeded. Other significant features of the legislation which have been explained in some detail by the shadow Minister for immigration, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), and other speakers in the House tonight include provisions for shifting the cost of detention and deportation onto the offender and making commercial immigration advisers accountable for their clients. My colleagues have already spelt out the major details of these Bills and, therefore, I do not intend to go into any great debate on these issues. I repeat what I said at the beginning of my speech tonight, and that is that this legislation has been handled in a way that I wish so much other legislation which has passed through this Parliament in recent months could have been.

It is to this Parliament's shame that last Thursday, 25 May, a very shabby exercise was undertaken aimed not at healing the damaging and divisive debate on this nation's immigration policy but at exacerbating and maintaining division. It was an obvious political stunt and was seen to be such by the nation, by the media and I think even, in the end, by this Parliament. As a result, it failed. It failed basically because the coalition's record, despite the rhetoric, surpasses that of the Government. Its record has been clearly and comprehensively documented by Opposition leaders in the debate that took place at that time and by those on our side of politics in this debate this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill and its associated Bill. These are important Bills which certainly deserve close scrutiny by members on both sides of the House. Like the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher), I feel that this debate has erased some of the bitterness associated with similar debates on migration issues in this and the other chamber in recent times. Certainly those who have contributed to this debate have put the record right.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is long overdue. The present Migration Act has proved to be ineffective in meeting the human demands placed on it. These demands are really the result of this country being one to which many people wish to migrate. It is seen as an el dorado to many in other countries. Certainly over the past few years an unprecedented number of people have applied to come to Australia. Obviously we cannot take them all. This means that the selection procedures and their application must be seen to be both fair and equitable. Decisions are often hard to make in individual cases. There are always borderline cases which demand some final ministerial discretion. This again makes it important that the review procedures themselves be seen to be fair and equitable. This legislation is aimed at producing both better selection and better review procedures.

In the postwar period Australia has been transformed from a monocultural society to a more polyethnic multicultural society. No-one, except racial bigots, can deny that we are the richer for the implanting of cultural diversity into this country. We cannot ignore the fact that since the end of World War II and particularly following the Vietnam war, Australia has become more acutely aware of her geographical membership of the Asia-Pacific region and of her direct involvement with several countries of the region. Increasingly, for a variety of reasons-some political and others economic and linked to trading relationships-we have as a nation in recent times been compelled to come to terms with the social, political and geographic reality: we are part of Asia. These changes of the postwar era have given the question of Australian identity a new sense of urgency. It was much easier in previous years to bandy the phrase, `We are British to our bootstraps'. Our cultural diversity today makes the task of forging an Australian identity more difficult.

The FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies identified citizenship as the ultimate expression of a commitment to Australia. No-one can disagree that immigration policy should be developed in the national interest for all Australians, as the FitzGerald report stated. That does not mean that we should discriminate in favour of or against any one nation. It does mean that family reunion is, and must remain, a key feature in our immigration policies; that we have a right to choose those with the skills and experience which will benefit Australia; that we have a right to choose who should be admitted under the refugee or special humanitarian program. Over 21 per cent of our population, or 3.5 million persons, were born overseas. I am to be classified amongst that huge number. More than one-third of the overseas born were from Britain and the Republic of Ireland. The importance of our immigration program in the post-war era is evident from the fact that since 1946, 40 per cent of our growth in population has been due to overseas migration and 60 per cent to natural increase.

In recent years the migration program has put a tremendous strain on the staff of the Department. I would like to take this opportunity of expressing my thanks to Mr David Jolly and his staff at the Perth office for their help and assistance in the variety of migration problems that come to the attention of a Federal member. I am informed that the workload in the Perth office has increased at a greater rate than in any other office of the Department in Australia. Certainly, Western Australia proportionately has the largest migrant population.

I now turn to one of the new proposals, which is to replace the present points system with a floating pass mark system. Already in this debate there has been a great deal of discussion about this matter. I do not wish to delay the House by continuing it. I think most honourable members would agree that the old points system was far from satisfactory. It created a great deal of unrest, particularly amongst applicants and their families. Whether the new system will improve the situation will be judged after it has been in operation for at least two years. Nevertheless, it will allow more flexibility in assessing prospective migrants. There is still, however, a need-and the Government has seen that need-for the Government to keep a cap on the intake so that it can remain in control of the numbers coming into the country.

I would like to commend the Government on its two-tier system of review. Again, this has been discussed at some length by previous speakers. The first tier review by specialist officers within the Department will speed up the decision-making process. Theirs will be an unenviable task, as they will find themselves in the position of making more adverse decisions than positive decisions because of the excess of applicants over places available. The second tier review is the important review. This will be conducted by the Immigration Review Tribunal. I welcome the fact that an attempt has been made to avoid creating the excesses of court like adversarial procedures which have been adopted and are being used by other tribunals. The system, whilst it excludes lawyers and also the Department, will still allow for interpreters who may be in a position to assist the applicant. This is very important in terms of the families of those from non-English speaking countries. I agree with the Minister that a non-confrontational approach in a non-threatening atmosphere is a better approach to the review of administrative decisions. However, I welcome, as indeed other members in this debate have welcomed, the retention of the ministerial power to make the ultimate decision as to who should enter Australia and who should remain here. Members on both sides of the House will agree that this Bill is a great improvement on the existing Act. It will create a fairer selection procedure and a fairer review system. On those grounds I support the Bill before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I have ever spoken quite as late at night as this.
—That is because you are so young.

—I think I have been here long enough to do it, but I do not think I have done it before. One of the reasons that I am sure honourable members are anxious to speak on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill and the Migration Amendment Bill is that we rarely get the opportunity to debate immigration legislation. It is not common to have such legislation in the House, and those of us who are interested in the subject consider it important, so we do not like our time to speak being shortened. But I will try not to be too repetitive in what I say so as not to unduly prolong the procedings.

SPEECH.PARA: These Bills are the conclusion of a rather long process of review of Australia's immigration policies, notably the review undertaken and reported on by the FitzGerald Commission to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies. It was not with the setting up of that inquiry and its report that the issue came to light. For some years now there has been dissatisfaction with the working of the immigration process and there has been an acknowledgment of the problems in it. This Bill attempts to address those problems and to provide solutions. Along with, I am sure, many other members on both sides, I do not feel it is a perfect solution, but those of us who have spent many hours discussing the alternatives and the proposals have had to come to the conclusion that this is one of those areas where there is no easy solution and that whatever we propose is manifestly imperfect. However, this changed system attempts to address in a realistic way the very real problems that have been building up in the system of immigration review.

I have mentioned the contribution of the FitzGerald report, but I would also like to acknowledge that I think this Bill has its genesis, at least partly, in a number of legal decisions. I, along with a number of my parliamentary colleagues, have become increasingly concerned at what appears to be an interest of judges in involving themselves in how migrants ought to be selected for this country. Although I am a lay person, I have been mystified by the conclusions of the judges on occasions in ruling on cases before them. It seems to me that parliamentary and government intent on the process that was desired to be undertaken or thought desirable to be undertaken was clear. Some of those judicial decisions have unearthed complexities and possibilities that those of us who have been involved in the process for years would never have dreamt were possible. One can only hope that this legislation will rectify the problems that those decisions have raised for this country.

The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), in his speech, made the statement that he believed that this Bill would lead to a lot of legal processes and lengthy court cases. I think that is probably right. It is probably inevitable, whatever we do in this area. However, there is quite an immigration review industry in this country, partly because of the build-up of pressures of people wanting to enter the country and the reduction in the last decade of the migration program. We have had some significant refugee programs in that time, and some pressures close to hand and overseas from people who feel that they need to come to this country, and from many others who feel that they want to.

I do not know whether it is my imagination, but it seems to me that the problem of illegal immigration has grown in recent years. When I entered Parliament in 1974, 15 years ago, we were starting to see the process of people with imperfect English coming here on visitors' visas and, when they arrived, telling the immigration officials that they believed that the approval of that visitor's visa meant that they had been accepted as migrants. There was great concern that people were being told that in their country that was correct and were being preyed on by people who knew very well that the approval of a visitor's visa did anything but give approval for them to stay in Australia for a long time.

It is my conclusion that since then the whole process has not so much changed in kind-that industry continues-but it has become more sophisticated and streamlined. As we hope we are closing one loophole another is discovered, and plane loads of illegal immigrants arrive in this country, something that would have been unthinkable 15 years ago and certainly a little further back than that. That may be partly as a result of pressures in the area and an awareness that Australia is a place where people have the possibility of humanitarian consideration of their case. I suspect it is also because the process of appeal and review has become so much the province of the lawyers, the courts and the judges. That has encouraged that sort of traffic in migrants-in human beings.

Over the years we have all witnessed many sad and worthy cases in which Ministers have sought to deport people who had no right to be here and whose story might well have been one that would appeal to one's softer nature. But those people had no right to be here and resided in Australia clearly in the knowledge that they had no right to reside here. We have all heard anecdotes in this debate, and I have a clear recollection of a case in which I was involved as the honourable member for Moncrieff. A married couple, illegal immigrants from Hong Kong, had come to Australia with two children on a visitor's visa. Their pattern of activity and residence since they had been in the country-which, by then, was six or seven years-made it clear that from day one they had intended to be nothing other than illegal immigrants. In the time they had been here they had had three more children who, under our previous citizenship laws, were Australian citizens. By the time they were detected and under an imminent deportation order-and that was when I first encountered them-the children who arrived with them had started school at Catholic schools and were as Australian as any child whose parents had a perfect entitlement to be here. I was approached by a school principal, who pleaded with me that these children were really Australian children and that it was not right to send them to Hong Kong.

My reaction to all that was essentially anger with the parents, that they would do that to their own children. Nevertheless, the parents had followed a fairly sophisticated pattern of activity and residence from the time they had come to Australia. They had owned and sold homes and businesses; some businesses had been successful and some had not. At that stage the father, whilst under a deportation order, had just purchased another business. Part of the basis of his plea was, `Give me a chance to make a go of this one and see what a good citizen I can be'. I may be a little on the conservative side, and maybe my school mistress background emerges on occasions like this, but my simple view is that people who come here with the intention of breaking our citizenship laws do not make a very good beginning as good Australian citizens. They are behind the eight-ball with me when they start.

Nevertheless, there are cases in relation to which I too have gone to the Minister. Various honourable members have tonight referred to the importance of ministerial discretion. Initially, this Bill would have eliminated ministerial discretion. In referring to the process that has culminated in this Bill before the House, I have so far referred to the FitzGerald inquiry, parliamentarians' contributions, through criticism, and the legal decisions.

I think that I ought to put on a par with that the contribution of the Opposition to the final form of this Bill. We were disturbed at the removal of ministerial discretion, but not because we want to be able to go and ask for favours for those who may have caught our ear. I know that I speak for both Government and Opposition members when I say that anyone who spends any time in this place inevitably encounters the totally worthy case of someone applying to migrate who does not fit the categories or the rules, who, so far as the provisions are concerned, appears to be a square peg trying to be pushed into a round hole. One knows that one is dealing with a person who is entirely worthy, a person that the country would welcome, a person who has proceeded in a legal way-not in the way of the illegal immigrants to whom I have just referred-and a person from whom this country would benefit by having as a resident and ultimately as a citizen. Surely it is the ultimate objective of any immigration legislation to identify, among the people who want to come to this country, those who could make a good contribution to it and would be good citizens.

During my 15 years in Parliament I have taken four such cases to various immigration Ministers. It has to be an extraordinary case and the application must be entirely worthy before I take such a course to gain approval. I have not always been successful. Indeed, I am sorry to say that, in those few cases that I have taken forward, I was rather less successful under the Fraser Government than I have been under the Hawke Government. It is important, when dealing in this human area, to have a mechanism by which individual human aspects of a case can be taken into account. When one is dealing with human beings, there are as many different cases as there are people on the face of this earth. I am pleased that, after the Senate held up the Bill, the Government has decided to reconsider the matter and reintroduce minsterial discretion in specialised cases. Of course, it is up to the Minister to decide whether to use that discretion. If we had a Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs who believed that it was inappropriate that ministerial discretion should be exercised, it would be open to that Minister not to exercise it.

Because of the legal processes that I referred to earlier, we have a very big backlog and some very real problems in processing immigration review cases. I think it is fair to say that that appears to be producing a situation that we do not want. I would defend the right of the government, rather than the courts, to determine the immigration program. Even while I am in opposition, even if I do not necessarily agree with the Government's programs, I will defend its right to determine the immigration program. I will certainly defend the right of Parliament to be involved at all stages. It is possible that this new approach of putting into regulations a lot of detail that was not there before will extend the legalistic nature of the handling of immigration decisions. On the other hand, it is a defence of government policy that clearly is needed.

I look forward to the operations of the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations. Over the years there have been different suggestions about having a parliamentary committee on immigration, though not necessarily for the reason for which this Committee is being set up. It appears that in this case it is an entirely appropriate way of handling regulations under the legislation. I welcome the fact that the Minister has accepted the Opposition's submission that there should be equal numbers of Government members and Opposition members on the Committee, although of course the Government has the right to supply the Chairman. I hope very much that the Committee will act in a way that achieves the objectives of its establishment. Actually, I am quite confident that it will. I hope that that will continue for years into the future, if the Committee endures that long. I hope that the Minister's act of goodwill towards the Opposition in accepting the changes that were requested will be vindicated by the actions of both Government and Opposition members. I look forward to serving on that Committee. I think that contributions to the debate by others who are clearly members of the Committee indicate that it has an excellent chance of operating in a spirit of goodwill.

As I said at the beginning, I do not want to protract the debate unduly by just repeating what others have said. I have sought to highlight those areas that I think are most important and I have much pleasure in joining with my Opposition colleagues to support the Bill, particularly for the reasons outlined by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like--
—This is going to be an unbelievably short speech.

—The Leader of the House is absolutely correct. The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill is such an all-encompassing Bill that there are very few things in it that one could criticise and therefore there are many things that one could support. I think for the first time the Bill adds a systematic approach to the immigration system in Australia. The approach is spelt out by legislation and ensures that the Government will be able to have some control over its immigration program.

SPEECH.PARA: The major features of the Bill are a mechanism to ensure that the planned intakes are not exceeded and that there will be a mechanism for providing people with an appeal system. There will also be a provision in the Bill to make commercial immigration advisers accountable to their clients. There has been a formal mechanism for review in the legislation since 1982 but it has been administrative rather than legislative and sometimes the powers have been rather difficult to appreciate. The new two-tiered system will be fair, economical, informal and, most importantly, quick. In my electorate, there are probably more people not born in Australia than in any other electorate in the country. What really gets on their goat is the fact that the review process takes so long. On behalf of my constituents I congratulate the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) on the new system. Its informality and absence of legalisms will be the key to the operations of the new Immigration Review Tribunal.

The Tribunal also will be designed to permit claimants to put the merits of their cases in a factual and straightforward way. They will not need formal representation though they will be allowed to have someone appear with them to assist them in their case. The Tribunal will examine the papers relating to the case-that is, the material put forward by the applicant and that prepared in the course of the primary decision of the review process. If the Tribunal can make a decision favourable to the applicant on that material, it will do so and that will be the end of the matter. If it cannot, it can make such a decision on the papers. If it cannot make a decision on the papers, it will invite the applicant to give oral evidence before it makes a final decision.

As I said earlier, the applicant will be able to be accompanied by an adviser. One would hope that people will not end up being accompanied by legal advisers but by people who are versed in the system and who could act as friendly assistants in the process. Of course, the Minister may override the decision of the Tribunal in cases where a more favourable decision could be established. In those cases, quite properly, the Minister will have to make a statement to the Parliament.

In the case of the applications by people already in Australia, once a decision is taken and reviewed the applicants should have to leave Australia if the application is not favourable to their point of view. The decision on any further application will not be renewable. One of the difficulties people in my electorate have is that at present the process offers numerous avenues for review. Unscrupulous people in both their communities and the wider community try to encourage people to go to the ultimate type of review. That gets people's hopes up. In the end they have spent a lot of money and achieved nothing. Because it will be far quicker and easier to understand, I think the new system will be a far better one to have.

The thing I find most satisfying about this legislation is that the Minister has finally decided to take action against those people who provide advice for a fee-the so-called immigration agents. The current legislation, prior to this Bill being enacted, simply requires a notification by a person who intends to act as a migration agent. Those provisions will be repealed by this Bill, which will substitute sanctions aimed at ensuring a responsible commercial relationship. Advisers will be committing an offence when they claim that they can influence or have influenced the making of a certain decision either in their own right or through a third person.

I also hope that they will be committing an offence when they take people's money and fail even to lodge an application, as has been the case with many people who have been into my electorate office. For a long time I have been concerned to have some regulation introduced into the migration agent industry. There are many very reliable and honest people providing a service to people at a reasonable cost; but unfortunately, as the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) would well know, a number of people who have set themselves up as migration agents are, quite frankly, ripping these people off. Not only do they not know what they are talking about but they charge exorbitant prices. I have had complaints about solicitors charging $1,000 or $2,000 for writing a letter to the Minister on behalf of a client. In fact, the cheek of one solicitor is beyond belief. He sent one of his clients to me. He charged the person $1,000 for writing a letter to me asking whether I would see the person. The person then came and asked me to write a letter to the Minister. This solicitor ripped that poor unfortunate person off for $1,000. They are the sorts of disgraceful things that were happening in the migration agent area.

Gloria Bourke in Sydney was one of the more notorious agents. She operated in my electorate for a long time, cheating people. She seems to have left the country in a hurry. Fortunately, that is good for the people of my electorate. Unfortunately, she left too quickly for the law to catch up with her. Sol Baltinos of the New Settlers Federation-a person whom my friend the honourable member for Dundas has criticised frequently in the past-has failed to lodge papers for a number of my constituents despite assuring them that he would be taking money for membership of his so-called federation. He has been charging them thousands of dollars-stealing from them; stealing from people who are very afraid of the position they are in. He is a person to whom the old Australian term `bludger' would certainly apply. If there was ever a bludger in Australia, it is Sol Baltinos.

These leaches prey on people who are very vulnerable. They are victims who have usually exhausted all the regular avenues of review. More often than not they are illegal immigrants in Australia and they are desperate to hear that there may be a way around the system. The claims of influence with either a Minister or someone in the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs at a price that are peddled by these agents are readily believed by these unfortunate people. Until now they have had no comeback.

In these regulations the Minister proposes that there should be some way to stop this. The Minister should be commended for that. In the legislation the Minister has also proposed that there be regulations that will be renewed every two years. That is a good idea because unfortunately in the past this piece of legislation has been set in concrete. It has been difficult to change. In the immigration area regulations are probably the best way to do it. The fact that the Minister is proposing to set up a committee of the Parliament to deal with it is a very good idea because it allows people who are involved in the area to have input and a say in it.

I think that the Minister has made a small mistake in setting up a new joint committee to do it. The most appropriate way would have been to provide a reference to the various Senate and House of Representatives committees, which could have met from time to time on a joint basis and made decisions on these matters. To digress just a little, I think that we are now adopting a position in the Parliament where if someone comes up with a problem we set up a new committee. I think we should be using the standing committees of both the House of Representatives and the Senate to deal with these matters, rather than setting up a new joint committee to look at the specific problem.

I commend the Minister for the two areas of the legislation that I have outlined. If it ensures that those who batten on to desperate people are brought under some sort of control, for that reason alone this will be a very important piece of legislation. If it ensures that the Gloria Bourkes and Sol Baltinoses can no longer bludge on unfortunate people, Minister Ray will have done a very important thing. I commend the Bill to the House on behalf of my Party and the people of my electorate, who probably have more need for and access to services in the immigration area than the people of any other electorate in the country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 I pay tribute to the many migrants who have come to this country, particularly those who came after the Second World War. Everyone in this House tonight is the son, grandson, daughter or granddaughter of migrants. Our indigenous population is only about 1 1/2 per cent of the total population, so we are all sons and daughters, if you like, of migrants. What an important role they have played in developing this great nation.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of the lateness of the hour, it is not my intention to speak for very long, but I wish to say how disappointed I was, as were other honourable members, with the Government's actions last week in trying to split the coalition or gain political advantage on the question of migration. Migration is one of the most important issues this country faces. It is important that we get our migration policy right, which is why I welcome this Bill and some of the improvements that will be made to the migration system through its application.

It is not often that we get a chance to speak in the Parliament about migration. Most of the honourable members who spoke before me have spoken eloquently about the Bill, and I do not intend to go over what they have said, but I want to raise a few issues on which the Minister Assisting the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding) might say a few words or the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) might take on notice. No doubt the Minister has already studied them. I know that he is fairly well versed in what is happening in the country in regard to migration.

There are five categories of migrants: independent and concessional, family, skilled and business, refugee and humanitarian, and special immigration. One matter that has been raised with me by people in my constituency relates to the business category. Rumours are circulating that people are involved in what the Minister calls scams in this area. In the business category, a person who has $500,000 to invest in a commercial enterprise which has the potential to increase exports or decrease imports, create jobs or introduce new technology has a good opportunity of migrating to Australia. A rumour is circulating in various electorates that some people who have wanted to migrate to Australia but have not had $500,000 have borrowed the amount, have paid interest on the money and paid some of it back before coming to Australia; and, after having migrated to Australia, have given the money back. I do not know whether this is possible, but it is certainly a strong rumour in my electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has to be investigated.
—It must be investigated. I agree with the Minister that anyone who migrates under those pretences, or any pretences whatsoever, is jumping the queue ahead of people who have a right to be here.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill touches on the matter of illegal immigrants. Although in Australia we do not have the problems with illegal immigrants that the United States, West Germany and other countries have, we still have a problem. I have noticed that some media people have a filing system with articles on shark attacks, the Bogle-Chandler case, the love life of Princess Margaret, something about Don Mackay and so on. Each month they pull something out-Don Mackay one month, Princess Margaret another month, and so on. If they find an illegal immigrant, they think that is wonderful because then they can go to town and play on the bleeding hearts of Australia, giving all the reasons why the person should stay here-never mind that the person has broken the law and is jumping the queue in front of people who should be here first. So I have very little sympathy for those people. I have a great deal of sympathy for Ministers who in the past have had to face this barrage. Of course, some Ministers have given in, for one reason or another, and perhaps that is why some members of the Opposition are saying that they do not agree with the total discretion of the Minister being taken away. No doubt there are some genuine cases, but I would say that in the majority of cases these people do not deserve to jump the queue in front of others and should be sent back to their country of origin.

Another matter I would like to touch on is the matter of acquired immune deficiency syndrome. I know that this is a health problem, but it is my belief that every migrant coming to Australia should be checked for the HIV infection before he comes here, with the intending migrant paying for it. Refugees should be checked in Australia, and we would have to pay for that. I do not think that it should stop there. Because of the nature of the HIV infection, whilst I am not a medical specialist I understand from what I read that sometimes it does not become evident for a number of months after infection. After these people arrive in Australia there should be another check, perhaps within the first 12 months, which should pick up about 90 per cent of cases. If these people do have the HIV infection, I do not believe they should be given permanent residency. This is not because I do not believe on a humanitarian level that we should not look after these people; of course we should. But the cost to Australia in looking after people who are already here who are infected by the HIV virus is going to be absolutely horrendous. It will take all our resources to look after them. If more infected people are coming in, not only will we have to look after them but it will cost an absolute fortune. In addition, there is the risk that they could pass on that infection to other people.

Another matter I would like to raise-and because the hour is getting late it will be the last one-is the question of visitors' visas. A number of people in my electorate have wanted their relatives to come to Australia from different countries throughout the world. In the countries of origin the embassy staff interview these people and decide whether they are coming as visitors or have another intention. In other words, they are a little afraid that they will become illegal immigrants. I have here a copy of a letter that has been sent to the relative of a constituent of mine. I will just take the time of the House to read this letter. It says:

I refer to your application for a visitor visa for Australia. Under current policy relating to applications received from persons seeking to visit Australia, visas are only granted to those persons who are assessed as being genuine visitors. In examining applications an assessment is made by the Australian Officer at this Embassy as to whether a person may wish to obtain visitor entry for other purposes, such as residence, employment or study. Careful consideration has been given to your application, but after taking all factors into account it has been assessed that the true purpose of your proposed entry into Australia may not be for tourism. In the circumstances, I am sorry to have to tell you that your application has not been approved. Yours sincerely . . .

A number of people have come to my office and said that what this letter is really saying is that `Your brother' or `cousin', or whoever, `is telling a lie; he or she does not want to come for the purpose of a visit'. I know it is a very touchy subject and one has to be very subtle about it, but I just wonder whether perhaps the wording of that letter could be changed slightly so as not to give that impression.

Finally, I would like to again impress upon the minds of everyone the importance of immigration to this country, particularly as, with our present tax regime, it is becoming almost impossible for young couples to have families and, therefore, to populate Australia by natural means. I hope things improve in the near future so that we can increase our population in that way as well as by migration. For the future of Australia, I believe that both natural growth and migration are the means of making Australia a prosperous nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that the hour is late. However, being a migrant myself, I would like to add an authentic voice to this immigration debate. The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill and the Migration Amendment Bill represent a major overhaul of our immigration policies and give a long overdue legislative base from which to introduce regulations to govern our immigration intake. These regulations will enable everyone to know what criteria apply, those criteria having been set before this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation contains a number of measures dealing with illegal immigrants and it sets a legislative base for review of decisions-a two-tier system of internal review and a review by the Immigration Review Tribunal. It also sets down a legislative base to achieve a total number of immigrants in a particular year, specified by the Government according to our ability to receive and absorb migrants and to provide them with the necessary services.

One thing that this policy and the regulations will ensure is that whatever criteria are set down, they will not take any account of the race, colour, nationality or religion of the people that we are going to receive. In whatever way we select our migrants, it will not be based on colour or race. Of course, that is a big advance on the past.

My Party is not quite innocent as far as racism is concerned in immigration. Our national platform of 1904 stated that we had to choose migrants so as to maintain racial purity. Our platform went on later to establish the categories of people that we should receive-a mixture of British and non-British people-and we finished up later with the white Australia policy. We were accused of that recently in a debate to which I do not want to refer tonight. However, whilst I do not know the history of the Opposition's policies, I can say that I know its practices.

I came to Australia from Italy in 1954 on a ship called the Neptunia. Just before we landed at Fremantle, a number of immigration officers accompanied by a couple of doctors came onto the ship, and they looked at our fingernails. I wondered whether they were checking to see whether our personal hygiene was okay; but no, they were looking at us, and at our fingers, to establish whether we had a negro ancestry. That was the practice during the period of the great arch-reactionary Prime Minister Bob Menzies. So, if we look at history, I do not think that either major party has much to be proud of in regard to immigration policies or practices. However, we have moved a long way since then. By the time the Whitlam Labor Government was elected, we had a policy which did not discriminate, and we had a practice whereby we started to look on migrants not as factory fodder, not as people brought here just to work in factories and to turn the wheels of industry, but as people who had human needs. That practice was continued during the period of the Fraser Government. I pay a tribute to former Prime Minister Fraser, because his views on race and colour and on that aspect of our immigration policy, or race and colour in general, were very humane. I think it will take the rest of his Party a long time to catch up; but I will come back to that.

I want to mention how our immigration policy developed in a bipartisan way to look at immigration as a means to increase our population, to be humane about it, and not to be selective in regard to race or colour, until about 1984, when Blainey suddenly discovered that we had too many Asians here and that this was the breaking point that the Australian community just would not tolerate. He did not conduct a survey; he just guessed this. As an academic I would have expected more of him. I would have expected him to make a study of the population's tolerance. He never did so. The surveys were done later by the media. If we ask someone whether he wants a slit-eyed Asian, or someone like that-using derogatory terms-as his neighbour or to marry his daughter of course the answer will be no. Blainey will be vindicated by a mass of rednecks if we put the question that way. Unfortunately, following Blainey's racist outbursts we have seen the former Leader of the Opposition voicing his concern about immigration. Last year on 1 August he said:
I do believe that if in the eyes of some in the community it-
meaning Asian immigration-
is too great, it would be in our immediate term interest and supportive of social cohesion if it were slowed down a little . . .

He was followed on 12 August by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), who said that the figures showed that there were too many Asians coming into the country. On 9 August Senator Stone said:
Asian immigration has to be slowed. It is no use dancing around the bushes.

I accept that the former leadership of the Opposition is now on the back bench. I hope that we are returning to some consensus as far as our immigration policies are concerned, not only in relation to intake but also as far as dealing with people who are already here by giving them equal opportunity and equal rights and supporting multicultural development. We should give rights to people whether they have come from Asia, Africa, Europe, England or elsewhere to be just as Australian as they wish, as anybody else who is of any other tradition. It is not the privilege of only those who migrated here from the United Kingdom a few generations ago to be Australian. It is a privilege that we have to extend to everybody if he wishes to take part in the building of this nation because that is what immigration is about. I wish that the consensus that we are talking about in this Parliament were extended to Opposition parties.

I have had to face four elections. The first candidate that I stood against issued a letter mentioning my name, which I changed 30 years ago never thinking that I would be in politics. I had a long name which was very hard to spell. My brother who migrated to Canada changed it to Kent and my brother who came here before me changed his name to Kent. So I naturally took it on without any thought that I would want to sound English, British or whatever. It was easier to spell. There are only four letters in the name Kent. The first thing Opposition candidates do when they oppose me is dig up my old name, distort and misspell it, and they print in the literature in block letters that I am foreign born. They suggest that I am somewhat less than others and that I should not have the privilege to serve this nation because I did not come here generations ago. As a matter of fact, I am a second generation Australian. My father came here a year or two before me. I followed him; I followed my family. My father and mother are buried in my electorate and my grandchildren are growing up here.

If someone wants to tell me that I am not serving this nation as well as anyone else, I want to see him outside. But nothing helps; people never learn. They think they will appeal to the rednecks if they print my old name. I am not ashamed of it. I can spell it out; that is not a problem. They highlight the fact that I am foreign born and suggest that I am somewhat less than one who came here three, four or five generations ago. The same people would not put those who came here 40,000 years ago on a pedestal. They look down on them too. They cannot have it both ways. We are all equal. We are all human beings. We are all here working together to build a better future for our children. Or are we trying to judge each other by our ancestry?

It will be a sad day for this nation if we turn child against child in our schools and judge each other on the basis of our origins, whether Irish, British, European, Asian, Aboriginal, or anything else. I can tell the House one thing: I agree with the former leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), with respect to one Australia. I am for one Australia; we are all for one Australia. But it depends what we mean by one Australia and what we mean by multiculturalism. Multiculturalism certainly does not mean that we will build little Italys, Greeces, Yugoslavias, Vietnams, Irelands, or United Kingdoms in this country. We will build one nation, an Australian nation, but we will be of varied origins and will all have the right to contribute and to bring our heritage here-just as the Irish did, just as the Aboriginals did, and just as other migrants will continue to do.

I am a great friend of the British. I admire them and have done so since the war. They are a people with backbone. They stood up alone against Hitler, for which I greatly admire them. I admire Britain's institutions, its democracy and its Parliament. We brought from Britain our trade union movement, as well as our individual freedoms and a free press. However, let nobody think that I, who admire that system and will fight to maintain it, will be put down by people who say, `He is foreign born and has a foreign name. Let's distort it and use it as propaganda so that a few rednecks might vote against him because of his name'. Honourable members opposite can tell whatever party member might contemplate standing against me that these tactics do not help. We thrashed them; we trounced them very soundly four times in Hotham. If that does not prove the tolerance of the average Australian, nothing will.

Australians will not follow anyone down that path of discrimination and intolerance. Anyone who takes up that path will lose not only the migrant vote, but that of every decent Australian. My advice is that, while we might have different political views and different ideas about how we can help this nation and create a better future for it, we should never divide on racial grounds, because we came from 70 or 80 different nationalities and our children and grandchildren will go together to school and will work shoulder to shoulder in factories or offices. If we ever judge each other by our ancestors, it will be a sad day. I propose that we look at our individual merits, our individual achievements and our individual contributions to this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with a great deal of interest to the contribution of the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent). I am a bit disappointed that some of the things he said were said about the past. I have found in a number of different facets of life that hindsight is 20 : 20 vision and that, looking back, one would do it differently with regard to a number of aspects of Australia's approach to the migration program over the years. It was not as easy at the time to perceive those sorts of situations as it is now, but overall I do not think for a moment that Australia has anything to be ashamed of in terms of its immigration program over very many years. I always feel very aggrieved when people within or outside Australia accuse Australians of being racist. Australia has a magnificent record in terms of its acceptance of people from many different nations. The honourable member for Hotham mentioned 80 nations, but the people who make up the modern Australian state come from well over 100 different nations. The percentage of overseas born, as a proportion of the total population, is second only to the figure for Israel.

SPEECH.PARA: We have, I think, in so many ways provided an example of which we can all be proud and for which we should argue strongly. We should never allow any critics to suggest that we are in any way inferior to any other nation in the world in terms of racial tolerance. If one looks at countries in the region and outside the region we stand up as a nation very well indeed. Just before I leave this subject, I think that the presence of the honourable member for Hotham in this chamber demonstrates very clearly the acceptance by the Australian people of people from all different backgrounds and the capacity that such people have to make a success of their lives in Australia. If honourable members look at successful stories in Australia, they will find that they are the stories of migrants in so many cases. Many migrants from so many different countries have contributed--

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you learn anything about the Australian habit of going home at 12 o'clock?

—The Leader of the House has encouraged a long speaking list from his colleagues. I thought that his colleagues were being limited to 10 minutes, but some speak a little longer than others. I will return to the subject under discussion. Australia provides the opportunity for people from so many different countries to make a success of their lives in this nation. I think it is something that we can be inordinately proud of.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill has been brought about simply because we have had the development, in a very real sense, of an immigration appeal industry. A ridiculous state of affairs has arrived whereby people within that immigration appeal industry are creating a situation which has virtually brought the administration of immigration policy in this country to a standstill. The general community is very aggrieved by the fact, for example, that some people who have no right to claim entry to Australia, nevertheless simply by being here have been able to have access to legal representation paid for by the Australian taxpayer. That is just one example of how the situation has developed which has caused very real concern throughout the general community. This Bill is an attempt to overcome the problem of the immigration appeal industry which we have seen developing over recent years. What has also happened is that the final delineation of immigration policy has, to a certain extent, been taken away from the Parliament and placed in the hand of the legal fraternity. That is a completely wrong situation to have developed. I commend the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) for doing something about overcoming that situation. Obviously immigration policy in this country should be made by the Parliament. It should not come about as a result of legal interpretation outside this Parliament.

In the original form the Government put forward some suggestions which the Opposition took exception to-in particular what appeared to the Opposition to be a handing over of the role of responsibility from the Minister and the Parliament to the Secretary of the Department and to the bureaucrats generally. I am happy to pay tribute to the Minister and his officials for the way in which those differences and difficulties have been worked through in consultation over some time now and we have achieved in large measure agreement as to the final shape of the legislation. If we can continue to work together-part of the Bill brings about a situation where that cooperative effort can be maintained-we will be going a long way towards developing a much stronger, unified approach to the whole difficult question of the administration and development of immigration policy generally.

I am glad that this cooperative effort has occurred. I hope that we will see a continuation of that strong wish which comes from this side of the Parliament to develop a cooperative approach to what are essentially, as we have seen over the years, very sensitive policy issues. Finally, I am extremely pleased that the Minister and the Government have agreed to the fact that the formulation and development of immigration policy should be maintained within the Parliament and that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs will retain the pre-eminent role in policy administration, which was the case in the past.
Friday, 2 June 1989

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that the hour is late and pressure is being placed upon us not only by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) but by our colleagues on both sides of the chamber in their keenness to terminate this debate and leave this place at a reasonable hour. It is early in the morning. I am pleased to speak in this debate because the Northern Territory, as most honourable members will know, is an extremely multicultural society. This landmark legislation will be of immense benefit to my constituents and will give them a great deal of pleasure.

SPEECH.PARA: There can be no doubt that migration not only plays a very significant role in the long term growth of our community by providing an economic base, skills for the labour force and capital infrastructure but also, most significantly in my view, adds essentially to the social fabric of our society. It is that aspect of the legislation and particularly the family reunion program that I am keen to support. The Northern Territory in recent times has been the beneficiary of a large number of migrants who have come to Australia as refugees from South East Asia, particularly from East Timor or Vietnam. If they have not come as refugees, they have come under the family reunion program. They have added significantly to the Northern Territory with their culture and their skills.
