It was stated earlier in the debate that one-fifth of Australia's residents in 1986 had been born overseas. Most of those migrants chose to live in our cities. Perth's population had the highest proportion of overseas born-33.5 per cent-and Darwin in my electorate had 27.7 per cent of its population born overseas. It is significant, as I said, that the Asian population has increased dramatically over the past decade. This trend is particularly noticeable in Darwin. Darwin is the Australian city that is closest to Asia. That is often referred to as Australia's front door. I certainly acknowledge that it is. It reflects our longstanding connections with our northern neighbours, particularly most recently the Philippines and Indonesia and, within Indonesia, East Timor. Of the recent South East Asian born migrants in Darwin, almost one-third or 29.7 per cent were born in the Philippines and 17.7 per cent in Timor. Vietnam has provided 16.2 per cent of our migrants and Malaysia 13.2 per cent. The general principles of this Government's migration policy, this landmark policy, not only served the national interest but are also non-discriminatory. The policy fulfils the most important of humanitarian obligations to refugees, and the family reunion component, as I said, is of essential and vital importance.

To me, the dramatic impact of this legislation is its rejection of racism. The debate which the community has seen over recent months has demonstrated that racism is endemic in the attitudes of those who would seek a discriminatory immigration policy. It is a policy which I am pleased to see this Parliament has rejected. This legislation not only reflects a maturity of approach to the immigration issue but also fulfils our obligation to our own citizens and to those who seek to live here.

This legislation is the most progressive in this nation's history, and it should be seen as such. It involves a non-discriminatory policy, with the family reunion program being its essential basis. This legislation recognises the separate criteria for family migration. An economic migration system has been put in place which reflects the economic priorities of the nation. A very important attribute of this legislation-indeed, it was commented on at length earlier in this debate-concerns the non-combative review system.

The detail of the legislation has been discussed at length. I want to complete my remarks by returning for a moment to the issue of multiculturalism. In my view, multiculturalism acknowledges the right of people to maintain their own heritage and culture whilst citizens of this country. It acknowledges the right of people to foster their culture within the constitutional, judicial and administrative framework of the Australian political and social system. It is within that context that we should be discussing multiculturalism in terms of this legislation, because it sets the framework for us to be able to bring migrants into this country who will add significantly to Australia in terms of a multicultural community. I think we should be at one in rejecting the views of people who, for their own reasons-base political motives or in many cases extreme racist motives-would seek to divide this community on the basis of migration and multiculturalism.

Recently, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) visited the Northern Territory and the Timorese community hosted a function for him. A broad cross-section of the Timorese community was present. Unfortunately, a parliamentarian from this place, a senator who is a member of the Northern Territory Country-Liberal Party (CLP), attacked a section of that Timorese community because they happened to be supporters of the Fretilin. It is well known that many of the East Timorese community in Darwin arrived there as refugees as a result of the Indonesian occupation in 1975. They still harbour quite justifiable concern about their relations in East Timor and about the way in which Indonesia has occupied that country. When those people have come to this country they have not sought to undermine our democratic processes by remaining concerned about the fate of their relations or their nation-the nation from which they have come as refugees or under the family reunion program. Yet this CLP senator attacked them for having some relationship with and concern for their community.

That sort of attitude is not one which is accepted by the Northern Territory community, and that is because of the multiracial and multicultural nature of that community. It is an attitude which should be rejected by this Parliament. I invite everyone in this Parliament and, indeed, all Australians, to visit Darwin in the dry season and to attend on Thursday evening the markets down on Mindil Beach, because there one can see a microcosm of multicultural Australia. One can see 3,000 or 4,000 people happily enjoying themselves with people from Malaysia, the Philippines, Vietnam, Cambodia, Indonesia, East Timor, and all the nations of Europe-as well as white Anglo-Saxon or Celtic Australians. They are all there together, as a celebration of multiculturalism. They are there sharing their own cultures and the ethnic diversity of our community. They are doing it in a cohesive way as an expression of their democratic right and of the value of a multicultural society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate is the culmination of the protracted process of the review of the Australian migration legislation. It is unfortunate that this process has coincided with a period of ugly and divisive debate on matters of race and ethnicity. Whilst one can understand, and almost excuse, the excesses of minority groups, the role of mainstream politicians in this debate has been disappointing. It is therefore appropriate to welcome the return of a bipartisan approach to the non-discriminatory nature of our migration program, as has been displayed by honourable members opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), in leading for the Opposition, gave an interpretation of what the Government had expected during that debate of bipartisan cooperation. I do not think that it was felt at any stage that we wished the other side of the political fence to agree to dotting the i's and crossing the t's in relation to everything that was going on. However, one of the base requirements on which we sought some leadership was a return to the non-discriminatory base.

Whilst the migration program necessarily has economic requirements, underlying those economic requirements are important humanitarian concerns. I know that most honourable members who have taken part in the debate and most members of this House, through their work in their electorate offices, know the requirements of being able to contend with that humanitarian base. One of the difficulties with the economic requirements of the program-this was alluded to by the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) tonight-is the recognition of overseas qualifications. I was pleased to see that on Tuesday in an answer in this chamber the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) assured us yet again that in trying to speed up the recognition of qualifications of tradespeople coming to Australia we are in no way impinging upon the need for proper training. He said that tradespersons are designed to deal with peak shortages. They are not designed as a substitute for training but to supplement the supply of tradespersons trained in Australia. That is important because it is something that people who have been against the nature of our present program have latched onto in criticising the program.

The legislation before us has three major features. It puts in place a decision making system in which policies governing entry to and stay in Australia will for the first time be spelt out in the migration legislative scheme. I am not as pessimistic about the dangers of this as the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) and the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), among others, have indicated they are. The due process of the legislation should not involve the great difficulties that are envisaged.

The second major feature is the two-tier review system: first an internal review and then a review by the Immigration Review Tribunal. That body will have a statutory independence and a separate administrative structure from the Department. The objectives outlined by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) in his second reading speech in the Senate were that this process would be fair, economical, informal and quick. Again, we know from the experience of an electorate office that all of those objectives are absolutely essential. Complex, lengthy, expensive and protracted decision making processes lead to great hardship and do not make for a better understanding of the system and the objectives of government policy. I welcome anything that makes the system simpler for those who have to deal with it.

The third major feature is that the legislation spells out the mechanisms for ensuring that planned immigration program intakes are not exceeded. Those are, of course, the so-called capping provisions. I agree that the changes that have been made late in the piece to exclude the applicants of the immediate family-the spouse, dependent children and aged parents-represent a good move which is to be welcomed.

Other features of the package that are welcome include the appointment of a joint parliamentary committee with the purpose of oversighting immigration regulations. I would have to agree, from what we have heard in the debate in this chamber and in the other place, that there seems to be a degree of goodwill about how that committee will go about its work. It should be quite successful. The last point that is worthy of note and emphasis is the Minister's undertaking to review the operations of the Immigration Review Tribunal and report back to the Parliament in two years of its being put in place.

In conclusion, it is important to note the part that migrants have played in the development of Australia. While I do not wish to make a controversial issue out of it, the nature of a multicultural Australia is also important. I tend to think that the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) got it right in his contribution. When we are talking about a multicultural Australia, it is not a matter of people going off in all directions; it is very much a matter of sharing-sharing past cultures, past practices and past habits-to make Australia a better place. It is important that that is done under our present parliamentary and legal setup. With that in mind-that multiculturalism is something that is very much a strength of Australian society-we should look at events in this place. At the moment, in another part of the building, there are many of us who are trying to convince ourselves that we are more of Irish descent than not, in a special farewell to the Irish Ambassador. The Irish form a group which has played an important role in the development of Australia.

On Tuesday I had a visit from 90 elderly Macedonians, not only from my electorate and the area of Thomastown-Lalor but from other parts of Melbourne such as Doncaster. One of the pleasing features of that visit was that these people insisted that I join them in traditional folk dancing in the foyer of this building. While my Macedonian dancing is perhaps in need of improvement, the invitation showed that these people recognise this building as being a symbol of Australian life and that they feel at ease in sharing in it as one of Australia's institutions. That is very important.

Migrants have played, and will continue to play, an important role in Australia's development. This legislation will provide a just framework within which our important migration system can continue. In the spirit of the debate, which has been quite a good one, I conclude my remarks by commending the legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories and Minister Assisting the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

SPEECH.PARA: A number of questions were asked which I will refer to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray). However, one question was raised by the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth), who indicated his support for the Migration Amendment Bill and asked for an undertaking on behalf of the Government that a consolidation of the Migration Act would be printed and made available for sale as soon as this Bill was enacted. I am happy to give that undertaking to the honourable member. Again, I thank all honourable members for the spirit in which they participated in this debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following paper was deemed to have been presented on 1 June 1989:
Health Insurance Act-Statement of particulars of ministerial determination made pursuant to section 106AA relating to Dr. L. S. Kotagama, dated 24 May 1989.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 6 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the VIP aircraft carrying him from Launceston on 17 December 1988 break the curfew at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, at his insistence, by landing at 11.25 p.m., 25 minutes after the curfew limit; if so, why did he have to be in Sydney at that time.
(2) Has he ever demanded that the curfew be broken on previous flights in his VIP aircraft.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The RAAF Special Purpose Aircraft on which I travelled from Launceston to Sydney on 17 December 1988 landed at Kingsford-Smith Airport at 11.15 p.m. (15 minutes after curfew). No demand was made for the aircraft to break curfew. When it became obvious that the aircraft would not reach Sydney by its scheduled arrival time, the Captain requested from the Civil Aviation Authority a dispensation in order to arrive during curfew, which was granted. Under the current arrangements, there is provision for dispensations to be granted to aircraft, including the VIP fleet, in limited circumstances, to allow landings at Sydney in curfew hours.
(2) No such ``demands'' are or have been made.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 11 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the statement by the Commissioner of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority in the Authority's annual report for 1987-88 that there is little doubt that the pressure of development in the mountains has led to an overall reduction in the quality of water in our catchment areas, that it is important that the quality of water throughout the Snowy Mountains is improved and that this is tackled as a matter of some urgency.
(2) In view of the urgency referred to in part (1), what are (a) the specific problems referred to by the Commissioner and (b) its health implications for downstream users.

(3) Have testing facilities and procedures been installed or introduced by the Authority, other Government agencies or lessees to monitor water quality; if so, (a) at what locations, (b) what was (i) the scope and (ii) the frequency of that monitoring and (c) what were the (i) average and (ii) maximum counts for (a) Escherichia coli and (b) other pollutants during 1988 at monitoring points in (I) Spencers Creek below Charlotte Pass, (II) the Thredbo River below Thredbo Village and (III) below the Perisher Valley sewage treatment outfall.
(4) What action is proposed by Commonwealth and State governments, and lessees, to reduce pollutants and improve water quality to acceptable levels.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Minister is aware of the reference contained in the (39th) Annual Report of the SMHEA presented by the Commissioner of the Authority Mr C. C. Halton.

(2) (a) The specific problems seen by the Authority as relating to water quality within the catchments of the Snowy Mountains Area, as proclaimed under the SMHEA Act of 1949, fall within the following areas:

The escalating volume of discharge of sewage effluents, mainly from tourist developments, into the streams of the region. Some of these streams remain biologically infected particularly during peak tourist periods when treatment facilities can be overloaded.
Soil disturbance and the impact of erosion products on streams and lakes resulting from the construction of recent and future developments.
The possible loss of the recreational resource of storages, especially of Lake Jindabyne, as a result of the continual loading of the lakes with excessive amounts of nutrients from the above sources.

(2) (b) The health risk to downstream users include viral, protozoan and bacterial disease transmission both to casual visitors and residents of the area and the possible effects due to the decomposition of excessive numbers of aquatic flora, especially algae. The possible degradation of Lake Jindabyne would be long term and difficult to reverse.

(3) (a), (b) and (c) The Authority carried out a monitoring program of Lake Jindabyne waters at seven locations betwen 1980 and 1986 in order to provide a bench mark of lake behaviour as an aid to subsequent assessments.

I am advised that the NSW State Pollution Control Commission requires the NSW Health Department or lessees, as appropriate depending on the location, to monitor water quality. During 1988, no samples were taken at locations (I) (II) or (III).

However, the NSW Health Department perform monthly bacteriological analysis at fifteen locations including at sewage treatment works to determine effluent quality prior to discharge. Water supplies at Guthega Power Station were found to have gross faecal contamination during a period of the 1980 winter.
Heavy concentrations of nutrients have been measured downstream of Jindabyne resulting from the discharge of sewage treatment effluents from the Jindabyne plant.

A water quality survey of the streams and rivers of the Snowy River upstream of Dalgety and including Lake Jindabyne commenced in March 1989. This survey is monitoring additional chemical and biological parameters of Lake Jindabyne waters not investigated previously and includes streams within Kosciusko National Park. There will be five sub-studies of which a study of Lake Jindabyne by the Authority and the NSW Department of Water Resources will involve the largest input. The study is of two years duration with a final report in December 1991.

(4) The Commonwealth and States are adopting an integrated approach to Natural Resource Management, including the issue of improved water quality. As part of this approach, the NSW State Government is imposing higher standards that will improve the water quality of alpine streams and necessitate the export of sewage effluent from new developments to other areas. One proposal is to discharge treated sewage effluent into the Snowy River downstream of Jindabyne Dam. This would require future dilution releases that would affect yield from the Snowy Scheme.

Another option of effluent disposal is irrigated eucalyptus plantations. The Authority has undertaken a preliminary engineering investigation of this option. This option would not require dilution releases of Snowy Scheme water. A feasibility study and appropriate species selection has been commissioned from a forestry consultant with the intention of co-ordinating the implementation of the proposal.
I am concerned about the issues which Mr MacKellar has raised and have asked the SMHEA to keep the situation under close review. I have asked for regular reports to me on developments.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 12 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What agreement was reached on 6 March 1989 about the agenda for the 35th Session of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development.
(2) What were the major disagreements in negotiating the agenda and what position did Australia adopt in those discussions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The agreement reached in Geneva on 6 March 1989 related to the agenda of the Second Part of the 35th Session of the Trade and Development Board of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development. The final agenda for the meeting represented a compromise between the interests of Group B (Industrialised Countries) and G77 (Developing Countries) in respect of some Agenda Items, notably Items 2 and 5.
Agenda Items 2 and 5, as agreed, read as follows:

Item 2: Selected issues requiring attention by the Board at the second part of its 3rd Session in follow-up and review of the implementation of the Final Act of UNCTAD VII in accordance with Board Decision 350 (XXXIV):
(a) Services within the mandate of UNCTAD as defined in the Final Act
(b) The respective roles of national policies and the external environment in promoting social and economic development in the context of paragraphs 25-32 of the Final Act.

Item 5: Other issues for consideration by the Board as mandated in General Assembly Resolution 1995 (XIX), and in the context of the relevant provisions of the Final Act on international trade, as well as other pertinent resolutions of the General Assembly and the Conference: the impact of technological change on patterns of international trade.

(2) The long discussion over Item 2 resulted from differences of view between G77 and Group B on the inclusion in the Agenda of items on the effects of national policies and the external environment in promoting social and economic development and on commodities. The Secretariat had originally proposed only a discussion on services as Item 2 (a). The G77 while seeking to retain the discussion on services on the Agenda, also proposed an item on commodities as (Item 2 (c)).

Group B agreed to discuss services, although most members of Group B took the view that this should be conditional on G77 agreeing to the inclusion of the effects of national policies on social and economic development under a proposed Item 2 (b). G77 endeavoured to confine discussion under the proposed Item 2 (b) to the effects of the external environment on social and economic development. Finally, it was agreed that the effects on both national policies and the external environment on social and economic development would be included.

Furthermore, Group B also took the firm view that the item on commodities proposed by G77 should not be included as commodities had been exhaustively discussed at the UNCTAD Committee on Commodities meeting in December 1988 and the report of that meeting was scheduled to be dealt with under Item 8 (b). G77 agreed to this.

On Item 5 the disagreement centred on the precise wording to be employed. G77 and the Secretary General sought wording that would facilitate an expansion of the scope of the work of the secretariat in the area of technological change and development, while Group B sought to contain it in line with the objective of its majors to restrain the expansion of work programmes of UN bodies. An understanding was reached between the Groups which made it possible to restrict the Board's discussion of Item 5 to technological change on patterns of international trade while acknowledging the Secretary General's existing mandate to identify additional themes on international trade for further work and future consideration by the Board.
Australia while supporting the board Group B approach on both Items, worked to facilitate a compromise on the agenda.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Torres Strait Protected Zone Joint Authority

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 13 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 339 (Hansard, 5 April 1989, page 1070), what is the location of the site acquired by the Commonwealth for the administrative centre of the Torres Strait Protected Zone Joint Authority.
(2) What was the date of acquisition of the site.
(3) From whom was the site purchased.
(4) What are the block and section numbers of the site.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The site for the administrative centre on Thursday Island is on Victoria Parade. It is not an administrative centre for the Torres Strait Protected Zone Joint Authority (PZJA), per se. The Queensland Minister for Primary Industries agrees with me that the building should accommodate the functions common to our two portfolios undertaken by Queensland officers from Thursday Island. The new administrative centre will therefore accommodate officers of the Boating and Fisheries Patrol, undertaking fisheries duties in accordance with policies and programs developed by the PZJA, and officers of the Queensland Department of Primary Industries, undertaking animal and plant quarantine duties.
(2) Settlement of the purchase took place on 24 August 1987.
(3) The vendor was Pearls Pty Ltd.
(4) The land comprises Lots 9 and 10 on RP 745644, Town of Thursday Island, Parish of Port Kennedy, County of Torres.
